HEADLINE: Illness, a New Baby, and Then a Struggle for Assistance

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
Cynthia Salomon was 7 months' pregnant when her husband, Jose Lazo, was diagnosed with testicular cancer. It was Jan. 8, their daughter's second birthday. They had three jobs between them -- he cooked in two restaurants, she answered the telephone in a bank. But by Feb. 3, after his first operation, she was just another applicant for relief and Medicaid at the East End Income Support Center.
Ms. Salomon waited for hours at the Manhattan welfare center, only to be sent home to call for an appointment. She called 15 times a day to get through. She submitted hospital records, rent receipts, birth certificates and bank statements, dealing with caseworkers trained to push people to work. 
 But by late April, when their second daughter was born and Mr. Lazo underwent more surgery, they still had neither Medicaid nor rent money for their East Harlem apartment.
On paper, the family was eligible three times over for Medicaid, the Federal and state health benefits program created more than 30 years ago for the very poor and the very sick. Even if they had not been close to destitution, Ms. Salomon and the children were entitled to coverage under expanded Medicaid eligibility for pregnant women and young children.
The Patient Accounts department of Mount Sinai Medical Center, where the baby had been born April 25th with a broken clavicle, eventually referred Ms. Salomon to REAP, the Resource, Entitlement and Advocacy Program, founded eight years ago by the hospital's auxiliary. The program wages a kind of rear guard action to capture not just Medicaid payments for the hospital, but every government benefit available to those who come to its storefront office on Madison Avenue and 97th Street.
Over several weeks, Penny Schwartz, the director, and Ydelina Reyes, one of the program's eligibility specialists, spent up to three hours a day calling administrators at the welfare center and city Medicaid offices on behalf of Ms. Saloman and her family, they said. But the computers kept spitting out rejections.
Ms. Schwartz finds it hard to convey to outsiders the Catch-22s of the system. For example, unemployed parents can rarely prove poverty to the satisfaction of the Medicaid system until they get public assistance, she said, because Medicaid requires income documentation like a welfare check or pay stub to show how expenses are met. Welfare system computers do not allow more than one change to be made to a case each day, so that when Ms. Salomon gave birth, caseworkers deducted a $50-a-month pregnancy allowance from the welfare grant the family had never received, and did not add the new baby.
By June, Mr. Lazo's hospital, Memorial Sloan-Kettering, was losing patience. He was scheduled for re-admission June 16 for chemotherapy and an expensive bone marrow transplant. The hospital financial department ruled that unless his Medicaid enrollment was completed by then, providing him a number that could be used for billing, his admission would have to be delayed.
"June 13th we were at home crying, thinking, 'Oh my God,' " Ms. Salomon recalled. "If he doesn't get the chemotherapy, the doctor said the cancer would kill him."
The crucial Medicaid number was activated later that day. "It was nerve-rackingly close," said Ms. Schwartz.

HEADLINE: Media Talk;
All Walks of Celebrities Offer Their Predictions

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
From two guys in a New Jersey basement comes this weighty tome: "Predictions for the New Millennium."
By day, Todd Nickerson, 30, and David Kristof, 32, are telecommunications salesmen. By night, they are neophyte authors with worldwide headquarters in a Basking Ridge basement with a computer data base of more than 6,000 celebrities who have received their brief queries to write predictions or messages of hope for the new millennium on a simple postcard. 
 More than 600 messages came back -- enough material to fill a book that will be published by Andrews & McMeel in November with reproductions of the handwritten or typewritten musings. The various millennium musers range from Bill Cosby and Joan Rivers -- who predicted that "interest rates will be higher and my breasts will be lower" -- to Desmond Tutu and the Dalai Lama, who expressed confidence that mankind will "act with more maturity in the next century and thus create better prospects for peace, harmony and tolerance."
Mr. Nickerson said that he and his partner did not have a particularly rigorous selection system; they gleaned names of the famous and infamous from magazines and newspapers, drawing the line at murderers. They unsuccessfully approached headliners like Monica S. Lewinsky, Linda R. Tripp and Paula C. Jones, but were satisfied with responses from Gloria Steinem, Chuck Yeager and Newt Gingrich.
"We weren't quite honestly sure that it would be a success," Mr. Nickerson said. "We've just been blown away by all the responses."
However, he expressed some disappointment that he did not get a postcard from President Clinton, who preferred to remain silent about the post-millennium. On this issue, he apparently agreed with Kenneth W. Starr, the independent prosecutor, who didn't return his card, either. DOREEN CARVAJAL

HEADLINE: C. R. Youngdahl, 82; Led Securities Firm

 BODY:
C. Richard Youngdahl, a former chairman and chief executive of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a firm dealing in government securities, died Aug. 6 at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. Mr. Youngdahl, a resident of Tequesta, Fla., was 82.
The cause of death was heart disease, said a son, John M. Youngdahl. 
 Mr. Youngdahl joined Lanston as an executive vice president in 1955 after an 11-year stint with the Federal Reserve Board. He was named chairman and chief executive of the company in 1969. He retired in 1981, but served on the board until 1986.
Mr. Youngdahl graduated from Augustana College in Sioux Falls, S.D., in 1937. He earned a master's degree from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy at Tufts University in 1938 and a doctorate in economics from the University of Minnesota in 1947. He spent several years teaching economics at, among others, George Washington University in St. Louis, American University in Washington and the Graduate School of Banking at the University of Wisconsin.
In 1943, he became a staff economist at the Federal Reserve Board in Washington, and he was promoted to assistant director of research in 1952. Mr. Youngdahl left the Fed in 1954.
He is survived by his wife, Catherine, of Tequesta; three sons, Carl R. Jr., of Bloomington, Minn., Lee R., of Short Hills, N.J., and John M., of Summit, N.J.; two daughters, Karen E., of Allentown, Pa., and Ann Youngdahl Weber of Sioux Falls, S.D.; a sister, Eileen Youngdahl Gunberg of Charlottesville, Va., and eight grandchildren.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 19, 1998, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an obituary on Monday about C. Richard Youngdahl, who led the securities firm of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, misstated the location of George Washington University, where Mr. Youngdahl taught. It is in Washington, not St. Louis.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
Little in Common but Friendship

BYLINE: By ANITA GATES 

 BODY:
The saddest moment in "Any Day Now" comes right after little Renee Jackson and Mary Elizabeth O'Brien pay their bus fares. Mary Elizabeth, who is white, plops down in the nearest available seat. Renee, who is black, walks back out of the bus's front door, goes to the back door and boards. In Birmingham, Ala., in 1962, apparently, sitting in the back of the bus isn't enough. Black people can't even walk past the white passengers in the good seats.
It's hard to trust that depiction, though, since so much of "Any Day Now," a new Lifetime drama series that has its premiere tonight at 9, strains credibility, embraces stereotype and generally falls short of expectations. 
 The series, set in Birmingham in the present, opens by showing the two girls all grown up. Renee (Lorraine Toussaint) is a high-powered Washington lawyer who lives on her cell phone and has lunch dates with senators. Mary Elizabeth (Annie Potts) is still in Birmingham, smoking cigarettes, handing out Happy Meals to her troubled children rather than cooking, and getting fed up with her unemployed, beer-drinking husband. The two women haven't spoken to each other for 24 years, but when Renee's father dies suddenly and she decides to move home to take over his law practice, the former childhood pals are reunited.
This could be the beginning of an interesting portrait of a friendship that survived tumultuous times, but the two personable stars have a lot of earnest, obvious dialogue to deal with. Mary Elizabeth's reaction at first sight of Renee: "You look beautiful, like something out of a magazine." Renee to Mary Elizabeth: "I travel a lot, mostly in Europe and Asia." Mary Elizabeth to Renee, later, when threatened: "You might be some big-shot lawyer but you're alone. You've got no husband, no kids." And in one of the show's many flashbacks, Renee and her father (who is, of course, a lawyer working with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.) have this exchange.
Dad: "And fear and ignorance breed -- what?"
Renee: "Prejudice."
Dad: "That's my girl."
Naturally, when Mary Elizabeth and Renee have a serious argument at age 19, they end up trading racial epithets.
In 1962, I was growing up about 30 miles from Birmingham, and I have trouble believing that this friendship between school-age girls of different races could have existed in that time and place. If the series grows stronger, maybe we'll gladly suspend disbelief. But the first episode doesn't look promising, with its use of unlikely coincidences like Renee's return visit to a lingerie shop where she and her mother (who looked and dressed like a black Jacqueline Kennedy) were once treated badly. She finds the same saleswoman still working there and seems genuinely surprised that the woman doesn't remember her.
What happened in Birmingham and throughout the South in the early 60's could be the inspiration for thought-provoking, multilayered drama. The subject deserves much better than this.
 
'Maggie'
Lifetime, tonight at 10
It's easy to sympathize with Maggie Day, wife, mother and would-be veterinarian. Maggie (Ann Cusack) is ignored by her husband, who is too busy being thrilled with having been declared a "leading" cardiologist in a news magazine. For Maggie's 40th birthday, her teen-age daughter gives her a book called "You're Over the Hill When . . . " No wonder Maggie regularly fantasizes about being ravished in her kitchen by a hunky actor from "Melrose Place."
And no wonder she's drawn to Richard (John Slattery), her boss at the animal clinic. He's handsome, he takes her seriously, and he's funny. When a man brings in his pet rabbit, who has been bitten by a pet duck, Richard explains that this is clearly a case of Warner syndrome, the belief that ducks and rabbits hang out together.
Back home, the teen-age daughter's best male friend, an aspiring artist, has decided to become gay because so many great artists have been. This puzzles Maggie. "Are you attracted to men?" she asks. The young man answers hopefully, "Not yet."
"Maggie" has a lot going for it: an appealing heroine played by the fabulous Ms. Cusack, a great supporting cast and jokes that are actually funny. What a concept!
 
ANY DAY NOW
Lifetime, tonight at 9

Nancy Miller and Gary Randall, executive producers. A Spelling Entertainment production.

HEADLINE: Tailoring A Healthy Message To Blacks

BYLINE: By LINDA VILLAROSA 

 BODY:
COMPARED with whites, black Americans have higher death rates from all kinds of serious illnesses -- from heart disease, diabetes, stroke, some forms of cancer and asthma. Black babies are more likely to be born small and die in their first year, and black adults live fewer years than their white counterparts.
In the past, many of these problems could be attributed to the fact that blacks were more likely than whites to be poor, to have received less education and to have inadequate access to health care. In recent years, though, the economic gap between blacks and whites has narrowed, yet the health gap persists. 
 This problem is attracting the attention of researchers, health officials and the President, who has made it a priority. He is seeking $400 million over five years for the Initiative to Eliminate Racial and Ethnic Disparities in Health, which would target six health categories that disproportionately affect minorities: infant mortality, diabetes, cancer screening and management, cardiovascular disease, H.I.V. and AIDS, and immunizations.
A large part of the problem, experts say, is the difficulty in communicating health information to the black community. Despite an increased public appetite for the latest news about medicine, nutrition and exercise, and increased coverage in the press, several studies and experts say health educators may not be communicating the message clearly or appropriately to blacks. Or, blacks may be ignoring it.
For example, three studies reported in a recent issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association found that black parents often missed hearing about a campaign to reduce the incidence of sudden infant death syndrome, or SIDS.
The Back to Sleep campaign was created in 1994 by the United States Public Health Service, the American Academy of Pediatrics and several other organizations after experts who attended a National Institutes of Health conference concluded that placing a newborn in a side or back sleep position helped reduce the risk of SIDS. The campaign seems to have had impressive results: In 1992, 70 percent of parents put their babies to sleep on their stomachs, which increased the risk of SIDS, and in 1996, only 24 percent did so. Since 1992, the rate of SIDS has declined by 56 percent.
But the research also showed that low-income black and Hispanic mothers are less likely to put their babies to sleep on their backs, and their rates of SIDS remain higher than those of their white counterparts.
"The Back to Sleep message is not being adequately transmitted to the black population," Dr. Michael H. Malloy, a pediatrician at the University of Texas Medical Branch in Galveston, wrote in an editorial accompanying the research reports.
Dr. Malloy, a member of the American Academy of Pediatrics task force that helped devise the campaign, noted that it had not been designed with any particular group in mind, though, at the time, it was widely known that the rate of SIDS was much higher for blacks than whites. Rather, he said, "we were more interested in a generic campaign," with brochures and posters mailed to health care providers to pass along Back to Sleep information to their patients.
In one of the medical journal studies, researchers found that the greatest influence on a mother's decision to put her baby to sleep on her back was advice from a health care professional. Yet, in a small study conducted in Louisville, Ky., researchers found that 72 percent of parents in a predominantly white private practice setting reported that their physicians had recommended putting their children to sleep on their backs compared with only 48 percent in a predominantly black inner-city clinic.
Dr. Reed V. Tuckson, the highest-ranking black in the hierarchy of the American Medical Association, said, "The public health information network in every major city is being dismantled, and the opportunity for a health care provider to spend quiet, deliberate time in conversation with patients is diminishing."
Dr. Tuckson, the A.M.A.'s senior vice president for professional standards, added: "There is a need to increase the cultural competence of doctors dedicated to service in poor communities. In the sleep studies, it wasn't that the mothers were stupid or irresponsible. They were concerned that the babies couldn't sleep on their backs or that they would choke. There is a need for their health care providers to go a little deeper."
Another study, by the Kaiser Family Foundation and the National Association of Black Journalists, involved surveys of 804 blacks and 664 whites to determine the effectiveness of the press in delivering health information. Compared with whites, blacks were much less likely to think the press provides enough health and health care coverage and more likely to think the press does a poor job of "telling people in this country what they need to know about health and health care."
Most blacks in the survey said they believed the press offered insufficient coverage of specific health concerns of black people, mainly because news organizations are not aware of or interested in the health problems of blacks.
Many policy makers say health messages must be targeted to and tailored for the communities they are designed to reach. "Too often the messages are not culturally or ethnically appropriate, because they are designed by policy makers who plan the programs rather than by the communities they are designed to serve," said Sharon K. Davis, Ph.D., director of the program in minority health policy research and disease prevention at the Harvard School of Public Health.
In an interview, Dr. David Satcher, the Surgeon General, offered an example from his experience. "Over 50 percent of black women are obese, and we have not made a major dent in reducing that risk in the black community, partly because obesity isn't viewed the same way as in the white community," he said. "I grew up in a culture where being overweight was considered healthy. 'You sure look healthy,' people would say. Given that, you can't communicate the idea that overweight is unhealthy with one generic message."
Dr. Satcher, who grew up in rural Alabama, said community groups and church organizations must be recruited to spread the message of good health. He noted that $50 million of the proposed spending for the health disparities initiative would be marked for public health education.
"Public health has to get as close to communities as we can," Dr. Satcher said. "We have to develop partnerships with community groups and churches and follow their leadership of how best to communicate health information."
One such program, Black Pearls, operates in Brooklyn under the auspices of the Arthur Ashe Institute for Urban Health. Black Pearls distributes information about preventing heart disease, breast cancer, sexually transmitted diseases and other illnesses through 11 beauty shops.
On a recent Saturday afternoon at Merita's, a salon in Crown Heights, 15 customers sat under hair dryers to hear a talk about breast cancer, which kills black women more often and at younger ages than white.
The lecture was delivered by Renee Murray-Bachmann, a dietitian, nutritionist and registered nurse who lives near the shop. She kept the talk upbeat and showed the women how to examine their breasts.
On other days, Merita's owner, Mary Edith Aikens-Reed, runs a video about breast cancer produced by the American Cancer Society on her small television and encourages her customers to fill out questionnaires to measure their knowledge of breast care as they have their hair done. She receives 50 cents per questionnaire and $100 per month from the institute.
"We wanted to bring the information to where people are," said Ruth C. Browne, director of the Arthur Ashe Institute, who added that her organization plans to start a similar program in barbershops next month. "This is a natural place and a comfortable environment for people to receive the information."
Andrea Phillips-Merriman, another health educator, conducts workshops on food and nutrition for the Brooklyn Perinatal Network. "I have to be sensitive, observant and aware of these people's lives," she said of the pregnant women and new mothers who are her clients. "Step out into the neighborhood, and you'll see that it's easy to buy fried fast food, but harder to find fresh vegetables and fruit. I can't do 'textbook teaching' about something theoretical like the food pyramid. How receptive are the women going to be to that message?"
Ms. Phillips-Merriman offers her clients inexpensive, available, healthful alternatives. "I try to give them suggestions using foods familiar to them," she said. "How about a mango smoothie or sweet potatoes instead of french fries?"
Still, no matter how innovative and well-intentioned any of these programs are, the real test is whether the diseases they target decline. "At the end of the day, the main thing that counts is outcomes," Dr. Tuckson said. "We have to develop accountability measures. The bottom line is: are people surviving?"

HEADLINE: Labor Eyes a Prize: Hotels of New Orleans

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS

 BODY:
Jacqueline Smith, a 40-year-old hotel maid, knows all too well the hard reality that lies behind this alluring city's tourism boom.
While the city's hotels command premium rates, thousands of workers who carry the industry on their backs -- housekeepers, banquet waiters and laundry-room employees -- work for wages that keep them below the poverty line. Ms. Smith earns $5.98 an hour cleaning rooms at the Wyndham Hotel. The $700 a month she takes home is hardly enough to support her three children. 
 "I do it to survive," said Ms. Smith, a high school dropout who says she is too busy working and rearing children to return to school. "Who likes to clean up behind someone else?"
New Orleans is hardly alone in moving toward a tourism economy that creates mainly low-skill, low-wage jobs. But its size and prominence have made it the focus of a campaign by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. to organize workers in one of the nation's fastest-growing sectors: tourism, hotels and casinos.
The effort represents an important new direction for labor, as three unions that have feuded in the past cooperate in what they term a "wall to wall" organizing drive that seeks to unionize all of the hotel industry's 16,000 workers here, rather than those in a few selected work places. The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations hopes to increasingly employ such industrywide, citywide drives.
And just as the citywide campaign recalls the industrial unionism of the 1930's, the organizers are pursuing a strategy rarely used since the 1960's. They are asserting, as the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. did when he marched with Memphis sanitation workers in 1968, that unionization converges with civil rights when it aims to bring economic justice to a mainly minority work force.
"You have these crushing ironies here that aren't acceptable in terms of basic social and economic justice," said the director of the organizing drive, Wade Rathke. "The industry is wildly profitable.
The Hilton here is one of the most profitable hotels in the chain, and room rates in New Orleans are rising about the fastest in the nation. Yet workers are caught in a minimum-wage service-sector situation where they don't make enough to live on."
With only 11 percent of the nation's hotel workers unionized, both business and labor are closely watching the organizing drive. New Orleans officials have long boasted that the tourism boom, aided by an immense convention center, has created a tide that is lifting all boats. But the unions are basing their organizing drive on a different premise: that the boom has been a bust for many hotel workers.
"We need a union because it will help get us benefits," said Ms. Smith, who says she earns too little to afford the health insurance offered by her employer.
But Bill Langkopp, executive vice president of the New Orleans Hotel and Motel Association, said: "I don't know that the employees are unhappy. I doubt very seriously that a lot of people are grossly underpaid, especially when the big problem I keep hearing about is hotels can't get enough help."
In searching the nation for places to mount major organizing drives, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. selected New Orleans because its hotel industry appeared to offer one of the best -- or worst -- examples of the chasm between haves and have-nots.
While the tourism explosion has created thousands of jobs, few pay well. Industry experts estimate that at a New Orleans hotel with 1,000 rooms and 700 employees, the manager might earn $120,000 to $150,000 a year, the five assistant managers $80,000 and the 50 or so supervisors $30,000 to $45,000. But the vast majority -- the housekeepers, waiters and kitchen prep workers -- earn less than $15,000 a year.
"It's an industry where 5 percent of the people are chiefs and 90-95 percent are Indians," said Stanley Turkel, a hotel industry consultant.
Union leaders argue that the city's hotels can afford to pay more because the average room rate -- $104.96 per night, according to the Smith Travel Service -- is by far the highest in the South and the fifth highest in the nation, higher than the rates in Chicago, Miami and Washington.
At the same time, housekeepers in New Orleans hotels are paid less than $6 an hour on average, which is less than in any major city, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
The Rev. James Orange, a Baptist minister who marched in Memphis with Dr. King and is working in the New Orleans campaign, said the inequities were both economic and racial. The work force, he noted, is overwhelmingly black and Hispanic, while the managers are overwhelmingly white.
"The workers I saw in Memphis in 1968 were better off than the workers I see here in 1998," Mr. Orange said.
Several hotel managers criticized the unionization effort and defended their pay scales, saying they were high enough to attract housekeepers and other workers.
Paul Tomey, manager of the 1,100-room Sheraton, which has a reputation for above-average pay, said, "We certainly want to make sure that employees get everything they need in working conditions and competitive pay. But we'd prefer not to have a third party between us."
With backing from the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the three unions cooperating in the drive -- the service employees, the hotel and restaurant employees and the operating engineers -- have a $1 million annual budget and 25 full-time organizers. But the campaign by the Hospitality, Hotels and Restaurants Organizing Committee is progressing slowly as hotels fight back.
In April, for example, one Sheraton manager sent out a memorandum asserting that "the union pushers" were hungry for dues money and taking the workers for granted.
"This union will stop at nothing to try to get its hands on your money," the memorandum said. "They want you to believe that the whole city of New Orleans is knocking down their doors just to get in. Nothing could be further from the truth. This union is broke. They need your money."
So far, the drive has had one big victory and one defeat. In January, 648 waiters, cooks and other workers at the Ernest N. Morial Convention Center voted by a ratio of 3 to 1 to unionize. But in February, the Superdome's food workers, who are employed by the Aramark Corporation, a Philadelphia-based contractor, voted, 273 to 128, against unionizing.
In June, Federal labor officials ordered a new election after finding that Aramark had improperly influenced the vote.
John Wattenberg, an Aramark spokesman, said, "Aramark doesn't believe that it is necessary to unionize our workers in New Orleans, as we prefer dealing directly with them, without third-party involvement."
Harold Toomer, a 60-year-old banquet waiter at the convention center, said he had voted to unionize because he earned less working a lunch or dinner than he did 30 years ago, after factoring in inflation.
Explaining why the workers voted to unionize, Mr. Toomer said: "It's like anything else. If you kick a dog long enough, it's going to bite you."
Like many outspoken union supporters, Mr. Toomer said his employer had cut back his hours to punish him.
"The hotels have put the fear of God in them," said Jacquelyn Clark, a union organizer. "When I visit people, they often tell me, 'I can't talk to you. I'll get fired.' "
Federal law prohibits employers from retaliating against any worker for supporting a union.
Valencia, a 27-year-old housekeeper who spoke on the condition that only her middle name be used, complained that she earned just $5.78 an hour after six years on the job. Only through Medicaid and food stamps can she support her three children, she said.
She also said that her hotel often gave her only three or four days of work a week in the summer lull.
"I do my best," she said, standing in front of a neatly kept house desperate for a paint job and roof repairs. "I try to make the money stretch out. It's nothing to live off of."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Analysts Ponder Banks' Woes, but Investors Jump Ship

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
How the mighty have fallen.
Bank stocks, among the sizzlers in the stock market's bull run of the last few years, have been battered in recent weeks. 
 The villains are varied -- financial turmoil abroad, concern about how easily some banks will deliver on the promises of their mega-mergers, escalating worries from regulators about bad loans both here and abroad. The extent of the drubbing is sobering.
Since mid-July, bank stocks have fallen twice as much as the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. The S.& P. money-center banks index, representing the country's largest international banks, has plunged 15.3 percent since July 15. Its counterpart, the S.& P. index of major regional banks, has sunk 14.3 percent. The downturn has far outpaced the 7.8 percent drop in the broad stock market and exceeds the weakness among other financial services companies sensitive to market sentiment, namely investment banks and brokerage firms.
Analysts are of many minds about the outlook for banking stocks, with some sounding alarms and others remaining cautiously optimistic. But investors' opinions have been more unified. They have punted their bank holdings over the last month.
To wit, a brief stroll through the wreckage:
Suntrust Banks, down 23 percent; Banc One, down 22 percent; First Chicago, down 21 percent; BankBoston, down 21 percent; First Union, down 19 percent; Citicorp, down 17.5 percent; Bankers Trust, down 16.3 percent; American Express, down 16 percent; Nationsbank, down 15 percent; BankAmerica, down 15 percent; Norwest, down 15 percent; Wells Fargo, down 14.3 percent, and Chase Manhattan, down 11.5 percent.
Bank stocks posted a solid rebound yesterday. And the fact that the bottom has fallen out of some bank stocks with such unforgiving rapidity may be just another sign that investors are too quick to flee stocks in an uncertain market. Some stock analysts suggest that the selloff in bank stocks has been overdone because of inflated fears about a possible downturn in the American economy and further spillover from the Asian financial crisis.
"I think all of these companies have been oversold unless you believe the U.S. is going into a recession on the heels of problems in emerging markets," said Diane Glossman, a stock analyst with Lehman Brothers Inc.
Henry Dickson, a stock analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, sided with Ms. Glossman. He noted that the stock price of any bank he covers with a market capitalization of more than $2 billion has doubled since the end of 1994. That performance was due, he said, to a historic reversal in the way that banks do business.
Between 1967 and 1992, banks did not earn high enough returns to justify their borrowing costs, Mr. Dickson said, culminating in the commercial real estate debacle of the late 1980's. Since 1992, banks have been earning far more than their borrowing costs, leading to a run-up in stock prices -- a trend he said would continue.
"The recent decline in bank stocks appears due to the belief that the banking industry will destroy value," he observed in a research report issued last week. "However, we expect the group to continue to create value as the banks are well positioned to continue to perform at or above the strong operating levels witnessed in the first half of 1998."
Not all bank stock analysts are as sanguine.
"Maybe investors are starting to realize that these stocks are still cyclical," said Charles Peabody, an analyst with Mitchell Securities in New York.
Banks historically earned money off the spread between what they paid for money and the rate they charged customers for that money. But in recent years, they have concentrated on fees earned for various services.
"People tended to believe that as banks replaced spread income with fee income, a new era in bank earnings had arrived," Mr. Peabody said. "Now people are starting to see that there are some credit risks associated with fee income -- for example, from activities like trading."
Banks with exposure to the tattered economies of Southeast Asia and other emerging markets in Latin America and Eastern Europe were among the first to scare off investors this year. Their ranks include Chase, Citicorp, J. P. Morgan, BankAmerica, Bankers Trust and BankBoston. Now investors are focusing on economic woes overseas that may wash ashore here, and stocks of other American banks are being savaged.
"I think Asia could continue to put sustained deflationary pressures on industrial economies like the U.S. and that will have an impact on the credit quality at banks," said Judah Kraushaar, a Merrill Lynch stock analyst. "People are starting to ask what happens if market-sensitive earnings come under increasing pressure."
Another drag on bank stocks has been fears about how sound some of the multibillion-dollar mergers will prove to be. Analysts and bank advisers said that the financial merits of Nationsbank's merger with BankAmerica and Travelers Group's merger with Citicorp are not in question as much as in three other big deals: Banc One's acquisition of First Chicago, Norwest's acquisition of Wells Fargo and Suntrust's acquisition of Crestar Financial.
There are doubts that Banc One can achieve the cost savings described as an important part of its merger. Norwest's purchase is fraught with doubts about how compatible it is with Wells. And Suntrust is seen as possibly overpaying, offering stock valued at more than $9 billion at the time the deal was announced. If the unease about any of these deals proves to be well founded, profits will suffer.
In the meantime, many investors have already fled or are hovering around the exits. Stay tuned.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Endthe Day Mixed Amid Russia and Japan Fears

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices ended slightly lower yesterday, while shorter maturities edged higher, as investors grew more concerned about the economies of Russia and Japan.
Investors were also cautious in advance of today's meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers. 
 The price of the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond slipped 2/32, to a price of 99 13/32, leaving the bond's yield at 5.54 percent, unchanged from Friday. The price of the two-year note rose 1/32, to 100 4/32, for a yield of 5.31 percent, also unchanged.
Russia's decision to float the ruble, effectively devaluing it by a third against the dollar, bolstered the Treasury market as investors moved from the riskier debt of emerging markets to the relative safety of United States and European securities.
Should such a so-called flight to quality continue, some Treasury market analysts said, bond yields could fall as low as 5 percent, while the yield on a two-year note might fall by a full percentage point.
Most market participants expect no change in interest rates to come from today's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's rate-setting panel. But some analysts and traders are looking for the central bank to change its bias toward raising interest rates.
Fed policy makers, said Scott F. Grannis, director and chief economist at Western Asset Management Company in Pasadena, Calif., "should first pat themselves on the back for a job well done, because inflation is truly dead."
"Next they should start to worry, because there are increasing signs that they have stepped on the monetary brakes too long and too hard," Mr. Grannis said. "If they don't step on the gas pretty soon, the U.S. economy may be in danger of following Asia into a recession."
Mr. Grannis said it was time the Fed began lowering short-term rates, to relieve the deflationary pressure felt by commodity producers, and reduce the dollar's strength against other currencies.
The Treasury sold $13 billion of new three-month and six-month bills yesterday in its regular weekly auction. Following are the results of the auction:

HEADLINE: Economy Lifts Incomes of Single Black Women Who Head Households

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: CHARLOTTE, N.C.

 BODY:
Three years ago, Nancy Wright was struggling to hold body and soul and two children together on the $237 she received in her monthly welfare check, supplemented by $187 worth of food stamps.
These days, Ms. Wright, 35, is earning almost $1,400 a month as a supervisor at a fiberglass plant. Though hardly affluent, she can afford to take her children out for a night on the town. She has bought a car, and she just returned with her two sons from a week's vacation in Atlantic City and New York -- the first time she had left North Carolina. 
 "I'm able to buy them clothes and school supples," she said, rattling off the benefits of her new-found prosperity. "I can take them out to get something to eat or go to the movies. I've accomplished a whole lot since I started working."
Ms. Wright's brightening fortunes are part of a little-noticed phenomenon among single black female heads of households. Long at the bottom of the economic scale, these women have seen their income rise sharply in recent years, pushed by a strong economy, tight labor market, increases in the minimum wage, more stringent welfare eligibility requirements and Government training programs.
In 1996, the latest year for which complete data are available, the median income for this group was $15,530, a jump of more than 21 percent in inflation-adjusted dollars from the $12,765 the women brought home in 1993, according to Census Bureau data.
Labor Department figures for single black female heads of families, a slightly different category because it includes only women with children, show a similar increase in income, rising to $16,256 in 1996 from $13,489 in 1993.
Incomes for these women are rising faster than nearly any other demographic group in the country, in part because they are starting from such a low base. Median income for white households (including married, living alone, or single parent) is $47,023. And a median income of $15,000 still leaves single black female heads of households squarely in the ranks of the working poor. But the increases come after two decades when their income barely increased or even declined. From 1969 to 1993, their medium income fell by more than 4 percent.
The fact that their income is improving is a sign of how much the benefits of the economic recovery are cascading down to groups on lower rungs of the economic ladder.
"They're doing much better than they have in years," said Edward Montgomery, chief economist at the Labor Department.
One reason is the recent increases in the minimum wage, which rose to $4.75 from $4.25 in 1996 and rose again to $5.15 last September. Economists say the bulk of single black mothers are hourly workers, so an increase in the minimum wage helped lift their income.
But even without a federally mandated increase in the hourly minimum wage, these women would still be benefiting from the strong economy, which is especially robust here in Charlotte, where the unemployment is less than 3 percent.
With such a strong economy, Labor Department data show that incomes at the bottom of the wage scale have begun to rise even more sharply than those at the top, seemingly reversing decades of rising income inequality.
"It's too early to call it a trend in terms of reversing income inequality," said Secretary of Labor Alexis M. Herman. "But there is no question we are heading in a positive direction."
In addition to being pulled into the job market by rising wages, many of these women are being pushed there by efforts to overhaul the welfare system. In 1995 North Carolina received waivers from the Clinton Administration allowing it to require welfare beneficiaries to undergo job training. A year later, the state received permission to set a two-year time limit for a family to receive cash assistance and to decline to raise welfare payments if a recipient had another child 10 months after going on the rolls.
Since the changes, North Carolina's welfare rolls have dropped to 65,873 families this past June from 113,485 in June 1995. Because about 65 percent of the families on welfare in the state are black, in 1995 and this year, and because about 60,000 people who have left the rolls have gotten jobs, single black mothers have been major beneficiaries of the policy changes.
Ms. Herman also said that new Labor Department studies show that 1.7 million people nationally were working last year who were on welfare in 1996, though she did not say how many of these people were unmarried black females who are heads of households.
For some, like Sherry Thomas, Government training programs made a huge difference. Divorced in 1992, on welfare and living in public housing two years later, Ms. Thomas re-entered the work force through the Job Training Partnership Act. The program paid her tuition at a junior college, covered the day care costs for her three children and paid her rent.
"Definitely that was my bridge to standing on my own and not having to continually depend on the system," she said.
Today, two years after subsisting on $278 a month from A.F.D.C., Aid to Families with Dependent Children, and an additional $350 in food stamps, Ms. Thomas is a computer programmer, earning "in the $30,000 range." She has also started a business designing Web sites and has bought a four-bedroom split-level house.
Rather than worrying about addicts and gunfire outside her door, she now savors the crepe myrtles bursting with pink flowers in her front yard, and the two apple trees, their branches heavy with fruit, growing out back.
"I still have bills and everything, but I'm raising my kids in a better environment, which is something I always wanted to do," Ms. Thomas said.
Beyond the changes in welfare and a strong economy, the improving conditions for many of these women stem from their own grit and determination.
Eleven years ago Cheryl McKnight dropped out of high school in Sumter, S.C., about 120 miles southeast of here, to get married and start a family. But after her first child died of leukemia at the age 2, Ms. McKnight's marriage soured.
After getting a divorce in 1993, Ms. McKnight went on welfare, but soon got a job as a laboratory technician in a plant that made dyes for textiles. The position paid $6 an hour, but Ms. McKnight considered it a dead-end job.
In 1997 she moved to Charlotte, the first time she had left her hometown, got a job flipping hamburgers at a Hardee's and enrolled in a community college course to earn her high school diploma.
Ms. McKnight worked from 4 A.M. to 11 A.M. at the all-night restaurant while attending classes from 12:30 P.M. to 3:30 P.M. every day and from 6 P.M. to 8:45 P.M. on Tuesdays and Thursdays. "I was determined to get that diploma," Ms. McKnight said.
After receiving the diploma last December, Ms. McKnight got a job as a receptionist and clerk at a drivers training school.
She is still struggling. Her pay of $7.50 an hour isn't much greater than what she earned as a lab technician or at Hardees. But she is studying college algebra, biology, psychology and chemistry to pass the entrance exam to get into the nursing program at a local community college.
"I can see a future financially for my son and I now," she said. "Moving to Charlotte was a big move for me in a lot of ways. I'm just a better person now."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Hewlett Posts Profit Above Expectations

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 17

 BODY:
After disappointing Wall Street in five of the six previous quarters, the Hewlett-Packard Company reported financial results today that exceeded analysts' estimates.
But beyond the bottom line, there was little to celebrate in Hewlett-Packard's fiscal third quarter. New orders grew just 1 percent from the corresponding quarter a year earlier. In addition, company officials said further revamping efforts would probably result in a charge of about $100 million in the fourth quarter. 
 Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said cost controls and strong financial management had helped strengthen earnings in a difficult business climate. The company also said that it remained cautious about future performance because of the continued financial turmoil in Asia, as well as concerns about economies in Eastern Europe, Latin America and the United States.
Still, shares of Hewlett-Packard rose sharply late today. The company reported its results after the regular close of the New York Stock Exchange, but its shares moved higher in late composite trading to close at $55.25, up $2.50.
"They had great expense control, but we're not out of the woods yet," said Steven Milunovich, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, With year-to-year order growth of just 1 percent, "the risk is you have another weak fourth quarter," he said.
For its third quarter, which ended on July 31, Hewlett-Packard earned $621 million, or 58 cents a fully diluted share, compared with $617 million, or 58 cents a diluted share, in the quarter a year earlier. Per-share earnings reflect an increase in the number of shares outstanding, to 1.08 billion from 1.06 billion. Revenue grew 5 percent, to $11 billion.
While earnings were essentially flat, Wall Street analysts had expected Hewlett-Packard to earn 54 cents a share, according to First Call, an investment research company that tracks analysts' estimates.
Mr. Milunovich, the Merrill Lynch analyst, said the company's revenue actually came in a bit below his expectations, but that costs rose far less and the company had unusually high "other" income, including interest, which accounted for most of the 4-cent-a-share difference.
Hewlett-Packard officials said that Asia remained very weak, with no improvement in sight, and that pricing pressures in the United States market for personal computers and printers had eroded earnings as well. They said the company took a less aggressive stance on personal computer pricing than in the second quarter, with the result that it lost some potential sales, but the PC unit returned to profitability.
"This quarter's slight increase in net earnings, flat earnings per share and decline in profit margins are disappointing," Robert Wayman, Hewlett-Packard's chief financial officer, said in a conference call with securities analysts. "We were below our plan in these and other key dimensions of performance."
On a more positive note, Mr. Wayman said operating expenses grew just 4 percent in the quarter, compared with 18 percent in the second quarter, and 13 percent in the year-earlier period.
Currency effects, temporary plant closings, reduced hiring and the drop in the company's stock price, which reduces the cost of stock appreciation rights, all contributed to the improved operating-cost performance, he said. The company cut its temporary work force by 1,000 in the quarter, compared with an increase of 2,700 in the third quarter of fiscal 1997.
Hewlett-Packard said orders for the quarter were $10.5 billion, a 1 percent increase over last year's third quarter. Orders in the United States grew 4 percent, to $5 billion, while orders from outside the United States were down 1 percent, at $5.4 billion. In Europe, orders were $3.3 billion, up 6 percent in dollars and 10 percent in local currency. In the Asia-Pacific region, orders declined 19 percent in dollars and were down 6 percent in local currency.
Hewlett-Packard officials said their goal for revenue growth was in the mid- to high teens, but that this performance was not possible until world markets stabilized.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Colonial Buys Unit of Rival In Australia Pension Business

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Colonial Ltd. said today that it would buy the Australian and New Zealand insurance and asset management businesses of the Prudential Corporation of Britain for $800 million (United States), becoming Australia's fourth-largest fund manager.
The deal comes at a time of strong growth and fierce competition in the Australian fund management market. Deregulation is feeding the growth as new employees, beginning in July, are allowed to choose their own pension funds. Existing employees will be given the option in 2000. 
 Prospects for a boom in the industry have led to several takeovers. In July, Colonial bought the Australian business of Legal and General P.L.C. of Britain for $892 million (Australian). In June, Salomon Smith Barney Inc., owned by Travelers Group, bought the local fund management arm of J. P. Morgan & Company of the United States for an undisclosed sum. Vanguard Group and Fidelity Investments have joint ventures with Australian companies.
The acquisitions have increased competition, with banks outpacing traditional insurers for fund customers. The competition has worsened Prudential of Britain's already weak position in the region, where its profit fell by 50 percent in the first half of 1998.
"The competitive environment and our relatively small market presence in Australia limited our prospects for achieving a long-term satisfactory return," Prudential, Britain's largest life insurer, said.
Prudential, which has no connection to the Prudential Insurance Company of America, will report a pretax profit of 200 million, or $323.7 million (United States) on the sale.
Colonial, which is based in Melbourne and does business in insurance, fund management and banking, will raise the money for its purchase with new debt and the sale of $144.6 million (United States) worth of shares.
Keith Bedell-Pearce, director of international development for Prudential, told AFX News that the company was selling its businesses in part because Australia's population of 20 million offered limited growth and its prospects were likely to remain depressed because of the Asian economic turmoil.
"We did not put these businesses up for sale," he told the news service. "Colonial approached us with an offer."
Once it takes over Prudential's $5.47 billion (United States) of funds, Colonial will have total funds under management and assets of $38.5 billion (United States). Colonial's managing director, Peter Smedley, predicted annual savings of $59.26 million (United States) in three years after the purchase.
Under Mr. Smedley, Colonial has expanded aggressively, though it was criticized for its Legal and General purchase, which some analysts saw as too costly.
Standard & Poor's warned today that it might lower Colonial's A+ rating because of the "operational and financial pressures" from the acquisitions.
Still, Colonial's shares have risen from $4 (Australian) in February to $5.24 (Australian) on Friday. Trading in them was suspended today.
On the London Stock Exchange, shares of Prudential fell 10 pence, or 1.32 percent, to 750 pence.

HEADLINE: Acupuncture for the Dog;
Alternative Medicine Catches On With Pet Owners

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

 BODY:
The stagger in his gait and pleading in his eyes said it all. Al had taken everything that a greyhound could be expected to, and then he had taken even more.
Once he had been a racer, sleek and fleet. Then came abandonment on the beaches of Brooklyn. Mercy arrived in the form of a new owner and a home in the New Jersey suburbs, but at age 8, Al's back gave out. Two painful surgeries and more than $6,000 later, he still wasn't the dog he used to be. 
 His journey into Manhattan on a recent Saturday morning was a pilgrimage of stubborn hope. There, in a backyard in Murray Hill, Al dipped into his own Lourdes, a circular pool of heated water that might do what the operations, acupuncture and Bach flower essences had not: heal him.
With Jodi Richard, a trained canine hydrotherapist, holding tight to his rump, Al paddled and paddled, going nowhere fast, his gimpy back legs freed from gravity so they could get the exercise they sorely needed.
His owner, Jackie Wright-Minogue, rushed to him as soon as he left the pool to rest under a pink towel on the cushion of a lawn chair.
"I want him to get well," she said, articulating the simple wish that had wrought such complicated ministrations. "I want him to have a good life."
That desire, seemingly boundless among many pet owners, has ushered in a whole new era in animal care. Ms. Richard's business, Bonnie's K 9 Swim Therapy Center, named for her German shepherd, is but one example.
Elsewhere around the New York region, veterinarians are hooking dogs and cats to electric acupuncture machines, dosing them with homeopathic remedies, placing putatively therapeutic magnets beneath their beds, even spraying the air around them with lavender, lemon or eucalyptus in the name of aromatherapy.
All of this is perhaps the inevitable outgrowth of a culture blissed out on St. John's wort and mesmerized by Andrew Weil. It is also the ultimate illustration of the degree to which many Americans insist on sharing their own habits and extravagances, from summer camp to spa treatments, with the four-legged members of their families.
Dr. Michael Garvey, director of the Bobst Hospital at the Animal Medical Center in Manhattan, described it as a kind of cross-species psychological transference. "We project our character flaws on our pets," he said. "We project our behavior on them. I've even had clients project their religion on them. This is very much in the same fashion."
Could your cat benefit from an adjustment? There are a growing number of veterinary chiropractors on hand. Is there knotting in your dog's muscles? You can take him to a canine massage therapist. If it has been tried on people, it is being tried on pets, and not just on the most common species.
Dr. Gerald M. Buchoff, a veterinarian in North Bergen, N.J., has performed acupuncture on iguanas with brittle bones. Dr. Marcie Fallek, who has offices in Greenwich Village and Fairfield, Conn., has administered homeopathic treatments -- solutions with minuscule traces of special plant or mineral ingredients -- to a pet raccoon that was seemingly depressed over a canine companion's death and had stopped using its litter box.
The raccoon's owner, fearful that law enforcement authorities would learn that she was keeping a wild animal, declined to be interviewed for this article, even anonymously, Dr. Fallek said. "Her psychic told her there might be trouble," Dr. Fallek explained. "Plus, Mercury's in retrograde and, well, you know."
Which raises the obvious question: How much of this is pure quackery? As it turns out, less than one might think.
Dr. Richard Swanson, president of the American Veterinary Medical Association, said that the legitimacy of acupuncture, at least on mammals with skeletal structures similar to people's, was beyond doubt, and that hydrotherapy and chiropractic were probably effective.
But Dr. Swanson cast a more skeptical eye on homeopathy, Bach flower essences and the like. "That's really getting on the fringe," he said, adding that a lack of rigorous scientific study into such treatments undercut the sunny testimonials of some veterinarians and their clients. "The world is made up of a lot of very vulnerable and gullible people," he cautioned.
It is also made up of increasingly generous people when it comes to the vim and vigor of their hirsute -- or, for that matter, feathered -- loved ones. According to the association, expenditures by Americans on all kinds of veterinary care for dogs, cats and birds rose to $11.1 billion in 1996, the most recent year studied, from $6.9 billion in 1991 (the figures were not adjusted for inflation). During that same period, the pet population grew only modestly.
The newfangled treatments that come under the rubric of alternative or holistic veterinary medicine certainly are not cheap. In New York City -- where, granted, prices for most things tend to be highest -- half an hour of acupuncture generally costs $50 to $75; an hour's worth of immersion in Ms. Richard's healing waters costs $75. Because treatments are usually repeated over the course of several weeks, the final bill can run into the high hundreds.
Alternative veterinary medicine began to emerge as more than just random experimentation more than two decades ago. Race horses were the guinea pigs, perhaps because the financial stakes surrounding the health of these animals were highest.
But in the last five years, the field has really taken off, drawing thousands of veterinarians around the country who either integrate alternative therapies into traditional veterinary practices or specialize in holistic approaches to healing.
The American Holistic Veterinary Medical Association, which was founded in 1982, reports a membership of 1,000 veterinarians. The International Veterinary Acupuncture Society, founded in 1974, reports 1,500 members, up from 500 five years ago, though that is still a small fraction of all veterinarians.
Donna Watkins, a spokeswoman for the society, said veterinary acupuncture has been around long enough that it is now being ventured on a wide variety of animals in addition to horses, cats, dogs and parrots.
"A friend of mine in California regularly does turtles -- well, not the shell," she said. "I know a guy in San Diego who is doing a dolphin."
There are dozens of newsletters and periodicals devoted to alternative veterinary medicine, along with a plethora of product catalogues, many with their own Internet sites.
The Internet site for the Botanical Animal catalogue provides a link to the Equilite line of herbal and floral elixirs for horses, including the "Broodmare Blend," the "Clear Thinking Blend," the "Ego Builder Blend" and the "Mellow Out Blend."
Although pets being given alternative treatments are often following their owners' leads, the inspiration sometimes works the other way.
"I started going to an acupuncturist for stress because I saw how well it worked for Lola," Liz Santander, an interior designer from Chappaqua, N.Y., said of her 150-pound Great Dane as the dog awaited her latest treatment the other morning in the offices of Dr. Phillip Raclyn on the Upper West Side.
It was a busy, busy day. While Lola, who was bouncing back from a stroke, cooled her paws in the lobby, Ike, a partially lame shepherd mix, received massage therapy in an examining room.
A condition known as degenerative myelopathy had essentially paralyzed Ike's hind legs, which his owner, Chris O'Sullivan, straps into a two-wheeled cart so Ike can still chase Frisbees. ("I have to throw the Frisbee right at him," Mr. O'Sullivan explained.)
But the cart was off now and Ike lay motionless as the massage therapist, Jean Marie Cooper, gave him what looked like a particularly intimate, thorough petting.
"Feel for the bony landmarks," Ms. Cooper instructed Mr. O'Sullivan, who planned to repeat the treatment for Ike at home in Chinatown. "Push away from the spine."
Meanwhile, in the examining room next door, Dr. Raclyn inserted an acupuncture needle into the forehead of Spike, a female cat with kidney problems. For a few seconds, Spike looked like a unicorn; then another dozen needles went in, and she looked like a pin cushion. Relaxed rather than bothered, she nearly fell asleep.
A few hours earlier and a few miles downtown, Ms. Richard's patients were decidedly more agitated, slaves to a sloshy, invisible treadmill. Al repeatedly swapped places in the water with Duncan, a three-legged Labrador retriever who needed to lose about 35 of his 106 pounds but, for obvious reasons, wasn't much for running.
Then they ceded the pool to Sydnee, a 12-year-old Shih Tzu recovering from surgery for a ruptured disk. The operation had left Sydnee without the use of his hind legs, which he may never fully regain.
This was Sydnee's first hydrotherapy session and he looked -- as best these things can be determined -- appalled and terrified about taking the plunge. "He's a good boy," Lauran Walk, his owner, called out as Sydnee's tiny, bearded face bobbed above the surface. "He's a good, good boy."
Ms. Walk, 27, who lives with her husband in Greenwich Village, said that she was definitely feeling the pinch of the $3,500 that Sydnee's various treatments had cost the couple.
But she said she abhorred the thought of putting him down, and would do whatever it took to avoid that, even though Sydnee was only a few years shy of the normal life expectancy for a dog.
"He represents 12 years of my life, so I've got to give him a chance," Ms. Walk said as Sydnee took a brief poolside rest, a shivering knot of fur with limited mobility. "I can't be selfish."

HEADLINE: Harold J. Ruttenberg, 84, Labor Leader Turned Executive

BYLINE: By ERIC PACE 

 BODY:
Harold J. Ruttenberg, a research director for the United Steelworkers of America who changed sides, became a business executive and remained outspoken on labor-management issues, died on Saturday at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 84.
The cause was heart failure, said his son Edward F. Ruttenberg. 
 Mr. Ruttenberg's switch to management, in 1946, was at a fairly lofty level. As The New York Herald Tribune put it in 1958, he "was the brilliant research director and economic wizard for the United Steel Workers and the righthand man of Philip Murray," the president of the steelworkers' union from 1942, when it was founded, until 1952. Mr. Murray was also president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations from 1940 to 1952.
In his years with the union, Mr. Ruttenberg broadened a thorough working knowledge of steel company employment and wage statistics. When he quit the union in 1946, Mr. Murray said that he had been an invaluable associate.
Mr. Ruttenberg was hired by Cyrus Eaton, the financier, to be an executive of the Portsmouth Steel Company. After three years in management there, Mr. Ruttenberg (pronounced ROOT-en-berg) went on to be, successively, president, chairman -- or both -- of four other American companies. He was also chairman of the Rehovoth Instruments Company in Israel from 1968 to 1978.
At his death he was chairman and chief executive of the American Locker Group Inc. of Jamestown, N.Y., which makes and markets coin-operated metal lockers and plastic security mail boxes. He had held the posts since 1973, when the concern was called the AVM Corporation.
In his years in the labor world and in management, Mr. Ruttenberg was a perennial advocate of improving ties between the two sides. He believed that giving unions a greater role in management operations would enhance productivity and he favored a guaranteed yearly wage for union workers.
Mr. Ruttenberg was born in St. Paul and grew up in Greene County, in southwestern Pennsylvania, where his father owned a general store.
He received a bachelor's degree in 1935 from the University of Pittsburgh and went on to hold posts in the labor movement before the United Steelworkers union was formed. They included the job of regional research director, for the Pittsburgh area, of the Steel Workers Organizing Committee, which was then considered the spearhead of labor in the steel industry.
Mr. Ruttenberg was research director of the United Steelworkers of America from its formation and was on leave from the union from 1942 to 1944, during World War II, while he was assistant director of the steel division of the War Production Board. In that post he had an important role in the board's Steel for Victory drive in Pittsburgh, which began in the summer of 1943 with the goal of increasing supplies of steel to aid the war effort.
With the union, he could be highly confrontational toward management. Early in 1946, he was chairman of the wage research committee of the C.I.O., while still research director for the steelworkers, when the panel contended that some Bureau of Labor Statistics figures on labor productivity were misleading and demanded that they be withdrawn by the Labor Department. The committee said the figures, showing that output per worker in 24 civilian industries had increased very little between 1939 and 1944, were being used by industry to justify refusals to grant adequate wage increases.
In 1971 Mr. Ruttenberg reminisced about his switch to management in a letter to The New York Times. He said that the leadership of the steelworkers' union had let him and two others resign from the union rather than have the union agree to pursue a policy that the three "had advocated of assuming responsibility along with management for increasing productivity as employment benefits increased so that the union could restrain steel price increases." He recalled that both the union and the management sides had refused to do that in 1945 and 1946.
In a 1958 speech, he contended that steelworkers needed "steady jobs with 52 regular pay checks a year" more than they needed higher hourly wages. In that speech he also criticized David J. McDonald, the steelworkers' union president, for "sidetracking the dynamic concept of the annual wage" and for resisting the development of any meaningful tie between wage increases and heightened industrial efficiency. In that speech, Mr. Ruttenberg also criticized top steel industry executives as failing to display leadership in the same direction.
He was the co-author, with Clinton S. Golden, of the 1942 book "The Dynamics of Industrial Democracy."
In addition to his son Edward, of Pittsburgh, Mr. Ruttenberg is survived by his wife of 61 years, the former Katherine Monori; his son James E. of Scarsdale, N.Y.; a daughter, Ellen Rabin of Lemoyne, Pa.; a brother, Stanley, of Bethesda, Md., and 10 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Pataki Seeks Plan for Land Near Airport

 BODY:
In another step toward preserving 6,200 acres of open space near Stewart International Airport near Newburgh, N.Y., Gov. George E. Pataki has directed the Department of Environmental Conservation to develop a management plan for the environmentally sensitive property.
The state transferred jurisdiction of the land from the Department of Transportation earlier this year. On Friday, the Governor asked John P. Cahill, Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Conservation, to appoint a committee to determine how to use the Orange County property, known as the Stewart buffer lands. 
 The Governor suggested that the committee be made up of local officials, environmentalists and representatives from sportsmen's and recreation organizations.
Also, in an effort to placate those in this economically struggling region who wanted the property developed, the Governor said the state would pay the school and town taxes on the land from now on. Ninety percent of the land lies within the boundaries of New Windsor and has not generated revenues since the state took it off the tax rolls when it acquired the property in 1971.
The Department of Environmental Conservation, the current oversight agency, estimated that the payments to New Windsor and other towns and school districts could be as high as $900,000 a year.
"If this is some kind of compromise on the Governor's part, I say, 'O.K.,' " George J. Meyers, New Windsor's Town Supervisor, said. "Send me the money!"
As announced in January, the Pataki administration also plans to allow development of an additional 1,200 acres of the Stewart buffer lands adjacent to the airport to further balance the needs of the environment and the interests of the local economy. There are no immediate plans for development.
Klara B. Sauer, executive director of Scenic Hudson, a Poughkeepsie-based group, said the plans represented "a win-win" for all sides. Noting that the property is the only intact example of the kind of lowlands that were once characteristic of the Hudson Valley, she said, "Unfortunately, most of what was there is now covered up by developments and urban sprawl."
The rock ledges, ponds, wet meadows and marshes provide habitat for the red-shouldered hawk, cooper's hawk and the great blue heron, she noted. And studies have catalogued a wide array of declining wetland-dependent reptiles.
The state bought the vacant tract through condemnation proceedings in 1971, when then-Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller hoped to expand the deactivated Stewart Air Force Base onto the land to build another major airport serving the New York City area. The expansion never took place, but the air force base eventually became Stewart International Airport, which serves about 400,000 passengers a year.
In 1995, Governor Pataki proposed selling the airport and buffer lands, 7,400 acres in all, as part of a plan to privatize the airport, which is 60 miles north of New York City.
Stewart was the first commercial airport in the nation that was approved for privatization under the Federal Aviation Administration's airport privatization plan. But because the sale of the airport was slowed by stringent Federal regulations and oversight, the administration reached a leasing agreement with the National Express Group, of Winchester, England, in April to run the day-to-day operations of the airport.

HEADLINE: Denied Western Funds, Russia Makes Its Choices

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
The Russian Government was denied additional financial help from the United States and several other allies over the weekend, causing it to take steps the Clinton Administration had opposed: allowing the ruble greater fluctuation, imposing a moratorium on repaying foreign debt owed mostly by banks, and restructuring much of the Government's debt.
"These particular choices were Russian choices in an exceptionally difficult environment," a senior Administration official said today. "We certainly expressed concerns." 
 Clinton Administration officials acknowledged that the Russians, faced last week with a spreading banking crisis, had little choice. "Given the inability to restore confidence, some change was necessary," said another Administration official.
A package of loans and credits totaling $22.6 billion announced last month by the International Monetary Fund was supposed to buy Russia time to enact the reforms that might restore investor confidence. As the currency and security markets continued to weaken after the I.M.F. package was unveiled, the strategy announced today seeks to buy time another way, by lessening Russia's debt burden and restoring confidence in its ability to get its fiscal problems under control.
The Administration's view is that no further funds would be forthcoming and that the onus is on the Russian Government to carry out economic reform, acccording to both Administration and fund officials who say that foreign aid is no substitute for Russia's cleaning up its own financial house.
In a statement today, Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin said: "We believe it is critically important that the Russian authorities move quickly to take actions to restore confidence, including the adoption of a careful and cooperative approach in dealing with its creditors and the full implementation of the measures outlined in the Russian stabilization program agreed with the I.M.F."
Having little leverage over the direction of events in Russia, officials in Washington went to great lengths to reassure investors that the United States was not abandoning Russia. "We wanted to be frank about the pros and cons," said one Administration official. "But there were no easy choices. It was the Russians' choice, but now that Russia has made its choice, we're committed to working with them to advance reform."
The roots of the current crisis go back to the early 1990's when Russia was battling hyperinflation. The Russian Government switched from simply printing money to finance the budget deficit and began issuing bonds. The deficits kept growing, at one point reaching about 7 percent of the value of its economy. As the debt ballooned, nervous investors were only willing to buy short-term instruments. That meant that the bulk of domestic debt matured quickly and constantly had to be refinanced.
In the last year, Russia has suffered a series of blows, namely a collapse of oil and commodity prices as well as the economic contagion from Asia. As investors grew more nervous, interest rates of 100 percent to 200 percent were required to entice buyers. Russia found itself in a classic debt trap: The investor requires a high rate of return to invest in Government bonds, raising the cost of servicing the debt and the possibility of a default.
Last week, when the I.M.F. package clearly had failed to restore confidence, the Yeltsin Government opted for a combination of time-honored but risky escapes. First, the prospect of a devalued ruble could set off inflation, which shrinks existing debt values. Second, the Government announced that it would restructure the ruble-denominated debt, which involves involuntarily forcing the holder of short-term maturity debt to accept longer-term maturities.
The new maturities, interest rates and other details of the restructuring are expected to be announced on Wednesday, the Russian Government said.
Initial reactions indicate that Russia's dramatic gestures may work. It is certainly not a case, as it was with Japan, of too little too late. Financial markets reacted relatively well today and investors seem to be waiting to learn more details. Whether the Russian gamble works will be evident in the next few weeks. Investors are waiting to see whether the run on the banking system and the currency subsides. The political fallout in Russia will focus on how people view the Government's breaking its promise to prevent inflation's return.
"This is not the time to abandon Russia," said Robert Hormats, managing director at Goldman Sachs. "It's a time to help them deal with some of the critical issues that led them to take these measures."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Stocks IgnoreGlobal Fears, Rising Steeply

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Wall Street shrugged off Russia's currency devaluation, another decline in Japanese stocks and saturation news coverage of President Clinton's grand jury testimony yesterday, pushing major market indexes higher and helping the Dow Jones industrial average post its largest one-day gain in two months.
Many investors -- apparently deciding that they had absorbed all the bad news they could handle and that all those negatives were reflected in current share prices -- dived back into stocks, pushing the Dow up 149.85 points, or 1.78 percent. The blue-chip index, led by gains in Merck, Eastman Kodak and American Express, closed at 8,574.85. 
 The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 20.92 points, or nearly 2 percent, to 1,083.67, and the Nasdaq composite index, an important technology-stock barometer, rose 27.85 points, or 1.56 percent, to 1,818.04.
Despite the strong showing, the gain was not broad based, and some stock strategists called it only a short-term rebound. Overseas, shares were mostly lower as investors took a less sanguine view of the Russian economic crisis.
In Germany, where the economy is considered the most vulnerable to Russia's travails, stocks fell eight-tenths of 1 percent as 20 of the 30 stocks in the DAX index declined. In London, stocks rose two-tenths of 1 percent. The exposure of American financial institutions to Russia is relatively limited.
In Japan, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 2.18 percent, to its lowest level in two months, largely reflecting concerns about further weakness in that economy and the region. This morning, the Nikkei rose 297.15 points, or just over 2 percent, to 15,091.81 at the midday recess. Most other Asian markets fell yesterday.
In recent weeks, a litany of bad news has battered stocks in the United States, pulling major-market indexes down 10 percent and more from highs reached a month ago. Investors have been rattled by corporate earnings disappointments and by Asian economics, in particular Japan's deepening recession, which has raised fears of a currency devaluation by China.
The political scandal surrounding President Clinton has also weighed on the market, which fears uncertainty. But yesterday, as Moscow floated the ruble, an effective devaluation, and as the public awaited news of Mr. Clinton's grand jury testimony and Japan's benchmark index reached a two-month low, investors finally saw bargains and started buying shares.
"In this kind of economy, you need high interest rates to kick the equity market" down, said Mitchell Held, co-manager for United States economics at Salomon Smith Barney.
"We went down too far too fast," said Harvey Hirschhorn, chief economist and investment strategist at Stein Roe & Farnham Investment Management in Chicago.
"There were a lot of buying opportunities for people who continue to believe the economy is O.K.," Mr. Hirschhorn said. "Russia has been a risk out there. It's a smaller economy. The ruble has been declining in value for years, and another partial collapse isn't going to make or break the German banks."
The benchmark Russian trading system stock index fell 4.8 percent yesterday. Among funds trading in this country, the Templeton Russia Fund fell 1 5/16, to 161 1/16. The Lexington Troika Dialog Russia fund remains near a 52-week low.
Generally, the funds saw steeper declines in May when the Russian central bank raised overnight interest rates to defend the ruble and when oil prices slumped.
Despite yesterday's renewed appetite for stocks, several analysts said the market could soon fall further. "I think this is a rally to sell into," said Byron R. Wien, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
"The market is becoming narrower and narrower; you could see this coming back in June," Mr. Wien said, noting that almost 75 percent of the issues on the New York Stock Exchange are down 20 percent from their highs this year.
Yesterday, only 31 Big Board stocks reached new highs, compared with 265 new lows. Advancing issues narrowly exceeded decliners on trading volume of 584.4 million shares.
The limited breadth of the advance leaves the market vulnerable to further declines, Mr. Wien and other economists said.
In addition, more corporate earnings disappointments are expected, and Mr. Wien said he believed that analysts had yet to reduce earnings forecasts enough to take account of that.
While the market seemed to shrug off Mr. Clinton's problems yesterday, the scandal is presenting difficulty, Mr. Wien said, adding:
"You don't want the American Presidency preoccupied with survival. You want it to take on world initiatives."
Russia's problems also illustrate that much of the rest of the world, outside the United States and Western Europe, is in a downturn, said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch.
"The downward trend we're in is not broken," said Mr. Steinberg, who forecasts that the stock market's slide will cause a profound slowdown in consumer spending in the second half of the year.
