HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
It's Time

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
It is now clear that President Clinton looked the American people in the eye last January and lied. Yesterday he acknowledged the inappropriate relationship with Monica Lewinsky that he earlier denied. He has betrayed his family, his party and his country. But we now have three stark choices: Impeach him, forgive him or limp along with him, berating him at every step and never allowing anyone to forget what he did. There is no stomach in the country for impeachment. There is too much at stake for the country to limp along for two more years. It's time to forgive -- not for his sake but for ours, not because his affairs are unimportant but because ours are more important.
It's time now for the first Democratic President since F.D.R. to be elected for a second term to actually begin his second term. That means Mr. Clinton has got to give up this crazy notion that his primary political role is to be Al Gore's campaign manager for the year 2000 election and instead to start fulfilling his own agenda, whether it's Social Security reform, education reform, child-care reform, campaign finance reform, tobacco legislation or expansion of free trade -- all of which will require his stepping on some traditional Democratic constituencies. The President talks a good game on many of these issues, but he has yet to really put his shoulder to the wheel behind most of them or to put them in concrete legislative form. 
 It's time for the President to make clear exactly what his Iraq policy is, which simply is not clear anymore. What is clear is that the Administration is playing games -- trying to shift responsibility for Iraq policy from the White House to the United Nations, which is to shift it to nowhere. What is clear is that Secretary of State Madeleine Albright has signaled the chief U.N. weapons inspector, Richard Butler, that the Administration does not want to stir up Saddam Hussein with any surprise inspections right now. If the Clintonites walk away from their responsibilities on Iraq it is the end of their foreign policy.
It is time that the leaderless Republican Party developed a serious domestic agenda (beyond arguing that shrinking government and ending abortion will solve all our problems), as well as a foreign policy befitting a superpower. Since Bill Clinton came to office the Republicans have spent much of their time just living off his misbehavior. On foreign policy they have either offered drive-by criticism, in which they drive by the White House, shout some epithet and then drive on, or adopted utterly irresponsible positions. These range from base pandering on the Middle East to indulgence of fringe Congressional Republicans who want to hold up key foreign-policy funding for institutions like the I.M.F. unless the U.S. stops all support for family planning, to mindlessly slashing the State Department's budget -- an outrage at a time when America's global responsibilities, and economic opportunities, have never been greater.
Without a serious Republican foreign policy, it makes it so much easier for the Clintonites to be unserious too.
For a long time now we have defined this era as the post-cold-war era. That is, we have defined this era by what it is not. It is not the cold war. But it is time we define it by what it is. It is an era of stunningly rapid change in workplaces, jobs, communities, educational demands and government responsibilities. It is an era in which corporations have never been bigger and yet individuals have never been more empowered -- to do good or ill. It is an era in which America has no single big enemy, but many, many smaller ones. It is an age when the gap between rich and poor is widening faster and faster. It is an integrated era in which the biggest threats to U.S. stability come from a weak Japanese economy, which we can't control, and a computer chip problem called Y2K, which we can't see.
It is an era in which the U.S. and the world need a President who gets these issues. The good news about Bill Clinton is that he does get them. The bad news is that even before the Lewinsky affair, this President was having trouble developing, and passing, the legislation for this new era. But he may now be getting a second chance to begin his second term -- a chance he doesn't deserve but we do.
It may be hoping for too much that Bill Clinton will take this opportunity to be the President he has the potential to be. But Lord knows it's time.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Desperate to Ease Crisis, Russia Devalues the Ruble
The Russian Government moved hastily to avert financial collapse with measures that included a devaluation of the ruble. The step eased the pressure on Moscow to defend the ruble's value by spending billions in foreign currency, but it also means the ruble's purchasing power has been radically reduced, hurting Russian consumers.
Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko said the program, which also includes a 90-day moratorium on some debt payments, had been made necessary by the near-collapse of Russia's banking system last week. Page A1.
 
Clinton Administration officials said the Russians had little choice in taking such steps, even though $22.6 billion in aid from the International Monetary Fund announced last month had been intended to buy Russia some time to restore confidence. A8.
 
Japanese Stocks Near 1998 Lows
The stock market in Tokyo fell sharply and flirted with the year's lows, pressured by the wobbliness on Wall Street last week and an expanding economic upheaval that is now ravaging Russia. Further pressuring the market was the persistent fear that the Japanese Government will fail to overcome the country's banking crisis and a renewed concern about the impact of Asia's troubles on corporate profits. D2.
 
Bonds End Little Changed
Treasury bond prices ended slightly higher while short-term maturities ended slightly lower, reflecting investor concern about Russia and Japan as well as caution ahead of today's meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers. The 30-year bond yielded 5.54 percent, unchanged from Friday. D7.
 
Women TV Executives Move Up
CBS named Nancy Tellem president of the network's entertainment division, the position vacated in April by Leslie Moonves, now chief executive of CBS Television. Ms. Tellem becomes the second woman to head a network entertainment division. Jamie Tarses is president of ABC Entertainment. D4.
 
Anne Sweeney, president of the Disney Channel, was named president of Disney/ABC Cable Networks, making her the highest- ranking woman in the cable industry. D4.
 
Toy Seller's Earnings Drop
Toys "R" Us earnings fell 63 percent in the latest quarter, reflecting the No. 1 toy retailing company's failure to find a hit product that could help it offset a loss of sales to discount store chains. D5.
 
Waste Haulers in $1.3 Billion Deal
Waste Management said it would buy Eastern Environmental Services for $1.3 billion in stock, a deal that would expand the geographic reach of the largest United States waste disposal company by giving it six landfills on the East Coast. Eastern Environmental shares fell 4.3 percent on the news. D6.
 
GE Capital Buying Met Life Unit
GE Capital said it had agreed to buy Metropolitan Life Insurance's commercial finance division. Terms weren't disclosed, but the price was estimated at $1 billion. D6.
 
Livent May Face Bond Buyback
Livent, the theater production company that said last week that it had found accouting irregularities, may be legally required to buy back $125 million of bonds that it issued just months ago under a little-noticed provision in its bond agreement. D6.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
WPP Group Reports A Good First Half

BYLINE: Bridge News 

 BODY:
WPP Group P.L.C., the British advertising company, said yesterday that its first-half pretax profit rose by 19.7 percent, in part because a strong United States economy has led to an increase in advertising spending by United States companies. WPP, the world's second-largest advertising group after Omnicom Group Inc., said its pretax profit rose to 93.8 million ($152 million) in the first half from 78.3 million a year earlier. Revenue rose 11.6 percent to 3.84 billion.
"Any impact of Asia Pacific economic difficulties has, so far, been more than compensated for by stronger-than-budgeted performance in North America and Europe," the company said.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
Russia Takes Measures To Avert Fiscal Collapse
The Russian Government moved to avert financial collapse with a series of drastic measures that included a 90-day moratorium on privately held foreign debt, a restructuring of Government bonds and the decision to let the value of the ruble float according to market forces. A1 

Russia took its steps, which were opposed by the Clinton Administration, after the United States and several of its allies refused it additional assistance. A8
 
Bombing Suspect Interviewed
Law enforcement officials said a suspect in the bombing of the American Embassy in Nairobi had been interviewed at length by American investigators after his return from Pakistan, but had not admitted a role in the bombing and did not implicate Osama bin Laden, the Saudi-born extremist thought to have inspired the bombings in Kenya and Tanzania. A7
 
Embassy families in Pakistan have been ordered to leave the country, and the State Department urged all Americans "to seriously consider leaving Pakistan" because of a range of threats against Americans, and especially American officials. A7

The British police arrested five men for questioning on the car-bomb attack in Omagh on Saturday that killed 28 people and injured 220 others. The blast is widely believed to have been the work of a a group whose members broke from the Irish Republican Army. A3

Rebels again cut electric power and the water supply to Kinshasa, Congo's capital of five million people, heightening fear that an attack was imminent. As the threat intensified, popular support for President Laurent Kabila grew. Several hours after the power failure began, the Government publicly acknowledged its loss of control over the Inga hydroelectric dam. A6

Students and women's groups defied a ban by Government officials and held emotional demonstrations in Beijing to protest looting, killing and rape directed against ethnic Chinese during riots in Indonesia in May. A group of several dozen from Beijing University staged a short sit-in outside the Indonesian Ambassador's residence, offering a T-shirt signed by more than 100 students protesting the atrocities. A6

The United Nations told the Security Council that its mediator in Iraq had failed to persuade Baghdad to resume cooperation with the two agencies trying to find and eliminate its weapons of mass destruction, diplomats and other officials said. A3
 
Negligence Cited in Serb Death
A Bosnian Serb who died this month in a cell while being tried by the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague bled to death because he did not get proper medical care, his lawyer said. A9

After Testimony, Clinton Tells Nation of Relationship
President Clinton testified for more than four hours at the White House in a closed-circuit television hookup with a Federal grand jury and later made an extraordinary address to the nation in which he admitted he had misled his wife and the public and had had an intimate relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky that was "wrong." In his testimony, an adviser said, Mr. Clinton acknowledged the relationship with Ms. Lewinsky, though he refused to answer several questions about the relationship, as well as other matters under investigation. A1

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Long a Defender of the Boss, Gore Praises Clinton Courage

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
In the early days of the Lewinsky investigation, Vice President Al Gore strongly defended President Clinton against all accusations of wrongdoing, saying Mr. Clinton was a strong and honest leader he was proud to work with.
But as the investigation dragged on, Mr. Gore adopted a somewhat modified approach to defending the President, saying that Mr. Clinton had denied any wrongdoing and that there appeared to be no reason to question that denial. 
 Tonight, after the President appeared on nationwide television and admitted that he had been less than forthcoming about his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, Mr. Gore, whose political hopes in the 2000 election could well depend on the outcome of this investigation, once again spoke out strongly in defense of Mr. Clinton.
"I am proud of him," Mr. Gore said in a statement issued by his office, "not only because he is a friend, but because he is a person who has had the courage to acknowledge mistakes. I am honored to work with this great President on his agenda for the nation, and I believe it is time to put this matter behind us once and for all and move forward with the business of the United States of America."
Mr. Gore is on vacation in Hawaii, about as far away from Washington, the President and the grand jury as he could get and still be in one of the 50 states. According to tonight's statement, he called the President after his television appearance and said that he and his wife, Tipper, had Mr. Clinton "in our hearts and in our prayers."
Jennifer Devlin, a press spokeswoman for Mrs. Gore, said the Mr. and Mrs. Gore and some of their children had gone to Hawaii for a break that had been "in planning" for at least three months.
"The Vice President and his family always take a two-week vacation at this time of year," Ms. Devlin said. "He's staying at a private home on one of the islands -- we're not saying which one -- and his schedule is private except that on Aug. 25 he'll do a Democratic fund-raiser in Honolulu and also will speak to a meeting of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees."
Did he spend the day on the beach or next to the television?
"Nothing on that," Ms. Devlin said.
The Gores arrived in Hawaii on Aug. 11 and will depart on Aug. 26 for San Francisco, where they will participate in several Democratic Party events before returning to Washington on Aug. 28. Ms. Devlin said the couple had a sentimental attachment to Hawaii, having spent their honeymoon there in 1970 and having returned several times.
On Wednesday, the Gores were spotted swimming with pet dolphins in a pool at the Hilton Waikoloa Village on the island of Hawaii, but not until security personnel had plunged in to check things out.
When Mr. Gore meets with Hawaii Democrats on Aug. 25, he is likely to face a warm and eager audience.
Hawaii has traditionally been dominated by Democrats. But because of cutbacks in military spending, a decline in the farm sector and a sharp falloff in tourism from Asia, the state is one of the few that face economic hard times. As a result, polls indicate, Democratic candidates throughout the islands will need all the help they can get in this year's elections.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1251 words

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: NEWS ANALYSIS;
Testy Finale, Risky Gambit

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 17

 BODY:
With his grand jury testimony and his brief and defiant public admission of an inappropriate relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky tonight, President Clinton is hoping, as he has so many times in the past, that the public will respond with forgiveness and not disgust.
The President, relying on polls and his own sense of the public's weariness with a sordid story of Presidential sex, took a calculated gamble that he can escape indictment by prosecutors or impeachment by lawmakers over what he declared was a private matter. In his testimony and his testy four-minute speech to the nation, he offered partial admissions but refused to answer many of questions that have swamped his Presidency since January. 
 And almost before he finished his grudging televised confession, he turned on his inquisitors and demanded that the investigation of his private life come to an end.
He confessed, he expressed regret and he asked for instant redemption.
"Now it is time -- in fact it is past time -- to move on," the President said with anger, not anguish, in his eyes, laying the blame for seven months of national trauma on his political enemies and Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel.
He left no doubt that his strategy is the same as it has been for the past seven months: To give as little ground as possible.
The President sacrificed some of the dignity of his exalted office by admitting a relationship with Ms. Lewinsky that was "wrong." But he implied that the investigation that has cornered him was just as wrong.
"This has gone on too long, cost too much and hurt too many innocent people," Mr. Clinton said.
He sought to justify his misleading testimony and his months of resistance to prosecutors as a fitting response to a politically inspired invasion of privacy.
Mr. Clinton is also counting on a continued strong economy and the forbearance of a public aware that he was a less than faithful husband even as they were twice electing him to the nation's highest office.
"Even Presidents have private lives," Mr. Clinton declared.
The President stopped short of explicitly acknowledging a sexual relationship, and while he admitted misleading his wife and others, he did not say he had been untruthful in his previous testimony. He offered only a curt denial of some of the more serious accusations -- conspiracy, obstruction of justice, witness tampering and suborning perjury -- saying only he had not asked anyone to lie or hide evidence.
The statement was a compromise between Mr. Clinton's lawyers, who wanted him to say as little as possible about his relationship, and his political advisers, who felt that only a full confession would allow him to put the matter behind him.
His words of apology and contrition were belied by a tone that was laced with anger and, in an important way, unrepentant. He said he has been subjected to an invasion of privacy by Mr. Starr that no American citizen should have to endure.
His questioning by Mr. Starr and three of Mr. Starr's deputies was hostile and only added to the anger the President and his top aides feel about Mr. Starr's inquiry, said lawyers at the session.
The President's lead private counsel, David E. Kendall, signaled the continuing hostility in a brief statement after the testimony.
"We're hopeful that the President's testimony will finally bring closure to the independent counsel's more than four-year and over $40 million investigation, which has culminated in an investigation of the President's private life," the ordinarily mild-mannered Mr. Kendall said with evident contempt.
Mr. Kendall said later that Mr. Clinton had refused to answer many of Mr. Starr's questions and, while candid, the President was less than complete in many of his responses.
Mr. Clinton's limited expression of contrition was only part of an emerging White House strategy to continue fighting Mr. Starr on broad legal and political fronts.
Mr. Clinton has privately raged at Mr. Starr, believing he is a Republican partisan and a blue-nosed moralist prying into the President's private behavior. He has dispatched a dozen aides and defenders to demonize Mr. Starr and question the legitimacy of his investigation. That explains his long refusal to answer Mr. Starr's questions about the Lewinsky matter and the scorched-earth legal strategy he has pursued to delay his date with the grand jury.
Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff, began calling leading Democrats within minutes of the end of Mr. Clinton's grand jury session, coordinating a political counteroffensive.
If anyone thought Bill Clinton would come away deeply humbled and considering resignation, they were wrong. He will fight.
President Clinton's most difficult day in office is now behind him. What now lies ahead?
Unlike President Ronald Reagan after the Iran-Contra debacle, Mr. Clinton cannot simply confess error, shoulder responsibility and dismiss a handful of top aides. In the Lewinsky matter, the fault was not in the President's policy, but in himself. It is vastly harder to repair a reputation than to repudiate a failed policy.
Still, the investigation by Mr. Starr is far from over. Whatever errors or evasions Mr. Clinton admitted today must be weighed in light of voluminous evidence collected over seven months that the prosecutor may believe add up to the "high crimes and misdemeanors" standard for impeachment set by the Constitution.
It is now up to Mr. Starr how to portray the President's actions and his words in a report expected to be delivered to Congress this fall. But however the President is judged by Congress, he must also confront the judgment of the citizenry, which has thus far been indulgent of its wayward President while also finding his personal standards of morality and honesty distasteful. But a growing proportion of the public has come to believe he was stingy with the truth, a fatal affliction for a politician with ambitions for a legacy among the top ranks of American Presidents.
The Lewinsky saga would be little more than a sordid soap opera if the stakes were not so great. Many observers believe that the Serbs in Kosovo, Saddam Hussein in Iraq and perhaps even the terrorists who attacked United States embassies in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam were emboldened by a perceived power vacuum at the White House. "It is no coincidence," said a top-ranking official of the State Department, "that the really bad guys of the world, like Slobodan Milosevic and Saddam Hussein, have picked this summer to cause the United States trouble."
And the American people, enjoying economic bounty, have sacrificed a measure of national pride because of the sex-stained spectacle.
"This scandal has prevented people from feeling better about the country because the principal complaint about the country is its moral climate," said Andrew Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press.
And despite recent polling that indicates Americans are willing to again forgive the President his trespasses, Mr. Kohut said the public verdict is not so certain.
"The public has the last and often a counter-intuitive word on issues like this," Mr. Kohut said. "The public is not so predictable and the impact on the President and the Presidency I think is yet to be determined.
"If he falls from grace, we will look for someone with grace to replace him in 2000," Mr. Kohut concluded. "It will be the equivalent of Jimmy Carter in 1976, a search for character."

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1386 words

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE PUBLIC;
Speech Deepens Split Over Clinton's Actions

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Aug. 17

 BODY:
Lisa Wessels describes herself as "pro-Clinton" and Scot Baker says he is "anti-Clinton," opposed points of view that have not prevented the Seattle couple from planning to marry. And when the two, both 30 years old, met after work this evening and watched President Clinton admit a "not appropriate" relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, both chose the same word to describe the televised address: "Embarrassing."
But their words, it turned out, did not mean the same thing. 
 Miss Wessels, a licensing specialist, felt bad for Mr. Clinton. "I can't believe that he had to do this, forced to stand up and talk about his private life like that," she said. "It was surreal. It's like I wasn't watching the President of the United States, I was watching Richard Dreyfus play the President of the United States in some bad movie. I feel sorry for him."
But for Mr. Baker, a recruiter for the Microsoft Corporation, the embarrassment was to America at large. "I always told my friends he has no integrity, that squinty little twinkle in his eye," he said. "Now we know for sure. But I'm not happy about it. It's embarrassing for the country. This is our President."
Around the nation, in their homes and crowded around television sets in public places, Americans in huge numbers stopped what they were doing for four minutes tonight to watch Mr. Clinton speak. But if such events often serve to bind people together in the face of a national tragedy or emergency, a series of conversations around the country afterward suggested that Mr. Clinton's speech had left people as divided about him as ever.
While many people still think that the matter is not enough to warrant impeachment of Mr. Clinton, polls over the last several months, and tonight, show a clear undercurrent of belief that now, more than ever, Bill Clinton needs to go.
"This man lied in front of the nation, and he basically admitted it," said Mike Bagdassarov of Baltimore, an intelligence analyst for the Maryland state police. "He shouldn't be President. It's that simple."
Jim Eichelberger, an Atlanta lawyer, said: "I think it was typical Clinton -- dishonest, blaming others, just what I anticipated. He owes it to the Democratic Party and the American people to resign."
And many of those who were inclined to forgive the President said they did not believe his speech would put the matter to rest, partly because, in their view, he did not really accept full responsibility for what happened.
"He's still trying to weasel out of it," said Janice Scallon, 27, an independent contractor for social-service programs in Chicago. "It wasn't even a full apology. Instead, he said it was inappropriate. If he just said, hey, he had sex with her, then it would be over."
Ms. Scallon also said she was deeply bothered that the very first motivation cited by the President for misleading people about the relationship was to save himself from embarrassment. "That just shows how selfish he is," she said.
While very few people seemed to watch the speech and find themselves liking the President any more than they had before, many said that they still felt strongly that the matter should be put to rest.
A New York Times/CBS News Poll taken immediately after the speech showed a continuation of the strong public desire to move beyond the scandal. Sixty-three percent of the respondents said the Lewinsky matter should be dropped, now that the President has testified to the grand jury and addressed the nation, compared with 18 percent who said he should resign and 12 percent who said Congress should begin impeachment proceedings.
And 65 percent said Mr. Clinton should have made a public statement about the relationship sooner, even as his job approval rating remained steady, in the high 60's.
The poll, based on a survey of 396 adults, has a sampling error of 5 percentage points. Such instant, one-night polls are considered less reliable than the typical New York Times/CBS News Polls, which are based on larger samples and conducted over several days. Moreover, initial reactions sometimes change.
There was little expectation among some before the speech that the President could say much to justify himself, and little feeling afterwards that he had succeeded.
"There was nothing he could say," said Jeff Lewelling, a project coordinator for a welfare-to-work program in Chicago, who watched the speech at a local pub. "His credibility was totally shot."
Mr. Lewelling said Mr. Clinton had made "a very vague admission" that had weakened the Presidency and also that he "totally hung his supporters out to dry."
In Austin, Tex., Shedric Jones, a 34-year-old shoeshine operator, said he was relieved, but not surprised, that the President had finally told the American people that he had been wrong.
"I'm glad that he admitted it, but he should have done the right thing earlier because people looked up to him," Mr. Jones said. "I assumed it was true all along, so this was no big deal. Maybe next time he'll be more careful."
But Larry Foster, a 57-year-old pilot for American Airlines in Dallas, also said he thought the President's remarks fell short. "He was hardly apologetic," Mr. Foster said. "I never saw any honest apology. He said, 'it's a personal matter.' It's not a personal matter. It affects every person in the United States. He swore to uphold the truth. It was a very poor apology. It wasn't sincere. He wasn't contrite."
To be sure, some people felt the opposite, that the President was too contrite.
"I wish he had said, 'Yes, I did it' -- everyone knew that, anyway -- but then was more forceful in saying, I did nothing illegal," said Andrea Wagner, an arts administrator in Seattle.
Ms. Scallon said the President looked like "an ashamed little boy -- he looked like a boy who had his hand caught in the cookie jar and said, 'Oopsie.' "
As much as people were willing to answer questions about Mr. Clinton, a number volunteered that they found themselves thinking about his wife and daughter as he gave the speech.
"I'm very curious to know what kind of personal life he and Hillary can have after this," said Marge Routon, 76, a retired insurance claims adjuster in Memphis. "I don't know how, as a woman, she can put this behind her again and again. Maybe all the work they have done together is just more important to her than sex.
Michael Doeckmann, 45, a customer service representative for a telephone supplies distributor in the Memphis area, said he felt deeply sorry for Chelsea Clinton, but not her mother. "I think she is so interested in his staying in office she will do whatever it takes to stay there," he said. "But I would like to know exactly what she really thinks about this. I don't think we ever will know, but I'd like to."
And in Houston, Natalie Wolk, 26, a psychological therapist, offered this thought: "It's Chelsea that I feel sorry for. I mean, here she is in her first year in college and she has to watch while her father talks about this to the whole world."
Mr. Clinton's appeal that the nation focus on other issues bothered many who watched the speech, who described at as a transparent attempt at diversion.
The speech, with its criticism of the investigation by the independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr, "kind of reminded me of Nixon's first Watergate speeches, talking about how important detente was," said Joe Heinen, a Chicago bartender. "Pretty shifty, actually."
Mary Drucker, a nursing student from Bellingham, Wash., described herself as livid after the speech. "It really burned me up when he said we should turn to the nation's problems," she said. "As far as I'm concerned, what he did goes to the heart of the nation's problems."
But at the Boulevard Cafe in the Crenshaw District of Los Angeles, where about a dozen diners sat amid posters of Frederick Douglass, the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., Malcom X and Joe Louis, patrons said they agreed completely with the President that the nation had much more pressing problems than his sex life, and on issues like the economy, they gave Mr. Clinton high marks.
" I really feel this is a private matter," said Maurice Phillips, 52, a financial consultant. "Since the economy has improved, no one should be concerned with what he does behind closed doors."

HEADLINE: Personal Health;
Health Scares That Weren't So Scary

BYLINE: By Jane E. Brody 

 BODY:
HOW often has your clock radio awakened you with the distressing news that something you eat, drink, breathe or do has just been shown in a new study to be a serious health hazard? And how often did it turn out to be a false alarm, unsupported by subsequent research?
The American Council on Science and Health, based in New York, recently updated and expanded its popular report, "Facts Versus Fears," reviewing what it considers the greatest unfounded health scares of the last five decades. Although controversy continues to rage about potential risks associated with some of these "scares," including Agent Orange and hormones in beef, most -- including those that resulted in serious economic damage and changes in public policy -- have been soundly discounted by subsequent studies. 
 The following review of some of the most prominent scares in recent decades serves as a cautionary tale that should help you realize why it is unwise to leap before you look more closely at what any new study actually means.
ALAR -- In 1989, the popular television show "60 Minutes," the Natural Resources Defense Council and the actress Meryl Streep denounced this chemical used to regulate the ripening of apples as "the most potent cancer-causing agent in our food supply" and said it was a cause of childhood cancer.
The accusation was based on a 1973 study in which a byproduct of Alar caused tumors in mice. The dosage used in the study was eight times greater than the so-called maximum tolerated dose, the amount above which tissue damage occurs even from innocent substances because of the high concentration.
Subsequent tests by the National Cancer Institute and the Environmental Protection Agency failed to show that Alar caused cancer. Only when mice were given extremely high doses, equivalent to 133,000 to 266,000 times the amount a preschool child might consume in a day in apples and apple juice, did any tumors result.
Still, millions of alarmed parents panicked and dumped untold gallons of apple juice and bushels of apples, the apple industry lost about $375 million, the Department of Agriculture lost another $15 million, countless children were given far less nutritious drinks in place of apple juice and Alar was taken off the market by its manufacturer.
COFFEE AND PANCREATIC CANCER -- In 1981 in The New England Journal of Medicine, Harvard researchers published an "unexpected" finding linking pancreatic cancer to coffee consumption. Just two cups of coffee a day doubled the risk and five cups tripled it, said the researchers, who estimated that coffee accounted for more than half the cases of this nearly universally fatal cancer.
But the study was designed to look not at coffee but at alcohol and smoking as factors in this cancer, and other researchers who had been studying huge numbers of people had found no such link to coffee. Nor did animal studies disclose any association between coffee and pancreatic cancer. Five years later, the Harvard group repeated its study and failed to confirm its own findings.
In "Facts Versus Fears," the council stated, "This brief scare illustrates the danger of putting too much credence in a single study without analyzing any possible biases or confounding factors."
ELECTRIC BLANKETS -- Everyone in modern societies is exposed to electromagnetic fields (EMF's) -- at home, at work and everywhere that electricity is in use. A 1979 report hinted at a possible relationship between childhood cancer and living near high-current residential power lines, and subsequently, electric blankets were singled out as possible risks, because of their nightlong proximity to the body.
In 1990, a study found a modest increase in cancers in children whose mothers had used electric blankets during pregnancy and a lesser increase in children who had used such blankets.
This prompted a warning label on all electric blankets and a redesign of the product that reduced EMF exposure to the background level produced by household wiring.
But subsequent studies have not borne out the 1990 finding, and this year a large National Cancer Institute study concluded that a causal relationship between childhood brain tumors and EMF's from appliances, including electric blankets, was unlikely. Other studies that examined several adult cancers also found no relationship to the use of electric blankets.
CELLULAR PHONES -- Like electric blankets, cell phones create EMF's. In 1990, a woman who had used a cell phone extensively for two years developed a brain tumor just behind her right ear, where she typically placed the phone's antenna.
Her husband filed suit against the manufacturer, saying that the phone's EMF's had caused his wife's cancer. In 1993 he appeared on the CNN program "Larry King Live" to proclaim his assertion, which prompted three lawsuits from other cell phone users making similar claims.
In response, the industry paid for independent safety studies, which have yet to clearly link cell phones to cancer. Although it is not possible to prove that EMF's are safe, there is still no convincing evidence of harm from the kind of EMF's that cell phones emit. While the incidence of brain tumors has risen slightly in recent years, there has been no disproportionate increase in tumors near the ears, despite a meteoric rise in cell phone use.
As the council points out in its report, by far the most serious hazard associated with these phones is their use while driving. Last year a study reported in The New England Journal of Medicine showed that drivers who use cell phones are four times as likely as nonusers to have an accident.
ASBESTOS IN SCHOOLS -- Asbestos that is contained in a solid substance is harmless. But when it becomes crumbly, airborne and inhaled, it can lodge in body tissues, where it can sometimes cause cancer. Asbestos insulation to protect against fire was required in schools until 1973, when the Environmental Protection Agency banned its use to reduce children's exposure. The 1980's produced two Congressional acts requiring schools to inspect for asbestos hazards and clean them up. Despite the fact that in most schools asbestos levels were extremely low (less than the amount that in 10 years of exposure might cause one additional death in 100,000 over a lifetime -- one-third the risk of being struck by lightning), by 1990 some $6 billion had been spent on asbestos abatement in schools.
Many experts believe that asbestos removal, which increased airborne asbestos, created a far greater hazard to the children, who might have benefited far more had this money been spent on enhancing their education.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 5, 1998, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
The Personal Health column on Aug. 18 about unfounded health scares referred incompletely to Government action on Alar, a chemical once used to make apples ripen uniformly. In May 1989, the Environmental Protection Agency announced steps to prohibit the use of Alar on apples and other foods, but allowed the chemical to stay on the market for at least 15 months. In the announcement, the agency said the chemical might pose an unacceptable risk of cancer in humans. Before the ban could take effect, the chemical's maker, Uniroyal, voluntarily removed it from the market. It is no longer used on food in the United States.
The article also omitted a description of the finances of the American Council on Science and Health, which has criticized the furor over Alar. It is a nonprofit organization that receives 60 percent of its financing from private foundations, individual contributions and sales. The rest of its support comes from corporations, including food manufacturers. This year Uniroyal contributed $10,000, which is slightly more than one-half of 1 percent of the council's $1.6 million budget.

HEADLINE: Seeking to Expand, Korn Ferry Files for Initial Public Offering

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
Korn Ferry International, the giant executive search firm, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering, the proceeds of which it plans to use to expand its business.
The company, which is based in Los Angeles, expects to raise about $230 million from the offering to repay debt, redeem preferred stock, expand to the Internet and make acquisitions, according to the filing. 
 The offering would be the latest recent public offering or planned stock sale by a professional services firm, including one by another large executive recruiter, LAI Ward Howell, which went public last year.
"You do, in general, tend to see companies from one industry file close together," said Ken Fleming, a research analyst with the Renaissance Capital Corporation. "One company sees that the environment may be favorable and the same factors are going to be affecting other companies in that area."
In the filing, Korn Ferry said its objective was "to expand its leadership position as a preferred global executive search firm by offering a broad range of solutions to address its clients' management recruitment needs."
The company has more than 380 consultants in 71 offices in 41 countries. It had revenue last year of $315 million, a 16 percent increase from a year earlier, but net income declined 41 percent, to $5.2 million, according to the filing.
Over all, the executive search business is booming because of a strong economy and corporations' emphasis on casting a wide net to fill top posts instead of simply filling them from within. Indeed, revenues for the top 10 firms grew by 23 percent last year, according to Hunt-Scanlon Advisers, publisher of Executive Search Review newsletter.
Still, the industry has become more competitive as clients demand more for their money. That has forced firms to look for ways to expand, which, of course, requires cash. And in an industry with a high turnover rate, firms that can offer stock and options may have an advantage to lure the best talent.
This is not the first time Korn Ferry has ventured into the equity markets. The company first went public in 1972, but it was a much smaller business with thinly traded and volatile shares. Its founders, Lester Korn and Richard Ferry, found the swing in the stock price distracting and later repurchased the shares and took the firm private.
Korn Ferry now wants to be traded as KFY on the New York Stock exchange.

HEADLINE: Fears Grow As Russia Postpones Debt Plan

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 18

 BODY:
The Russian Government tonight put off the announcement of its plan to change the repayment terms for its debt, after alarm had spread in the world financial community that Russia was prepared to discriminate against foreign creditors.
Deputy Prime Minister Boris G. Fyodorov, in charge of economic policy, said he would first review the plan with representatives of J. P. Morgan; Goldman, Sachs, and Deutsche Bank. Details of the expected swap of Treasury bills for longer-term securities, a crucial element in program to deal with the economic crisis, were to have been released on Wednesday. 
 The prospect of a discriminatory policy has "seriously damaged the credibility of the Russian Government and the Russian Central Bank," said Daniel McGovern, managing director for emerging-markets research at Merrill Lynch in London. "They have damaged the ability of Russian banks to deal in a normal way with their Western counterparts."
Foreign investors, lured by sky-high interest rates for several years, have bought more than $50 billion of Russian bonds payable in rubles.
Rumors that the Government was proposing a plan that would penalize foreign creditors in favor of Russia's own troubled banks swept through the foreign investment community here today, prompting warnings that such a plan would kill off any future foreign investment in Russia.
"Everyone was becoming more and more nervous, and bitter," said a Western investment banker who insisted on anonymity. "Had they gone ahead with the plan we were hearing it would have created enormous concerns in the investment community. Now we feel that fairness and market practices will come into play."
Investors said the Government was considering proposals that would differentiate between foreign and Russian creditors as way to shore up its banking system. The proposals, which reportedly include a two-tier redemption schedule, were the subject of heated debate today in the Government, one expert said.
The trading in Treasury bills was suspended on Monday, when the Government announced a crisis program that imposed a 90-day moratorium on privately held foreign debt and set the ruble free to float to as low as 9 1/2 rubles to the dollar, from 6.4 rubles recently.
Russian banks and their foreign creditors are to discuss the debt moratorium on Monday. That covers $4 billion in outstanding loans. The Government has said it will continue making payments on its publicly held foreign debt.
As the value of the ruble skittered downward at banks and exchange booths across the country, shoppers and bankers, both Russians and foreigners, waited to see who would be left holding the bag.
A countrywide survey broadcast on television news programs said not that many people rushed today to exchange their rubles for dollars, preferring to wait and see where the currency will land.
At the Moscow currency market the value was fixed at 6.8 rubles to the dollar, roughly the rate at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, after a day of heavy trading in ruble futures. The rate here on Monday was 6.4 and in Chicago 6.5.
The Central Bank said it would move against traders who posted more than a 15 percent spread between their buying and selling prices.
Some analysts interpreted ruble rates of 9, 10 or even 15 to the dollar posted by some banks and traders as the equivalent of hanging an "out of order" sign on the tellers' windows.
"Those are 'we don't want to trade' levels," one expert said. "Essentially people are waiting to see if things are going to calm down."
But for average Russians, lurking behind the devalued ruble is the fear of inflation, similar to the one that emptied their pocketbooks in the early 1990's, when Russia let go of Soviet-era price controls.
In scattered cases the ruble's drop showed up on shelves, despite threats by the tax police to ride herd on merchants who raise prices to take advantage of the confusion.
At a small grocery store in central Moscow, the store's administrator, Olga Larina, said she had raised prices on imported goods 10 percent after suppliers had announced that they would increase their prices.
"We realized," Ms. Larina said, "that this was the pattern when three of our suppliers told us the same thing."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Rally Overseas Helps Bolster U.S. Markets

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Led by a surge in technology shares and rallies overseas, United States stocks rose for a second day yesterday and helped the major indexes erase most of the declines suffered over the previous two weeks.
Although the market remains substantially below the highs reached a month ago, analysts said investors apparently were heeding reports pointing out how a wide array of stocks had fallen to relatively cheap levels. 
 The buying spree lifted the Dow Jones industrial average 139.80 points, a 1.6 percent gain, to 8,714.65, after a 1.8 percent gain Monday.
American Express, Sears, Roebuck, International Business Machines, Hewlett-Packard and the Aluminum Company of America each added more than 10 points to the blue-chip gauge, as 16 of its 30 stocks ended higher.
The Standard & Poor's 500-company index rose 17.53 points, to 1,101.20, also a 1.6 percent increase. Microsoft, General Electric and Pfizer led the advance.
Led by strong gains among such bellwether technology issues as Microsoft, Intel, Cisco Systems and Dell Computer, the Nasdaq composite index fared even better. The key technology barometer rose 37.08 points, a 2 percent gain, to 1,855.12.
Investors also felt more confident buying shares because political uncertainty surrounding President Clinton had eased considerably after he admitted during grand jury testimony on Monday to having an "inappropriate" relationship with Monica Lewinsky, a former White House intern.
In addition, the market's nervousness was soothed by Russia's decision to devalue its currency on Monday, which ended speculation about what steps that country would be taking to avert an economic collapse.
Stock markets in Europe were strongly higher, reflecting investor optimism that Russia had taken decisive action, and the momentum from those gains was felt on Wall Street when trading began.
Germany's benchmark equity index rose 3.1 percent to its highest level in four months. Stocks gained more than 3 percent on London, Amsterdam and Paris exchanges.
In Japan, stocks rose nearly 2 percent, erasing most of Monday's loss.
"Prices have reached attractive levels and cash has built up and all of that conspired to get us to buy stocks," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation.
In addition, he said, "the stage of being very alarmed about Russia and Asia may be behind us."
Investors' renewed confidence in the market also helped smaller-company shares erase nearly all of last week's declines.
The Russell 2000 index of smaller company stocks rose 7.33 points, to 411.29 points, a 1.8 percent gain.
Shares of Skytel Communications, the Russell's leading gainer, rose 5, to 18 5/8, after the company announced that AT&T would sell its nationwide paging services.
The buying yesterday was more broad based than in the previous session, when the gains were largely confined to big stocks.
On Monday investors "stuck their toe in the water," said Richard Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Inc. in Baltimore. But yesterday, he said, "they were more willing to go into small and midcap names."
He pointed to shares of United Rentals, a small equipment-leasing company. This week, both Legg Mason and Salomon Smith Barney recommended the stock to investors, pointing out that it has fallen almost 40 percent from its high of $48 on July 20. Yesterday, United Rentals closed at 32 7/8, up 3 7/8. Before yesterday, individual investors showed little interest in the shares, he said.
Over all, technology shares, financial services companies, telecommunications companies and drug stocks were among the leading gainers.
On the New York Stock Exchange advancing issues outnumbered declines by more than 2-to-1.
Despite these gains, analysts remained cautious in their outlook and said that investors were primarily seeking shares of companies that appear to have a relatively clear picture of future earnings.
Another sign of investors' defensive stance was a strong flow of cash into large-company stock funds, particularly index funds, said AMG Data Services, a California research firm that tracks mutual fund trends.
Robert Adler, the president of AMG, said these funds accounted for the bulk of the $1.5 billion that flowed into equity mutual funds in the week ended Aug. 12.
That flow was more than three times the total of the previous week.
Mr. Johnson of First Albany said his recent buying was limited to shares of Pepsico as he continued to hold a large number of consumer staple stocks, which he believes will provide dependable earnings regardless of market conditions.
His holdings include drug stocks like Merck, consumer products companies like Procter & Gamble and food companies like Sara Lee. He also favors larger technology companies like Dell, I.B.M. and Compaq.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
From Art Society to Times Sq., Elbows Bare

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

 BODY:
IT was probably inevitable that the man who invented those lurid chartreuse stickers cemented to certain car windows around town -- "This vehicle violates N.Y.C. parking regulations!" -- would not last forever as president of the Municipal Art Society.
It's not that Brendan J. Sexton has no sense of esthetic decorum; in fact, most preservationists agree that he has helped improve the city's physical landscape in the three years that he has led the art society. But ultimately, Mr. Sexton is an operations man, as they say at City Hall, the kind of guy who likes to get his fingernails dirty planning sanitation routes and figuring out traffic patterns and engaging in the delivery of city services in a way not usually practiced in the more rarefied world of the urban-design association. 
 Which is why many of his friends believe his next job as president of the Times Square Business Improvement District will be such a snug fit. Running one of these districts means supplying basic services the city has neither the money nor the will to provide, along with cheerleading and long-term planning. As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has recently come to realize, it's a bit like being mayor of one of the city's best-known, most prosperous neighborhoods, with $6 million in tax money to play with and no daily news conferences.
"It's a perfect match for Brendan," said Stanley Brezenoff, who as a Deputy Mayor in the Koch administration was Mr. Sexton's boss. "When he was running the city's Office of Operations, he reveled in figuring out how to make the agencies work better, coming up with milestones and benchmarks for sanitation and public safety and the general quality of life. He likes digging into problems up to his elbows."
At just under five-and-a-half feet tall, Mr. Sexton, 53, is a feisty and talkative man whose elbows are usually exposed by rolled-up sleeves. He is careful not to denigrate the job he is leaving, pointing out that the society played a major role in the design of the structure that is to replace the Coliseum at Columbus Circle, as well as the new Hudson River Park. But his role at the arts society was primarily that of a negotiator and lobbyist, testifying at hearings, writing beseeching letters to public officials, and speaking with newspaper reporters. When he talks about his next job, one can almost hear his heart pounding.
"What we've seen in Times Square in the last several years is what I think New York's next century will be very largely based on," he said, sitting in the society's crisp midtown offices in the Villard Houses, on Madison Avenue near East 50th Street. "Times Square is the place where New York is both encouraging and experimenting with the density of the future, the combination of residents and visitors that makes this the global capital of world. You get paid to be excited, to foster excitement, to make excitement friendly and safe."

MR. SEXTON said he wasn't looking for a new job but had expressed interest after a search firm called him, looking for a replacement for Gretchen Dykstra, who is leaving after six years to move to San Francisco. During Ms. Dykstra's tenure, the neighborhood scraped off its grime and ousted its shabby restaurants and movie theaters to become the city's new real estate playground, an overheated greenhouse for developers, publishers and entertainment companies thriving in the city's end-of-century exuberance.
But both Mr. Sexton and Ms. Dykstra insist that the hard work is far from over. The district's problems now involve managing its success: finding sidewalk space for boisterous crowds that often spill over the curb, planning for the day when economic growth begins pressuring Eighth Avenue and Hell's Kitchen, getting ready for the unimaginably large celebration of the new millennium that will occur exactly 500 days from today. Mr. Sexton says he wants the district to grow without losing the "little things that make you happy to be there," like the Colony Record store or the musical instrument dealers on 48th Street.
He will also have to accommodate the looming presence of Mr. Giuliani, who recently shut down another improvement district after its director was insufficiently deferential. But that should not be an enormous problem for Mr. Sexton, who long ago learned to deal with a mayor-sized ego when he worked in several posts for Mayor Edward I. Koch, including as sanitation commissioner.
Some officials at City Hall were hoping the job would go to Finance Commissioner Alfred C. Cerullo 3d, but despite a few disagreements with the Giuliani administration over the years, Mr. Sexton's ties to City Hall are fairly strong, and officials there did not seriously object to him. The district's board also didn't seem to mind that he has occasionally criticized some of the major developers in Times Square who will now be paying his salary.
Mr. Sexton, who grew up around Kew Gardens Hills in Queens, now lives in the St. George section of Staten Island, where his seven children (counting three from his wife's previous marriage) were reared. Despite the substantial salary that comes with the job, he's getting worried about convincing his children that he still works for a living.
"I don't know if the person in this job is more of a ringmaster or a maitre d' at a really super party," he said. "It's hard to justify yourself to your kids when you tell them your job is to make New York as much fun as possible."

HEADLINE: EDITORIAL OBSERVER;
In Bad Times, Blame Speculators

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Financial markets are again under stress in Asia and Russia, and local authorities know whom to blame. It's the speculators.
"Speculators have been deploying a whole host of improper measures," said Donald Tsang, Hong Kong's financial secretary, as he disclosed that the Hong Kong government had bought millions of dollars in stock. Among them were the "spreading of vicious rumors" that Hong Kong's currency might be devalued. 
 Hong Kong's stocks rallied, and the idea of government intervention is spreading. Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamed, said he might try the same tactic.
The S-word was also used in Russia, where a central bank official complained that Russian banks were speculating against the ruble by buying dollars. The central bank set out to squelch that speculation by barring such purchases by some banks.
It is not hard to sympathize with the officials involved. They think their economies and markets are going to get over a rough spot, and along comes somebody -- often identified as the dreaded hedge funds run mostly by American investors -- betting that things will fall apart. If those speculators can just be defeated, then all will be well.
In Hong Kong, the government says speculators were trying to drive the currency and the stock market down, and interest rates up, to make money in all three markets. To block such manipulation a little government intervention was necessary, authorities say. So they bought the local currency and shares in all major Hong Kong companies.
So far, it has worked. But a final verdict is not in. In the early summer of 1997, Thailand routed hedge funds that were borrowing the Thai baht and selling it, betting it would fall. Big purchases by the Thai Government temporarily raised the value of the baht. But then a funny thing happened. Ordinary Thai citizens and companies began to wonder whether a currency that needed such extraordinary intervention to protect its value was really fundamentally sound. Companies that owed dollars realized they would be in trouble if the baht were devalued, so they bought dollars. A few weeks later the baht plunged, beginning the Asian crisis.
Similarly, what the Russian central bank saw as speculation was in fact the reasonable response of Russian banks that were being pressed to repay loans they had taken out in dollars, and that were seeking to accumulate dollars as protection in case the ruble was devalued. When it became clear the Government was afraid of such protection, devaluation became inevitable.
In Hong Kong now, investors may be asking themselves whether share prices really are reasonable if they can be maintained only by government buying. Perhaps many will decide it would be safer to reduce their positions. If so, the government will have accomplished little, other than to lose a lot of public money.
All this is not to deny that speculators had a lot to do with the current problems. But when the real speculation was taking place, governments were looking on with glee. That was in 1996, when foreigners were pouring in money. They invested in Indonesian companies thinking that the fact the companies were tied to President Suharto's family was enough to assure profits. They poured money into Russia thinking it was the next emerging market, and lent money to Korean banks that were financing shaky conglomerates.
Now those who foolishly risked money in years past want to salvage what they can. Companies that owe dollars fear being bankrupted if the local currencies collapse. Both groups want to cut their losses. Is that speculation? Or prudence?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Fed Leaves Rates Steady As New Data Pose Few Risks

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Today's good news about the United States economy was the refreshing absence of bad news: the Federal Reserve did not raise interest rates at this morning's monetary policy meeting. Inflation did not rise much in July. And the trade deficit did not widen further in June, as economists had expected.
Despite the lowest unemployment rate in a generation, consumer prices edged up just two-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Commerce Department reported. Prices are up just 1.7 percent from a year ago, an extraordinary performance for the seventh year of an economic expansion. And despite the robust dollar and deepening recession in Asia, the United States trade deficit fell by more than $1 billion in June, to $14.2 billion. In dollars, that is still close to a record high, but as a share of the economy -- a more meaningful yardstick -- the trade deficit is still just two-thirds of its 1980's peak. Exports fell, but at a far slower rate than in recent months. Imports fell as well, as businesses bought less equipment from abroad and oil prices dropped another notch. 
 Against that backdrop, the Federal Reserve announced that it was leaving its target for the overnight lending rate, known as the Federal funds rate -- a benchmark for all interest rates -- at 5.5 percent, and the discount rate, the rate the Fed charges banks for emergency loans, at 5 percent.
As usual, the central bank offered no explanation of its decision, but hardly any economists were predicting a change in policy. With inflation tame, the economy slowing but not in immediate danger of slipping into recession, and turmoil in Russia and elsewhere, the Fed's best action was inaction.
"The Fed has been very successful, and blessed," said Robert Di Clemente, co-head of United States economic research at Salomon Smith Barney. "Most of us feel that they would have been compelled to tighten if it had not been for the shock from Asia."
Stocks rose sharply for the second consecutive day. But whatever the market was celebrating, it probably was not economic news, which came as no surprise to Wall Street.
Inflation may well be leveling out after declining for much of this expansion. Right now, however, the strong dollar and the growing share of imports are helping to hold down prices. Consumer prices for goods are up just four-tenths of 1 percent from a year ago. It is not just that imports, like gasoline, clothing and consumer electronics, are cheaper. It is also that inexpensive imports are helping to restrain domestic prices by intensifying competition.
The most encouraging news in today's consumer price report is that inflation in the service sector -- which accounts for two-thirds of spending and more than four-fifths of employment -- is a remarkably tame 3 percent. That is half the rate of inflation in services at the end of the 1980's boom.
"Services inflation is very benign," said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber. "It's higher than goods inflation, but it hasn't accelerated."
That is true across a wide range of services. From a year ago, for example, housing is up 3.3 percent; car repair, 2.4 percent; haircuts and other personal services, 2.2 percent, and airline and other transportation, 1.2 percent. Even the prices of medical services, a category in which economists expect heftier increases now that the shift to managed care has pretty much been completed, are up just 3.2 percent, faster than a year ago but moderate by past standards.
With labor markets tighter than they have been in decades, employment in services is growing by more than 230,000 workers a month, and wages are rising handily. So the absence of inflation in services is a puzzle.
Like the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, Mr. Harris said he suspected that the productivity of workers in services might be rising faster than the official measures were capturing. Also, competition in services is fierce, so businesses are having a tough time raising prices.
And finally, cheaper imports are having an indirect effect on wage-setting in the service industry by holding down the cost of living.
The trade deficit will almost certainly keep getting bigger as the troubles in Asia deepen. Exports to Asia have already fallen 21 percent from a year ago, and exports to the rest of the world are growing very slowly. Imports are apt to bounce back; those from Asia are beginning to head higher. Indeed, the trade deficit is likely to remain the biggest drag on economic growth, as it was during the year's first half.
The unexpected improvement in the trade deficit is a temporary respite. June's smaller trade deficit implies that economic growth in the second quarter, which slowed to 1.4 percent from 5.4 percent in the winter, might have been a bit stronger than first estimated. But one detail of today's trade report -- a sharp decline in imports of capital goods -- implies that business spending on new equipment may have been weakening at the end of last quarter. If that is so, the effects would cancel each other out.
So far this year, the widening trade deficit has knocked 2.5 percentage points off economic growth. The negative effect is likely to diminish over time, though economists expect it to persist well into next year.
"That's bad news for American manufacturers, but good news for inflation," said Pierre Ellis, senior economist at Primark Decision Economics, a forecasting firm.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices Close DownSlightly For Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended slightly lower yesterday.
A smaller-than-expected trade deficit in June suggested to some investors that economic growth might be quickening, raising the prospect of a pickup in inflation. 
 In addition, market participants focused on the dollar, a Treasury bill auction of new one-year bills and a rally in United States stocks.
The price of the benchmark 30-year bond fell 6/32, to 99 7/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.55 percent from 5.54 percent on Monday.
Federal Reserve policy makers, as expected, left interest rates unchanged at their meeting yesterday.
"The Federal Reserve adhered to an unchanged monetary policy in light of the perceived counterbalance between a slackening economic advance, benign inflation environment, budget surplus and continued fragility in overseas financial markets on one hand," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, "and robust consumer spending and torrid housing activity on the other."
The dollar fell against the yen as Japanese officials said they were ready to act to bolster the currency. A weaker dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities less attractive to foreign investors. Stocks in the United States also gained for the second consecutive day, and that helped ease some of the flight to quality into the debt market.
Elsewhere in the Treasury market, traders said the sale of a new one-year bill yesterday went off without a hitch, with the average rate at 5 percent, the lowest since 4.965 percent on Jan. 29. Following are the results of the auction:

HEADLINE: TESTING OF A PRESIDENT: THE PUBLIC;
Reactions in Milwaukee Include Disappointment And a Sense of Betrayal

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, Aug. 18

 BODY:
For her loyalty to the President, Mary Allen had endured the snickers and condescending smirks from friends, a sister, her husband.
A lifelong Democrat, Ms. Allen spent seven months believing and defending Bill Clinton's denials of a sexual relationship with a former White House intern. "Now I feel pretty foolish," she said today. 
 As the 41-year-old homemaker from suburban Greenfield watched President Clinton acknowledge on television on Monday that he had "misled people" about his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, she simply shook her head with disappointment.
Like a majority of Americans, Ms. Allen does not believe the President should lose his job, or that the investigation by the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, has been worth the time and money spent. She still believes Mr. Clinton has done a good job as a world leader and steward of the nation's economy.
But she said she would never trust him again. "He looked us right in the eye and lied to us," Ms. Allen said, recalling the President's impassioned, finger-wagging, "now listen to me" insistence last January that he had never had sexual relations with Ms. Lewinsky.
In this Middle America city of smokestacks and church spires, a hard-working place famous for making Harley-Davidson motorcycles and Miller beer, people seemed intrigued with the steamy details of the President's predicament, even as they professed a weariness about the long-running national soap opera.
To most people, it amounts to a sorry mess that has no heroes and plenty of villains: a flawed President, an overzealous prosecutor, backstabbing co-workers, arrogant lawyers, spin artists and intrusive journalists.
Judging from more than two dozen interviews in this metropolis of about 1.4 million people -- at outdoor cafes on the trendy East Side, on the broom-swept sidewalks of immigrant neighborhoods, at the campus of Marquette University, inside the gleaming shopping malls on suburban Blue Mound Road -- many voters found Mr. Clinton's televised admission to be rather grudging and shallow. Most also expressed alarm at the President's apparent recklessness and said they were disappointed in his actions, his foot-dragging and what they saw as his half-hearted apology.
"He didn't help himself with this speech," said Terry Welch, 45, whose family owns a business that makes leather finishes in Milwaukee.
Characterizing the President's talk as more legalistic than candid, Mr. Welch said that Mr. Clinton is becoming something of a parody. "When you have to listen to his tenses of speech -- Subjunctive? Conditional? -- you've got some problems with credibility."
The host of a radio call-in show on WISN-AM, Jerry Bott, noted that Mr. Clinton's speech was conspicuously missing two words: "I'm sorry." A caller from Brookfield named Patrice said she was angry about the President's tone. "He was defiant," she said, "like he dared us to even question him."
Plenty of voters say the President's private life is nobody's business but his family's. Mr. Clinton's defenders, and even a few of his political foes, expressed concern about a 90's brand of McCarthyism -- inquisitors searching under every bed, not for Communists, but for paramours.
"We don't have a right to know who he's sleeping with," said Jeff England, a 35-year-old stock trader. "It makes government so frivolous."
Tom Van Hoof, a 45-year-old architect who lives in the leafy Shorewood community along Lake Michigan, said there was a simple explanation for Mr. Clinton's actions. "Guys cheat on their wives, that's just the way the world works," said Mr. Van Hoof, a married man, who excepted himself from the crowd.
But others accepted no such excuses. George Ziedonis, a 41-year-old warehouse worker who clutched a thermos as he waited for the 7 A.M. bus, said that Mr. Clinton's performance on Monday night was characteristically riddled with wiggle words.
"He was true to form," Mr. Ziedonis said. "He never tells the whole truth. He lives in a fantasy world where he thinks he can go by his own rules."
To most people who voiced anger about Mr. Clinton, it was the lying more than any sexual misdeed that caused the most harm.
A city with a tavern on almost every corner, Milwaukee is nonetheless known as a well-behaved, follow-the-rules kind of town, a place where immigrants from Germany and Eastern Europe brought up their children to respect the flag, the police and the church.
Despite its strong Democratic leanings, Milwaukee is a much more culturally conservative place than Madison, 60 miles to the west. And Milwaukeeans do not generally tolerate the sorts of political shenanigans that are commonplace in cities like Chicago.
On the day of Mr. Clinton's address to the nation, the Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel, a newspaper that has generally been friendly to the President, published a searing editorial under the headline, "Mr. President, we've had enough." The next day, the newspaper's editorial was titled, "Clinton's speech falls woefully short."
If conservatives and liberals agree about anything on this case, it is a shared lamentation that children can no longer read newspapers or watch the television news without being confronted with the sort of sexual talk that used to make people blush.
"Can you imagine Walter Cronkite talking about oral sex and semen stains?" said Mr. Welch, the business owner.
But on the campus of Marquette University, a Roman Catholic institution run by the same Jesuit order of priests that educated Mr. Clinton at Georgetown University, young people say the Lewinsky case simply reflects a looser culture, and did not shape it.
Robyn Coleman, a 22-year-old physical therapy major at Marquette, said that most young people grew up watching risque television shows like Melrose Place and Beverly Hills 90210. She said that the Jerry Springer show, a wild, profane tabloid talk show that almost always focuses on sex, is the hottest show on campus.
"Sex is just part of life," Ms. Coleman said. "People aren't embarrassed to talk with each other about it. Unless maybe it's with your parents, you know."
In this sordid case, the deepest sympathies among voters, Democrats and Republicans, lie with the President's daughter, Chelsea, a student at Stanford University. Most people expressed support for Mrs. Clinton, but there was even a measure of disappointment with her.
To Ms. Allen, the suburban homemaker, Mrs. Clinton has disappointed those who cheered her as a symbol of strong womanhood.
"She's lost credibility on women's rights," said Ms. Allen, the mother of two young children. "How can you have any respect for a woman who puts up with a marriage like that."
The Rev. Ralph Gross, a Roman Catholic priest who is in the business of hearing confessions, said he was concerned by the holier-than-thou indignation that seems to prevail among many Americans.
"I'm troubled by this hunger for details," said Father Gross, the 54-year-old pastor of St. Margaret Mary church, saying that Mr. Clinton's acknowledgment of having done wrong should suffice, without a specific accounting of sexual misdeeds.
"We must be very careful about making judgments," he said. "People struggle with different parts of their lives. For some people, it's lust. For others, its racism or sexism. Let's be forgiving and leave the judging to God."
Father Gross said it should come as little surprise that Mr. Clinton was reluctant to confess his wrongdoing on national television.
"I've been to confession myself many times," he said, "and I sure wouldn't want to have my sins broadcast all over the place."

Three of the national telephone surveys were based on new random samples: ABC News with 587 adults, NBC/Wall Street Journal with 503 adults and Gallup for CNN and USA Today with 633 adults. The New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone callbacks with 403 adults first interviewed by CBS News Aug. 11 to 13, and then called back on Monday night.
 
The margin of sampling error for these polls is four to five percentage points. But polls completed in one night are subject to additional errors because of the limited time available to reach respondents. And polls taken immediately after an important event or address capture only the public's initial reactions, which may change.

HEADLINE: North Korea's Nuclear Ambitions

 BODY:
North Korea seems to have been caught preparing to betray its 1994 commitment to trade in its nuclear weapons ambitions for $6 billion in international assistance. American intelligence agencies have detected construction of an elaborate underground complex. If completed, the nuclear reactor and plutonium reprocessing plant expected to be built there could allow the North to produce as many as half a dozen nuclear bombs two to five years from now. Washington must insist that work on this project be halted immediately. If North Korea wants economic cooperation from the United States it must honor its promise to renounce all nuclear weapons activity.
North Korea has not yet violated the letter of its 1994 nuclear agreement with the United States. Reprocessing of spent nuclear fuel from the North's existing, above-ground reactors into bomb plutonium remains suspended. Construction work has not yet begun on either the new reactor or new reprocessing plant. That means the nuclear cooperation deal can be preserved, provided North Korea stops work on the new site. 
 The 1994 deal provided for North Korea to freeze all work on suspect nuclear programs. In exchange a group of countries, led by the United States and South Korea, agreed to provide fuel oil and to build two replacement power reactors whose spent fuel cannot easily be converted into bombs. Washington has fallen badly behind on fuel oil deliveries, with less than half the annual amount due by October so far delivered. The North has complained about this shortfall, and it is conceivable that its recent construction work is intended to pressure America into speedier oil deliveries. If so, it is a badly misconceived tactic sure to stiffen Congressional resistance to paying for more fuel.
Later this week, Washington's special envoy for Korean nuclear issues, Charles Kartman, will meet North Korean officials in New York. Halting the newly discovered construction work will rightly be high on his agenda. Beyond that, the Administration needs to proceed firmly but carefully, closely coordinating its diplomacy with South Korea, whose new Government remains committed to expanding economic cooperation with the North.
North Korea is a dangerous, unpredictable country. A breakdown of the nuclear cooperation agreement would heighten tensions on the peninsula, where 37,000 American troops still stand guard. Washington should make every reasonable effort to keep the nuclear deal alive. But the agreement clearly cannot survive if North Korea still imagines itself becoming a nuclear power.
