HEADLINE: Record Sales Bolster Starts Of New Homes

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Housing starts unexpectedly surged last month to their highest level in more than 11 years as contractors worked harder to keep up with record home sales.
The Commerce Department said today that housing starts rose 5.7 percent in July, to 1.718 million units at an annual rate. Analysts had expected the report to show a decline, to a rate of 1.596 million units. 
 The department also revised the annual rate of June's housing starts to 1.626 million units from the 1.615 million units first reported.
A combination of low mortgage and unemployment rates and rising incomes and consumer optimism is increasing the demand for new homes.
The only concern, said Suzanne Rizzo, chief United States economist at the New York consulting firm Maria Fiorini Ramirez Inc., is that there is "a shortage of workers and builders, not a shortage of people willing to buy homes."
The July pace of housing starts was well above the monthly average for the year's first half. Starts in the first six months averaged 1.576 million units a month at an annual rate, up 7.1 percent from the first six months of 1997. July starts on single-family homes rose 3 percent, and starts on multifamily buildings increased 15.1 percent.
Building permits for new-home construction, a gauge of future construction starts, rose 4 percent in July, to a rate of 1.578 million units. In June, permits fell an unrevised 1.7 percent, to 1.517 million units.
Regionally, housing starts last month rose 11.8 percent in the Northeast, to an annual rate of 152,000 units; 6.8 percent in the South, to 813,000 units; 4.3 percent in the West, to 436,000 units, and 1.9 percent in the Midwest, to 317,000 units.

HEADLINE: Survey Finds Layoffs Slowed in Last 3 Years

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The most comprehensive survey of permanent layoffs in America finds that in the last three years, a smaller percentage of workers were downsized than in any other period in this decade. But the layoff rate is still significantly higher than in the 1980's, and women now get pink slips almost as often as men.
These were among the findings in yesterday's release of the latest job displacement survey from the Labor Department, covering the years 1995 through 1997. Eight million people were pushed out of their jobs involuntarily, or one out of every 15 adult jobholders. That was down from 8.4 million in the prior three-year period, or one in 12 workers, the decade's worst performance. 
 "We are seeing the normal cyclical behavior of the labor force reflected in these numbers," said Henry Farber, a Princeton economist, referring to the strong economic growth in 1996 and 1997 and the falling unemployment rate. "The puzzle is why has it taken so long to get the layoff rate down this far and why is it not even lower."
Downsizing is still occurring at a greater rate than in the late 1980's, the last time an economic expansion lasted as long as the current one. Then the displacement rate was one out of every 18 jobholders.
The Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics began its biennial job displacement surveys in 1984, when widespread permanent layoffs were just becoming an issue. Those surveys found that downsizing fell back quickly after the 1981-1982 recession. The 1990's were different. Permanent layoffs rose in the 1990-1991 recession and then failed to fall back. They even kept rising despite the recovery. The pattern remains the same when the Labor Department's figures are adjusted, through the use of a moving average, to reconcile overlapping annual numbers from different surveys.
Labor economists offer various explanations for the persistent downsizing. The phenomenon spread in the 1990's from blue-collar to white-collar workers, and from manufacturing to service industries. Growing competition has also played a role, and so have corporate mergers.
"American companies are much more concerned than in the past about labor fat in their organizations," said Jared Bernstein, a labor economist at the Economic Policy Institute in Washington. "Some of that has to do with a heightened emphasis on short-term profits, achieved in part through labor-cost cutting."
Still, the latest survey brought a bright side. While layoffs have risen among white-collar workers and women, job losers found themselves re-employed quickly. Seventy-six percent of the 2.4 million full-time workers laid off in the latest three-year period found themselves re-employed in full-time jobs by the time of the survey, which was conducted last February. The rest were still among the unemployed or had dropped out of the labor force.
But that 76 percent was up from 72 percent in the mid-1990's and 69.6 percent in the late 1980's. What is more, the median period between jobs fell to 4.1 weeks from 5.1 in the 1993-1995 period, and 6.1 weeks in the late 1980's.
When part-timers are added to the mix, then the rate of re-employment falls and the average wage for those who are re-employed also falls. The new wage averages 10 percent or more below the earnings in the old job, according to a recent study by Mr. Farber. The Bureau of Labor Statistics does not include such data in the published results of its surveys. But among the full-timers who were re-employed in full-time jobs, 55 percent earned as much or more in their new jobs as they had in their old ones, the bureau said. That was up from 48 percent in the previous survey, but down from 60 percent in the late 1980's, also boom years.
The Clinton Administration, seeking to highlight its assistance programs for dislocated workers, focused on the 24 percent of full-time workers who were re-employed in full-time jobs by the time of the survey, but in jobs with salaries that were 20 percent or more below their old wages.
They are "why the department's programs and grants to assist dislocated workers are so important," Secretary of Labor Alexis Herman said in a statement.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics also compiles job displacement numbers for people laid off after having held jobs for three or more years, a figure that most labor economists consider less important than the broader category. The trend for the longer-tenured jobholders was roughly the same, although the decline was sharper -- 3.6 million displaced workers in the 1995-1997 period, compared with 4.2 million in the 1993-1995 period.
The latest survey also documented trends in downsizing that have characterized the 1990's. The job-loss rate for women is now nearly as high as the one for men: 6.5 percent of all adult women employed versus 6.7 percent for men. Whites, blacks and Hispanic workers are also gradually converging, with the white displacement rate at 6.1 percent in the latest survey, blacks at 7.1 percent and the Hispanic rate at 8.8 percent. The spread was twice as great in the late 1980's.
And since the last survey, in 1996, the layoff rate among manufacturing workers has declined slightly, while that for service workers has edged up, continuing trends that go back to the 1980's, when they were much more pronounced. Still, blue-collar workers are more likely to be laid off, with one of every 20 blue-collar workers losing jobs in the latest three-year period, compared with one in every 22 white-collar workers.

HEADLINE: Details for New Center at Newark Airport

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, Aug. 19

 BODY:
The developers of a proposed hotel and conference center complex on the fringes of Newark International Airport today detailed their plans for the project, which would tap into a growing need for hotel rooms and meeting space within easy reach of the airport.
The 55-acre site will include a 50,000-square-foot conference center, a 550-room deluxe hotel and a 250-room limited service hotel, said Emanuel Stern, the president and chief executive of Hartz Mountain Industries, the developer. He said work on the project would create 3,000 construction jobs and 2,500 permanent jobs once the work was completed. Construction of the $150 million project is to start early next year, company officials said, and is expected to be completed by 2000. 
 Plans for the site, stretching along the long-unused Waverly rail yards a little over a mile west of the airport, have for much of the last decade been little more than a gleam in the eye of developers and Newark officials. The expectations have risen and fallen with the changes in Newark's fortunes, the real estate market and air travel.
In the last two years, the chances of development on the site have increased tremendously as the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey planned and began construction to extend the existing airport monorail to a new terminal for New Jersey Transit commuter trains and Amtrak trains adjacent to the Hartz Mountain property. Last spring, the developer won in its bid to build a pedestrian walkway connecting the hotel and conference center complex to the terminal.
Walter M. Smith Jr., executive vice president of operations with Hartz Mountain Industries, said the property the developer acquired from Newark in 1988 had gone from being a likely industrial site with little access to the airport to a vastly more valuable property with a direct line into the stream of 30 million people who use the airport annually.
"It's the current upturn in the economy which really makes this possible," he said. "And we have been hearing that there is an increasing business travel meeting space requirement for companies that might want to fly people into a single airport in the morning, get them to an all-day meeting near the airport and then fly them home that same night."
Mr. Smith said Hartz Mountain spent between $3 million and $5 million to rid the site of hazardous materials like heavy metals.
Details of the plans were revealed today as Hartz Mountain executives and other business people joined Newark Mayor Sharpe James and Senator Frank R. Lautenberg on a tour of a number of economic development sites in the city, which has been undergoing a resurgence and attracting the interest of developers after years of economic decline. As Mr. Stern described the company's plans, a steady stream of airplanes could be seen just over his shoulder, noisily sliding down the glide path to the airport's runways.
Mr. Lautenberg, who was instrumental in winning Federal financing for the monorail and the commuter and Amtrak rail terminal, said the transportation links and the need for meeting space would make the location "a premier site" in the region.
There are now about 3,700 hotel rooms within two miles of the airport, Newark economic development officials said, and the proposed Hartz Mountain complex will, by itself, increase that number by more than 20 percent. Newark was listed as the 16th busiest airport in the world in terms of takeoffs and landings in 1997, by the Airports Council International -- ahead of La Guardia, which was 33d, and Kennedy International, which was 34th. In total passengers, Kennedy was 15th, Newark 16th and La Guardia 37th.
In the last year, Newark has been the fastest growing airport in the New York area, Port Authority officials said.

HEADLINE: U.S. SEEKS MEANS TO BRING SUSPECT FROM AFGHANISTAN

BYLINE: By JAMES RISEN; This article was reported by Steven Erlanger, James Risen and Tim Weiner. It was written by Mr. Risen.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
As United States officials focus on a Saudi exile, Osama bin Laden, as a prime suspect in the embassy bombings in Africa, they are considering strategies for how they might negotiate his capture with the Taliban, the fundamentalist Muslims who control Afghanistan, officials said.
In Afghanistan, a high-ranking official of the Taliban opened the door today to such discussions.
Since 1996 the Taliban have sheltered Mr. bin Laden, a wealthy Saudi whom the United States calls one of the world's leading financiers of terrorism. 
 Wakil Ahmed Mutawakil, the spokesman for the Taliban and the second-highest ranking official of their Supreme Council, said in a telephone interview from Afghanistan that if the United States provided hard evidence of Mr. bin Laden's involvement in the bombings, the Taliban would be willing to meet with American officials to discuss what to do about him.
"Our understanding is that the U.S. is continuing to investigate this matter and there isn't any solid evidence of his involvement," Mr. Mutawakil said. "If you call someone a terrorist, you must have proof. If there is proof, we will certainly sit down and talk to the U.S."
But Mr. Mutawakil's comments served more to raise difficult questions for American policy makers than to open any immediate prospect of a resolution to the investigation of the bombings at the United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania on Aug. 7, which killed more than 250 people and wounded 5,000.
While Mr. Mutawakil is a top figure in the Taliban, his statement comes in the midst of contradictory statements from the mullah who leads the movement. That raises American worries that there is a rift and that the Taliban might ultimately be unwilling to deliver Mr. bin Laden.
Any deal could be complicated -- or short-circuited -- by Washington's longstanding complaints with the Taliban. Those include their harsh treatment of women, other human-rights questions and their involvement in narcotics trafficking.
But this may be a good time to negotiate with the Taliban. Having nearly defeated their opposition at home, the Taliban are desperate for international recognition and economic support.
Any deal for Mr. bin Laden would almost certainly also have to involve Pakistan. Despite Pakistan's cooperation with the bombing investigation in recent days, American-Pakistani relations remain complicated since Pakistan's tests of nuclear weapons earlier this year.
Still, American officials are deliberating whether they can provide incentives to the Taliban to win their cooperation in helping to bring Mr. bin Laden to face any charges that may be filed against him in the bombings.
No such charges have yet been brought, but senior Clinton Administration officials say he is their leading suspect.
United States officials reacted cautiously to Mr. Mutawakil's statement, saying they were not yet ready to open talks with the Taliban concerning Mr. bin Laden.
"If we get to that point, then we'll deal with it," one official said. "We've had discussions with the Taliban in the past about bin Laden. And if we were to establish information that shows he did not live up to his obligations as a 'guest' in Afghanistan, then we would provide it to the Taliban, and certainly take up" the suggestion of direct talks.
There have been conflicting statements from the Taliban's leadership in recent days about their willingness to deal with the United States on Mr. bin Laden. Mr. Mutawakil's statements came on the heels of hard-line comments made earlier Wednesday by other senior Taliban officials, including the group's leader, Mullah Mohammed Omar, vowing to protect Mr. bin Laden.
Insisting that Mr. bin Laden was not involved in the bombings, Mullah Omar vowed to the Pakistan-based Afghan Islamic Press that "even if all the countries of the world unite, we would defend Osama with our blood."
American officials have to contend with this split in the Taliban over the movement's relationship with Mr. bin Laden, a Saudi exile who helped finance Afghan rebels in their long war against the Soviet Union in the 1980's. Some United States officials say there is a faction among the Taliban that sees him as a liability that they inherited from the previous Afghan government.
As they deliberate how to approach the Taliban in the future, United States officials said they would not trade Mr. bin Laden's capture for American recognition of the Taliban's de facto government. But they said the Administration was weighing other ways to persuade the Afghans to cooperate.
Diplomacy may be the only answer, since several American officials said a military or covert operation to capture Mr. bin Laden was unlikely or impossible.
There are no evident signs that the United States is considering a military operation against his compound, despite rumors to that effect in Pakistan. The American Ambassador in Pakistan, Thomas Simons, has dismissed the possibility that the United States would use Pakistan as a staging ground for a military assault.
"You can't shoot a Tomahawk at Kandahar from some ship in the ocean," said one diplomat in the region, referring to a cruise missile used by the Navy. "It would take infantry."
Any land-based military operation would almost certainly have to be mounted from Pakistan, whose Interior Minister, Shujat Hussain, ruled out such a mission today. "We cannot be a party to that," he said.
A covert mission to flush Mr. bin Laden out of hiding is conceivable. Last year, the C.I.A. and the F.B.I. lured Mir Amal Kansi, the convicted killer of two C.I.A. employees, out of hiding in Afghanistan to a hotel in Pakistan, where he was arrested after a four-and-a-half-year manhunt. The Pakistanis cooperated in Mr. Kansi's capture.
But Mr. bin Laden has much greater financial and political resources than Mr. Kansi and is far less likely to succumb to trickery or fall into a trap laid by American intelligence operatives.
A senior diplomatic official familiar with the leadership of the Taliban, said: "If bin Laden is involved, they've got a big bargaining chip," one that they might use to negotiate for the international recognition they strongly desire.
Another senior American official added: "We may be on the verge of a new relationship of Taliban to the world, and if they insist on calling themselves a government, they may have to act more like a government, with international norms and responsibilities. That includes restraining terrorism, which touches on the issue of his residence in Afghanistan."
On Tuesday, visiting the bombed American embassies in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, and Nairobi, Kenya, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright first raised the issue of the Taliban's turning over Mr. bin Laden when she said that the Afghans would improve their chances for international recognition if they stopped sheltering known or suspected terrorists like Mr. bin Laden.
Yet American officials have been frustrated in their previous attempts to win the support of the Taliban leadership in curbing terrorism.
In April, Bill Richardson, the United States chief delegate to the United Nations, met with Taliban leaders in Afghanistan to discuss Mr. bin Laden, but Taliban leaders rejected a request that they extradite him.
Before the Africa bombings, the United States suspected Mr. bin Laden of involvement in the bombings of American military installations in Saudi Arabia.
The Taliban have told State Department officials that Mr. bin Laden has guaranteed them, after Saudi Arabia demanded such a guarantee, that he will not conduct terrorist activities from inside Afghanistan. This is thought in Washington to be an empty promise.
In addition, Mr. bin Laden is thought to pay the Taliban for sanctuary, in part out of his profits from his legitimate businesses and, allegedly, narcotics dealing.
Any United States negotiations with the Taliban will have to involve Pakistan. While Pakistan has close military and intelligence ties to the United States -- ties that have proved crucial in the spreading investigation of the embassy bombings -- Pakistan's Government is furious over American sanctions imposed on the country after it tested nuclear weapons.
A bargain with Pakistan could bring Washington's goal of stopping the spread of nuclear weapons into conflict with its counterterrorism goals.
Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott and other American diplomats will meet with Pakistan's Foreign Minister, Shamshad Ahmad, on Tuesday in London. American efforts to obtain Pakistani and Indian cooperation to halt their nuclear weapons programs are high on the agenda. So are the Taliban and Mr. bin Laden.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
On-Line Ad Spending Seen Rising Tenfold

BYLINE: By Jennifer Steinhauer 

 BODY:
On-line advertising spending will reach more than $15 billion worldwide in 2003 from $1.5 billion in 1998, according to a report released yesterday by Forrester Research Inc. in Cambridge, Mass. 
 The report, "Media's Global Future," predicted that on-line ad spending in North America would grow to $10.5 billion in 2003 from $1.3 billion in 1998. Spending overseas will be led by Europe, according to the report, where it will increase to $2.8 billion in 2003 from $105 million this year.

HEADLINE: 3 Candidates For Governor Turn on Rival

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: BRENTWOOD, N.Y., Aug. 19

 BODY:
Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross came under attack tonight by her three rivals for the Democratic nomination for governor, who used a debate here to question her loyalty to Democratic values, her political experience and her competence.
In a debate that had been largely marked by comity and unity of purpose -- the candidates spent the bulk of the evening assailing Gov. George E. Pataki -- the three other Democrats made the same choice when offered a chance to select one candidate to question: They turned on Ms. McCaughey Ross, the former Republican who is now seeking the Democratic nomination to run against the man who brought her into politics. 
 "I wonder, in all earnestness," said one of the candidates, Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney, "what is it about your experience as Lieutenant Governor that prepares you to be the chief executive of a state with a $72 billion budget."
Another candidate, James L. Larocca, the former state transportation commissioner, asked why Ms. McCaughey Ross, who is also the Liberal Party candidate for governor, would not agree to support the winner of the Democratic primary if it was not her.
And the other gubernatorial candidate, Peter F. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker, asked if Ms. McCaughey Ross was aware that he had introduced city legislation mandating the use of trigger locks on handguns, similar to a bill Ms. McCaughey Ross has called for statewide.
The exchange came in a race that has until now been remarkably placid. Indeed, until the questions about Ms. McCaughey Ross were posed at the debate at Suffolk County Community College here, the discussion had been free of wrangling. Until then, each candidate had taken turns, in their second debate, serving up a variety of criticisms of Mr. Pataki's effectiveness as governor and his political ethics.
The attacks on Ms. McCaughey Ross seemed to reflect continuing uncertainty among the various camps over the shape of the race and how best to position their candidate. From the start, she has been assumed to be a front-runner, if only because she is the only woman in the race and because her husband, Wilbur Ross, an industrialist, was said by her campaign to be prepared to finance a heavy television advertising campaign on her behalf. (With the election less than a month away, it remains unclear whether he will actually do so.)
Mr. Vallone's aides distributed a statement attacking Ms. McCaughey Ross's record even before the debate began.
Ms. McCaughey Ross appeared unfazed by the attacks, seeming to welcome the jostling.
When Mr. Larocca accused the Lieutenant Governor of using government funds to print a report on the state economy that has become a staple of her campaign appearances, she brushed aside his remark as "a distortion." (A notice on the report says it was not published at taxpayers' expense.)
And when Mr. Larocca pushed her about why she would not promise to support the Democratic candidate if she lost the nomination, Ms. McCaughey Ross dismissed the line of inquiry as irrelevant.
"When working families watch this on television," she responded, "they are less concerned with insider party politics than the fundamental issues facing the people of New York."
As a group, the Democrats differed on one major issue: the death penalty. Only Mr. Hynes opposes it. Mr. Vallone strongly endorsed capital punishment, referring to convicted killers who murder prison guards. "There are people who will kill again," Mr. Vallone said. "I have no problem whatsoever in sending them back to their maker."
Ms. McCaughey Ross said she was more concerned about domestic violence. But she said she has "come to accept the death penalty."
"A society has a right to express its moral outrage," she said.
But Mr. Hynes promised that his top priority, if elected, would be to revoke the law that was a centerpiece of Mr. Pataki's 1994 campaign.
"The death penalty is a phony," Mr. Hynes said. "It's a phony issue. It's not punishment at all to stick a needle in someone's arm after 15 years of appeals."
He said he favored "real life without parole, the kind of punishment the Federal Government gives to John Gotti, who spends 23 hours a day in a jail cell."
Mr. Larocca sought to distinguish himself from his opponents by urging them to sign a pledge promising not to take money from interests doing business with the state. "We cannot make the case against George Pataki, who runs his campaign on this self-interested big money, if we ourselves are part of this process," he said. "I am the only candidate who is not part of this system."
None took Mr. Larocca up on his offer.
And on an issue of particular concern here, the state takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, Ms. McCaughey Ross, Mr. Vallone and Mr. Hynes denounced the deal and said it should have been put up for a public referendum. Mr. Larocca, the only Long Island resident in the race, said the issue should be abandoned.
"I think it's for Long Island to put this issue behind us," Mr. Larocca said. "Most Long Islanders are happy to be getting rid of the company they didn't like, happy to get the rebates they're going to get. It's time for politicians to find the next issue to make their bones on."
For all that, though, the candidates were nearly in unison as they attacked Mr. Pataki on a variety of fronts, ranging from his administration of the state government to his fund-raising practices to his recent display of national ambition.
"Governor -- we have problems," Mr. Vallone said. "You're out of state. You're out of touch. You have to come back and address those problems."
The candidates assailed Mr. Pataki for pushing for increases in tuition for the State University of New York. "Pataki's huge tuition increase at SUNY, combined with the deep cuts in their operating budget, has deprived students of an education," Mr. Hynes said.
The four candidates also criticized Mr. Pataki for allowing the state debt to increase during his first four years in office. Mr. Larocca said he would push legislation that would mandate that 25 percent of any surplus go toward paying down the state's debt.
"George Pataki came to New York and said he was a fiscal conservative," Mr. Larocca said. "He is sinking New York into debt at a rate that would make Nelson Rockefeller and Abraham Beame blush. We are on our way to a debt situation exactly like 1975, when we were at the brink of bankruptcy in New York."

HEADLINE: World News Briefs;
Aide to King Hussein To Be Next Premier

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 19

 BODY:
King Hussein of Jordan will appoint the chief of his royal court, Fayez al-Tarawnah, as Prime Minister, the official Petra news agency said today.
The agency said that Prime Minister Abdul-Salam al-Majali, 74, was expected to submit his resignation to King Hussein, who is undergoing treatment for cancer in the United States. A Government minister said he expected that a new Cabinet would be announced on Thursday. 
 Mr. Majali, who was appointed in March 1997, has been under fire for his Government's handling of a recent water-pollution crisis that has forced Jordan to import water from Saudi Arabia.
Mr. Tarawnah, 50, an economist educated in the United States, is from a prominent Jordanian political family and was one of Jordan's main negotiators in talks that led to its 1994 peace treaty with Israel.
He served as Jordan's Ambassador to the United States before being made Foreign Minister last year. He was later appointed chief of the royal court.

HEADLINE: Sometimes the Homeless Are the Working Poor

 BODY:

To the Editor:
San Francisco's homeless problem is actually more insidious than your Aug. 16 news article suggests. Poor people are being forced out of the city as it becomes unaffordable, not the other way around. 
 The lack of affordable housing in San Francisco makes it virtually impossible for the working poor, let alone the homeless, to live here. In fact, the working poor and the homeless are one and the same. A recent study by the Institute for Children and Poverty shows that in at least 41 percent of homeless families, one family member has a job or has been unemployed for less than a year.
Far from being a magnet, San Francisco's housing crisis is pushing people, mostly long-term residents, out of the city. There is a real fear that San Francisco is becoming a city only for the rich.
 
REBECCA VILKOMERSON
San Francisco, Aug. 17, 1998

HEADLINE: Bullish on Times Square Neon;
Wall Street Muscles Into Mecca of Commercial Glitter

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Ever since Trimble's Whiskey erected the first neon sign there nearly a century ago, Times Square has been New York's glowing, pulsating marketplace for everything from steam irons to video cameras, Camels to Calvins. Now, though, it is beginning to hawk a very different kind of product: the stock market.
The biggest of those advertisers -- at least in terms of neon acreage -- will be the Nasdaq market, which is waging an upstart campaign to overtake the New York Stock Exchange. Nasdaq recently signed a deal to build the largest single sign in Times Square: a $15 million, multimedia kaleidoscope of stock tickers, video screens and colorful billboards that will festoon the cylindrical tower of the building now rising along Broadway between 42d and 43d Streets. 
 The sign will be big -- roughly the size of three basketball courts -- but it will hardly be alone. Times Square will soon be a visual metaphor for the way the stock market -- news about it, talk about it, anxiety about it -- seems to pervade life these days.
The Nasdaq sign, on the skyscraper known as the Conde Nast building, will stand directly across the street from Dow Jones's electronic zipper, which encircles the signpost tower at 1 Times Square. That, in turn, is directly across the street from where Reuters, the British media and financial information company, will hang a series of electronic signs on its new American headquarters, at Seventh Avenue and 42d Street.
And those three signs will be only five blocks south of three amber-colored, 157-foot-long stock and financial information zippers that strut across the face of the Morgan Stanley Dean Witter building, at 1585 Broadway.
"There's going to be a shootout in Times Square between Nasdaq, Reuters, Morgan Stanley and Dow Jones," said George N. Stonbely, president of Spectacolor Communications, the electronic sign company that designed the giant Kodak, Hertz and AT&T signs on the face of the Marriott Marquis hotel, at Broadway and 47th Street. "They're all talking about mega-hardware on the outside of their buildings. It's going to be funny to see so much financial information in Times Square, instead of a Coke bottle or a can of Planters peanuts. Someone who hasn't been here in many years is going to think they're in the wrong place."
Stocks and bonds are certainly a far cry from the products that were traditionally hawked on the district's billboards and neon signs, like Maytag washers, Wrigley's Spearmint Chewing Gum and Trimble's Whiskey, which was depicted on that first neon sign in 1904. The most famous billboard of all was the Camel cigarette sign, designed by the sign specialist Douglas Leigh, which blew rings of steam over Broadway between 1941 and 1966.
But with Times Square the symbol of New York's recent resurgence, it is fitting that the businesses fueling that boom -- finance, along with media and entertainment -- should be jostling for space there.
"Times Square has always been a little bit ahead of the game in displaying the rawest edge of commercialization of our society," said Thomas Bender, a history professor at New York University. "It makes sense that Wall Street should display itself on the biggest public stage available at a time when we have the most open celebration of the marketplace in history."
To some extent, the changing images on the square's signs reflect the changing nature of the business being done in the offices behind them.
As a longtime entertainment district, Times Square was a logical location for media giants like Reuters, Viacom or Bertelsmann A.G. But the financial services industry has become a large and growing presence, most notably Morgan Stanley, which signed a tentative deal last week to erect its third tower at the north end of the square.
Still, for the financial industry, Times Square's greatest charm is its advertising might, especially at a time when the number of Americans who own stock has soared to 43 percent of adults, from 10 percent only two decades ago.
"If you're going to compete in the global marketplace, what better place than the international crossroads of the world," said David Arena, who heads Morgan Stanley's corporate real estate department and is well aware of the estimated 20 million visitors who pass through the square annually, not to mention the 250 million television viewers around the world who watch the ball drop from the former Times Tower on New Year's Eve.
Of course, the unbridled proliferation of signs in Times Square has some people worried that the billboards will eventually all look like so much undifferentiated "wallpaper" to the thousands of office workers and visitors who course through Times Square every day.
"There was never this much clutter, this much clamor for attention," said Jason Perline, who has put up signs in Times Square for 32 years. "It's anybody's guess how long it'll be an attractive media buy. Time will only tell, but I do question it."
Reuters is going to great lengths to insure that its signs will be unique among that "clutter," by hiring the designer Edwin A. Schlossberg and by dropping plans for a zipper, at least for now.
In the meantime, Frank G. Zarb, chairman of the National Association of Stock Dealers, which owns the Nasdaq market, has made no secret of his plans to build a world financial market that would rival the New York Stock Exchange. He has already acquired the American Stock Exchange and may move it, together with the association's headquarters, to Times Square.
With its giant sign and other attractions in Times Square, Nasdaq hopes to sell itself to the public by creating a virtual trading floor that rivals the much-televised opening bell of the New York Stock Exchange, which is larger and better known. Unlike the telegenic trading floors of the New York exchange, Nasdaq is an electronic market composed mainly of telephone lines and computers.
Michael Jones, a senior vice president at the National Association of Stock Dealers in Washington, confirmed that Nasdaq was planning to move its marketing operation to Times Square, but he declined to provide details. Sign builders and real estate executives say, though, that the association's board approved a 65,000-square-foot leasing deal on Aug. 6 for the gigantic sign, a television studio and marketing center at 4 Times Square, at 43d Street and Broadway.
Real estate executives who have seen the plans said the Nasdaq marketing operation would move from an obscure berth on the ninth floor of 33 Whitehall in lower Manhattan to 4 Times Square. There would be a broadcast studio with a curving wall of television monitors looking out on Times Square from behind a semicircular, two-story glass wall, where daily briefings and public stock offerings would be announced. A public entrance would lead to the second floor, where there would be an auditorium and interactive displays for visitors wanting to track the progress of various stocks. The association is also taking some office space.
The huge sign itself would rise from the third story and ascend about 125 feet, the executives said, and is expected to cost $15 million, about three times the price of Morgan Stanley's giant electronic zippers, but only half of what Reuters may spend to build 15,169 square feet of sophisticated, high-resolution video signs on the side of its building.
Though ever popular, signs in Times Square have only in recent years generated big money. Last year, a German investment group bought 1 Times Square for $110 million, or nearly four times the price paid by Lehman Brothers two years earlier. The value of the deal was in the signs, not the building. The four large signs that climb up the front of 1 Times Square, home of the New Year's Eve ball drop, generate more than $7 million a year in rent from Budweiser, Nissin, ITT and Panasonic.
The current Times Square revival is in stark contrast to the 1970's, when many New Yorkers avoided the area and neon signs fell out of fashion. By the time Mr. Leigh sold his 14 billboards in Times Square to the Van Wagner sign company, 13 were blank. The sole renter was Sony. Mr. Perline, a founder of Van Wagner, said he could not sell space to American companies because of the image of Times Square as dowdy and dangerous. He recalled a salesman for Philip Morris saying, "We don't want a sign seen only by pimps and prostitutes."
"I said, 'Who smokes more than pimps and prostitutes?' " Mr. Perline said. "But it wasn't a good sales pitch."
Van Wagner turned its attention to Sony's contemporaries in Japan, emerging companies looking to make a name for themselves. Unlike many New Yorkers, the Japanese realized that millions of camera-laden tourists were still pouring through Times Square every year in a kind of civic pilgrimage akin to visiting Mecca or Lourdes. Soon Hitachi, Minolta, Konica and Fuji were pitching up billboards and neon spectaculars in Times Square, the first step toward becoming household words in America.
For the most part, American companies did not return for another decade, and not until the city imposed an ordinance in 1987 requiring new buildings in the Times Square district to display oversize, bright signs on new buildings along Broadway and Seventh Avenue. At the time, civic groups hailed the ordinance as a tool to save Times Square, but real estate developers who were trying to douse the bright lights and create a new office district hated it.
"Investment bankers and lawyers don't want to work in an environment surrounded by flashing lights," David S. Solomon, the developer who built the Morgan Stanley building and then lost it in the recession, said at the time. "They want museums and sidewalk cafes."
Even when Morgan Stanley moved into the tower in 1995, it was reluctant to dangle bright, garish signs off the side of its buildings. But Disney has moved onto 42d Street and a museum, albeit Madame Tussaud's, is on the way, making the area more respectable. And Morgan Stanley has since merged with Dean Witter, providing the investment bank with a vast retail clientele that can be reached through the signposts in Times Square.
"The signs of the 20's -- Presto steam irons and Royal typewriters -- were about liberation from drudgery," said Tama Starr, co-author of "Signs and Wonders: The Spectacular Marketing of America" and president of Artkraft Strauss, a family-owned sign maker. "Now the signs are about the world market and the information age."

HEADLINE: TV WEEKEND;
Hard Bargain: Buying a Baby, Selling a Soul

BYLINE: By Anita Gates 

 BODY:
Stockard Channing does not look at home in a Louisiana trailer park. Which is a point "The Baby Dance" wants to make. There she is, as Rachel Luckman, a well-dressed Hollywood executive, making her way through the trash-strewn yards, fending off barking dogs, avoiding the stares of half-naked men who are working on a car. Finally she reaches the trailer of Al LeFauve (Richard Lineback), an unemployed pipe fitter, and his wife, Wanda (Laura Dern), who is very pregnant with their fifth child. Rachel is there to buy their baby.
"The Baby Dance," which has its premiere on Showtime on Sunday night, shows us just what an agonizing, invasive and ultimately soul-destroying process that kind of transaction can be. The film, written and directed by Jane Anderson, based on her 1989 play, is alternately funny and poignant. 
 As Hollywood white collar and Shreveport blue collar eye each other with polite words barely disguising mutual horror, the story teeters constantly on the brink of the ridiculous. But thanks to Ms. Anderson's restrained directing style and to strong, sure performances by this cast (including Peter Riegert as Rachel's husband, Richard), the film hangs onto its dignity. And the final scenes are as heart-wrenching as screen storytelling can be, made all the more powerful by the comic encounters that preceded them.
Rachel and Richard have come to Shreveport for a first meeting with Wanda and Al, who answered their "baby wanted" ad and have contracted to give up their child for adoption by the Luckmans. The two women start out politely. Rachel brings flowers to Wanda and says, "Isn't this lovely?" as she enters the cramped, hot trailer. Wanda brings out a cold-cut plate with white bread for lunch. But the trouble has already begun.
Rachel and Richard had sent the LeFauves $500 to buy an air-conditioner, but the money has been spent elsewhere. Wanda is smoking, drinking coffee and not taking the prenatal vitamins that Rachel had recommended. And Rachel's question about whether Wanda might have ever considered an abortion prompts a rather basic discussion of religion.
Wanda just wants to be sure that the Luckmans do "go to church." The next thing you know, Rachel, who is Jewish, is promising to celebrate Christmas with the child and in the spring to observe Easter as well as Passover. As Rachel is waxing poetic about the universality of the seder as a celebration of freedom, Wanda interrupts her with "Well, will you still have chocolate bunnies and jelly beans and all?"
If Laura Dern plays one more white-trash character this effectively ("Rambling Rose," "Citizen Ruth"), her fans are going to forget she grew up privileged in Hollywood. And although Ms. Channing is in "Six Degrees of Separation" mode as a sophisticate of good will who enjoys her own clever remarks, she is heartbreaking. The scene in which Rachel rests her head on Wanda's stomach to listen to her future daughter's heartbeat and whisper the name she has chosen could have been maudlin, but Ms. Channing turns it around.
The scene in which Ms. Channing spies Wanda's 12-year-old daughter in the backyard -- long, silky, golden hair flowing and catching the sunlight as she does cartwheels -- could easily have come across like Humbert Humbert's first glimpse of Lolita. But Ms. Channing makes it pure. And when Ms. Dern then remarks, "Now you know what the girls look like," her voice conveys all the bitterness and the loss of the pact she has made with the Devil.
The film is far from perfect. There are a few truly terrible lines like Mr. Riegert's to Mr. Lineback in the hospital just before the baby's birth: "You always have the advantage over me, my friend. You have the ability to make life." But the production designer, Brent Thomas, has a real eye for rural squalor. And if the joke is on the poor couple -- ridiculing their home, their language, their taste -- the Luckmans are eventually shown to have numerous flaws of their own. One very significant flaw, in fact, reveals itself at the end.
 
THE BABY DANCE
Showtime, Sunday night at 9
 
Jane Anderson, writer and director; Meg LeFauve and Vicky Herman, producers; Jodie Foster, Robert Halmi Jr., Tony Allard and Matthew O'Connor, executive producers; Jan Kiesser, director of photography; Brent Thomas, production designer; Norman Buckley, editor; music by Terry Allen; costumes by Gregory Mah.

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE

 BODY:

 Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Summer hours vary for galleries and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
 * "a k a LEWIS CARROLL," Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0008 (through Aug. 30). To the public he was Lewis Carroll, the author of "Alice's Adventures in Wonderland," but in private life he was Charles Lutwidge Dodgson (1832-1898), mathematician, Oxford don, cleric, poet, pamphleteer, deviser of games and puzzles, ardent theatergoer and gifted amateur photographer. This show, assembled largely from the library's own collection for the 100th anniversary of Dodgson's death, offers hefty slices of Dodgson and Carroll material, ranging from the adoring photos of little girls that were a Dodgson specialty to original illustrations for "Wonderland" by the Punch cartoonist John Tenniel. Associated memorabilia include Dodgson's White Rabbity big silver pocket watch and a ring belonging to Alice Liddell, the child who inspired "Wonderland." An enjoyable tribute to this Victorian who somehow found the freedom to let the child in him out. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays, 10:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Admission: $6; $4, students and the elderly (Grace Glueck). 

 JANINE ANTONI, "Swoon," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 74th Street, (212) 945-3600 (through Nov. 15). Best known for performances and sculptures that often involved symbolic but grueling labor -- like mopping the floor with her own hair -- Ms. Antoni has made a largely successful foray into video installation. The sad, seductive final pas de deux from "Swan Lake" forms its heart, expertly danced by a ballerina and her partner, seen on a double screen that is partly obscured by a curtain on one side. They dance without music, so the sounds of their movements, footfalls and labored breathing provide an audible account of the effort, discipline and suffering behind ballet's breathtaking illusion. When Tchaikovsky's beautiful music suddenly fills the gallery, swooning is a definite possibility. For a few exhilarating moments, the dancing looks effortless and weightless, but the music quickly fades, and reality sets in once more. Hours: Wednesdays, and Fridays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays, 1 to 8 P.M. Admission: $9; $7 for students and the elderly (Roberta Smith).
 
 * "THE ART OF THE MOTORCYCLE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Sept. 20). Yes, it is weird to see motorcycles in the Guggenheim, but American art museums have always shown objects of design, and if there's a certain peril in taking this curious show altogether seriously, on one level that's fitting because motorcycles are frivolous to begin with. The exhibition covers the ground between an 1868 French velocipede with a steam engine beneath the seat (ouch!) and a sleek 1998 MV Agusta. The show is way too big, but many of the bikes really are great to look at, and to like them you don't have to have a tattoo or know what a single-overhead-cam valve gear with enclosed rockers is. Frank O. Gehry's installation of shiny stainless-steel panels covering the rotunda side of Wright's ramp miraculously dematerialize the rotunda and makes the inside of the museum resemble a machine, an apt metaphor. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. Admission: $12; $7 students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).
 
 * "BOCCIONI AND WOMEN," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Oct. 18). A key member of the Italian Futurist group at its height, from 1909 to 1916, Umberto Boccioni (1882-1916) worked toward an art that reflected the speed and dynamism of 20th-century civilization. This small show of drawings, prints and one sculpture relating to women conveys the important shifts in Boccioni's style from 1905 until his death while serving in World War I. Unlike, say, Picasso or de Kooning, Boccioni used the women in his life -- his mother, sisters, neighbors and mistress -- to explore artistic strategies rather than his own psyche. In this show, his mother appears to be his favorite model, and the most powerful work is a sculptured head of her that is remarkable for its melding of soft, fleshy contours with Cubistic angles and planes that create a surface as roughed up as a New York City street. This show only hints at Boccioni's real achievements, but it whets the appetite for another retrospective. Hours: Fridays and Saturdays, 9:30 A.M. to 8:45 P.M.; Sundays, and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M. Suggested admission: $8 for adults; $4 for students and the elderly (Glueck).
 
 * "BONNARD," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9480 (through Oct. 13). Don't miss this exhibition. Americans still don't appreciate Pierre Bonnard enough. He doesn't fit comfortably into the history of modernism, so he tends to be regarded as an anachronism, an Impressionist after Impressionism was dead. But his best art deserves to be ranked with Matisse's and Picasso's, and if you doubt this, spend time in the last rooms of the show. It ends with the paintings of Bonnard's wife, Marthe, in the bath -- mysterious elegies of love -- and with his self-portraits, which are unequaled, and that's not forgetting Rembrandt, van Gogh or anyone else. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays, 10:30 A.M. to 8:30 P.M. Admission: $12.50; $9.50, students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 "MATHEW BRADY'S PORTRAITS: IMAGES AS HISTORY, PHOTOGRAPHY AS ART," International Center of Photography Midtown, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43d Street, (212) 768-4682 (through Sept. 6). Brady's studio photographed most of the American men of achievement (and some of the women) of the mid-19th century. Brady was consciously trying to create a new kind of history to be read through the faces of the people who made the nation what it was. His enterprise also produced a major record of the Civil War. And then he went broke. This exhibition, the first in more than a century to show the full range of his work, is especially good at revealing how photography was disseminated through lithographed or engraved copies before the half-tone was invented. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $5.50; $4, students and the elderly (Vicki Goldberg).
 
 BRONX MUSEUM OF THE ARTS, 1040 Grand Concourse, at 165th Street, Morrisania, (718) 681-6000. This is one the city's more animated and resilient cultural spaces, and this summer its exhibitions and permanent collection can be sampled both in the Bronx and in Manhattan. "Histories (Re)membered: Selections from the Permanent Collection of the Bronx Museum of the Arts" is in the lobby gallery of the PaineWebber building, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, at 51st Street, (212) 713-2885 (through Sept. 11). Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. Free. And four shows of contemporary art fill every inch of the museum. Two solo mid-career surveys, "Tomie Arai: Double Happiness" and "Rimer Cardillo: Araucaria," are on view through Sunday. An installation by Juan Sanchez, "1898: Rican/Struction, Multi-Layered Impressions" and the annual "Artists in the Marketplace Exhibition" are up through Sept. 27. The museum is a shaping player in New York art of the present and the future; it always repays a visit. Hours: Wednesdays, 3 P.M. to 9 P.M.; Thursdays and Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 P.M. to 6 P.M. Donation: $3; $2 for students over 12; $1 for the elderly (Holland Cotter).
 
 "ROBERT COLESCOTT: RECENT PAINTINGS," Queens Museum of Art, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 592-9700 (through Oct. 4). Nineteen paintings by Mr. Colescott that represented the United States at the Venice Biennale last year. His raucous pictures swarm with cartoon characters who act out wildly scrambled blackface burlesques of race, sex, violence and death. Nothing if not contradictory, his paintings are also beautiful, smart and poetic. Though raw, they have a lush, painterly sensuality, and though bumptious, they speak to complex philosophical matters through metaphorically loaded images. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. Admission: $4; students and the elderly, $2 (Ken Johnson).
 
 * "DEEP STORAGE: COLLECTING, STORING AND ARCHIVING IN ART P.S. 1," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Aug. 30). This ambitious show documents the urge to document in recent art, a tendency broadened in the 1970's by Performance and Conceptual Art. With Duchamp's "Green Box," which documents his masterpiece "The Large Glass," among its jumping-off points, the show ranges through five decades of mostly American and German art that amasses and orders large quantities of things: be they objects, materials, images or bits of information. Joseph Cornell, On Kawara, Hanne Darboven and Bernd and Hilla Becher fill in the older generations. Representing the younger are Louise Lawler's deadpan photographs of museum storage rooms, an enormous installation piece (in a box) by Jason Rhoades and the portrait-lined pantheons of the painter David Deutsch. Of particular interest from Germany is Karsten Bott's "One of Each," a manically methodical accumulation of everyday objects, and "Detonation Deutschland," a video installation by Piero Steinle and Julian Rosenfeldt that orchestrates images and sounds of old German buildings being blown up, to mesmerizing, ineffably sad effect. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Smith).
 
 "MARTIN LEWIS'S WORLD: CITYSCAPES ON PAPER," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Oct. 25). Few printmakers of the 1920's and 30's caught the spirit of New York in that era with quite the pizazz of Lewis (1881-1962), an Australian who came to the city at 19 and made it his own. Buildings, views, neighborhoods, street gangs, storefronts, rooftops, shoppers, workers, idlers, relationships, even the weather seemed especially staged for Lewis, who got it all down in black and white, capturing people and architecture in the etching and drypoint technique of which he was a master. At his best, he was a wonderful chronicler and illustrator whose vision of the city rings true. The show is accompanied by the period photographs of other intense urbanites like Berenice Abbott, Lewis Hine, Arthur Leipzig, Walter Rosenblum and Adolf Fassbender. You could cut the nostalgia here with a knife, but it's a pleasant wallow. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays, 11 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $10; $6 for children under 12 (Glueck).
 
 * WILLIAM SIDNEY MOUNT, "Painter of American Life," New-York Historical Society, 2 West 77th Street, (212) 873-3400, through Oct. 25. American 19th-century art is rarely as simple as it looks, and such is the case with the work of Mount (1807-1868). Mount more or less invented American genre painting, with its emblematic scenes of everyday life, and this carefully honed show of his smallish paintings captures the spirit of an enigmatic man and his complex time. His scenes of barn dances and cider making are, at their best, magisterial in structure and rich in observed detail. But many of them are also highly coded and opinionated political commentaries touching on the inflammatory issues of race, political morality and the double-edged power of popular culture. Mount's own take on his subjects is often ambiguous; and his willingness to let his art be inscrutable is provocative. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission: $5; $3, students and the elderly (Cotter)
 
 * FABRIZIO PLESSI, Guggenheim Museum SoHo, 575 Broadway at Prince Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Sept. 13). Well known in Europe for his large-scale video installations, Mr. Plessi weighs in for the first time in New York with four room-size works. The common theme is the clever theatrical play of video imagery with down-to-earth substances and situations: water, stone, metal, architectural elements and the like. In short, he mixes the virtual with the real, as in the show's most impressive piece, "Baroque Cathodic Movements" (1996), in which three ominious-looking wooden structures, painted black and echoing 17th-century architectural motifs, gyrate slowly from the ceiling. Each resembles a sort of furnace whose maw contains amazingly real-looking video flames that appear to be consuming the ancient architecture with a fierce roar. Ultra-theatrical, a ballet in themselves, they suggest coffins for the past while conveying a shivery sense of hellfire and brimstone. Hours: Sundays, and Wednesdays through Fridays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Saturdays, 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. Admission: $8; $5, students and the elderly (Glueck).
 
 CHARLES RAY, Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through Aug. 30). The sculptures by this Los Angeles artist in his mid career survey include a mannequin with real-looking genitals; a pseudo-Minimalist black cube filled with ink, but not so that you could tell it isn't solid -- a trick of the eye -- and, exceptionally, a painstaking, strangely melancholic reconstruction in all-gray Fiberglas of a wrecked Pontiac. There's also a 12-minute 16-millimeter film, a la 60's home movies, during which a mannish woman models 100 spectacularly awful outfits by Mr. Ray. The effect is a kind of slacker Surrealism, with nods to Kinetic Art, Body Art, Pop and so on. Mr. Ray's truest virtue is combining his strange wit with a certain hangdog humanity. His photographs of himself, for instance, look calculatedly, touchingly ridiculous. He's the nerd with the pocket protector, Harold Lloyd dangling from the clock, one of the guys in "The Full Monty." We sympathize. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).
 
 LIISA ROBERTS, "Blind Side," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 74th Street, (212) 945-3600 (through Oct. 4). Borrowing a little too much from "Wavelength," the 1967 avant-garde film classic by Michael Snow, this young American artist has created a well-thought-out film installation involving twin life-size images of a formal sitting room through whose windows day changes to night and back again in about six minutes. The viewer's reflection and shadow provide the figurative element as the room disappears and reappears, and the windows, looking out on a bustling city, suddenly resemble little film screens. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).
 
 * "TONY SMITH: ARCHITECT, PAINTER, SCULPTOR," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9480 (through Sept. 22). Tony Smith's works work, when they do, by causing you to look carefully, as Smith did, at the way geometric forms can be combined into abstract shapes that seem to shift as you move around them. Change, the idea that the same forms can keep mutating in provocative ways, is Smith's constant. A virtue of the Modern's intelligent, not-too-large retrospective is that it brings together the three aspects of his career -- architecture, painting and sculpture -- so that we can see, for example, how Smith's approach to form had as much to do with Frank Lloyd Wright, Le Corbusier and Mies van der Rohe as with Barnett Newman and Clyfford Still, and more to do with Newman and Still than with Donald Judd. When it's not good, Smith's work suggests a certain anonymous and chilly indifference because he brought an architect's mentality to everything; he planned what he often let others complete. At the same time, he spent a lifetime trying to endow geometry with feeling, to distill emotion from indifferent forms; and there was a sense of wonderment in the way he kept discovering new shapes in these forms. Hours: See above. Admission: $9.50; $6.50, students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 * "LOUIS COMFORT TIFFANY AT THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 31). This austere exhibition, drawn almost entirely from the Met's collection, outlines Tiffany's varied production in the exquisite detail for which he is justifiably known. The opulent sensuousness comes across in small doses, sometimes kitschy, sometimes innovative. Included are examples of furniture, jewelry, ceramics, enameled objects, paintings and design studies, stained-glass windows and lamps, and the Favrile glass vases that are his most lasting achievement. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).
 
 * "THE UNICORN TAPESTRIES," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 6). The Unicorn Tapestries are among the most famous works housed at the Cloisters, the Metropolitan's upper Manhattan branch devoted to medieval art. But this year they're spending the summer downtown at the museum's main headquarters on Fifth Avenue. Who commissioned them, where they were made and what their images are all about are still matters for speculation. But they've had a fascinating history -- including a stint protecting potatoes against frost after the French Revolution -- and they are absolutely exquisite. Dense with flowers, animals and courtly hunters, with the unicorn himself at the center, playing the part of a captivated lover or perhaps the suffering Christ, they have a tumultuous vivacity and suggest the flavor of a medieval world in which every detail of life was exactingly recorded and everything was more than it seemed. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).
 
 "URBAN ENCOUNTERS," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 20). This jam-packed exhibition documents the histories of six activist art collectives that have held their own in Manhattan over the last decade and more: ABC No Rio, Bullet Space, Godzilla, Guerrilla Girls, Repohistory and World War III Illustrated. The curator, Gregory Sholette, asked each group to design its own installation, and the results are full of visual incident and detailed historical information. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 P.M.; Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays, noon to 8 P.M. Admission: $5; $3, students over 18, artists and the elderly (Cotter).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
 "PORTRAITS OBSCURED," Gagosian Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 76th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through Sept. 12). This oppressively museumlike show presents one work each by seven famous male heavyweights, living and dead. The title is loosely relevant: there's a camouflaged self-portrait by Andy Warhol and a big collage of expressionistic ancestral portraits by Anselm Kiefer. A gloomy, gray, abstracted woman by Picasso could portray a lover. But works by Jean-Michel Basquiat (a nice one), David Smith, Willem de Kooning and Francesco Clemente don't look like portraits at all (Johnson).
 
 "SHIP/SHAPE," Keith de Lellis, 47 East 68th Street, (212) 327-1482 (through Aug. 28). The shapes of ships, from ocean liners to rowboats, from purely architectural studies to romantic visions, is the substance of this show. It includes some 70 prints by more than 30 photographers, from 1914 to the mid-60's. Celebrated talents like Edward Steichen, Weegee and Margaret Bourke-White share wall space with lesser-known photographers like the future Edward VIII when he was the Prince of Wales. Among the more striking images are Herbert Matter's 1938 close-up of a pair of worn, weathered sails in full rig, James Doolittle's 1930 study of a sturdy anchor chain dropped from the skyscraper prow of a huge ocean liner, and Gordon Coster's "Untitled (Sky)" (1929), a view of a big, cloudy sky with the cabin and masts of a ship just visible on the horizon line. The show is a beguiling way to spend an hour at sea (Glueck).
 
 * STEVE WHEELER, Richard York Gallery, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through Aug. 28). Steve Wheeler was of the Abstract Expressionist generation but went his own way in small, intricate linear compositions. Here, 15 gouaches and their silk-screen counterparts, made in 1947 to illustrate the artist's own, self-promotional monograph "Hello Steve," offer implosive little worlds in which no centimeter is left unactivated. "Marine Garden," with its jazzy, calligraphic forms in white on blue-gray paper has the snappy elegance of a Cole Porter song (Johnson).
Galleries: 57th Street
 
 SHIRLEY GOLDFARB, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 752-1223 (through Sept. 4). Ms. Goldfarb's paintings from the 1960's and 70's look good enough to make you wonder why you've never heard of her. She was born in Altoona, Pa., in 1925, and lived in Paris from 1954 until her death in 1980. During the 60's she began using a palette knife to create all-over fields of little squares. Some are monochromatic, some multicolored; "Chartres" has the bejeweled luminosity of stained glass (Johnson).
 
 YASUHIKO TSUCHIDA, Yoshii Gallery, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 265-8876 (through Aug. 31). A dozen lovely cups by a young Japanese-born glassmaker who lives and works in Italy. Each handleless cup has a slightly wobbly, irregular form and appears to have been made by fusing separate facets, resulting in loose grid or checkerboard patterns. They're not great art, but the jewel-like colors and the humble, slightly comical forms are irresistible (Johnson).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
 "ANONYMOUS," the Work Space, 96 Spring Street, (212) 219-2790, (through Sept. 12). More photography about photography and truth. This show focuses on the human figure, which appears anonymous because, in most cases, it's so blurry. Tanya Marcuse's small, fragmentary shots of bridal lingerie and skin are sexy; Jon Naiman's large picture of a corpulent fellow with feet and head cut off by a paper floor and ceiling is funny. But too much of the show is caught up in uninteresting technical manipulations (Johnson).
 
 PAUL DICKERSON, American Fine Arts, 22 Wooster Street, (212) 941-0401 (through Sept. 3). Most of the improvisational, trash-laden assemblages in this exhibition were made in the three years before Paul Dickerson (1961-1997), a New York sculptor, committed suicide, and have never been exhibited. Thus this is simultaneously a show of new work and last work, of promise and finality. The pieces exude a fierce, not always pleasant energy, suggesting a studio that looked more like a junkyard, and an artist who challenged himself to make a sculpture from the first 3 or 5 or 10 things that caught his eye. His drawings are peppered with pertinent remarks, as in the Frank Stella-esque aphorism: "Whatever you want to call it is whatever you want to call it" (Smith).
 
 "HEADSTAND," Elga Wimmer Gallery, 560 Broadway at Prince Street, (212) 274-0274 (through Aug. 31). Obliquely true to its title, this scruffy exhibition features five young artists whose work in sculpture, video and late Conceptual Art involves various inversions or displacements that twist reality one way or another. Subjects, objects or events include a demolition derby, traveling through the sewers of Los Angeles, grass-covered models of Manhattan, Marge Simpson's hair and substitute parents. The artists responsible are Tim Hutchings, Jennifer Cohen, Henry Steingieser, Jane Benson and Kristin Mojsiewicz. A good time is had by all (Smith).
 
 ANN LOVETT, Dorsky Gallery, 379 West Broadway, near Broome Street, (212) 966-6170 (through Aug. 28). In "Conundrum," a neatly composed installation combining photographs of antique medical books, pictures of her own naked body printed on loose, sheer fabric and a room-circulating line of text that reads, "Neglect me, absolve me, ignore me, want me, consume me" and so on, Ann Lovett evokes familiar connections between ideology and the body. The didactic tends to override the poetic (Johnson).
 
 "MAPS," Paul Kasmin Gallery, 74 Grand Street, (212) 219-3219 (through Aug. 28). Don't expect conventional cartography in this group of maps by six artists, each of whom has his own interpretation of the word. The broadest is James Turrell's grand-scale topographical drawing for his "Roden Crater" project, the reshaping of an extinct volcano rim north of Flagstaff, Ariz. The most "mappish" is Buckminster Fuller's "Dymaxion Air-Ocean World Map" of 1980, said to be the least distorted layout of the Earth's surface in cartographic history. Other views of the world, or particular pieces of it, are offered by Andy Warhol, Jasper Johns, Donald Baechler and the Italian team of Alighiero e Boetti, whose flat, colorfully embroidered rendition of the globe delineates each country in terms of its national flag. Move over, Rand McNally (Glueck).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
 RINALDO HOPF, "Golden Queers," Wessel & O'Connor, 242 West 26th Street, (212) 242-8811 (through Aug. 28). A celebratory installation of 69 Warhol-style portraits of famous gay (or supposedly gay) people by this German artist. Each photo-based canvas is silk-screened in black on white, and the figure's skin is gold-leafed. Subjects include Allen Ginsberg, Sophocles and Eugene Delacroix. The whole-wall grid has a nice decorative impact, but the pictures are too mechanical. Warhol himself would have done it with more stylish sensuality (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
 "SECTION 33," Dumbo Arts Center, 45 York Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 624-3772 (through Sept. 19). This exhibition inaugurates the Dumbo (Down Under the Manhattan Bridge Overpass) Arts Center. The mixed bag of works by 15 artists is less adventurous than you'd expect of such an upstart enterprise. Notable items include Richard Bottwin's compact, geometrically playful plywood constructions; white, ivory smooth surfaces bearing tiny incidents of organic abstraction by Sonita Singwi; and sensitively rendered industrial landscapes by Nicholas Evans-Cato (Johnson).
 
Last Chance
 
 "THE ACADEMY AND AMERICAN ART: HISTORY AND HIGHLIGHTS," National Academy Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Sunday). A good, economical selection of works from the museum's collection, including a pair of over-inflated allegories by the Hudson River School painter Asher B. Durand, a couple of dark seascapes by Albert Pinkham Ryder, two lovely still lifes, by William Merritt Chase (a sparkling silver ewer and a Chinese teapot) and John La Farge (a lush magnolia blossom in a purple glass), and a sharp, faux-folk portrait carved in wood by Anne Arnold. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 P.M.; Fridays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $5; $3.50, students and the elderly (Johnson).
 
 "MASTERS OF COLOR AND LIGHT: HOMER, SARGENT AND THE AMERICAN WATERCOLOR MOVEMENT," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Sunday). The 140 paintings are all from the museum's estimable watercolor collection, which hasn't been given an airing on this scale in more than a decade. The chronological span is broad and the selection eclectic, with a core group of about a dozen pieces each by Winslow Homer and John Singer Sargent. What's most engaging is the story the show tells of how an art form rose from humble origins to help define what "American" meant in American art. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).
 
 GORDON MATTA-CLARK, "Reorganizing Structure by Drawing Through It," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Sunday). An extensive exhibition of works on paper by the visionary architectural deconstructor, who died in 1978 at age 35. Felt-tip pen drawings of imaginary plants, clouds of little arrows, sketchy diagrams and geometric figures cut through stacks of paper all show graphic ingenuity. But nothing on paper conveys as effectively as several films in video form what a boldly original artist Matta-Clark was. Also on display are two reconstructions of vintage works: "Dumpster," a maze in a real Dumpster, and "Doors, Floors, Doors," a vertical shaft cut through four floors. Hours and admission: See above (Johnson).

PUB-DATE: August 21, 1998

SECTION: Section D; Page 2; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1070 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Thanks to Overseas Sales, Honda Reports Big Profit Gain

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 20

 BODY:
The Honda Motor Company is benefiting more than ever from its global reach, a distinction once ridiculed by domestically focused competitors in Japan's automotive industry.
Even with the domestic market shrinking rapidly, Japan's No. 3 auto maker, behind Toyota and Nissan, reported a 26 percent profit gain today for the latest quarter, largely because of sales in Europe and in Honda's largest market, the United States. 
 Those overseas sales once earned Honda criticism, much the same way that Sony's vast international sales once led industry titans here to dismiss it as "not really a Japanese company."
These days, with almost every Japanese business executive praising the benefits of globalization, Honda's pioneering spirit is admired.
Its new president, Hiroyuki Yoshino, says he believes the reach that Honda has already established will protect it from the forces of consolidation sweeping the global automobile business.
With Daimler buying Chrysler, Volkswagen buying Rolls-Royce and BMW clearly looking to expand, the Japanese auto makers seem like attractive potential partners with their dominance of Japan's huge car market and deep penetration in Asia.
But Mr. Yoshino says he is convinced that the Japanese auto makers can hold their own. "The way I look at Daimler and Chrysler is: Chrysler is really only in North America, Benz has only a small presence there," he said in an interview earlier this month. "They didn't have a global strategy."
Honda makes more than 100 products in 40 countries. "Honda's global strategy has been established, and I think it is top rate," Mr. Yoshino said. "We build our cars in North America, Asia and Europe -- we're already there."
Mr. Yoshino also has a novel way of looking at Honda's spot in the global hierarchy of car manufacturers. Annually, Honda sells about 5 million motorcycles and 3 million pieces of power equipment, he points out, in addition to 2.3 million cars.
"Even G.M. sells only nine million units a year, and Toyota sells only five million," he said, only half in jest. "If you look at it on a unit basis, we're outselling them."
That may sound arrogant. But Honda has needed a strong sense of itself just to survive.
Honda is not a member of a kei retsu, the powerful business agglomerations built around banks that have until recently provided endless amounts of credit regardless of borrower quality.
Honda has been more reliant on shareholders and the capital markets for financing, and it has done a good job of making them happy. "It's one of the most transparent companies in Japan," said Noriaki Hirakata, an automotive analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Tokyo.
An example of the company's honest appraisal of its performance came earlier this month when Honda reported a small increase in June domestic sales. Rather than portraying the increase as a sign of strength, Mr. Yoshino explained that it was largely because of a change in the way that Accord station wagons were counted. Domestically sold Accord wagons produced elsewhere -- and thus not counted in the 1997 numbers -- were now produced in Japan and counted in 1998.
"I don't want to give too much of an impression of success," he said.
Mr. Hirakata at Morgan Stanley and others have some concerns about Honda. One is whether the company may run out of production capacity. Another is whether it can continue to make money pursuing the "small is smart" strategy it is pursuing in the domestic market.
Honda, like other auto manufacturers, has had more luck selling mini-cars in the Japanese market, where rising unemployment, a shaky financial system and a virtually nonexistent social safety net are among the worries keeping consumers from showrooms.
In October, the company will start selling newly designed mini-cars, and Mr. Yoshino said he was confident they would help Honda's second-half performance. He said Honda must rely on smaller cars to sustain its performance in Japan, since an economic turnaround was unlikely any time soon.
Smaller cars, however, typically provide smaller profit margins. Mr. Yoshino said he was not worried.
"We've made profit on the mini-cars that we've been selling so far, and profits from the ones we start selling in October should be higher," he said.
As for capacity constraints, Mr. Yoshino said he could understand the worries. But he was uneasy about the United States market, where Honda will introduce a redesigned Acura later this year, and said he was reluctant to commit more capital to production lines at this time.
"With that concern in the back of my head, what we'll do is stick to our current production capacity," he said, adding that the company could compensate for some capacity limitations by purchasing employees' paid vacation time so they could keep working.
Mr. Yoshino also noted that Honda had a second North American line opening in Canada, where it would produce mini-vans.
On the home front, Honda's nemesis, the Toyota Motor Corporation, has also thrown down a challenge. Toyota, Japan's largest auto maker, is worried about the unpopularity of its cars among younger people and has vowed to woo that demographic group, which is Honda's main customer base.
Mr. Yoshino acknowledged that Toyota was a threat, but said he was not intimidated. "One reason we attract younger people is the motorcycle business and our reputation in it," he said. "We also are back in Formula One racing, which helps, too."
His predecessor, Nobuhiko Kawamoto, took Honda out of that business in 1992 when profits were hard to come by, but put it back in this spring, announcing plans to return to Formula One racing in 2000.
Mr. Yoshino conceded that Toyota's stodgy image had been helped by its hybrid "clean" car, Prius, which uses an electric battery and gasoline engine and is far lower in emissions than a regular car.
"I am gritting my teeth a bit," Mr. Yoshino said of the flood of good press Toyota has enjoyed from Prius. "But I'd say their technical expertise with that car is not so great."
Whatever his opinion about Toyota's technical expertise, he is not repeating Mr. Kawamoto's bold suggestion that Honda, which produces fewer than half the cars Toyota does, could overtake Toyota as Japan's No. 1 car maker.
"Bigger is not always better," he said. "If everything else stays the same, then bigger is better. But things rarely stay the same."
