HEADLINE: Fed Voted 10 to 1 in July to Keep Rates the Same

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Federal Reserve policy makers voted 10 to 1 at their meeting on July 1 to leave the overnight bank lending rate unchanged at 5.50 percent, minutes of the session released today showed.
Jerry Jordan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, dissented for the third time this year, citing growth in the money supply as a reason to raise the lending rate. "He believed that the unsustainably rapid growth of domestic demand -- fueled by the acceleration of money and credit growth in the past year -- was reflected in the recent sharp increase in imports," according to the minutes. 
 The Federal Open Market Committee also maintained a stance, or bias, at the meeting in favor of raising the interest rate target, if need be, to guard against an acceleration of inflation, the minutes showed. The committee shifted to a heightened state of alert at its meeting in March.
"Many of the members expressed concern that the expansion in demand might continue at a fast enough pace to raise pressures on wages and prices over time," the minutes showed. In addition, several members emphasized "that they continued to see a high probability that some tightening of monetary policy would be needed later to curb rising inflationary pressures."
William Poole, president of the Fed bank in St. Louis, who had dissented at the meeting on May 19, decided at the July meeting that an immediate interest rate increase was not needed. Mr. Jordan argued at the March 31 and May 19 meetings for higher interest rates.
The latest minutes show there was less division in July than in May. "It looks to be a little less hawkish," said John Ryding, senior economist at Bear, Stearns in New York. "It probably increases the chances they switched to a neutral directive" at this week's meeting, he said.
The committee voted on Tuesday to leave the overnight rate unchanged. Minutes of that meeting will be released in early October.
Fed members said that it was too early to determine what effects the turmoil in Asia would have on the United States economy. Still, "several suggested that the consequences were likely to be more severe and longer lasting than they had anticipated earlier," the minutes showed.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
VenezuelanStocks Tumble On Fears of a Devaluation

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Venezuelan stocks plunged 9.5 percent today, the biggest one-day drop in nearly four years, as the market here was rattled by worries that the Government might devalue its currency.
With investors concerned about possible currency devaluations in Latin America, the selloff was felt on markets from New York to Argentina. Mexico's chief market index fell 2.93 percent. In Brazil, the Sao Paulo stock exchange's Bovespa index fell 6.4 percent, to its lowest level in nine months. And in New York, Brady bonds and American depository receipts of Latin American companies fell sharply. 
 The Caracas Stock Exchange's general index fell 363.82 points, to 3,460.64, its lowest since April 1996. The drop was the largest since Nov. 21, 1994. Venezuelan bond prices also tumbled, with the yield on the latest 20-year global bond soaring to 23.37 percent, up from 13.98 percent on July 30, when Venezuela sold $500 million of the bonds.
"There's definitely nervousness in the market, and it's justified," said Francis Freisinger, an economist at Merrill Lynch & Company. "Russia's collapse has added psychological pressure."
The financial turmoil here has created long lines outside exchange houses as anxious Venezuelans line up to buy dollars and it appears to have bolstered the electoral chances of one presidential candidate, Hugo Chavez Frias, a leader of a failed coup in 1992 who has said he may stop repaying foreign debt if he wins the December election.
Reports here said the Government was planning to devalue the currency, the bolivar, by as much as 20 percent. But Planning Minister Teodoro Petkoff said at a hastily arranged news conference today that the Government had no plans to devalue the bolivar.
"The stronger the denials, the more the likelihood of a devaluation -- we saw that in Russia," said Vinod Sehgal, managing director of SG Cowen Securities in New York. "Markets are effectively closed to them."
A 33 percent plunge in oil prices this year narrowed petroleum-rich Venezuela's trade surplus and widened its budget deficit, putting pressure on the currency. The Government relies on taxes on oil exports for almost half its revenue and on Wednesday said that it might scrap a $1.4 billion bond sale because of surging interest rates, making it harder to plug the deficit.
Despite the turmoil on stock and bond markets, the bolivar steadied today. The currency ended at 574.50 bolivars to the dollar, compared with Wednesday's close of 573.25 bolivars.

HEADLINE: Mildred E.B. Smith, Specialist In Agriculture, Is Dead at 99

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Mildred Elizabeth Buller Smith, who cut a singular swath through the 20th century by, among other things, picking apples and digging potatoes for the Women's Land Army in World War I, riding herd on New England milk prices for the Office of Price Administration in World War II and becoming a Connecticut television celebrity as a consumer price specialist, died on Aug. 12 at a nursing home in Hartford. She was 99, and it seems almost beside the point to note that she had been an agricultural economist for the University of Connecticut.
To say that Miss Smith followed her own path would hardly do justice to someone who became a farm specialist after growing up on the streets of Chicago. 
 But Miss Smith, who spent several girlhood summers on a farm, was ever an original, one whose career included driving a hotel jitney in Florida, starting and running the country store for Henry and Clara Ford's Wayside Inn in Sudbury, Mass., and creating and starring in "Millie's Market Basket" on Connecticut television.
Never one to be hampered by convention, Miss Smith went to work for the agriculture department of the Connecticut Agricultural College before she received a bachelor's degree from the University of Chicago; became an assistant professor at the University of Connecticut (as the agricultural college became in 1938) before she received a master's degree from Radcliffe College, and never did bother to get a doctorate, although she did complete postgraduate studies at the London School of Economics.
For someone born in the Victorian era, Miss Smith adapted well to 20th-century culture, much to the occasional dismay of her mother, a staid woman who had derived her Victorian outlook in situ, growing up in England, and who was properly shocked when her daughter, who had not come of age in the Roaring Twenties for nothing, would go off for weekends with her young man of the moment.
(Miss Smith, whose romantic life became a subject of intense speculation among her grandnieces and grandnephews, apparently found a satisfying solution to the problem of juggling job and family: attracting a steady supply of smitten suitors without actually succumbing to matrimony. She derived enormous delight a few years ago when she received a proposal from an admirer at her Hartford retirement community on the very day the Social Security Administration notified her that she had died -- as, it turned out, another Mildred Smith had done.)
Miss Smith's sense of personal mission began early. With three of her four older brothers serving in the military in World War I, she was so eager to do her part that, ignoring her mother's objections, she dropped out of the University of Chicago to enlist in the Women's Land Army, a paramilitary organization that sought to fill the vacuum left by mobilized farm workers.
Typically, Miss Smith, who had a lifelong fascination with statistics, not only picked apples and dug potatoes on a farm in East Corinth, Vt., but counted them, computing yields and other data for reports that she later deposited with the Schlesinger Library at Radcliffe.
After the fall harvest one year, the farmer whose land she had worked tried to find her a winter job at a resort that his friend Henry Ford owned in Eustis, Fla., but wondered whether Miss Smith knew how to drive, a requirement for the job of shuttling guests to and from the train station.
In a reply that later delighted her grandnieces and grandnephews, Miss Smith reassured him: "I've been driving tractors since I was 12."
Indeed, Miss Smith did so well as a jitney driver that she apparently impressed Ford and his wife, Clara. In 1923, when they bought the inn made famous by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, they recruited Miss Smith to start and run the country store that became a part of the historic restoration and preservation project.
By 1931, Miss Smith had found her life's work in academia, but after a decade as a statistician and consumer price specialist at the University of Connecticut, she decided that it was time to complete her own college education.
So, again flouting convention, she returned to Chicago and received her degree at age 42.
Later, after becoming an assistant professor in 1943 and spending three years with the O.P.A.'s Boston office, she received a master's degree from Radcliffe.
She remained an assistant professor, but her work as a teacher and consumer marketing specialist -- among other things turning out pamphlets and conducting radio and television programs stressing thrift -- was so impressive that when she retired in 1961, she was named professor emeritus.
In retirement Miss Smith wrote historical pamphlets on New England agriculture and taught herself bookbinding, selling leather-bound notebooks and other items at craft fairs to finance her yen for travel, which included 18 trips to England and the Continent, where as a young woman, it should come as no surprise, she had climbed the Matterhorn.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Foreign Turmoil Drives Investors From Dow to Treasuries

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Turmoil in overseas economies sent investors fleeing stocks for the safety of bonds yesterday, pushing the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond to another new low.
Rumors that Russian bank failures were imminent and that Venezuela might be forced to devalue its currency, the bolivar, to combat a growing budget deficit, and persistent concerns about a similar move by China, buoyed the Treasury market. All of these things added to investor conerns that the financial crises among emerging markets might be spreading. 
 In addition, an announcement by President Clinton that the United States had bombed suspected terrorist camps in Afghanistan and the Sudan in retaliation for the bombings at United States embassies in East Africa earlier this month contributed to a strong rally in Treasuries in the afternoon.
"We've got a lot of disturbing things going on around the world," said Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities Company International. "In that type of environment, the Treasury market is the best place to be."
The migration to the Treasury market hurt stock prices, which fell for a second day after a rally earlier in the week. Analysts cautioned that further declines were possible.
Meanwhile, the dollar fell for the fourth consecutive day against the yen, reflecting fears that the Japanese Government would sell dollars to defend the yen's value.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 81.87 points, to 8,611.41. Financial services companies like American Express and J. P. Morgan led the declines. The drop in those shares reflected investor concerns that Venezuela's plight might hurt other Latin American economies and jeopardize bank holdings of emerging-market debt as well as repayment of loans made to those countries.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index fell 6.46 points, to 1,091.60. The Nasdaq, led by declines in the chip-related stocks Intel and Applied Materials, lost 10.24 points, to 1,832.45.
The 30-year Treasury bond's price rose 21/32 to 99 28/32, which means bond investors gained about $6.56 for each $1,000 of bonds they held.
The yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, fell to 5.51 percent, from 5.55 percent. The yield is now at its lowest level since the Treasury Department began issuing the bonds on a regular basis in 1977.
The strength in the bond market may last a while. Analysts said one sign of its stamina is that long-term bond yields have been below 5.60 percent for six consecutive days.
In addition, many analysts say that bond yields can fall further, causing the Treasury yield curve to flatten even more as the spread between long-term yields and those on shorter-term Treasury securities narrows. A flattening yield curve can be an indication that interest rates will fall.
"I actually expect that to happen," said Kathleen Camilli, director of economic research at Tucker Anthony, a regional brokerage firm.
Ms. Camilli said the long bond's yield could fall to 5 percent this year. At that level, the yield would fall below the current Federal Funds target rate, a benchmark for short-term interest rates, now at 5.5 percent.
Such a move might prompt the Federal Reserve to lower short-term interest rates, she forecast.
At present, yields on shorter-term Treasury securities, like the 10-year and 2-year notes, are already below 5.5 percent. That indicates, Ms. Camilli and several other economists said, that investors believe that the next move by the Fed will be to lower interest rates.
If Treasury yields fall further, it might send investors rushing back to stocks, said Anthony Conroy, a managing director at Bankers Trust Global Investment Management. At lower yield levels, investors might decide that they can get a higher return by investing in stocks, he said.

HEADLINE: U.S. FURY ON 2 CONTINENTS: THE BACKGROUND;
Long Enmity Between U.S. And Sudan Boils Over

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 20

 BODY:
The air strike against a factory in the Sudan today marked the first act of open warfare in the long-simmering hostilities between the United States and the Islamic Government in Khartoum.
Washington has been at odds with the governing National Islamic Front in the Sudan almost from the moment it seized power in a 1989 coup and set up a conservative Islamic theocracy. 
 Over the last nine years, the United States has repeatedly accused the Khartoum Government not only of supporting Islamic revolutionaries in neighboring countries but also of harboring various anti-American and anti-Israeli Arab terrorists, among them leaders of the Palestinian group, Hamas, the Cairo-based Islamic Holy War and the Egyptian Muslim Brotherhood.
One of the most important of these figures is Osama bin Laden, the Saudi businessman whom American investigators accuse of organizing the bombings of United States Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania two weeks ago.
Mr. bin Laden lived for several years in the Sudan and still owns several major businesses there.
In a speech justifying the air strikes today, President Clinton said the factory American missiles destroyed about 12 miles north of the Sudanese capital was "associated with the Bin Laden network." He said the plant was manufacturing chemicals used in nerve gas, while the Sudanese said it made drugs.
Today, angry Sudanese demonstrated outside the burning factory, while hundreds more stormed the American Embassy, throwing stones and chanting anti-American slogans, according to the Associated Press.
The United States removed its diplomats two years ago, but the compound was sometimes used when diplomats came in for meetings. It was closed after the embassies in Kenya and Tanzania were bombed.
Khartoum has long charged that Washington supports a protracted rebellion in the mostly Christian and animist southern part of the country. The revolt has cost more than 1 million lives in the last decade.
The southern rebels have been struggling against Khartoum for 15 years, but their movement has been crippled by factional divisions. They maintain they are fighting for more autonomy for the south, a secular government and religious freedom.
The Clinton Administration denies it supports the rebels directly, but it acknowledges giving military aid, not including weapons, to the neighboring countries of Uganda, Eritrea and Ethiopia, which have in turn funneled arms, radios and other equipment to the rebels.
American officials have also made it plain that the United States supports the rebellion's goals. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright even met with the main rebel leader, John Garang, last December during a visit to Uganda.
For their part, the leaders of the Sudanese Government, however, blame the United States for the continuing war, which has sapped the economy and demoralized northerners. Many in Khartoum see the rebellion as part of an American strategy to undermine the Sudan and eventually oust its Government.
The war serves other American goals in the Middle East. It weakens Khartoum's ability to support Islamic militants opposed to Egypt's Government.
Over the last year, members of the Sudan's political elite have taken pains to present a less threatening image internationally.
A new Constitution adopted this year guarantees the freedom of religion and association, opening the door to a return to party politics, they say.
Since 1996, they maintain they have tightened immigration rules to keep out terrorists and expelled many known Islamic militants. They also point out they have reached peace agreements with all the major rebel leaders except Mr. Garang and are in negotiations with him.
But American diplomats have dismissed many of these measures as cosmetic. American intelligence officials say the Sudan continues to provide a haven to terrorist organizations and that the National Islamic Front's leaders still have an iron grip on power.
As rescue workers struggled tonight to ferry wounded workers to hospitals and to put out the fire at Al Shifa pharmaceutical factory, Sudanese officials portrayed themselves as the victims of naked aggression.
Ghazi Salaheddin, the Information Minister, said the plant had been opened two years ago and produced nothing but medicines.
"This is a crime," he said. "There is no justification for this attack."
But Mr. Salaheddin said the attack was predictable, given the recent history of the two countries. In a sense, he suggested, the simmering conflict between the United States and the Khartoum government had finally come out into the open.
"We would like to remind people that this is a very old battle between right and wrong," he said.

HEADLINE: New Jersey May Cancel Staten Island Rail Link

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
A half-finished freight rail link between Staten Island and New Jersey was dealt a setback yesterday when an official in Union County, N.J., moved to pull out of the joint project, saying that changes in the plan meant that New York City now stood to reap nearly all the benefits.
The move outraged the Giuliani administration, which with the help of Federal money has rebuilt tracks and a bridge across the Arthur Kill that would give New York City freight direct access to the world west of the Hudson for the first time in nearly a decade. The New Jersey section of the project, a five-mile link to Conrail's main north-south tracks, is still being designed. One New York official said the project was now a "bridge to nowhere." 
 The Union County Manager, Michael J. Lapolla, recommended yesterday that the county's Board of Freeholders withdraw from the project at the next board meeting. He said that the project originally called for the operator to provide local freight rail service for businesses in New Jersey towns. Now, he said, Norfolk Southern/CSX, the freight giant recently appointed to operate the rail link, planned to use the New Jersey part of the track solely as a means to take freight from Howland Hook Marine Terminal on Staten Island to Conrail's Lehigh Valley line, on larger trains than were originally contemplated.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which is coordinating the project, and environmental groups that have supported it criticized Mr. Lapolla, saying he was overlooking an important benefit of the project: It would get thousands of trucks off Union County's congested roads.
"Based on the tremendous regional benefits for both New York and New Jersey, it would be shortsighted if this project did not move forward," said Christopher O. Ward, the Port Authority's chief of planning and external affairs.
Although the State of New Jersey owns the track on the New Jersey side and could complete the link without Union County's approval, state transportation officials said they would not interfere.
New York City, New Jersey, the Federal Government and the Port Authority have provided $30 million for the link.
Charles Millard, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, the agency in charge of New York's part of the project, said he hoped the Board of Freeholders would defy Mr. Lapolla at its meeting on Aug. 27. But the nine freeholders tend to go along with the county government, and Mr. Lapolla said he consulted them before making his recommendation.
The disputed project began in 1994. On the Staten Island side, New York City has bought and rebuilt 15 miles of track on the north shore of Staten Island and refurbished the 39-year-old Arthur Kill Lift Bridge, which has a 500-foot-long span that can be raised 100 feet to let ships pass through. The bridge has not been used since 1991.
Rail access, Mr. Ward said, is crucial to the future of the Howland Hook Terminal, near the base of the bridge, which was reopened in 1996. Howland Hook handles about 65,000 freight containers a year, less than 5 percent of the total volume of the Port of New York and New Jersey.
The New Jersey section of the project runs west though Elizabeth, Linden, Roselle and Cranford before linking up with the Conrail's Lehigh Valley line, one of the main freight lines in the Northeast.
As originally conceived, Mr. Lapolla said -- and state and Port Authority officials agree -- the operator of the line would have been a small freight carrier that would offer freight service to industries along the line and along another stretch of track west of the Lehigh Valley line. This, Mr. Lapolla said, would have allowed the county to market and redevelop several vacant industrial parcels and "brownfields."
"The whole point of us being involved in this was to redevelop abandoned, underutilized properties," he said.
But after Norfolk Southern and CSX reached an agreement to take over Conrail's operations earlier this year, the conglomerate, which is the largest freight carrier east of the Mississippi, expressed an interest in operating the line itself.
In May, the agencies involved in the project -- including Union County -- appointed Norfolk Southern/ CSX to run the line. But at a meeting last month, Mr. Lapolla said, Norfolk Southern/CSX officials told him they did not intend to offer local service immediately and instead planned to upgrade the track to run bigger, heavier trains from Howland Hook on Staten Island. Norfolk Southern/ CSX officials would not comment yesterday.
Mr. Lapolla criticized the Port Authority, saying it failed to insure that the county got the rail access it was offered. He called the situation "another example of the county getting the short end of the stick" from the authority, which owns more than 2,000 acres there, mostly at Port Elizabeth and Newark International Airport. For years, Union County and Elizabeth have been trying to get the Port Authority to increase the $1.7 million a year it pays in lieu of property taxes.
There are other possibilities for moving freight off Staten Island by rail. The Port Authority has proposed a connection from the New Jersey side of the Arthur Kill Bridge to existing freight tracks on the Chemical Coast line, which refineries on Union County's waterfront. But the Mayor of Elizabeth, J. Christian Bollwage, opposes that link, saying he fears it may be used to transport New York City's garbage after the Fresh Kills landfill closes, a concern also cited by Mr. Lapolla in his letter to the freeholders.

GRAPHIC: Photo: New York City, with help from the Federal Government, has rebuilt 15 miles of track and the Arthur Kill Lift Bridge, which was to connect with a rail line in Elizabeth, N.J., at left. But the New Jersey section of the project, a five-mile link to Conrail's main north-south tracks, may never be built. (Richard L. Harbus for The New York Times)
 
Map shows the planned route of the Staten Island-New Jersey rail link.

HEADLINE: Ferraro Turns Testy With TV Interviewer Over Repeated Requests to Debate

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
A routine television interview with Geraldine A. Ferraro turned into an on- and off-air scrap yesterday as her host repeatedly pressed Ms. Ferraro about why she was declining invitations to debate in the Senate Democratic primary race.
Ms. Ferraro, flustered and angry, attacked her questioner, Marcia Kramer of WCBS-TV, as unprofessional and sarcastically suggested that she was on the payroll of one of Ms. Ferraro's rivals. 
 With a control room full of technicians, producers and reporters watching, Ms. Ferraro turned increasingly tense as Ms. Kramer pressed the candidate on why she had declined several invitations to debate her two major Democratic rivals, Mark Green and Charles E. Schumer. The candidates have appeared in two public forums and are not scheduled to do so again until the Sunday before the Sept. 15 primary.
"We've debated the other two people," Ms. Ferraro said as the taping of "Sunday Edition" began with Ms. Kramer explaining to viewers that Ms. Ferraro had declined to appear unless it was apart from Mr. Green and Mr. Schumer.
The two women continued to talk over one another, with Ms. Kramer challenging Ms. Ferraro to agree to a debate right on the spot. The candidate finally turned to her host and said, "Do you think you're doing a disservice to your viewers by focusing on the politics of debates, rather than where I stand on issues?"
When the segment ended for an advertisement, Ms. Ferraro turned up the tenor of her complaints to Ms. Kramer. "What attack issue are you taking next?" she inquired archly, her off-air remarks blaring over the speakers in the control room. "I was curious which campaign you are working for."
As Ms. Kramer defended her question as legitimate, Ms. Ferraro shook her head in disagreement. "Unprofessional," she said. "Unprofessional. Let's move on."
After the appearance, Ms. Ferraro's aides said she had been ambushed because she had been brought in on the pretense that it would be a regular interview. Ms. Ferraro said that Ms. Kramer had done the "Green spin on this," adding, "Marcia's annoyed because we didn't agree to do a debate with them."
Ms. Ferraro considers herself the front-runner in the race and, as such, she is following a standard course in trying to minimize debates. The candidates have appeared together twice, and neither debate was televised.
Ms. Ferraro has said that debates are time-consuming for her campaign and more likely to produce damaging attacks among the candidates than insights on what they stand for. Ms. Ferraro was largely ignored by the other candidates in their last debate.
Yesterday's encounter was unusual in that Ms. Ferraro, who has tried to avoid making the kind of attacks on Mr. Green and Mr. Schumer that might bring attention to their campaigns, exhibited no such restraint when it came to WCBS-TV.
"Fortunately, said Ms. Ferraro's spokesman, Stephen Gaskill, "the voters see through tabloid journalism and are drawn to candidates who talk about the issues that appeal to them: education, health care, the economy and the environment."

HEADLINE: Youth March Organizers Sue the City

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
The organizers of a planned Million Youth March sued the city in Federal court yesterday, saying that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's refusal to grant them a permit to hold the event in Harlem next month was both unconstitutional and reflective of the Mayor's discriminatory treatment of the city's black residents.
The court action came as Harlem's most prominent black minister, the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, threw his support behind the march, saying it was a perfect opportunity for young blacks to call attention to issues that affect them, like unemployment and the high cost of health care. Other civic leaders in Harlem have also stepped up their support for the march in recent days, saying the Mayor's resistance is an affront to their community. 
 City officials have said they denied the permit because the neighborhood cannot safely accommodate the one million participants the organizers had said they expected.
But the organizers, appearing before Judge Lewis A. Kaplan in Federal District Court, said the city had refused to grant a permit to hold the rally along Malcolm X Boulevard on Sept. 5 only because of Mr. Giuliani's "dislike for one of the conveners of the rally," Khalid Abdul Muhammad.
They said it made no sense for the city to reject their permit application, since the city regularly grants permits for even larger rallies and parades. "The only issue is whether or not the Constitution applies to the people of Harlem," said Roger Wareham, a lawyer for the march organizers. "The city's policy is totally arbitrary about who they grant permits to and when."
Mr. Muhammad and other organizers have billed the event as a show of unity among young blacks from across the country, much like the Million Man March that was held in Washington in 1995.
But Mr. Giuliani has denounced it as a "hate march," citing anti-Semitic and anti-white remarks by Mr. Muhammad, a former top official in the Nation of Islam. The Mayor has repeatedly condemned Mr. Muhammad and criticized the organizers' plan to invite gang members to the rally.
In court yesterday, lawyers for the city questioned why the march organizers had waited so long -- their permit application was rejected in February -- to take their case before a judge. They said Mr. Giuliani's opinion of Mr. Muhammad had nothing to do with the denial of the permit.
"The Mayor did not decide whether the permit should be granted or denied," said Michael D. Hess, the city's Corporation Counsel. "This did not turn on the words of Mayor Giuliani one way or the other."
For his part, Mr. Giuliani continued to denounce the march organizers yesterday. "There's no question that this is a march that is about hatred," he said at a news conference. "It's about a group that has talked about hatred all throughout the country."
Judge Kaplan said the organizers' late filing date might be a factor in his eventual ruling, but it was not sufficient reason to dismiss the case. He scheduled a hearing for Wednesday, ordering the city to reveal how many permits it had granted for parades and rallies since 1993 and how many participants had been expected at each.
Judge Kaplan also agreed to read an amicus brief filed by the New York Civil Liberties Union on behalf of the march organizers. Norman Siegel, the group's executive director, said that "we as an organization have no other option than to protect the First Amendment."
The city has offered Randalls Island and Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx as alternative locations for the march. It has also recommended Sept. 19 as a more suitable date to avoid conflicts with parades and other community events already scheduled for the Labor Day weekend.
But Mr. Wareham said yesterday that the march had to take place over Labor Day weekend because high school and college students might not be able to attend once the school year began. He said it would be inappropriate to hold the march anywhere but Harlem, which he called "a mecca of black life."
Although the organizers said earlier this year that they expected as many as one million people to attend the march, they told Judge Kaplan that only about 170,000 would attend. Many people from other parts of the country have backed out because of the controversy with the city, they said. Malik Zulu Shabazz, the national coordinator for the march, said only about 25 percent of the participants would come from outside New York City.
Mr. Butts, the pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem and a frequent critic of Mr. Giuliani, said he thought the march should take place even if the court does not grant a permit. He emphasized that he was not supporting Mr. Muhammad, but the young people who were helping to organize the march.
"Nothing these young people are talking about includes violence or hatred toward any people," said Mr. Butts, who earlier this year called Mr. Giuliani a racist. "In that spirit, I'm for the march."
State Senator David A. Paterson, a Harlem Democrat who has held several meetings with the march organizers, said yesterday that support for the march was growing in Harlem. Mr. Paterson and several other elected officials from Harlem have expressed disgust toward Mr. Muhammad and warned that the march should not take place without a permit, but Mr. Paterson said that most people in Harlem disagree.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Malik Zulu Shabazz, a coordinator of the Million Youth March, speaking at the Federal courthouse in Manhattan yesterday with Roger Wareham, left, a lawyer, and Talib Abdul Muhammad, an organizer. (James Estrin/The New York Times)

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
U.S. Launches Missiles In Afghanistan and Sudan
Dozens of American cruise missiles struck targets in Afghanistan and Sudan, in what President Clinton described as an act of self-defense against imminent terrorist plots and of retribution for the bombings of American embassies in Africa. A1 

The strikes came after United States intelligence and law enforcement agencies had gathered what officials described as the strongest evidence ever obtained in a major terrorist case, evidence that President Clinton said showed that Osama bin Laden was behind the bombings. A1
 
Most of President Clinton's political opponents supported the action, but some lawmakers questioned its timing. A1
 
The United States issued a new worldwide warning to Americans and diplomatic personnel "to exercise much greater caution than usual" following the strikes. A13
 
Israel was quick to congratulate the United States for the attacks, but most other governments in the Middle East were notably silent. A12
 
American agents teamed up with the Albanian secret police for a series of raids and they appear to have thwarted a bomb plot against the American Embassy in Albania's capital. They also seem to have broken up a ring of Egyptian Islamic terrorists using the anarchy in Albania to set up a base. A13
 
Canada Rejects Vote To Secede
Canada's Supreme Court said a simple vote in Quebec was not enough to allow the French-speaking province to separate legally from the rest of the country. The landmark opinion is widely seen as fortifying the Federal Government's efforts to keep Canada from breaking up. A3

A rebel leader in Congo said he was willing to negotiate a cease-fire in the 18-day war that is increasingly becoming a political battleground for rival African nations. HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Treasury Bond Yields Fall As Investors Flee Stocks
Turmoil in overseas economies sent investors fleeing stocks for the safety of bonds, pushing the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond to 5.51 percent, another new low. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 81.87 points, to 8,611.41.
Rumors that Russian bank failures were imminent and that Venezuela might be forced to devalue its currency, the bolivar, to combat a growing budget deficit, and persistent concerns about a similar move by China, buoyed the Treasury market. All of these things added to investor concerns that the financial crises among emerging markets may be spreading. Page D5. 

Venezuelan stocks plunged 9.5 percent, the biggest one-day drop in nearly four years, as the market was rattled by worries that the Government might devalue its currency. Other Latin American markets also declined. Mexico's chief market index fell 2.93 percent. In Brazil, the Sao Paulo stock exchange's Bovespa index fell 6.4 percent. D2.
 
Barnes & Noble Unit to Go Public
Shares of Barnes & Noble rose 7.5 percent, or $2.8125, to $40.0625, after the bookseller said it planned to sell 20 percent of its on-line venture to the public. Barnes & Noble also announced that its loss for the second quarter tripled, primarily because of a $23 million loss by the on-line venture. D3.
 
Microsoft Trial Is Delayed 2 Weeks
A Federal judge has pushed back the starting date of the antitrust trial against Microsoft until Sept. 23. Lawyers for the company and Justice Department were also bickering over where and how pretrial questioning of William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, would take place. D3.
 
Fed Group Voted 10 to 1 on Rates
Federal Reserve policy makers voted 10 to 1 at their meeting on July 1 to leave the overnight bank lending rate unchanged at 5.50 percent. The lone dissenting vote was from Jerry Jordan, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland. D4.
 
Japanese Stocks Lower Early Today
Japanese stocks were down about 100 points at the midday recess after Okura & Company, a trading company that sells steel products and machinery, said it would seek protection from creditors. D2.
 
Foreign Sales Bolster Honda Profit
Honda Motor reported a 26 percent profit gain in the latest quarter, largely because of sales in Europe and the United States. Those overseas sales once earned Honda criticism, but now many Japanese business executives are praising the benefits of globalization. Hiroyuki Yoshino, the new president of the auto maker, predicted that the overseas expansion would protect Honda from the consolidation sweeping the automobile business. D2.
 
Novell Beats Earnings Estimates
Third-quarter profit at Novell beat analysts' expectations by one cent as the maker of networking software cut costs and improved sales by selling new Internet-based products. Net income was $26.6 million, or 7 cents a diluted share. The company had been expected to earn 6 cents a share. D4.
 
Autodesk Buying Discreet Logic
Autodesk, a maker of software for engineers and designers, plans to buy Discreet Logic, a maker of special effects for movies and television, for about $520 million in stock. D3.
 
I.R.S. Set to Permit Use of Plastic
The Internal Revenue Service will accept payments of Federal tax bills by credit card next year. A18.
 
Strained Relations in Advertising
The relationship between ad agencies and advertisers is deteriorating, according to the 1998 Salz Survey of Advertiser-Agency Relations. The surveys for 1996 and 1997 had brought surprisingly better responses from executives at agencies and client companies when asked about the nature of their relations. But that era of good feelings proved brief. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D4.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL BRIEFING;
Surprise Showdown Looms in Wyoming

BYLINE: By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
Wyoming is one of the nation's most Republican states, with the Grand Old Party enjoying a 2 to 1 registration edge over Democrats. So the odds are that the state's Republican Governor, Jim Geringer, will handily win a second term this fall.
Still, in the aftermath of Tuesday's primaries in the Cowboy State, the race now merits watching. 
 Mr. Geringer easily won renomination. But in doing so, some weaknesses were exposed, and as a result the Democratic nominee, state Senator John P. Vinich, who also easily won nomination, probably has a better shot at the Governor's job than he originally had reason to expect.
Ever since he took office three years ago, the Governor has struggled to get the Wyoming economy moving, but with little success. With its small population, limited job base and vast remoteness, the state is the rare economic exception in this era of boom, and throughout the primary season the Governor's critics were quick to put the blame on him.
His main challenger in the primary, Bill Taliaferro, a sheep rancher, hammered him relentlessly on the matter. But the Governor also had to contend with the issue and its political fallout when one of the state's highest-ranking Republicans, Secretary of State Diana J. Ohman, announced she too was unhappy with his leadership and approved a last minute write-in campaign for the nomination on her behalf.
Ms. Ohman did not cut very deeply into the Governor's support. But her campaign underscored the divisions within the Republican Party.
Worst of all for the Governor, when the primary was over, Mr. Taliaferro, who pulled about a third of the Republican vote, announced that he would not automatically throw his support to the Governor in the fall but instead might consider supporting Senator Vinich.
He said he would try to make his supporters "players" in the contest by urging them to go with the candidate who offered them the most. Then he called on the Governor to institute economic reforms to solidify the Republican vote.
"There are 29,000 votes out there," he went on. "Who wants them? Vinich or Geringer?"

HEADLINE: U.S. FURY ON 2 CONTINENTS: THE PROTAGONIST;
Man With Mission Takes On the U.S. At Far-Flung Sites

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
From his Afghan redoubt, Osama bin Laden has declared war on American interests everywhere, fueled by rage against American power in the Middle East, and backed, United States officials say, by an international network of terrorists and companies.
Mr. bin Laden is the self-appointed president of a "terrorist university" in Afghanistan, a senior American intelligence official said today. 
 "Terrorists of various nationalities have trained there," a senior intelligence official said. "This is the largest Sunni terrorist training facility in the world."
From 1991 to 1996, Mr. bin Laden established similar sites in the Sudan, which then, under pressure from Washington, told him to leave. In that time he formed a close alliance, officials say, with the Sudan's most powerful man, Hassan al-Turabi. Leader of the ruling party, the National Islamic Front, Mr. Turabi saw himself as the world's leading voice for Islamic fundamentalism.
Until recently Mr. bin Laden had saved his strongest anger for American forces and American allies in his homeland, Saudi Arabia. This year he publicly warned that American civilians were his targets as well. Today the United States made war on him and his Sudanese allies. His followers in Afghanistan reported that he survived, making it likely that his violent dialogue with the United States would continue.
"We don't know where bin Laden is," a senior official said, adding, "The prospect of retaliation against Americans is very, very high."
A decade ago the United States saw Mr. bin Laden as an ally in a noble cause.
He was involved with the American-backed Afghan rebels who fought off Soviet invaders in 1980's. "We knew him as one of the Saudi benefactors,"said a retired American official who helped fight that battle, describing a man who aided its widows and orphans.
Mr. bin Laden spent millions supporting the Afghan guerrillas, financing thousands of volunteer foreign soldiers who came to Afghanistan from places throughout the Islamic world, and creating a network of guesthouses and charities to support them and their families.
"He had a common cause with the United States," said Zalmay Khalilzad, a former State Department and Pentagon official of Afghan descent who monitored the war. "But with the end of the Soviet occupation in 1989, his struggle became the struggle against the United States, the dominant power in the world and in the Middle East."
Mr. bin Laden returned to his native Saudi Arabia in 1989, and officials say he began to support militant Islamic groups opposing moderate Islamic governments.
His rage against the United States reportedly ignited during the 1991 Persian Gulf war. The presence of American troops in his native Saudi Arabia struck him as an invasion by infidels. "He regarded that as an occupation of the Islamic holy places by the United States," Mr. Khalilzad said. Mr. bin Laden swore vengeance against what he called "the crusaders" of Christianity and the Saudi rulers who invited them into the land of Islam's two most venerated sites, Mecca and Medina.
As Kenneth Katzman, a former Central Intelligance Agency analyst, put it: "What this man thinks about every day is: How do I get the U.S. out of my home in Saudi Arabia, and how do I get those corrupt pharaohs out of power?" Mr. Katzman is the Congressional Research Service's expert on Middle Eastern terrorism.
Mr. bin Laden's view is shared by Mr. Turabi, and the bond between the two men helped place the Sudan on the United States' short list of state sponsors of international terrorism, officials said.
"Bin Laden is inspired by Turabi's expansive vision," Mr. Katzman said. "He sees eye to eye with him. They are allies. They are close associates. They are business partners. Bin Laden is Turabi's alter ego, his field commander, his operations chief."
Several intelligence analysts noted today that the American Embassy in the Sudan was all but evacuated in 1996, after a terrorist threat, and relocated at the embassy in Kenya, which was bombed on Aug. 7, along with the embassy in Tanzania.
Businesses established by Mr. bin Laden in the Sudan in the early 1990's continue to flourish. The National Islamic Front is a partner in his various businesses in and around the capital, Khartoum, experts say.
"Bin Laden has made financial contributions to the Sudanese military-industrial complex," a senior American intelligence official said today, "of which, we believe, the Shifa pharmaceutical facility is part." That plant was attacked by the United States today.
In 1991 and 1992, experts say, Mr. bin Laden gave jobs in the Sudan to hundreds of his proteges, veterans of the Afghan war who had come from North Africa, the Middle East and South Asia. These veterans started looking for new worlds to conquer.
According to Abdul Haq, a politically moderate Afghan veteran commander, they told one another: "We have a British grave in Afghanistan. We have a Soviet grave. And then we will have an American grave."
Mr. bin Laden began working to build that grave.
He went to work trying to form "a multinational organization for jihad, to purge the world of Western corrupters and their Arab friends," an American intelligence official said. Jihad is the Arabic for holy war.
His goal, said the official, is "a stateless, global jihad without borders," and with his millions, he aimed to build "a huge alliance of likeminded groups."
He became the world's leading individual sponsor of terrorism against Americans, spending a large part of the $250 million fortune he inherited from his father, who built palaces, mosques and public works for the Saudi royal family. The inheritance, hidden in a maze of Islamic financial institutions throughout Africa, the Middle East and South Asia, went to help create a global network of armed fundamentalists, backed by businesses and banks that functioned as front organizations.
"He has a very intricate financial infrastructure," said a senior United States intelligence official. "He has networks on every continent almost. He has an infrastructure that's very, very replete with capability, people, money."
Over the years, United States intelligence agencies trying to track Mr. bin Laden and have compiled a chronology of his career, including these highlights:
In December 1992 his operatives tried to bomb a hotel in Aden, Yemen, where 100 American soldiers were billeted en route to support United Nations peacekeeping operations in Somalia. The job was botched; two Australian tourists were killed.
In February 1993 the World Trade Center was bombed in New York. There is no concrete evidence tying Mr. bin Laden's followers to that attack, but Pakistani intelligence officials say Ramzi Ahmed Youssef, the convicted mastermind of the bombing, spent most of the three years until his arrest at a guest house owned by Mr. bin Laden.
Beginning in 1993, experts say, Mr. bin Laden channeled tens of millions of dollars a year through Islamic banks and charities to terrorist organizations and militant groups based in Egypt, Algeria, Yemen, the Sudan, Lebanon and the Philippines. He also provided support for the group known as Islamic Jihad, United States officials say. In addition, he has said he supported Islamic movements in Bosnia, Kashmir, Tajikistan, Chechnya and Somalia.
By January 1994 Mr. bin Laden had established at least three terrorist camps in the Sudan, where rebels from a half-dozen nations received training, according to American intelligence analysts. And by 1995, his camps in the Sudan had provided safe haven to followers who then fanned out across the Islamic world.
In May 1996, under intense pressure from the United States, the Sudan expelled Mr. bin Laden, hoping to receive American economic assistance. It never came. He returned to Afghanistan, where he received protection from the Taliban, the fundamentalist group that now controls much of Afghanistan.
He has been living there, first outside Jalalabad, then outside Kandahar, ever since. He established at least two terrorist training installations. The bigger, near the provincial capital of Khost, was attacked by the United States today.
Egyptian Islamic Jihad members were in the Khost camp, including their leader, Ayman el-Zawahri, who is wanted for terrorism in Egypt; so were members of the Islamic Group, which killed Egypt's President, Anwar el-Sadat, in 1981, American officials said today.
Mr. bin Laden is thought to have played at least a supporting role in the bombing of two American military installations in Saudi Arabia in 1995 and 1996.
He hardly disavowed it. In a February 1997 interview with an Arabic-language newspaper in London, he said: "We had thought that the Riyadh and Al Khobar blasts were a sufficient signal to sensible U.S. decision-makers to avert a real battle between the Islamic nation and U.S. forces, but it seems they did not understand the signal."
On Aug. 6, the day before the bombings of the American Embassies in Nairobi, Kenya, and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, the Egyptian Jihad group sent the United States a warning: they would soon deliver a message to Americans "which we hope they read with care, because we will write it, with God's help, in a language they will understand."
Today the United States replied in kind.
"This is a war," Mr. Khalilzad said. "They did two bombings, we did two, in two different countries, two different targets. If the targets associated with bin Laden were destroyed, there will be some effect on his ability to do things. Whatever plans he may have had in place, whether those will be affected by the attacks, we can't tell. Whether his organization will be deterred, who knows? But this is a strong message to those people who thought they could remain beyond the reach of civilized law in the anarchy of Afghanistan."

HEADLINE: METRO BUSINESS;
Gifts to United Way In New York Rise 8%

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
United Way of New York City said yesterday that it had raised $33.8 million in pledges in the year ended June 30, up $2.6 million, or 8.3 percent, from the previous year. The campaign was the third in a row in which donations grew significantly faster than the rate of inflation.
The city United Way also revised its report of the previous year's campaign. It had reported last year that its 1996-97 campaign raised $31.6 million, but yesterday it lowered that figure to $31.2 million. Without the change the increase in donations for 1997-98 would have been just under 7 percent. 
 Nancy Hite, a United Way spokeswoman, said the previous year's results were revised because of an accounting change involving United Way of Tristate, which raises money at 137 companies in the metropolitan area for 30 local United Ways.
Money collected during the tristate campaign will add $42.7 million to United Way of New York City's figures. Those funds, together with foundation grants and money from the city school board and other government agencies, will bring total revenue in the current fiscal year to $109 million, said Ralph Dickerson Jr., the organization's president.
John Biggs, chairman of United Way of New York City, said that gifts of more than $1,000 grew faster than donations over all, in line with a trend in which United Ways across the country are increasingly relying on such major gifts. Major gifts now account for one-fifth of United Way giving nationwide.
United Way of New York City, which allocates money to more than 800 social-service charities in the city, was the last large United Way in the country to announce its results.
 DAVID CAY JOHNSTON

HEADLINE: AMP Rejects Allied Signal's Takeover Bid Of $10 Billion

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
AMP Inc., a leading maker of electronics equipment, rejected a $10 billion bid yesterday from Allied Signal Inc., igniting a rare hostile takeover battle in a market that has grown accustomed to friendly mergers.
AMP, which dismissed Allied Signal's all-cash offer as too low, overhauled its top management yesterday and appointed Robert Ripp, formerly executive vice president, as chairman and chief executive. The company, based in Harrisburg, Pa., has enacted "poison pill" defenses against hostile bids and vowed to shed divisions, close plants and lay off workers to make itself more profitable. 
 "There are no synergies between our companies, and we are not interested in a combination," Mr. Ripp said in an interview on his first day as AMP's chief. "We absolutely believe that we have far greater value than the offer they put on the table."
Allied Signal, based in Morristown, N.J., makes aerospace and automotive products. It said it would seek to take control of AMP by appealing to shareholders and fighting the company in court. Lawrence Bossidy, Allied's chief executive, denounced the rejection of the offer. He described Mr. Ripp, a former I.B.M. executive and chief financial officer of AMP, as having "neither the experience or track record" to improve AMP's business.
"It is puzzling that a company in dire operating straits would appoint as C.E.O. someone who had no operating experience prior to this year," Mr. Bossidy said in a statement that observed few of the usual corporate courtesies. "AMP's manufacturing and administrative structures are antiquated, its margins are lower than its competitors' and its market share is eroding, resulting in plummeting profits and a bleak future."
In contrast to the 1980's, when companies routinely tried to resist corporate takeovers, most mergers and acquisitions are now amiable. Purchasers most often use stock, which has been driven up by the long bull market, as the currency. Allied Signal is a good example. It has used stock to make a string of acquisitions of smaller companies in recent years, deals intended to keep its earnings growth strong. All its purchases have been friendly, a company spokesman said.
But Allied Signal decided to make a hostile bid for ailing AMP, which declined to negotiate a sale despite overtures from Allied Signal that began a year ago. AMP officials say that Allied Signal has sought to buy its shares at a steep discount to their proven value.
"They are just trying to buy us on the cheap," Mr. Ripp said.
AMP's results have suffered this year as sales growth has dwindled and profit margins have contracted. Mr. Ripp blamed Asia's economic crisis -- the company sells 20 percent of its interconnection devices there -- for most of its sales slump.
The company's share price has plunged by half in 10 months. It hit a low of $28 on Aug. 3, the day before Allied Signal made its offer of $44.50 a share. Allied Signal argues that the offer is a 55 percent premium to its share price on the date the offer was made. AMP says the offer is a 20 percent discount to its peak price and called the bid "opportunistic."
AMP's board chose Mr. Ripp, 57, to replace James E. Marley as chairman and William J. Hudson as chief executive. Mr. Marley will retire and Mr. Hudson will become vice chairman. Mr. Ripp told analysts yesterday that he would speed up a reorganization plan first announced in July. That includes closing several production plants and dismissing 3,500 workers, about 7.5 percent of the company's work force.
Allied Signal has sued to test the legality of AMP's measures to thwart a takeover. Pennsylvania law has strong anti-takeover provisions that tend to favor the board of a target company. The laws recently helped Mellon Bank of Philadelphia to defend itself against an unsolicited bid from Bank of New York.
Allied Signal has also appealed to AMP shareholders to tender their shares despite the board's rejection. Shareholders will have an opportunity to accept Allied Signal's offer, beginning Oct. 15.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Despite Brief Comeback, Bank Shares Continue to Slide

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
The week started out with a bang and ended in a whimper for bank stocks.
The stocks, which have been battered for a month, rebounded earlier this week before economic turmoil in Russia and concerns about financial instability in Latin America sent the group reeling. 
 For the week, the stocks of big money center banks were down 4.52 percent as a group, while large regional banks plunged 3.14 percent as a group.
While Russia alone hardly poses an earnings threat to banks, and a rumored currency devaluation in Venezuela is not disastrous in itself, investors are backing away from banks because several hazards are starting to add up.
Several of Southeast Asia's once robust economies are already severely wounded. Link those woes to the possibility that the travails in Venezuela and Russia could spill over into the rest of Latin America and Eastern Europe and the scale of global economic problems looms much larger -- and may portend economic troubles in the United States.
"The market capitalization of the banking industry has declined by $200 billion in the last month," said Michael Mayo, an analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston. "The risks in emerging markets, year 2000 problems and other factors are getting better reflected in stock prices."
Large American banks that do business overseas -- the money center banks -- have only $3.5 billion of lending and investment exposure to Venezuela, spare change by big bank standards. But they have $25.7 billion in exposure to Brazil, $17.3 billion to Mexico and $16.2 billion to Argentina, according to Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. The exposure is $98.9 billion to Latin America and the Caribbean as a whole.
The stocks of banks that do a lot of business in Latin America were punished yesterday. Citicorp fell $4.75, or 3.4 percent, to $134.3125; Chase Manhattan fell $1.6875, or 2.6 percent, to $63.6875; J. P. Morgan dropped $3.4375, or 2.8 percent, to $119.375; Bankers Trust fell $4.9375, or 4.9 percent, to $96.3125, a 52-week low, and BankBoston sank $2.4375, or 5.5 percent, to $41.9375.
"This group has led the market in both directions, and that behavior is likely to continue," said Raphael Soifer, an analyst at Brown Brothers Harriman. "But we do feel that the banks are oversold based on the fundamentals."
For big United States regional banks, subject to a potential drop-off in loan growth and heightened credit concerns, yesterday also ended on a sour note. Nationsbank slipped $1.0625, or 1.5 percent, to $70.3125, and Norwest dropped $1.0625, or 3.2 percent, to $32.0625. First Union, on the other hand, rose 56.25 cents, or 1.1 percent, to $51.625.
"I think 50 percent of the selloff is emotional and 50 percent is fundamental," said Edward Furash, a banking consultant with Furash & Company in Washington. "But it's clear that the banks that don't have the capacity to cover earnings shortfalls with other sources of income are going to get hurt."

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Decline

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The number of newly out-of-work Americans seeking unemployment benefits slipped by 2,000 in the latest week, according to the Labor Department. Initial jobless claims, which give an early reading on the resilience of the labor market, fell to 301,000 in the week that ended last Saturday, down from a revised 303,000 in the prior week and well below the 310,000 that private economists had forecast. In the last four weeks, initial jobless claims have averaged 303,000, down from 307,000 in the previous four-week period, the department said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Overseas Markets Send Wall Street Reeling

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON and JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Investors hoping for a languid summer day of stock trading were treated instead to a wild ride yesterday.
After the markets in Asia and Europe recorded sharp drops, the Dow Jones industrial average acted like a bungee-jumper. The Dow plunged 280 points just before noon, then bounced back to end the day at 8,533.65, a loss of only 77.76 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent. The Nasdaq composite index fell 34.84, or 1.9 percent, to 1,797.61. 
 American stocks were again caught in a global downdraft, as there was no bad domestic news yesterday. The United States economy remains robust by almost all measures and consumer confidence is still high. The housing market is strong, auto sales are expected to do well as General Motors recovers from two plant strikes and personal income is rising.
"A confluence of events overseas is overwhelming what I believe to be very good fundamentals for the U.S. economy," said Timothy J. Morris, chief investment officer at Bessemer Trust in New York.
It is clear, for example, that Asia has not yet righted itself. Adding to fears that Japan's economy is worsening, Okura & Company, a Tokyo trading concern, sought protection from creditors yesterday, the nation's third-largest corporate bankruptcy this year. Investors were also disappointed by Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi's reluctance to reduce the 5 percent consumption tax. The yen lost ground again to the dollar, falling 1.2 percent.
And Russia's financial crisis shows no signs of abating, and its stock market dropped 5.6 percent yesterday.
A newer worry on the international scene is Latin America. Inflation rates are rising in the emerging-market nations of Venezuela, Brazil and Argentina, and their currencies are sinking. As a result, there is increased concern that their troubles will have an impact on American exports. Roughly 20 percent of United States exports go to Latin American nations.
Indeed, some analysts think the selloff in emerging markets signaled the realization among investors that the backstops of the International Monetary Fund and the Group of Seven leading industrial nations may no longer be there.
John Lipsky, chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank, said that even if the I.M.F. did try another bailout, such a move would no longer reassure investors because it has not proved to be effective. "The awareness that the crisis management is in crisis adds to investor uncertainty and market volatility," he said.
As a result, some investors are beginning to question whether American stocks can be a port in a worldwide economic storm.
"The risks to the U.S. are rising," said Bill Dudley, economist at Goldman, Sachs. "The International Monetary Fund is out of money and out of credibility. The pressures on emerging market countries are real. And the U.S. economy is more fragile because of its dependence on the stock market."
Investors seem to be bracing themselves for the second wave of Asian troubles. The first stage in the crisis was an expected decline in exports, evidenced in the June trade figures. Of the $10 billion slide in the last six months, $8 billion of it was a collapse in exports. The second stage is a flood of cheap imports into this country, which has not yet happened. If it does, American corporations will find their margins squeezed as they are forced to compete with these lower-priced goods.
Another worry among economists is that the capital spending boom that has kept the United States economy perking is about to end. "You do have tantalizing signs that the capital spending boom is finally over," said M. Cary Leahey, chief economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y. "The classic economic problem now is firms are preparing for a party in 1999, and maybe nobody's going to show up."
Mr. Leahey argues that American corporations have prepared for an economy growing at 5 percent annually -- built plants, added capacity, hired employees -- and they are going to end up with an economy growing at maybe half that rate.
Charles Clough, chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, said that a slowdown in capital investment would put a drag on economic growth. "Investment is just running too fast," he said.
If investment was to slow, so would the economy.
Compared with markets around the world, American stocks held up well. European markets were down yesterday: Germany's DAX index lost 5.4 percent of its value, and Spain's IBEX fell 5.81 percent. Mexico's chief index fell almost 2.5 percent. The Brazilian stock market lost 2.85 percent.
Seeking some calm in the worldwide storm, investors fled to Treasury securities. The yield on the 30-year bond fell to 5.43 percent, its lowest level in decades At midday, when stocks were at their lows, long-term Treasury yields, which move in the opposite direction from their prices, touched 5.38 percent.
In yesterday's trading, shares of banks, semiconductor makers and computer manufacturers were particularly hard hit. J. P. Morgan lost 14 percent of its value, Hewlett-Packard fell 4.6 percent. Bucking the trend were drug stocks and consumer packaged goods makers. Johnson & Johnson gained 4.38 percent, and Procter & Gamble rose 2.57 percent.
The market started to rebound shortly after noon. One trader speculated that investors thought that declining Treasury yields would make stocks more attractive.
Even after this summer's downdrafts, stocks are still trading at high prices historically, which makes them very vulnerable to external shocks. "The market is faced with a manifold set of issues that cannot be resolved quickly," said Marshall Acuff, equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Turning Crises Into Comedy In the Bronx

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
JONATHAN ROSARIO answered his door dressed as if he were ready to go on stage and do his comedy routine: black vest over a loose white shirt, burgundy jeans and impeccably shined shoes. He excused himself and lingered in the foyer, where he keeps a pantheon of saints and celebrities.
"If you don't mind, let me light my candles," he said. "People come by and leave their names so I can pray for them. I don't think I'm anything special, but people think my prayers do something for them." 
 He touched a match to candles near a statue of an Indian, one of the Virgin Mary and a black cloth doll that clutched a pile of business cards. He glanced at autographed photos of Whoopi Goldberg and Melba Moore. They were divine in another way, having survived tough times in their pursuit of the big time.
"Melba Moore," he said reverently. "One day, I'm going to open for her."
Along Bainbridge Avenue in the Bronx, Mr. Rosario is hailed as a stand-up guy, and not just for his shtick. Although cutbacks cost him his day job as a crisis counselor at a housing center, he still tackles cases for no pay. Old ladies and single mothers short on money or luck stop him on the street and ask for advice.
Few of them know that the counselor-comic faces his own quiet crisis. He expects an eviction notice to be slapped on his door because he owes $4,100 in rent on his tiny apartment. Reluctant to burden anyone with problems that also include a close friend's death and a recent break-in, he mines his life for laughs.
"I'm so broke that when I go to the A.T.M., I get food stamps," he said. "Then there's my paranoia. Every time I open my door and see a restaurant menu, I think it's an eviction notice."
He certainly knows the difference. He has been working -- either for pay or for nothing -- as a housing advocate since he was a teen-ager. He got into it seriously soon after he had testified in a court case involving someone who he knew was not guilty of a drug hit.
"If someone can walk in here with a really nice suit and say something against somebody who doesn't look so hot, that means that the one with the suit will win," said Mr. Rosario, 25. "That means that sometimes innocent people have to pay for something they didn't bring upon themselves."
That remains enough of a hook for him that he continues his freelance counseling even though his unemployment benefits have run out, his phone is about to be cut off and his part-time job at a video store isn't cutting it. When he hits the streets of Norwood, he becomes the answer man.
"The only way I am able to forget about my problems is to help people with worse problems," he said. "I'm a lonely guy. I really have nothing to do with my time except see who else is lonely and who needs help."
HE exaggerates, since he also sends out dozens of letters to clubs, producers and anyone else who might discover him. He also writes new jokes, sometimes drawing on the absurdity of the social services maze. He dreams of being on "The Rosie O'Donnell Show," since he shares her love of wonderfully cheesy sitcoms. Like her, he said, those old shows helped ease a rough childhood. "She's like one of my biggest inspirations," he said. "I loved her even before she had her own show. I remember her from 'Gimme a Break.' I can even sing the theme song."
Until he gets his own break, Mr. Rosario has enough fans in Norwood looking out for him. When they learned that he was not being paid for all the problems he was solving, they took care of him. His hair stylist never charges him. The thrift shop gives him a discount on clothing. And every day, Efrain Cruz feeds him pasteles and flan at his restaurant, A Touch of Latin.
"He puts everybody else prior to him," Mr. Cruz said. "I tell him to pay when he can. With certain people I do that. Not everybody. You got to take care of those who have heart. If somebody has heart, you got to have heart."
Mr. Rosario does not forget the favors. "If I ever make it, I'm going to make him the next Jimmy's Bronx Cafe," he vowed. After a while, and a brief hello to Esther, his "hair savior" down the street, Mr. Rosario returned to his apartment. Some of his friends think he's wasting his time writing jokes. He slogs on, even though on some days it's enough of a chore to get out of bed.
"This time is not wasted," he insisted. "One day, all the things I'm writing about I'll be able to express little by little."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE SCENE;
In Sudan, Furor And a Warning Amid the Ruins

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 21

 BODY:
Not quite 24 hours after American cruise missiles hit a factory in a decrepit industrial area of this capital, clouds of white smoke and acrid smells still hovered over the site tonight. Deep puddles of water on muddy ground attested to the firefighting efforts after the strike.
The factory, which is about a half-mile square, was destroyed in the attack, though surrounding areas went unscathed. There were no known deaths at the plant, which was hit at night, when it was closed, but local reports said 10 people were hospitalized, 4 of them in critical condition. 
 The nation's Islamic Government invited foreign diplomats to tour the ruins today. Afterward, many remained puzzled, saying it was not clear whether the plant, as Washington asserts, made precursors for nerve gas or whether it was purely a medical manufacturing site, as the Sudan contends.
After Friday prayers in the city's mosques, worshipers were urged to attend frenzied rallies, where leading figures of the Government accused the United States of being a terrorist state, and where the American flag was torn, burned and trampled into the ground.
At one rally, pictures of President Clinton and Monica Lewinsky were on prominent display -- a juxtaposition that is interpreted as the ultimate mockery in this very conservative society.
The Foreign Minister, Mustafa Osman Ismail, said the Sudan would remain a "tomb for its enemies, whatever this costs us in human lives."
But the most important Sudanese leader, Hassan al-Turabi, who is the Speaker of Parliament and the ideological power behind the governing National Islamic Front, remained silent today.
American intelligence officials have called Mr. Turabi a close comrade of Osama bin Laden, whom the Administration has accused of being the mastermind of the bombings of two American embassies in East Africa that left hundreds dead.
The Clinton Administration accuses the Sudanese Government of assisting Mr. bin Laden in terrorist activities. The Sudan rejects the charge and has asked for an urgent meeting of the United Nations Security Council to discuss the missile strike.
Mr. Turabi has always been considered a Rasputin by Westerners, a mysterious figure of the fundamentalist Government that took power in a military coup in 1989.
The army general who is the Sudanese President, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, made up for Mr. Turabi's silence today by furiously waving a long stick as he addressed a raucous crowd.
President Bashir said he would prove that the pharmaceutical plant hit by the American missiles was not a cover for making the precursors of nerve gas as Washington charged. "We have undeniable proof" that the plant was only used for pharmaceutical products like children's and anti-malarial medicines, he said.
He said international companies that had provided equipment for the plant, which opened two years ago, would back him up. He did not name them.
In describing the reasons for destroying the plant, President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said today that Mr. bin Laden had given key financial help for the plant, which was part of the "Sudanese military-industrial complex." Mr. bin Laden lived in the Sudan from 1994 to 1996, a period when Washington says he invited international terrorists to train at camps here.
He was forced to leave in 1996, when the Government decided that he was too much of an embarrassment and his presence too costly. After telling Mr. bin Laden to leave, the Government hoped to win some concessions from the Clinton Administration, including economic aid, but failed to do so.
As part of their case that the plant was a benign operation, Government officials said today that it was owned by a Sudanese businessman, Salah Idrisse, who is also a citizen of Saudi Arabia.
The heart of the factory, where most of the smoke was still billowing, was off-limits to reporters today, and it was impossible to tell what was made there. In the rubble at the front of the compound, there were wrappers from a veterinary solution made at the plant and leaflets on how to take Profenil, a trade name for ibuprofen, a widely used pain reliever. Trays of small empty brown bottles, apparently used for medicine, were scattered about on the ground.
Mohammed Hussein, 23, a builder who lives about a mile from the plant, said he had seen bright lights and then heard the swoosh of missiles during the attack. At first, he said, he thought the nearby power station had been struck. Then he thought a plane had crashed. Then, he said, it occurred to him that John Garang, the leader of a southern rebel group that has been waging a civil war for more than a decade, had finally struck the capital.
The plant's managing director, Sayed Hamed, said the factory employed 360 workers. He said the enterprise made 30 kinds of drugs for humans and 23 kinds of veterinary medicines.
A hospital spokesman said today that 10 people wounded from the strike were admitted to the wards. Four of them were in critical condition, he said. The plant does not operate at night, and there were apparently few workers around during the attack.
A spokesman for Sudanese opposition political parties based in Cairo, Faruq Ahmed Adam, said today that he agreed with Washington that the plant was a cover for the manufacture of chemical weapons. He said another factory, in the suburb of Kafouri, also made chemical weapons. He added that Sudanese security forces were investors in the plant.
Relations between Washington and the Sudanese Government have gone from bad to worse in the nine years of fundamentalist rule. But even so, ordinary people seemed to be bewildered why American should aim cruise missiles here.
