HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Bernard Goldberg, Hotel Innovator;
5 Lodgings Sold, He Seeks a Bigger Challenge

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
BERNARD GOLDBERG thinks that minibars in hotel rooms are appalling. He contends that free chamber music performances will pay for themselves in guest satisfaction. And if orange juice is to be billed as fresh squeezed, he said, those oranges should stay intact until just minutes before the juice is delivered.
Mr. Goldberg's views on hotel operations command a certain amount of attention. Over the last 10 years he has taken five rundown but well-located small hotels in Manhattan and converted them to attractive properties catering to the city's booming tourist trade. 
 Now he wants to try something different. Last month he sold his entire portfolio, consisting of the five hotels plus an office building at 39 West 55th Street, to Credit Suisse First Boston, reportedly for close to $150 million. The hotels are the Shoreham, the Wales, the Franklin, the Mansfield and the Roger Williams. The office building is being converted into an addition to the Shoreham.
"It's time to do something different in size and concept," said Mr. Goldberg, who is chairman of Gotham Hospitality Group. He said he hoped to acquire control of one of the city's older, larger hotels and restore it to an elegance and style that he said they once had, but have lost.
"There are these old dowagers in this city that are tired and in need of an infusion of light and air," he said. Mr. Goldberg said he was looking for a hotel in the 800 to 1,200 room range. He declined to identify them, but hotel industry analysts said the group that he is considering probably includes the Pennsylvania and Roosevelt hotels, both of which are older properties that have undergone renovations.
Some hospitality specialists caution that running a big hotel is different from managing boutiques. Smaller hotels can afford to cater to business travelers and tourists, but large hotels must market themselves to larger groups to fill the rooms.
"A large hotel is a different animal in many ways from a boutique property," said Sean Hennessey, New York director of PricewaterhouseCoopers' gaming and hospitality practice. "Small hotels shun the group market, but big hotels have to concentrate on the group market to succeed."
He said that, as far as he knew, there had been no examples of an operator buying a big hotel and grafting boutique hotel concepts to it. But he did note that large hotels had the advantage of economies of scale, with management costs being spread over a larger number of rooms.
"If anyone can do it, Bernard can," said John A. Fox, a senior vice president of PKF Consulting, which specializes in hotels. He said Mr. Goldberg's success in taking buildings that were little short of single-room-occupancy residences and turning them into upscale hotels demonstrated his ability to add value to properties.
MR. GOLDBERG'S plans for a big hotel, provided he succeeds in gaining control of one, consist of style, customer satisfaction and variable pricing. All three, he said, are important to creating an experience that will induce travelers to come back to the hotel when they visit New York.
"When you stay at a hotel in Paris, you know that it is Paris," he said. "You need the same thing in New York. The hotel has to be thematic. It has to have the feeling of New York."
Although he said he had looked at hotel properties in Chicago and Aspen, Colo., he said he was not likely to acquire anything outside of New York. "New York is what I know," he said.
For his smaller hotels, Mr. Goldberg chose every piece of art and made sure that what was on the wall of the corridors was coordinated with furnishings in the guest rooms. He said that integrating the public spaces of a hotel with the guest rooms was important to creating a pleasant experience for guests.
"I looked at an 800-room hotel in the Broadway district where the owners had spent a lot of money on refurbishing rooms," he said. He said to reposition the hotel, as the owners wanted, would require throwing out all the newly purchased furniture because it clashed with the mass-produced hunting scenes decorating the walls. "They were from different countries and different periods," he said.
Small things count, Mr. Goldberg maintains. Like fresh flowers in public areas and guest rooms. "I was at one of the most expensive hotels in the city and they had an array of silk flowers in the lobby," he said. "Why not spend $100 to $200 a week to have fresh flowers in the rooms? That's called thinking about the guest."
Mr. Goldberg is a real estate lawyer who redeveloped distressed housing before buying his first hotel, the Wales, on Madison Avenue between 92d and 93d Streets, in 1988. He contends that a short-sighted focus on immediate earnings leads some hotel managers to do things that degrade the guest experience. Many hotels lease out ground floor space to retailers, because of the high rents these businesses are willing to pay.
But if the result is a tiny lobby, guests are cheated, he said. "If you have a 200-room hotel and a lobby that only fits 40 people, the guests notice it," he said. At the Roger Williams and the Mansfield, he took out stores to increase space in the lobby.
He said free amenities, such as chamber music concerts, breakfast and after-theater snacks, add to the guest experience because the hotel does not appear to be trying to squeeze nickels and dimes out of them. And he said the cost of these amenities is more than made up by higher room rates.
"You can change the character of a hotel with these amenities," he said. "You should serve scones and strawberries at tea time along with chamber music." He said he had installed machines that made cappuccino from freshly ground beans in his smaller hotels so that guests could serve themselves at any time.
Which is why he hates minibars. Forcing guests to pay high prices for a meager bag of chips or a soft drink leaves a bad taste, he said, Similarly, charging extra to watch a taped movie adds to the feeling of exploitation, he argues.
"Would you charge somebody to watch a movie at your home?" he asks. "That's what the guest experience should be, like a visit to your home."
With a big hotel, Mr. Goldberg said he would likely divide it into separate areas, with distinctive decors. His plan includes having a concierge on each floor, to help guests with their business or holiday in New York.
HE said he was planning to price rooms at an average of $225 a night. That would put prices between the current rates for first class and luxury hotels. According to PricewaterhouseCoopers, first-class hotels in the city had an average rate of $193 a night in the first quarter of this year, while luxury hotels averaged $251 a night.
But the $225 number is only an average. Mr. Goldberg said he planned to use a form of marginal pricing to try to fill his hotel every night.
"People are saying that it is great that we have 90 percent occupancy," he said. "But in a 1,000-room hotel, that means that 100 rooms are vacant. That is the equivalent of a small hotel that is unoccupied."
He said he would follow a pricing model similar to the one used by airlines, which charge the highest prices to business travelers with inflexible schedules. The bargain seats are sold at far lower prices to people with more time than money, to insure that the airplanes fly as full as possible.
"We will have suites at $350 a night, but we will also have rooms for $99 a night," he said, to keep vacancies at a minimum. He said that food, music and other amenities would be available to all guests, regardless of what they are paying for their room.
"Anybody can make money running a hotel in New York today," he said. "But what happens when the downturn comes? If you are the hotel of choice for a lot of people, the business will take care of itself."

But some specialists caution that running a big hotel is different from managing a small one. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Help Wanted Isn't Getting The Help Needed

BYLINE: By BILL SLOCUM 

 BODY:
FOR four long years now, the Help Wanted sign has sat on the counter of the Photo Shop in Greenwich, alongside the cash register and the boxes of Kodak film. The owner, Chris Holdt, occasionally dusts it, but that's about the only kind of activity the sign generates. There hasn't been a worthy applicant at his store in two years.
It's not as though Mr. Holdt is necessarily looking for help in the darkroom, or duplicating video footage. "We really just need someone who has basic sales skills, McDonald's even, who knows how to work a cash register, has a high-school diploma and can speak English," he said with a shake of his head. 
 Mr. Holdt's predicament is one familiar to business owners throughout Connecticut. Large or small, they have struggled to find what has become perhaps the state's most elusive species: the resident looking for work. The situation is particularly acute when it comes to workers with college educations.
In a survey of employers conducted by the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, more than 90 percent of 359 respondents reported that they either were having difficulty filling job openings or anticipated difficulty in the months ahead. Released last month, the survey may indicate that a years-long resurgence of the state economy has reached a plateau, association officials say.
"Right now you've got the mirror test: if you can breathe, you can work," said Peter Gioia, a C.B.I.A. economist. "When you realize how much Connecticut is dependent on skilled labor, in fields like insurance, computers, high-tech manufacturing and pharmaceuticals, then you see problems."
The theory is simple: Businesses need to add employees in order to grow. With a scarcity of new workers, they must improvise not only to find workers, but also to retain them in the face of a more competitive employment environment.
This is obviously a nice problem to have if you are searching for work, or if you are an incumbent politician dealing with an unemployment rate around 5 percent. But it troubles those who hope the state can regain the robust private-sector presence it enjoyed through the 1980's.
One person who has been tracking the issue since the beginning of this year is William A. McEachern, editor-in-chief of The Connecticut Economy Quarterly. More than 100,000 jobs have been recovered in state since late 1992, when the period he calls "The Great Recession" came to an end. What troubles him is the fact that Connecticut's labor force has been dipping, by 2,000 workers between early 1997 and early 1998 alone.
"If you're looking out there, saying what are the potential problems, and exclude things like the Asian crisis outside state borders, this is the chief concern," said Mr. McEachern, who is also a professor of economics at the University of Connecticut.
Mr. McEachern likens the situation to the riddle of the bumblebee, which is able to fly despite wings that are aerodynamically too short. While workers are in demand in other states, too, Connecticut's declining work force makes it unique.
"Through the 80's, we had very high labor participation, among the highest nationwide," Mr. McEachern said. "Now we are lower than the national average. How could that happen so quickly? I'm still wary of the numbers."
For many of the state's employers, the dilemma of the incredible shrinking work force is all too real. Asked if he's having difficulty finding workers, Dave DeMeo, vice president of administration for Fire-Lite Alarms, asks: "Do you know anybody?"
Mr. DeMeo was laughing, but added the situation is "not good." Fire-Lite, which produces complex fire detection systems nationwide and employs 525 people at its North Branford headquarters, is looking for help, especially engineers and computer programmers. There are typically 10 or 15 openings at Fire-Lite at any one time.
"I don't want to say it stifles growth to the point of reaching targets, because we're still enjoying revenue growth, but I could bring products on-line faster and add more projects," he said. "If I had an unlimited supply of workers, I think our growth could be faster."
One reason for Fire-Lite's growth is an engineering group in Louisville, Ky. "It's much easier to find qualified people there," he said. "We can actually place an ad and find people that way. Whereas here, there are certain people you just can't find."
What concerns observers isn't just that companies like Fire-Lite might relocate in search of a more easily tapped work force, but that other businesses outside Connecticut will be less encouraged to come into the state.
At the Pitney Bowes Credit Corporation in Shelton, it's becoming increasingly difficult to find people who can spend several hours a day on a telephone answering customer questions or chasing after unpaid bills. Peggy Anson, vice president of human resources, is looking to fill a total of 60 openings at this growing financial-services spin-off of the Stamford-based adding-machine giant.
"The cost associated with not filling a job in time becomes increasingly expensive," she said. "Then I have the incremental cost of having an existing employee cover. There I am running the risk of having that existing employee run out on me, which can cost money, too."
Such costs can include classified advertisements, plump benefits packages and even "finder's fees" to existing employees. Pitney Bowes Credit has even put together a videotape that highlights work-environment features like a coffee-break lounge designed to look like a 1950's diner.
People's Bank offers an unusual scholarship program that pays the total cost of higher education programs for participating employees. There are even stock incentives for those who earn associate's, bachelor's or graduate degrees.
"So there's a double hit here," said Barbara Phillips, People Bank's head of human resources. "We are willing to pay for your education, and we value what it brings to the bank. So we'll keep you around a while."
But the bank, based in Bridgeport and the largest lending institution based in the state, is still dealing with a higher turnover rate than it did two years ago, and averages 30 to 35 job openings a week.
The information-technology field is a particularly difficult place to find workers, Ms. Phillips said, because so many of them are being soaked up by Year 2000 projects. But tellers and customer service people are also in high demand.
One might expect the problem to be most acute in Stamford, which remained a magnet for new business throughout Connecticut's lean years and up to the present.
Mr. McEachern says Stamford has indeed seen a rise in job growth, but so has every other region of the state, even long-troubled areas like Danielson.
The Hartford metropolitan area seems to have more jobs than it can handle. According to the Connecticut Capitol Region Growth Council, a recent survey found more than 4,500 job openings at 32 companies based in Hartford and surrounding towns.
"Work-force development is the crucial issue," said Robert Santy, manager of the Growth Council's Millennium Project. "It's not that companies are saying they will move, but if we don't address this, that could become a problem."
The Millennium Project has sought to address the issue by retraining people for understaffed fields like precision machining, as well as trumpeting the region to young professionals.
"The biggest difficulty is competition," Mr. Santy said. "Young professionals have a lot of choices on where to go, and we haven't done a good-enough job recruiting them. It's not the package being offered by the company, it's the place itself."
Jim Nolan, president of the Branford-based Institute for Pharmaceutical Discovery, details several small but annoying problems in recruiting top-notch people to the New Haven area.
He recalled a recent visit to his company by a scientist and Nobel laureate whom Mr. Nolan wanted to impress. There were no hotels in the area, so they had to put the scientist up in a motel. There was no room service at the motel, so the scientist had to go outside and head for a diner a mile and a half away. There were no taxicabs, so the scientist had to walk to the diner.
"Connecticut needs a lot of work in the ways in which companies are attracted to an area," Mr. Nolan said. "I think the desire is there, but it has a ways to go."
The state's Department of Labor has stepped up its once-dormant job fair program, holding five of them in June alone. The department administrator, John Tirinzonie, noted that employers completely booked all but one of those fairs, with 82 at the Danbury fair alone.
Mr. Tirinzonie said the labor-dearth issue, while not severe, needs addressing. But he predicted the economy would continue to grow in Connecticut, especially in computer-related fields.
Mr. McEachern remains concerned. "As you dig deeper and deeper into the labor force, you get diminishing returns," he said.
"It's a good problem to have, particularly in the short run," he added. "You can see wages go up. But in the long run, if Connecticut becomes a more expensive place to do business, than it isn't so good."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
Norwalk Bustles With Projects and Prospects

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
WHEN construction projects now under way are completed, and if the many proposals in negotiation between the city and several developers become realities, Norwalk could one day have some four million square feet of new retail, office, hotel and residential space. About two million square feet of the total would be added to an existing four million square feet of offices.
"In five years you won't recognize Norwalk," says its Mayor, Frank Esposito. 
 "We do have a lot of proposals," said Edward Musante, executive director of the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency, which has oversight on most of them.
Noting that many projects could not begin construction for two years or more, he said that "in five years we expect a lot to be done -- as long as the real estate market holds up."
Interest in the city is at a peak. "Norwalk is getting the play because there is no dirt left in Fairfield County and Stamford is filled up," said Brian Dornan, a broker with Pyramid Realty of Stamford. He has been handling commercial rentals in Norwalk for 10 years.
The city's plan focuses on extending development from the historic district of South Norwalk to the heart of the city's downtown, on Wall Street a mile away. In between, along West Avenue, there is a wasteland of vacant or marginal stores, troublesome nightclubs and a stretch of state-owned land at Exit 15 of Interstate 95 that cannot be developed beyond its current status as a grassy strip relieved by some outdoor sculpture.
It has been Mayor Esposito's long held vision "to tie South Norwalk to downtown," he said, "making us one city again."
Downtown and South Norwalk have been helped in recent years by city grants for facade improvements and by new businesses moving in. But they remain two disparate communities.
The traditional business district has always been downtown, but South Norwalk was reborn 20 years ago when Arthur Collins, a Stamford developer, restored Washington Street's abandoned, crime-infested 19th-century brick factories as boutiques and condominiums, creating a historic district with the help of Federal tax credits.
It got further help when the Maritime Aquarium around the corner on North Water Street opened 10 years ago, attracting tourists and day-trippers. Today it is the second of the state's major tourist attractions after Mystic Seaport, and it is expanding into an adjoining building.
But most of the original shops on Washington Street are gone, unable to meet rent increases or find a customer base, and the replacements are not always of good quality. Renting space to nightclubs in an effort to keep the street populated after dark backfired when tenants living above the clubs complained about loud music and rude behavior of patrons. One of them sucessfully sued the Rattlesnake Bar & Grill, according to the Mayor. "They had better start monitoring the noise or there will be more lawsuits," he said.
Empty stores, vandalism, dirty sidewalks and crime spilling over from the surrounding depressed neighborhoods have not discouraged new businesses and retailers from coming in. But, said Mr. Dornan, the real estate broker, "as much as you like to put in cutesy retail, you have to pay the rent."
"Greenwich Avenue and Westport have Banana Republic and the Gap to do deals with," he said. "This is Norwalk."
The city hopes to improve crime control by building a $10 million, 45,000-square-foot police station, designed by Valus & Carpenter, Westport architects, on Monroe Street, across from the South Norwalk Metro-North station and two blocks from Washington Street. "It will take two and a half years," said Harry Rilling, Norwalk's Chief of Police. "That area is full of weeds, abandoned buildings and graffiti. Cleaning it up and having a police presence there would encourage investors to come into the neighborhood."
The Mayor's plans focus on the Maritime Aquarium as a fulcrum from which new development will radiate. Across the street from the aquarium the Lock Building, an enormous old foreclosed factory, is to be developed by Clay Fowler, head of the Spinnaker Companies in Stamford, as a 600-car garage, with shops at street level and possibly offices above.
DIAGONALLY across from the aquarium one of its parking lots, with 126 spaces, will be replaced with a 150-unit apartment house developed by Mr. Fowler. A second 294-space lot north of the aquarium would be redeveloped by Simon Konover of Hartford as a 250-room hotel and an 85-unit apartment house overlooking the Norwalk River with onsite parking.
Behind the aquarium and running along the riverfront the linear Heritage Park is being installed by the city. When it is completed next year pedestrians and bicylists will be able to use it to travel from the aquarium over two new footbridges, past a new fishing pier and under an I-95 overpass to Mathews Park on West Avenue, home of the historic Lockwood-Mathews Mansion Museum. The Connecticut GraphicArts Museum is also in Mathews Park. An 18,000-square-foot Stepping Stones Children's Museum is also proposed for the park.
While utilities are being placed underground, a half mile of West Avenue from Mathews Park to Wall Street is being torn up in anticipation of a $150-million mixed use redevelopment by Stanley M. Seligson of Norwalk, designated developer for the project.
He is working with Landauer Associates in Manhattan to secure financing, and Arrowstreet of Somerville, Mass., on the architectural design. "A 40-acre combination of restaurants, apartments and shops with offices upstairs," said Mr. Seligson, "will make it look like Newbury Street in Boston."
Under construction by Mr. Seligson on Route 1 are new big-box stores for Sports Authority and Circuit City, fronted by an 18,000 square foot of small shops. Meanwhile, the West Norwalk Association is appealing in Superior Court in Stamford the Norwalk Zoning Board's approval of Mr. Seligson's proposal to build a Costco discount store nearby, objecting to increased traffic and concern over cleaning up existing soil contamination.
Opposite the Sports Authority and Circuit City sites a Super Stop & Shop is under construction, filling a dwindling number of parcels available on Route 1. The area is already lined with several major stores built within the last several years, including a Home Depot, Linens 'n' Things, Shoprite, two Staples stores, Nobody Beats the Wiz, Bob's Stores, Toys 'R' Us, TJ Maxx, Barnes & Noble and Comp USA.
Proposals by Fred F. French of Stamford carry the largest square footage of all. As the developer of two sites at West Avenue and Reed Street, the company could build 900,000-square-feet of offices in two or three nine- to 15-story buildings under current zoning regulations.
A third parcel behind Exit 15 of I-95, site of the Connecticut Limousine depot, is targeted by the company for a 15-story, 350,000-square-foot office building that would also accommodate the airport transportation service. Part of the property was purchased by the Norwalk-based Field Brothers, who would eventually have to work out a rental or sale to the French company, or face possible condemnation by the city, according to Mr. Musante.
"As the city's preferred developers, French, Konover and Fowler have until next June to come with an agreement with the city on their plans," said Mr. Musante. "During that time, while they are spending large sums on planning, architectural, engineering and legal fees, we will not talk to other developers regarding those sites. We already have an agreement with Mr. Seligson. He has three years in which to redevelop the West Avenue property. We expect a preliminary plan in about nine months."
Other projects yet to break ground are a 168,000-square-foot building to be erected for Purdue Frederick, a pharmaceutical company on Route 1, next to its existing 185,000 square foot headquarters; a 400,000-square-foot building for Norden Systems, radar systems producers, on their 84-acre property at the Westport border; a 250,000-square-foot building at the Merritt 7 office park on Route 7 for Hewitt Associates, employee benefits consultants in Lincolnshire, Ill., and another 250,000-square-foot building approved by the city for construction at Merritt 7 by the office park's owner, John Crosby.
If all this comes to fruition, will Norwalk's high taxes of $42 to $46 per $1,000 of assessment be reduced? "There will be some beneficial effect," said Kenneth Whitman, the tax assessor, "but most new construction will replace old buildings that are already taxed."
Whether the decline of Washington Street can be reversed is another question. "It will evolve the way it evolves," said Mr. Dornan. "South Norwalk clubs are the hottest in Fairfield County," he said, citing Symmetry, Velvet, Shenanigans, and the Loft, on South Main and Washington Streets.
"If a resident has a gift shop under him, O.K., but if it's a noisy nightclub -- it's a Catch 22," he said. "The city wants it but it's not working."

LENGTH: 1549 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Loan Programs to Keep, and Draw, High-Tech Firms

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
NEW JERSEY'S three-year effort to retain and attract emerging high-technology companies took a step forward recently with the start of two financing programs by the state's Economic Development Authority.
They are the $100 million Technology Funding Program, meant for growing companies to expand, and the $3 million Seed Capital Program, intended to help businesses bring new products to the market. Under both programs, which became available in June, technology companies can get below-market-rate loans to construct new buildings, renovate existing buildings or to buy equipment. 
 Meanwhile, construction has started on the fifth building at the Technology Center of New Jersey, the state-sponsored research park taking shape on 50 acres along Route 1 in North Brunswick. The 60,000-square-foot structure has been designed for multiple tenants who get the space for a reasonable price and can expand in place as they grow. The new building, called Tech II, will join four others, together totaling 130,000 square feet, now at the park, which ultimately will comprise up to 800,000 square feet of office, research and production space.
The state has devised "a special program that takes a three-pronged approach" to nurture the growth of high-technology business, said Caren S. Franzini, executive director of the autonomous development authority. The approach, she said, involves promoting New Jersey as a high-technology state, making real estate available to companies and now providing financing to them. The authority is administering the financing programs and, using public and private funds, is developing the technology center in North Brunswick.
"We recognize that these companies can become the Microsofts of tomorrow," said Gualberto Medina, commissioner of the state's Department of Commerce and Economic Development. "Creating a favorable environment is good for these businesses and good business for the state because it will create jobs." Providing financing is another step in that direction, he added.
Science and technology-related companies are considered a growth engine for the state, which ranks seventh in the nation in the number of high-technology jobs. In 1997, about 168,000 people were employed in technology-related business, ranging from telecommunications and electronics to biotechnology and pharmaceutical concerns, with a total payroll of $9.9 billion, according to the latest figures available from the Federal Department of Commerce. There were also 145,000 research and development employees working in 700 laboratories.
New Jersey's appeal to emerging firms in those industries is not surprising. It is home to such communication giants as AT&T and its spinoff Lucent Technology, as well as to the David Sarnoff Research Center, which conducts electronics research. They provide a strong resource for the over 5,000 electronics, software and information technology concerns already in the state.
And its large concentration of drug companies -- including Bristol-Myers Squibb and Merck, which produce at least 43 percent of the pharmaceuticals sold in the nation -- serve as a magnet for the 601 biotechnology, biomedical and health-care related firms that have sprung up here, says the New Jersey Technology Council, a Princeton-based nonprofit trade group.
The two recently initiated financing programs are expected to bridge "the gaps in the lending market" faced by these companies, which private lenders have viewed as risky because they lack the traditional "bricks and mortar collateral," said Ms. Franzini of the development authority. The programs are the result of discussions over the last year among state, industry, banking and academic leaders, she said.
To that end the authority, using its owns funds, which are derived from loan origination fees or interest income, will either provide loans itself, participate in or guarantee a portion of the loans secured from banks or do both. The programs are expected to assist 75 to 100 companies over the next few years, Ms. Franzini said.
The first company to take advantage of the Technology Funding Program is Price Systems, a software development and licensing business in Mount Laurel. Last year, the Lockheed Martin Company, its parent, wanted to sell the company and entertained bidders from other states that would have moved it out of New Jersey, said Anthony A. DeMarco, president of Price.
Instead, he and three other managers, using a $1.6 million state loan, purchased the assets of the business in July from Lockheed Martin. Mr. DeMarco said he would increase his New Jersey workforce, now at 26, by five to 10 employees a year for the next five years.
T HE goal of the management team was to retain as much equity and control of the company as possible," said Mr. DeMarco. Without the state loan, he said, that would have been difficult to do because while the company had "intellectual products, it had few of the tangible assets" banks traditionally look for when providing loans.
The Technology Funding Program, a joint effort of the authority and six commercial banks, is providing $100,000 to $3 million loans for up to 10 years to growing companies. To be eligible, companies must have, among other characteristics, a detailed business plan, a reasonable forecast of profit and licensing arrangements with or that it is selling to established companies.
Under the program the bank provides 70 to 75 percent of the loan at a market rate, and the authority gives the rest at a below-market fixed rate of 5 to 7 percent. If needed, the authority will also guarantee up to 50 percent of the bank's loan.
The blended interest rate lowers borrowing costs, Ms. Franzini said, while the shared financing reduces a bank's risk and leverages the authority's funds.
Bank executives agree.
"This gives banks the backing we need to get over the collateral issue," and makes the lending process "more palatable," said Christopher C. Giamo, a vice president at Commerce Bank, a lender based in Cherry Hill that was involved in the loan to Price Systems. He said the program will help stimulate more such loans.
Under the Seed Capital Program the authority, using $3 million of its own funds, provides loans of $25,000 to $200,000 to "first-stage companies." They are companies that, among other things, can demonstrate an ability to raise capital through investors, have a strong management team and have a product that exhibits a strong likelihood of commercialization. The loans are for five years and are at a fixed interest rate of 5 to 7 percent. Repayment terms will be flexible and varied and include royalties and warrants, Mr. Franzini said.
Last January Gov. Christine Todd Whitman also signed a package of bills into law, effective next Jan. 1, that will offer tax credits and tax incentives to technology-based businesses to help offset the costs of research and development. Prime among them is the technology business tax certificate transfer program, considered to be the first of its kind in the nation.
Under the program, to be administered by the Economic Development Authority, companies will be able to sell their unused net operating loss carryover and unused research and development tax credits to other businesses for at least 75 percent of their value. The selling company uses the proceeds of the sale of the tax benefits to help finance their growth within New Jersey, while the buying company uses the value of the benefits to reduce state taxes.
B Y freeing up more capital these companies, which live day-to-day, can breathe a sigh of relief," said Debbie Hart, executive director of the Biotechnology Council of New Jersey, a Trenton-based nonprofit trade group, referring to the financing programs. No one incentive is the panacea, she said, but added: "One-by-one the state is adding more tools to the arsenal to make it easier for companies to do business."
Providing affordable office and laboratory space at the Technology Center of New Jersey in North Brunswick is another way the state hopes to assure the future growth of high-technology companies. Construction began two and a half years ago at the center, which is designed to meet the needs of small and large research and development companies involved in biosciences, micro-electronics communications technologies and other pursuits. The 130,000 square feet of space in its four existing buildings has been fully leased to six companies employing more than 250 people.
Base rents at the center are $25 a square foot, which is 12 to 16 percent lower than the rent for comparable space in the area, said Thomas P. Sullivan, first vice president of the Iselin office of CB Richard Ellis, the national commercial brokerage, which is marketing the project. In addition, the Economic Development Authority offers financial assistance to help companies design and build their spaces, including tenant improvement allowances of up to $100 per square foot.
The 60,000-square-foot, one-story building now under construction, to be completed by next spring, could be divided into areas as small as 6,000 square feet, said Mr. Sullivan. Construction of the rest of the space will be driven by the market and include build-to-suit deals for specific tenants.

HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Calling Cadence for a Million

BYLINE: By ANDREA KANNAPELL 

 BODY:
I want you to listen to me," the voice boomed out across a Harlem street Tuesday afternoon. "I did not have sex with that woman, Miss Lewinsky."
Craig Muhammad paused and smiled to himself. Then he lifted the bullhorn back to his lips and said: "Don't listen to the lying Mayors and Presidents! Come hear a black man tell the truth. Saturday, Sept. 5, head for the hills. The youth are coming, right here to Malcolm X Boulevard." 
 Mr. Muhammad is a warm, friendly 33-year-old with a big brother's smile and a few gray hairs in his close-cut fade. A lifelong resident of northern New Jersey, he is the son of a lawyer and a nurse, the brother of an accountant. Since he was 19, he has been immersed in the Nation of Islam, the black self-determination movement often associated more with incendiary rhetoric than with the frustrations and concerns that motivate Mr. Muhammad.
Mr. Muhammad is also the head of New Jersey's Million Youth March committee. No small job: after months of leafletting, phoning and driving in car caravans papered with march posters in Newark, Paterson, Jersey City, East Orange, Orange, Plainfield, Elizabeth, Trenton and Camden -- as well as supportive visits to Harlem, like Tuesday's -- he says he optimistically expects somewhere between a quarter of a million and half a million marchers from New Jersey.
And, he thinks, not a minute too soon.
"We've been told, just get an education, go to school, and everything will be all right," he said. "Well, it's not turning out like that."
Mr. Muhammad started working on the march last year, sandwiching it between the classes he's taking to get a bachelor's degree in engineering. The march was born after the Million Man March, in Washington D.C. in 1995, and the Million Woman March, in Philadelphia last fall, each of which drew hundreds of thousands of people.
Despite the similar titles, the three events have separate organizers and goals. The Million Man March was the creation of Rev. Louis Farrakhan, the leader of the Nation of Islam, and was billed as a call for black men to reclaim their place in the family. The women's march was the work of local Philadelphia activists, most of whom were not associated with the Nation, and focused on solidifying families and experiencing their own strength in numbers.
The youth march is largely the work of Khalid Muhammad, a former lieutenant of Mr. Farrakhan who was dismissed after a 1993 speech that included anti-Semitic and other controversial remarks and who is still considered "distanced" from the Nation. So are Craig Muhammad and others who spent long years devoted to the Nation but who chose to work on the march.
The seriousness of the rift is a question: some black Muslims say Mr. Farrakhan, who has also been known to make anti-Semitic remarks, is just testing Khalid Muhammad, and will eventually hand over the leadership of the Nation to him. Craig Muhammad, who admires both men, dismisses the charges of anti-Semitism as beside the point. "We're not out there because we're concerned with Jews," he said. "We're out there because we're concerned about black and Latino youth."
The march plans were opposed by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, and the resulting tug-of-war has split Harlem, with some residents and much of the area's political establishment, like Representative Charles Rangel, denouncing the event as a "hate march." The organizers have been forced into court to fight for a march permit.
In any case, the march's mission is not only to bring together black and Latino youth (defined loosely, organizers say, as anywhere from 13 to 35 years old) for a lesson that "there's more to life than drinking and smoking and partying," according to Malik Zulu Shabazz, the march's national coordinator. The event, Mr. Shabazz said, is also meant as an exercise in organization that will leave in place a civil rights network -- the Black Power Organizing Committee.
Another goal, said the march's Washington organizer, Daniel Alec Runnels, is "to bring the next generation of leadership to the center stage."
For Craig Muhammad, the point of the march is to pick up where he believes the Civil Rights movement stopped: just short of addressing real economic and social disparities.
His awareness came early, back when he still went by the last name Smith. After the 1968 riots, his family moved from East Orange to Plainfield, and then in '79, when he was in his mid-teens, to an all-white neighborhood there, where the social world revolved around things he knew nothing about, like country clubs, social clubs, even, he said, the library.
"I saw just how really far apart the worlds were," Mr. Muhammad said. "We were not their social equals. It was like this: We were at the point where the whites could say, you can work with me, and you can live next to me. But we're still worlds apart."
While the neighbors went to prep schools, he attended Plainfield High, a public school. He got into fights, got expelled, did some drugs. And he kept wondering why black people were suffering. His grandfather had worked to desegregate schools along the Jersey Shore, which were some of the last in the northeast to hang onto racial enrollment. The struggle against apartheid in South Africa was becoming bloodier. Everywhere he looked, it seemed, he saw trouble. "There was a reason for it," he recalled thinking. "There had to be."
He sought answers, and began finding them in an unusual place. His barber was Keith Muhammad, an early follower of Louis Farrakhan.
Craig Muhammad said he remembered listening to his first Farrakhan speech, on tape. "I heard Minister Farrakhan break down the scriptures and relate it to black people's struggle in America," he said. "When I studied more, it all made perfect sense. I was like, wow. This is it! My search is over."
Keith Muhammad, the leader of a Nation of Islam mosque in Plainfield, said his new student flourished. "Because of his intelligence, he rose quickly through the ranks," he said, "and ultimately became a minister himself." In the process, Craig Smith became Craig X, losing what he calls his "slave name" and entering a new chapter of his life, eventually accepting from the Nation of Islam the last name Muhammad.
The teachings he has embraced include the beliefs that black people are divine by nature but behave badly because of circumstances and that white people are lesser descendants of black people, a reversed appropriation of the 19th century tenet that justified European colonialism. For Mr. Muhammad, the ideas are a way out of a cruelly limiting white-defined notion of what it means to be black. And the teachings stress that black people can uplift themselves only through their own efforts.
"It's time we get true freedom, justice and equality," he said. "I want to be able to drive down the turnpike and not be looking in my rearview mirror. I want to walk in a store and browse without people looking at me like I'm trying to steal something.
"There's a lot of factors about growing up black in America," he said, with a small, bitter laugh. "If I want to go buy a car, it takes 20 minutes for the salesperson to wait on me. A white person comes in, and they're all up in their face. With me, first thing, they run a credit check."
Mr. Muhammad never lost his historical understanding of World War II, and the Holocaust. "I'm not an idiot," he said. "I know it happened. And I realize Jews have suffered."
But he does see the events of World War II against a broader historical canvas: the deaths, which he numbers in the hundreds of millions, of enslaved Africans. "I really see there being a double standard," he said.
Between the organizing activities and doing enough construction work to pay his bills, Mr. Muhammad seems to have a life rich in purpose and in comrades, but one that has little time left for simple friendship.
DeLacy Davis, the founder of Black Cops Against Police Brutality, a New Jersey group that often works with the Nation of Islam, said he considered Mr. Muhammad a friend, but added: "In the black liberation world, or in the abolitionist world, as I prefer to call it, almost none of us socialize. It's a community based on principles, virtues and values. I have no desire to socialize. And it's safer for all of us if we keep ourselves diverse."
Mr. Muhammad chats easily with Cleve X, his captain, who serves as both assistant and bodyguard. But when Mr. Muhammad asks whether certain tasks were taken care of, Cleve X drops his conversational tone and makes sure the word "sir" peppers his answers.
Romantic relationships, too, are missing -- though Mr. Muhammad points out that his brother, Carl, the accountant, is also single. "I don't know what his problem is," he laughs. "I have a halfway flimsy excuse: I'm too busy."
At 8:30 P.M. on Tuesday, Craig Muhammad was wrapping up his day in Harlem at a march meeting, listening to Malik Shabazz address the audience of several hundred.
He had been more than 38 hours without sleep, and kept wiping his hand across his tired eyes. But when Mr. Shabazz lifted his fist at the end of his address and began chanting "Black Power" Mr. Muhammad's fist shot up too, and his voice lifted firmly in answer: "Black Power! Black Power! Black Power!"
 
Catching a Bus to the March
THE Million Youth March is scheduled for Saturday, Sept. 5. Craig Muhammad, the march organizer for New Jersey, says he expects the state to deliver the single largest parade contingent. (New York organizers agree.) He's hoping to put together a delegation of 250,000 to 500,000 people.
Buses will leaves from many college campuses and from Newark, Elizabeth, Jersey City, Camden, Trenton, East Orange, Plainfield and Asbury Park.
 People who need information about bus locations and fares should leave messages at (888) 832-8976 or (973) 510-5648, or call the march's New York office at (718) 398-1766.
The address for the march's website is www.millionyouthmarch.com.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Craig Muhammad flanked by Malik Zulu Shabazz, left, the national coordinator, and Talib Muhammad, another organizer. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1473 words

HEADLINE: Leather for the Car: A Rising Tide of Hides

BYLINE: By DAN NEIL 

 BODY:
AMERICAN drivers have had their flings with vinyl, their dalliances with synthetics and crushed velour. Now, they seem to have developed a fetish for leather.
Auto makers tripled their use of leather from 1982 to 1992, according to a trade group, Leather Industries of America. Demand doubled again in the next five years, and the trend is accelerating. American tanneries serving the auto industry buy 20 percent of the 36 million hides produced domestically. At roughly 45 square feet per cow, that's 58 square miles -- enough to upholster Manhattan two and a half times, with enough skin left over for headrests. 
 Once the schmaltzy offering of a few luxury import brands like Rolls-Royce and Jaguar, leather is now tres ordinaire on midpriced sedans like the Toyota Camry and even economy cars like the Chevrolet Cavalier, and practically de rigueur on high-end sport utilities and top-line pickup trucks.
"People in the 60's might have been in love with synthetics," said Philip D. Kaltenbacher, 60, chairman and chief executive of the Seaton Company, a big supplier of leather seats to car makers. "The buyers' generation of today has this profound love of natural materials, like cotton, wood, stone and particularly leather."
 Five years ago, fewer than 2 percent of Honda Accords were sold with leather trim; about 35 percent now have it. Roughly half of the Ford Explorers and Jeep Grand Cherokees sold have leather interiors, along with nearly all the Lincoln Navigators and Mercury Mountaineers, the Lexus LX 470's and RX 300's, the Mitsubishi Monteros and GMC Denalis.
In sheer acreage, sport utilities account for much of the increased demand. "S.U.V.'s use two to three times more leather than the average car," said Drew Winter, an analyst with Ward's Automotive Reports.
 Even proletarian pickup trucks are filled with the heady scent of leather. About 10 percent of pickups have leather interiors, which may not sound like much until you consider that full-size pickups "are the highest-volume vehicles in the market," Mr. Winter said, with annual sales of almost two million. "That's a lot of leather."
 It is also a lot of money. Big trucks and sport utilities -- the industry's cash cows, if you will -- have taken a drubbing over environmental issues, and leather executives are eager to seem green. "The last thing we want is people thinking we're burning down rain forests for cattle just to put leather in big sport-utes," said Jeffery Bonello, a spokesman for the Eagle Ottawa Leather Company of Grand Haven, Mich., the largest supplier of leather to auto makers. In fact, most of the world's $2 billion supply of auto leather comes from North America.
 Tanneries have their own bad press to live down. Anders Segerdahl, president and chief executive of Eagle Ottawa, remembers when the chromium-laced effluent from one of his plants turned the hulls of white fishing boats shades of red. But his company, with annual sales of about $500 million, is now recognized as a pioneer in environmentally friendly tanning.
 "Nobody has done as much to clean up the leather-making process," said Charlie Myers, president of Leather Industries of America. In 1991, Eagle Ottawa's Grand Haven tannery was the first to convert from solvent-based to water-based finishing processes. In 1993, the company completed an on-site waste-water treatment plant. For his efforts, Mr. Segerdahl received the Theodore Roosevelt Conservation Award in 1992 from President George Bush.
 These days, Eagle Ottawa is promoting its recyclable Phoenix leather, the first American automotive leather made without chromium. It is tanned with a vegetable extract made of Peruvian berries. (The exact kind is a closely held trade secret).
 Phoenix leather made its debut on the 1998 Volkswagen Passat, and though it is more expensive and trickier to process -- vegetable-tanned leathers tend to crack and discolor when subjected to intense sun, heat and cold -- it already exceeds vehicle recycling regulations anticipated in Europe.
Mr. Segerdahl, 74, learned his trade in the Old World, sorting hides in a 300-year-old tannery in Sweden, where his family's products included leather for buggy whips and Ford Model T's. He is also a footnote in the realm of kitsch culture, having coined "rich Corinthian leather," the catch phrase Ricardo Montalban trilled in the 1970's in commercials for the Chrysler Cordoba. "It was just a name we picked," Mr. Segerdahl said with a chuckle. "We thought it was funny when Montalban made it so famous."
 Mr. Montalban's seductive salesmanship lent an exotic touch to what was, in fact, a rather mundane type of embossed leather. Indeed, the Cordoba's interior wouldn't make the grade in today's marketplace of high-grade skins.
And while consumer expectations have soared, prices have remained relatively stable because of slackening demand in the domestic leather goods industry. In 20 years, for example, shoe production has fallen from 400 million pairs a year to 139 million.
Plenty of hides are available. While consumption of red meat -- the prime factor in the hide supply -- has declined in the United States and Europe, it has increased in Asia and the Pacific Rim. As a result, a slew of moderately priced cars can be had with newly affordable leather options. A leather package adds $895 to the sticker of a 1999 Mercury Cougar V6, or $795 to the Mercury Tracer LS Sport.
 Manufacturers can offer leather at the low end by making their cowhides go further. "If you look at the fine print on the sticker," said Mr. Myers of the leather industry group, "it may be a leather seating surface, but the entire interior of the car is not leather. Often the seat surrounds and backs are vinyl."
 The leasing boom has also raised demand. "When the salesman says, 'You know, for 10 bucks more a month you can have leather,' people go for it," Mr. Winter said.
And when the lease is up, leather often holds more of its original value than other add-ons. "When you consider usage and convenience it virtually pays for itself," said Tim Hippo, sales manager of Sir Walter Chevrolet in Raleigh, N.C.
 Such a statement might astound anyone who has tried to salvage the leather-lined insides of an old British sports car. Older leathers did not have much protective coating, and while they were softer, more aromatic and developed a lustrous patina through long use, they didn't look new for long. "In America, people want leather to wear like vinyl," said Don Brown, national product planning manager for Toyota.
 Manufacturers have mostly overcome the durability issue, but one problem remains. "Leather can be kind of boring, I guess," Mr. Brown said. "Designers are always looking for ways to add interest."
 The current generation of high-tech leather tries to recapture the feel of old-fashioned leather. These products can be coated, textured, perforated or embossed with a natural grain, or infused with a fragrance.
Mr. Segerdahl, dean of the industry, seems eager to face the next technical challenge and scorns retirement. "You know," he says, setting up the inevitable pun, "the business just gets under your skin."
 
Seeking Seats Without Skins
 
THE increasing use of leather in automobiles has come even as some fashion designers have turned away from leather, fur and other animal products. The designer Kenneth Cole recently introduced a line of leather-free shoes and belts.
Fashion and celebrity often travel hand in hand. Some music stars have gone out of their way to resist the ubiquitous use of leather in luxury vehicles, special-ordering their cars with prosaic cloth interiors.
"With leather seats, you're sitting on a lot of misery," said Dan Mathews, a spokesman for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals. Mr. Mathews noted that Paul and Linda McCartney typically custom-ordered their top-of-the-line Mercedes sedans with cloth seats, even though they had to wait weeks for delivery.
When a longtime animal rights activist, Kate Pierson, singer with the B-52's pop band, tried to buy a Mercedes ML320 sport utility last year, she couldn't find one with fabric upholstery and the premium sound system she wanted. The dealership in New Jersey told her it would take 10 months to custom-build an ML320 with cloth seats and the high-line audio equipment.
"I just wanted the options without the leather, and it seems like you can't do that," Ms. Pierson said in an interview.
Mercedes is by no means alone. Cloth interiors are either unavailable or require a special order in top-of-the-line cars from manufacturers like BMW, Lexus and Jaguar. In lesser models, leather is grouped with other popular features. "They call it the 'Leather Package,' " Ms. Pierson said. "Can you imagine that? What if they had the 'Fur Package'?" DAN NEIL

HEADLINE: Inspector Says He May Test Iraqi Resolve On Arms Sites

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The chief United Nations arms inspector for Iraq, Richard Butler, warned today that he might soon test Baghdad's resolve to block further weapons inspections by sending his team to examine a new site.
"I do not rule this out," said Mr. Butler, the Australian diplomat who heads the United Nations Special Commission, or Unscom, which is charged with eliminating Iraq's weapons of mass destruction. "We have plenty of interesting information, and it is I who decide when to launch an inspection." 
 The arms inspectors must certify that Iraq has destroyed its long-range missiles and chemical, biological and nuclear weapons before the Security Council will lift economic sanctions imposed in 1990 after Iraq invaded Kuwait, touching off the 1991 Persian Gulf war.
"If the Iraqis block us then obviously we can't do the inspection," Mr. Butler continued in an interview, adding, "but I simply don't know what the Security Council would do then."
Last Monday, the Security Council called Iraq's refusal to allow the inspectors to visit new sites "totally unacceptable" and instructed the inspectors to continue their work. But it studiously avoided making any new threats against Iraq or saying what it would do if the inspectors were stopped.
In an article on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times that day, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said that the commission had planned "some particularly intrusive inspections" this month, which Mr. Butler, consulting with her, canceled after Iraq broke off cooperation with the inspectors.
"Some in the Security Council would have muddied the waters by claiming again that Unscom had provoked Iraq," the Secretary of State wrote.
But a fresh standoff now between Iraq and the arms inspectors would increase the pressure on the Security Council to acknowledge that its orders are being flouted and to decide on a suitable reaction.
Many diplomats here have noted the contrast between the Clinton Administration's willingness to use force against terrorist organizations in Afghanistan and the Sudan this week and its reluctance to threaten any similar action against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
Since Aug. 5, when Iraq said it would no longer allow the inspectors to visit new sites, the 100-member United Nations inspection team has been confined to monitoring those it has already inspected to insure that they are not used for making prohibited weapons again.
Mr. Butler said he expected Iraq to begin a new vilification campaign against him and his commission on Monday when the United Nations mediator in Iraq, Prakash Shah of India, briefs the Council on his unsuccessful efforts to persuade Iraq to resume cooperation with the inspectors.
"We fully expect a stepped-up campaign in the Baghdad press and from senior officials, accusing us of being American stooges responsible for all the suffering of the Iraqi people," he said.
"They have done it before and they will do it again. The aim is simply to create a smoke screen around their refusal to cooperate or to give me the information I asked for."
Mr. Butler said that on four occasions in 1997 and 1998, independent teams of experts from as many as 15 countries examined Iraq's account of its biological weapons program and pronounced it "not even remotely credible."
He pointed out that for the first four years after the gulf war, Iraq denied having developed any biological weapons at all, only admitting that it sought to produce them in 1995.
Similarly, in the chemical weapons field, Mr. Butler said Iraq began by admitting to having made only 200 liters of the deadly nerve agent known as VX, which proved unstable and could therefore never be used in weapons.
But in fact, he said, the Special Commission has now established that Iraq manufactured some 3,900 liters of VX. Inside broken bomb casings, it has also found traces of both VX and the chemical used to stabilize it, which shows that Iraq did develop VX weapons.
Finally, Mr. Butler said he suspected that Iraq might be modifying its Volga and Al Samoud missiles to give them a range of more than 150 kilometers, about 95 miles, which is prohibited by the Security Council.
"When I asked them to stop," he said, "they refused and said I could monitor the missiles. But what chance is there of successful monitoring when they've suspended cooperation?"

SECTION: Section 3; Page 6; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1280 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: C. Beth Cotner;
Putnam Investors Fund

BYLINE: By WILLIAM R. LONG 

 BODY:
WHEN to sell is an anxiously asked question in a jittery stock market. C. Beth Cotner offers some answers.
Ms. Cotner, lead manager of the Putnam Investors fund, imposes a "trim discipline" for fast-growing stocks: If a holding goes up 10 percent or at more than twice the market rate within 10 days, she trims her position by 10 percent, thus locking in some profit. 
 "A lot of times when stocks go up quickly it's because there's very positive news or positive developments that investors get euphoric about," she said, "and then later on, the euphoria wears off or something happens so the stock comes back down again."
On occasion, she buys back trimmed shares after the price has declined.
Such practices have helped make Putnam Investors a strong performer during her tenure. The fund -- categorized as a large-capitalization growth fund -- returned 18.59 percent for the 12 months ended Thursday, surpassing the 16.79 percent average of its peer group, according to Morningstar Inc., the financial publisher in Chicago. And the fund has narrowly outperformed the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index over the last three years and five years.
Started in December 1925, Putnam Investors is one of the three oldest open-end funds in the country. It has assets of $4.5 billion. Ms. Cotner, 45, has been lead manager since the end of September 1995; she previously managed mutual funds at Kemper Financial Services.
 THE fund's management team uses quantitative screening with a point system to find attractive stocks.
A computer model developed by Putnam Investments, based in Boston, scores companies on a 1-to-5 scale in each of five categories: potential earnings surprises, earnings revisions, cash-flow reinvestment, dividend yield and sales-to-price valuation.
Combining the category scores gives a company a composite score of 1 to 5, and a stock with a 1 or a 2 merits further study.
"When we've back-tested our model, 1's and 2's have consistently outperformed the market," while 5's have underperformed, Ms. Cotner said.
Then comes fundamental research -- visiting the companies, their suppliers and their competitors, then putting together extensive five-year earnings and cash-flow models.
Ms. Cotner said she discussed all buying decisions with the fund's co-managers, Richard B. England and Manuel H. Weiss.
"If there's a controversial issue, we try to assign someone to be the devil's advocate," Ms. Cotner said. No miracles are required for a stock to make the portfolio, she added, but "we try to reach the right decision, not just one that seems to be easy to reach."
Once a stock is in the portfolio, the three managers continually review its financial and management fundamentals. If there is a basic problem, or a company is likely to miss earnings targets, Ms. Cotner said, "we'll eliminate the whole position."
Or, when a company is doing well and its share price is growing, "we'll trim the stock, if it just gets to be too large as a percentage of the overall portfolio," she said. The co-managers rebalance the portfolio each quarter.
For example, "we would trim back something like Microsoft to 3 percent," Ms. Cotner said. "If we just let it ride all the time and it never hit the trim discipline, it might just gradually over time grow to be 10 percent of the portfolio, and that's too big."
Using their quantitative scoring program, the co-managers rescreen the portfolio's stocks daily, immediately looking into any that have fallen to a 4 or 5.
"If it remains a 4 more than a week or two, it triggers a sell decision on our part, and by the time it gets to a 5, it's gone from the portfolio," she said.
Growth stocks tend to do better than value stocks under current economic conditions, with a slowing economy and stable interest rates, Ms. Cotner said, but she acknowledged that because of its growth bias, Putnam Investors tends to be slightly more volatile than the benchmark S.& P. 500 and could underperform in a down market.
 FINDING stocks that would weather a bear market is not easy, she said. The best bets might include drug chains and grocery chains, "areas that are relatively immune" from economic or political events, she said.
Among these groups, Putnam Investors has stakes in Safeway Inc., the Walgreen Company and the CVS Corporation.
CVS, the nation's No. 2 pharmacy chain, after Walgreen, has been expanding rapidly through acquisitions and now has more than 4,000 stores.
In 1997 it merged with Revco, which had more than 2,500 stores, and this year it bought Arbor, a Michigan chain with more than 200 stores.
"They get a lot of their sales through filling prescription drugs," Ms. Cotner said.
Thanks to the aging population and recent approvals of new drugs like Viagra, "prescription drugs are growing very rapidly," she said, adding that "drugs are taken no matter whether the economy is strong or weak."
CVS is also good at merchandising in the other parts of its stores, she said, adding, "They have been able to go into the newly acquired stores and ramp up their product offerings in what's called the front end of the store."
Ms. Cotner predicted that CVS earnings would grow 18 percent this year and again next year. Putnam Investors bought the stock, which is now trading at $44.25, at $22 more than two years ago. She expects the stock to reach $57 in 12 months.
Another retailer that Ms. Cotner likes is Wal-Mart Stores. It has been improving its systems by allowing stores to cut prices to meet local competition and to manage in-store inventories more efficiently. Putnam Investors started buying Wal-Mart stock in spring 1997 at about $28 a share, and it continued to buy over the last year, for an average cost of about $40, Ms. Cotner said. The stock ended last week at $65.1875.
A year from now, the price could be $75, she estimated.
The No. 1 holding in Ms. Cotner's fund is Tyco International, a holding company with a market capitalization of about $35 billion and subsidiaries that offer disposable medical and specialty products, fire and security services, flow-control supplies and equipment, electrical and electronic components and underwater telecommunications systems.
Tyco announced in May that it was buying the U.S. Surgical Corporation, a medical products company, in a $3.3 billion stock trade. That and other acquisitions, Ms. Cotner said, are expected to raise the company's earnings.
"Basically, their strategy is to buy the company," Ms. Cotner said. "They cut costs quickly in the first year, and then they build the businesses in the second, third and fourth years so that not only do they get cost-cuttings, but they get growth."
Tyco is expected to earn $2 a share for the fiscal year ending in September, up about 40 percent, and for the next year she foresees $2.65, up about 33 percent.
Her fund bought Tyco early last year "at around 30," she said. In Putnam's last S.E.C. filing in January, Tyco accounted for 2.1 percent of assets. A spokesman said the fund had since built up the position, but declined to say how much. Tyco is now trading at $59, and Ms. Cotner predicted that it would reach about $80 in 12 months.
Such predictions, of course, are based on the assumption that a particular stock's gains will not be wiped out by the treacherous currents of a volatile stock market. But the thought does cross Ms. Cotner's mind.
She spent her childhood in Crescent City, a usually tranquil spot on the coast of Northern California, where a tidal wave struck in 1961. "A lot of houses there got wiped out -- a lot of casualties," she said. "Maybe you can tie that in to the tidal wave of today's market."
