HEADLINE: Ministers Call for Prayer After Clinton Admission

 BODY:
President Clinton's acknowledgment of an inappropriate relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky was a focus of sermons in churches around the nation yesterday. Following are excerpts from several sermons, as recorded and transcribed by The New York Times.
 
'We Are Not Quite Sure Where It Will Take Us'
The Rev. Richard Manzelmann
Cornwall Congregational Church
Cornwall, Vt.
There were some sad and revealing confessions by the President of these United States. Some may be glad, I suppose, but others may well be a bit shaken by it. I don't suppose we were really very surprised by these confessions, but had hoped against hope that it wasn't so. And we are not quite sure where it will take us. . . . 
 There are texts about forgiveness which some may want to think about. And there are texts which bring it home to us as well. Paul says quite clearly, "We all fall short." . . .
And Jesus, who never wants us to be too hasty with our judgments, said, "Do not judge so that you may not be judged yourself. For with the judgment you make you will be judged, and the measure you give may be the measure you get." The words may sting a bit. Well, He makes it come home, doesn't He? Not just there, but here. It's endless. It makes us mad. It makes us sad. We are tired of it. Let us get on with our life together. There are other, more frightening things to worry about.
 
'Whatever the Loss,' There Can Be an End to Grieving
The Rev. Hardy S. Clemons
First Baptist Church
Greenville, S.C.
The sermon was based on I Samuel 16:1-3, in which Samuel anoints David to lead Israel after rejecting many other men deemed unsuitable.
Sometimes we never know the answer to our grief will take until we've gone all the way through the valley and the shadow of death, but for Samuel in this case, he did find an answer to the grief that was debilitating him.
Of course, we are aware that Israel is not the only nation that has grieved over a tall, handsome, brilliant, powerful leader and his struggles with character and sin. We know something about that kind of national grief as well.
I cannot speak for you. I can tell you about my hurt, my anger, my sorrow, my incredulous unbelief at what we have experienced in these last days, but I'm not here to talk about that situation, I'm here to say that whatever the loss that occasions grief, there can be an end to grieving. This is our hope as believers. . . .
If grief is ever going to end it will end when you learn you've got to do it badly before you do it well. I think we see that to some extent with Mr. Clinton this week. All sorts of reactions have come forward about what he should have said and what he shouldn't have said. I would love to have been a consultant to him in the writing of that speech. I believe I could have helped him if he would have let me.
But I also came away from that speech with a genuine respect for a man who will get up, having looked the nation in the eye and lied, who looked in our eyes and said, "What I did was not only inappropriate, it was wrong." And if he didn't do it to my satisfaction, I don't think that's as important as that he did do it.
And I would invite you to apply that to whatever grief you may be struggling with in your own experience, related to illness, related to death, related to some other disappointment or loss. It is very important to do it badly in order to learn to do it well. Grief will last long enough for us to learn that.
 
'Not Judging,' Yet Seeing 'A Very Painful Truth'
The Very Rev. Nathan D. Baxter
Washington National Cathedral
We may yet have legitimate suspicions about the political motive of the endless investigations. However, we can no longer deny that the haunting shadows we have dreaded are indeed much more the sad reflections of a soul we would love, than the projections of a partisan body politic which would assault it. . . .
Now Jesus taught, "Judge not that ye be not judged." And I know all too well the truth in St. Paul's words where he says "that all have sinned, you and I, and fallen short of God's glory." But this is not judging, it is acknowledging a very painful truth. I still believe Mr. Clinton loves his country and I know that he loves his family, and I know that he loves his God. And I know that God loves him. But our desire to keep sin private or ignore immorality is a judgment upon all of us. Unless we acknowledge moral failing -- without excuse -- the soul of our nation will not heal. I believe, more importantly, our children will be even more confused as to whether the truest treasure of our common life as a nation is found in the state of the economy or the character of our moral integrity. . . .
I still believe that there is a social agreement in human society, among the children of Eve and Adam. A standard which is often abused but is still the barometer of our moral life, and that is modesty. We do expect, including in our sexual matters, responsible behavior, self-control and respect for the sensitivities of others. People of faith understand that this commitment is not just moral but it is also holy -- it is blessed of God. Responsibility, self-control and respect. This is modesty, our moral contract as a community.
The contract of modesty belongs in business, it belongs in religion, it belongs in law, and in the social sector, just as it does in politics. But we often wink at its abuse in politics because we say politics is about the negotiating of power, and therefore we believe that politics by nature is dirty work. But I know some very fine politicians, and they remind me that politics is also about stewardship. It is about the stewardship of values.
Ultimately what should make us respect leaders in a democracy is not simply intelligence, or charisma, or competence with power, ideology or any professional skill or native gift. The most important characteristic of leadership in a democracy is the ability to demonstrate accountable character, morally accountable character. Ultimately, the real power of politics is moral.
 
'It Is Appropriate for Us To Come Together in Prayer'
Dr. J. Kie Bowman
Hyde Park Baptist Church
Austin, Tex.
This has been an interesting week, a challenging time in our country. Our President is involved in a personal scandal that could end up disgracing the personal office of the President. This puts us at risk as a nation. Therefore it is appropriate for us to come together in prayer.
As de Tocqueville told us, America is great because America is good. And he said that America will only continue to be great only as long as it is good. Today, we need to pray for this nation. . . .
Lord, we lift our President before you today. As I Timothy Chapter 2 tells us, we are to pray for our leaders. So Lord, I lift the President of our country before you. Give him moral courage and give him wisdom.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "Unless we acknowledge moral failing -- without excuse -- the soul of our nation will not heal," the Very Rev. Nathan Baxter, left, said yesterday at the Washington National Cathedral. (Photographs by Justin Lane for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: SHAKE-UP IN RUSSIA: THE U.S. REACTION;
Despite Confusion, Clinton Will Keep Date With Yeltsin

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Senior Clinton Administration officials said today that they were troubled by President Boris N. Yeltsin's decision to dismiss his reformist Cabinet so close to the summit meeting with President Clinton next week in Moscow. But a spokesman said Mr. Clinton had decided to go ahead with his trip.
Officials acknowledged that they were taken by surprise by the move, which also reinstated the former Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin. Five months ago, Mr. Yeltsin dismissed Mr. Chernomyrdin without warning and installed the young Sergei V. Kiriyenko as Prime Minister with a Cabinet of economic reformers with no evident political constituency. 
 "This won't affect the trip or the timing of the summit at all," said P. J. Crowley, a White House spokesman. "We have important bilateral issues. This is an internal Russian matter and we obviously will watch it closely. We will continue to work with the Russian Government to advance the reform agenda. What faces Acting Prime Minister Chernomyrdin is the need to take effective steps to address Russia's economic difficulties."
Asked whether Mr. Yeltsin's action raised doubts about his control and stability, one official said, "It depends on your starting point." Senior officials say that Mr. Yeltsin has "his ups and downs," and that he has never regained the stamina and focus he displayed before his heart attack at the end of the 1996 presidential campaign.
"He can get up for a big meeting or telephone call with Clinton," one official said. "But it's not clear he can work for more than a few hours at a time."
While Mr. Clinton did not try to reach Mr. Yeltsin today by telephone, Vice President Al Gore spoke with both Mr. Kiriyenko and Mr. Chernomyrdin, who is closer to Mr. Gore than to any other American official. Mr. Gore tried to gauge the political climate before Mr. Clinton arrives in Moscow on Sept. 1, and to ask how Washington can help calm markets.
"Gore's purpose was to urge a continuation of the policies of economic reform," a senior White House official said. "Chernomyrdin has demonstrated in the past that he's more of a reformer than many people thought, and he has a lot more support in the Duma," the Russian Parliament, which has been blocking reforms demanded by the International Monetary Fund.
The official said it was inappropriate for Mr. Gore to raise the question of postponing the summit talks. Another official said, "It would be a great mistake for us to pull the plug."
But some prominent and experienced voices outside the Government urged postponement and expressed concern over the apparent American policy of supporting Mr. Yeltsin no matter what he does.
Zbigniew Brzezinski, the national security adviser for President Jimmy Carter, called on Mr. Clinton to postpone the talks for a month or more.
"There is no point for a bleeding President to be visiting a sick and unstable President," Mr. Brzezinski said in an interview. "I think a postponement would be very good for both sides. Under the circumstances it will be very difficult for Clinton to concentrate on long-range issues, and they need to be discussed by leaders able to make their policies stick. Right now it will be a summit of posturing and pretense on both sides. And the United States and Russia need serious, useful summits."
Mr. Brzezinski said it was clear that Mr. Yeltsin "is passing from the scene," and he urged the Administration to "reach out and establish a dialogue with other leaders," including Moscow's Mayor, Yuri Luzhkov; the former general Aleksandr Lebed, now a governor in Siberia; the economic reformer and Yeltsin critic Grigory Yavlinsky, and the Communist Party leader, Gennadi Zyuganov.
"We ought to very clearly and deliberately get off the 'My dear friend, Boris' kick," Mr. Brzezinski said. "Yeltsin governs at most a perimeter of 30 kilometers outside Moscow, and even that is not under his full control."
American officials said that Mr. Clinton plans to meet opposition and Parliament leaders on Sept. 2 in Moscow, and that all the men Mr. Brzezinski named were invited.
The return of Mr. Chernomyrdin, Mr. Brzezinski said, "begins to turn a tragic situation into a farce." Mr. Chernomyrdin's return had been pressed on Mr. Yeltsin for some time by the Russian economic oligarchy, in particular by Boris Berezovsky, who once served as Mr. Yeltsin's national security adviser.
The oligarchs stand to lose a lot of money because of the devaluation of the ruble last week -- which Mr. Yeltsin insisted would never happen and which Mr. Kiriyenko carried out anyway. "We now have what we might call a provisional oligarchical Government," Mr. Brzezinski said.
Anders Aslund, a former economic adviser to the Russian Government and now with the Carnegie Endowment, described the Yeltsin move as a disaster.
"It means Yeltsin is finished, it makes him look like a puppet, and Russians can't stand weak leaders," Mr. Aslund said. "This really puts Clinton in an awful situation. You don't want to go to a country where there is so much uncertainty in the Government."
The reversion to the stolid Mr. Chernomyrdin will not please the markets, Mr. Aslund said. "Chernomyrdin is the man who ran Russia into its big economic troubles, and the oligarchs are very happy to have him back," he said. "It won't provide confidence to the markets."
A senior American official said market confidence was Mr. Gore's theme with Mr. Chernomyrdin, especially with key Parliament sessions coming. "We'll find out this week if the shift of authority leads to any noteworthy changes of emphasis in the Russian economic plan and in the level of support the Duma is willing to provide," the official said. "The market reaction will be very significant."
Dimitri Simes, president of the Nixon Center, a Washington-based think tank, said Mr. Kiriyenko's Government was too narrow and too liberal, "uninterested in dialogue with the Duma and contemptuous of public opinion and attitudes."
Mr. Chernomyrdin, for all his faults, has demonstrated his support among foreign investors and in the Parliament, where he controls the second-largest faction, Mr. Simes said.
In general the Clinton Administration seemed to fumble for a response this August Sunday, with the President at Martha's Vineyard, some top advisers at the beach and others at home in Washington trying to recover from a stressful week.
The national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger; Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, and Defense Secretary William S. Cohen were all on Sunday talk shows, but their interviews had been taped before the news came out of Russia.
Until this latest shock from Moscow, senior Administration officials were minimizing the risks to Mr. Yeltsin and his Government of the economic upheavals, which officials attributed largely to the Asian crisis and the softness of oil prices.
Still, senior Treasury officials were not prepared to provide Russia any more money after the failure of the last I.M.F. loan package of only a month ago, which sent $4.8 billion to Moscow as part of a $22.6 billion package.
And senior State Department and White House officials were very angry with Mr. Yeltsin's sharply critical comments after the American missile strikes last week against targets in Afghanistan and the Sudan. Mr. Yeltsin, perhaps for domestic advantage, was harsh in his reactions, criticizing Washington for not consulting him and not working through the United Nations Security Council.
To American leaders who felt they were acting with urgency to protect more American lives, Mr. Yeltsin's comments were "offensive," one official said, "and went over very badly around here."

HEADLINE: How Routine Parade Application Set Off Harlem Political Tempest

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
In late January, New York City received two applications from a nonprofit organization in Washington seeking permission to stage a "First Amendment Educational Event."
In one sense, the applications were routine if somewhat unclear, representing only two of the tens of thousands of requests that the city receives every year for block parties, parades and street fairs. In another sense, the two pieces of paper were the bureaucratic equivalent to kindling; in the months to come, they would pit an out-of-town black nationalist who spouts anti-Semitism with a smile against an outspoken white mayor with few ties to the city's black leadership. 
 Now, Khalid Abdul Muhammad -- best known for his anti-white diatribes -- has charged in a lawsuit filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan that the discriminatory policies of the Giuliani administration prompted it to deny his application for a Million Youth March in Harlem on Sept. 5, the Saturday of the hectic Labor Day weekend.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, meanwhile, has alternated between keeping his counsel and denouncing the event as a poorly planned "hate march" that his aides expect will take place in some form, permit or no permit.
Caught in the middle of this race-tinged quarrel is the community of Harlem, whose leaders are now bracing for an event that several of them never wanted. Some criticize Mr. Muhammad for promoting an event that couples, however subtly, the instructive message of black-youth empowerment with destructive messages of intolerance. They also say that for all his talk of black unity, he was woefully late in sharing his plans with most of Harlem.
"Let me get this straight," said Bill Perkins, the City Council member from Harlem. "You're going to have a party in my house and you don't even tell me about it?"
At the same time, several leaders say Mr. Giuliani has used harsh, simplistic language to describe an event that also stresses pride among blacks and loving guidance for their young. The Mayor can afford to generalize, they say, because most of his political support comes from whites and conservatives, far from the streets of Harlem.
These leaders say many people may participate in anti-Giuliani protest rather than in pro-Muhammad support. After all, they argue, Mr. Muhammad has neither the appeal nor the money to stage a significant event -- especially when another, better-organized event for the country's black youths is being held in Atlanta on the same weekend.
"I can't think of any individual who has been more deliberately destructive than Khalid Muhammad, but what separates him from just being a racist is that his statements are all calculated to evoke a reaction," said David A. Paterson, the State Senator from Harlem. "And he tried to use inflammatory language to dupe Mayor Giuliani into attacking him. And since Giuliani is an unpopular person in the African-American community, he then comes back to the community and plays himself off as a martyr, an Adam Powell who is being attacked, or a Malcolm X. He disguises himself as the current-day Adam or Malcolm, when in fact he's a cheap carbon copy."
In the end, Mr. Paterson said, the Mayor "gave the marchers what they wanted."
In dismissing such opinions as "absurd" on Saturday, Mr. Giuliani used the very language that makes some Harlem leaders cringe. "We either had to just ignore it and pretend that a person who has engaged in the worst kind of rhetoric about Jews, about whites, about Catholics, about the Pope -- that he should be allowed to carry a banner leading a lot of children. Or we could say something about it, which we did."
Mr. Giuliani's aides leave the First Amendment implications of blocking the march to be discussed in court, with the next hearing scheduled for Wednesday. But they maintain that the administration has wisely handled one of the most delicate and potentially volatile predicaments that a municipality can face.
As for the Mayor's occasional comments, Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington said New York City was more than just Harlem; there are Jews, Roman Catholics, gay men and lesbians -- all concerned with the message of Khalid Muhammad.
"They want to know that the leader of this city is focused," he said. "They want to hear what he's thinking."
At first, no one knew what to think, in part because Mr. Muhammad's plans kept changing. In the applications filed in January, his aides requested the date of Sept. 19, not Sept. 5; they now say they want to reach young people before schools and colleges reopen. One request asked for Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn; the other asked for Malcolm X Boulevard in Harlem. In a third request, to the Parks Department, organizers had also asked for Central Park, Randalls Island "or street."
If Mr. Muhammad's intentions were unclear, his history was not. The man behind the applications is so virulent in his anti-Semitic, anti-white speeches that he managed to annoy Louis Farrakhan, the minister of the Nation of Islam who has also been known to make anti-Semitic remarks. Since being ousted from the Nation of Islam hierarchy in 1994, Mr. Muhammad has become a college-campus attraction who commonly refers to Jews as "bloodsuckers" and "hook-nosed."
According to Mr. Washington, the Deputy Mayor for Community Development and Business Services, the discussions between the city and the organizers began poorly and got worse.
At first, Mr. Muhammad wanted to stage the event on Fifth Avenue, and then on Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn -- both of which the city refused. The city countered with Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx or Randalls Island, on Sept. 19 -- all of which the organizers refused.
In late May or early June, Mr. Muhammad told the city that the march would take place in Harlem over the Labor Day weekend. City officials explained that more than 100 permits had already been granted for activities in Harlem for that weekend, that the days-before-school sales of local businesses would be disrupted, that the police for the holiday weekend were already taxed.
"Basically, he tells us what he's going to do," Mr. Washington recalled, "against the will of the city, without permits." He added, "They virtually hijacked the community."
Malik Shabazz, a lawyer from Washington and a close aide of Mr. Muhammad's, said the organizers had become frustrated with what they perceived to be an institutional thwarting of their rights to free speech. "Essentially, they were trying to derail the process," he said.
By early July, Harlem's leaders had learned that an event called the Million Youth March was probably coming to their neighborhood. They also learned that both the city and the organizers had been discussing this possibility for weeks. Mr. Paterson and Mr. Perkins were among those not placated by a visit from an emissary of the Mayor's -- in this case, Mr. Washington -- to explain the situation.
"Some of us felt that they're calling on us to deal with this, but when we have other issues -- youth issues or other concerns -- we don't get the calls back," Mr. Perkins said. "But overriding that was the sense of responsibility that this was taking place in our neighborhood. And regardless of the poor behavior of the Mayor, we had a responsibility to deal with it."
Mr. Washington dismissed those concerns, saying that notification a few days earlier would not have changed the dynamics. And there was another factor. "The Giuliani administration doesn't negotiate by consensus," he said. "They're legislators. They don't run programs, they don't operate the city, with all due respect to them. Never do we call people and ask for their advice and tell us what to do."
Mr. Paterson said that attitude was both typical and self-defeating. "No one is denying that he's excellent in lowering the crime rate and being the catalyst for business and economic development," he said of the Mayor. "Black people are affected by that too. But he comes to the table with such a negative understanding of how black people feel: 'They're not going to support me, so I'm not going to pay attention to their concerns.' "
Mr. Paterson and others say most of Harlem learned of the planned event not from its organizers but from news reports of the increasingly antagonistic quarrel between Mr. Muhammad and Mr. Giuliani.
Mr. Muhammad seized the media attention to share a view of a world that he sees as dominated by Jews -- New York is a "Jewish-controlled city," for example -- and to issue thinly veiled threats of what might happen if the city did not relent, threats that seemed to contradict his purported message of nonviolence. He reminisced about bringing 50 armed followers to a Ku Klux Klan rally in Jasper, Tex., in June, and threatened to lead an angry march, including gang members, through the Jewish neighborhood of Crown Heights in Brooklyn.
"We have radical revolutionary youth who will be coming here," he said, "who will be quite ready and quite prepared in the numbers of hundreds and thousands and millions to fight this devil in the streets."
Mr. Giuliani called Mr. Muhammad a hatemonger -- correctly, Mr. Paterson said. But he said Mr. Giuliani had coupled that condemnation with the denial of the march permit, allowing critics to contend that the strong-willed Mayor was violating constitutional rights to block yet another message he found offensive.
Then last week, a critic from the Mayor's past surfaced to further complicate a tense situation. The Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, a prominent Baptist minister who was criticized earlier this year for calling Mr. Giuliani a racist, expressed his support for the march, but not for Mr. Muhammad. The Mayor, who had previously allowed aides to speak for him in denouncing the minister's racism charge, now seized the opportunity to respond.
"You may have forgotten, but I don't, the hate language he used in reference to me," Mr. Giuliani said last Thursday. "So I would expect that he would naturally gravitate toward a march that engages in this kind of hate rhetoric against Jews, against other people."
Mr. Paterson, Mr. Perkins, and others in Harlem saw the Mayor's remarks as gratuitous and inflammatory. Mr. Perkins said he immediately told Deputy Mayor Washington to deliver a message: "Tell him to please shut up. Now, you put it to him the way you think appropriate."
It is not known where this fight over the rights to a Saturday in Harlem will lead. Although most agree that a Million Youth March would not attract a million people -- organizers predict about 150,000, while city officials expect a much smaller number -- there remain many questions.
If Mr. Muhammad receives a permit, does he have the money to pay for the insurance, portable toilets, security details and other costs of holding a street event? Will the entertainers being touted as participants actually attend? If he marches without a permit, how many will join him? How will the city respond? And, last, could the city have better handled this challenge?
Charles B. Rangel, the Harlem Congressman and an early critic of Mr. Muhammad, declined to respond to the last question. He said his time and thoughts would be better spent on joining others in preparing Harlem for the unknown.
"It's a very sensitive thing," he said.

HEADLINE: Shift in Politics And Economics Seen for Hawaii

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Aug. 23

 BODY:
For the last seven years, Hawaii has felt the winds of economic change blowing only one way across the Pacific Ocean.
While most of the country has prospered, enjoying job growth, state budget surpluses and contented citizenry -- all to the benefit of many political incumbents facing re-election this year -- Hawaii remains a stubborn exception. 
 Here, despite the spectacular vistas of ocean, mountains and lava fields that make tourism the backbone of the state economy, turmoil in Asian financial markets has rocked the islands like an unrelenting hurricane, causing a sharp decline in investment, minimal growth in tourism, job loss and public pessimism. Hawaii's annual economic growth rate in recent years, half of a percent, pales beside a national rate that has reached as high as 3.9 percent.
In recent weeks, economists have detected slight indications that the worst may have passed and that Hawaii could finally be turning a corner -- much to the relief of Gov. Benjamin J. Cayetano, the latest in an unbroken line of Democratic governors since Hawaii joined the union in 1959. Upon his election in 1994, he inherited the worst fiscal crisis in state history, and now that the budget has been balanced for two years, he is trumpeting his policies as a reason to re-elect him in November.
But Mr. Cayetano, the nation's first Filipino-American Governor, may yet become just another victim of the Asian crisis.
As if the stars over Hawaii's sparkling beaches and pristine waters have suddenly realigned, a Republican, Mayor Linda Lingle of Maui, is favored to defeat him in November, according to the latest statewide polls. How startling is that? Among the 76 members of the State Legislature, only 14 are Republicans, and across Hawaii, Republicans are outnumbered by such a wide margin that some say they are embarrassed or reluctant to admit their affiliation.
Nonetheless, the enduring sluggishness of the economy seems to be pushing many people beyond a point where party loyalty determines their vote, and after four decades of Democratic rule, the state's 1.2 million people might finally be in for a change.
"There is a growing sense here that Hawaii has become a little like the old Soviet Union or North Korea with its centralized, absolute power," said Randy Roth, a law professor at the University of Hawaii on the island of Oahu and president-elect of the state bar association. "Monopoly of political power has cut off all debate, and that has evolved into the political culture."
Mr. Roth, whose nonpartisanship allowed him to moderate a local radio talk show for five years, became so impressed with Ms. Lingle that he abandoned his neutrality last week to join the campaign as a volunteer.
Economic policy and one-party rule were never major concerns in Hawaii until the collapse of the Japanese yen in the early 1990's ended years of heavy investment by Japanese banks. The economic activity had become so frenetic and dazzling that Cayetano officials now concede that it stunted any creative planning by the previous administration of Gov. John D. Waihee 3d.
"This was a boom period, and government wanted to stay in control," said Seija Naya, a former bank economist who is director of the state's Department of Business, Economic Development and Tourism. "They added more regulations, charged more fees and made it harder for businesses to receive approvals."
The Japanese investors barely noticed. Then the bubble burst, and recession set in. Since 1991, many hotels and businesses built with Japanese money have sold for a fraction of their original cost. And no longer do Asian investors knock on the doors of fancy homes and offer the owner $1 million or more to sell on the spot.
The Asian withdrawal overshadowed other disturbing developments. Production of sugar and pineapple, once staples of the state economy, has been falling for decades as the Philippines and Caribbean nations produce them more cheaply. Only a few plantations are still operating, and the number of agricultural jobs in the state decreased by 36 percent, to 7,200 last year from 11,300 in 1982.
The Federal Government also hurt the state economy, largely through the reduction of personnel at the state's military bases. In 1996, the number of Federal employees in Hawaii fell by almost a quarter, to 74,119, from a high of 97,853 in 1988.
Mr. Cayetano, 57, a lawyer and former state legislator, has worked hard to blunt the impact of the Asian crisis. In an interview at the Capitol last week, he recited a long list of accomplishments, saying he has reduced the size of government by 500 people, cut the state's personal income tax for the first time, increased spending on marketing to attract visitors to islands other than Oahu, and created novel incentives like eliminating landing fees for airlines to attract new carriers to the state.
"We have made some hard decisions that have hurt us politically," he said. "But that's the way it is."
Ever so slowly, his policies are beginning to help nudge the state forward again. Tourism from the mainland is rebounding, compensating for Asian visitors who are staying fewer days and spending fewer dollars. Unemployment is starting to drop. New small businesses are opening. An embryonic high-technology industry is emerging.
But those changes have done little to dampen growing support for Ms. Lingle, who is attracting people in both parties who say Mr. Cayetano and the Legislature have done too little too late to make any meaningful recovery possible.
Ms. Lingle, 44, a native of St. Louis who came to Hawaii in 1976 as a journalist, has served as Maui's Mayor the last eight years. She is facing a former Mayor of Honolulu, Frank F. Fasi, in the Sept. 19 primary. But Mr. Fasi, 77, a native of Hartford and a frequent candidate for Governor who has run as a Democrat, a Republican and as leader of his self-created Best Party, is not viewed as a serious threat.
In part because her island is favored as a vacation spot more by Americans than Japanese, Maui has resisted much of Hawaii's economic downturn. The number of jobs on Maui has increased in five of the last six years, enabling Ms. Lingle to sharpen her attack on Democratic policies that have not done more to help the state economy. She has outlined a five-point revitalization strategy, which includes a comprehensive plan to diversify the economy and simplify business regulations.
"This is a turning point in our history," she told a rally of 600 voters this week in the middle-class suburbs of east Honolulu. "It's time for a change, and change is about joining the other 49 states with economic revitalization that is taking place all across the country."
Though few of Ms. Lingle's ideas are radically different from Mr. Cayetano's, she has nonetheless caught a wave of voter disenchantment, emerging at a time when many Hawaiians are receptive to the idea of change if only for change's sake.
Ms. Lingle has also captured the attention of leading Republicans on the mainland. Just last week, she flew to New York City for a fund-raiser with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani that she said had brought her $100,000 in campaign contributions.
"I'm intrigued by her," said Calvin Griffin, the owner of a small tent manufacturing company here on Oahu who described himself as an independent voter and frustrated over policies that have caused him to subcontract work to California and Mexico, rather than employ Hawaiians. He said he had come to the rally to hear more of Ms. Lingle's ideas.
"I could create 50 to 100 more jobs, but I've had to cut back because of restrictive regulations," Mr. Griffin said. "I think it's because of the good old boy network here. It's not what you know. It's who you know."
Mr. Cayetano argued that his administration was taking steps to eliminate the red tape that frustrates small business owners like Mr. Griffin. He also said that any Governor would have been stymied by the dramatic drop in foreign investment that Hawaii experienced, to less than $500 million in 1994 from $3.6 billion in 1990.
Though conceding that the state must do a better job finding new jobs and revenues to ease the reliance on tourism as the major economic engine, Mr. Cayetano said many voters had ignored the accomplishments of his administration and failed to see the nascent signs of recovery.
But he also acknowledged that convincing voters that the state is finally on the right track could be a daunting challenge this year. "There is a big mood for change here," Mr. Cayetano said, referring to Ms. Lingle. "She is the favorite to win the Republican primary. She is a good speaker, and she has painted herself as a fresh face on the screen. But we have planted the seeds so we can diversify the economy. And finally we are seeing some positive signs."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Gov. Benjamin J. Cayetano, above left, seeking re-election in Hawaii, joined one of his opponents, Frank Fasi, right, a former mayor of Honolulu, for a candidate debate recently. Mayor Linda Lingle of Maui, right, who is seen as the front-runner in the race, did not participate. (Photographs by David Scull for The New York Times)

INTERNATIONAL A3-9
 
YELTSIN DISMISSES AIDES PUSHING ECONOMIC REFORM
President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia dismissed his new team of economic reformers and reinstalled Viktor S. Chernomyrdin as Prime Minister, just five months after he derided Mr. Chernomyrdin as a spent force and cast him out of the Government. Mr. Yeltsin offered no explanation for his decision, which raised fresh doubts about the Kremlin's commitment to tough economic reforms and unsettling questions about President Yeltsin's ability to govern. A1
 
Senior Clinton Administration officials said they were troubled by President Yeltsin's decision, taken so close to a summit meeting between the two leaders scheduled for next week in Moscow. But a spokesman said that Mr. Clinton had decided to go ahead with his trip. Officials acknowledged that the move had caught them by surprise. A9 

Using Mountains as Defense
The mountains of Afghanistan, where Osama bin Laden is accused of setting up terrorist camps, have long provided a formidable defense to attack. The Soviet Union tried and failed to destroy the camps in the 1980's. Although American officials claimed "moderate to heavy" damage after hitting them with cruise missiles, it is uncertain that the United States can do much better. A1
 
Hassan al-Turabi, the driving force of Sudan's Islamic government, said he believed that Osama bin Laden would try to retaliate against the United States. The Sudan also persisted in its assertion that the plant destroyed by American missiles in its capital, Khartoum, was not capable of making a precursor for nerve gas. A6
 
A welter of reports about new suspects and leads for the investigation into the bombing of the United States Embassy in Kenya have appeared in Kenyan newspapers, all unconfirmed, some tantalizing, some patently untrue, while the F.B.I. has kept a tight lid on information. A6
 
Setback for Congo Rebels
Government soldiers and their allies in Congo recaptured a critical military base near the Atlantic coast, greatly reducing the possibility that rebel forces could march into the capital. But the rebels appeared to have seized Kisangani, the country's third-largest city, solidifying their positions in the east. The developments raised the possibility of a protracted war in which the Government and the rebels would fight each other from entrenched positions. A1
 
Details on Sudan Attack
Facing questions about the missile attack on a pharmaceutical plant in the Sudan, the Clinton Administration sought to justify the strike by offering details linking the factory to the production of chemical weapons. Two Administration officials said that before the strike last week, the United States had obtained a sample of a chemical used in making VX, a deadly nerve agent. A6 
 
NATIONAL A10-14
 
For Hawaii's Voters, It's the Economy
Despite recent indications that the worst may have passed for Hawaii's economy, its Governor may still become a victim of the Asian financial crisis that has rocked the islands. Gov. Benjamin J. Cayetano is the latest in an unbroken line of Democratic governors since Hawaii joined the union in 1959, but polls show that a Republican is favored to defeat him in November. A1
 
White House Strategy Struggle
On the day in January that the accusations about Monica S. Lewinsky and the President became public, one set of advisers -- the lawyers -- wanted Mr. Clinton to be vague in his public responses and by no means say the word "sexual." The other set -- the political team -- pressed for early candor. The fight over strategy reflects the ongoing tension inside the White House and inside the President. A13
 
Federal officials who hoped the President's speech last week would end months of distractions forced by the Lewinsky matter found themselves disappointed. They now face fallout that threatens not just Mr. Clinton's legacy, many said, but his Administration's muscle as well. A13
 
A Mother's Campaign
Yolanda Manuel has become the spiritual leader of what she calls a campaign for justice to pressure the authorities into bringing charges against a college student who saw at least the initial stages of a sexual assault and strangulation of her 7-year-old daughter last year, but did not go for help. A10

Hurricane Bonnie swept through the Bahamas on a route that could threaten the East Coast of the United States. A14
 
Smoking's Danger to Fetuses
Researchers have found the first direct evidence that a nicotine-derived chemical that is the only known lung carcinogen found solely in tobacco smoke is transmitted to fetuses by pregnant smokers. A10
 
More Talks in Phone Strike
Talks resumed between U S West and 34,000 striking union members, amid accusations of equipment sabotage and unfair practices by both sides. A11
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 
 
Harlem the Battleground In Dispute Over March
The community of Harlem is caught in the middle of a race-tinged quarrel between a black nationalist, Khalid Abdul Muhammad, and the Giuliani administration. Mr. Muhammad, best known for his anti-white diatribes, has charged in a lawsuit filed in Federal court that the discriminatory policies of the Giuliani administration prompted it to deny his application for a Million Youth March in Harlem on Sept. 5. The Mayor has alternated between keeping his counsel and denouncing the event as a poorly planned "hate march." A1

HEADLINE: In Brooklyn, Same Cast in New Race

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Four years ago, Javier A. Nieves was a young, first-term State Assemblyman widely described in political circles as one of Brooklyn's bright, up-and-coming legislators. But the years since then, at least in political terms, have not been particularly kind to him.
In 1994, Mr. Nieves was defeated in his first re-election campaign, losing by 79 votes. A year ago, he tried to run for a City Council seat, but his nominating petitions were challenged and he was removed from the ballot in the Democratic primary. 
 This year, Mr. Nieves, 40, is running again for the Democratic nomination for his old Assembly seat, vying to represent a district in Brooklyn that meanders from Park Slope to Bay Ridge, with its anchor in Sunset Park. In a race laced with bitterness that has lingered for four years, Mr. Nieves is facing the man who defeated him, Assemblyman Felix W. Ortiz.
While Mr. Nieves, an architect, has considerable name recognition within the 51st Assembly District and has put together a large network of campaign volunteers, all of that muscle is apparently being matched by Mr. Ortiz, 38, who in the last four years has garnered support from a wide array of politicians in and near the district.
Mr. Nieves's strategy is to portray Mr. Ortiz as a lackluster Assemblyman who has done little to bring new jobs to a community that has more than its share of unemployed residents.
"This is an area with significant unemployment," Mr. Nieves said. "And this is an area where our schools are not performing nearly as well as they should. We don't hear anything from the incumbent Assemblyman on these issues."
He suggests that he would be more attentive than Mr. Ortiz to the district's constituents. "I would devote myself more effectively to economic development and in helping to create jobs," he said.
Mr. Nieves insists that, although he has neither money nor the support of elected officials, his continued work in community organizations and his two-year stint in the Assembly have made him as well known as Mr. Ortiz. Also, he said, he has put together a political network of workers in the district who will undertake a strong effort to get voters to the polls in the Sept. 15 primary.
"The way I'm going to win this race is through pullout," Mr. Nieves said, standing beside a parking meter on bustling Fifth Avenue one morning last week. He said he considers it an achievement to have made it on the ballot, explaining that the Democratic Party organization in Brooklyn had challenged his petitions in court, a step frequently taken to keep insurgents off the ballot.
"I've survived and overcome the first hurdle," he said. "They didn't expect me to make it on the ballot. But now, I've got my people, my volunteers ready to get people to the polls. I lost by 79 votes four years ago. That's not going to happen again this time. We're determined to win this time."
That may well prove more difficult this year, however. Since his election to the Assembly, Mr. Ortiz has himself assembled a formidable network of political volunteers. Last year, Mr. Ortiz oversaw the successful campaign of his friend and political confidant, Angel Rodriguez, who ran successfully in a crowded Democratic primary for a City Council seat. The volunteers are being called out in full force this year.
Unlike 1994, Mr. Ortiz's campaign is enjoying the strong support of the Brooklyn Democratic organization and its chairman, Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., as well as the support of some unions.
"In 1994, I had no union support, no political endorsements, and I still managed to get elected," Mr. Ortiz said. "I will do this year what I did then: put together a grass-roots campaign. I am knocking on doors and meeting people at the subways. The hard work will pay off."
In a recent discussion of the campaign, Mr. Ortiz barely talked about his opponent, whom he never mentioned by name. Instead, he talked about several of his initiatives. For example, he discussed committees that his office had established to study the needs of immigrants coming into the district.
"I try to focus on what my constituents need," Mr. Ortiz said. "I prefer to think of myself as a public servant, instead of a politician."
And he talked about his efforts to provide more stringent monitoring of some manufacturing conditions through legislation, saying there were sweatshops in his district where working conditions need to be improved.
The 51st Assembly District was redrawn in 1992 to increase Hispanic voting strength. It includes largely Hispanic sections and parts of the growing Asian population in Sunset Park. In the 1990 census, the district was about 60 percent Hispanic, 21 percent white, 11 percent black and 8 percent Asian. Demographers say that the number of Hispanic and Asian residents has increased steadily since then.
Several Democratic officials in Brooklyn suggested that Mr. Nieves faced a decidedly uphill struggle. While he was considered an effective legislator in his single term and became vice chairman of the Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus, he nonetheless developed a reputation for being aloof.
Mr. Norman, the Brooklyn Democratic leader, said the party organization was putting some of its financial and organizational resources at Mr. Ortiz's disposal.
"He has done a great job, and we're very committed to helping him," Mr. Norman said. In the meantime, Mr. Nieves has sought the support of some of Mr. Norman's political opponents, namely United States Representatives Edolphus Towns and Nydia M. Velazquez, both of Brooklyn. But neither has made an endorsement.
Neither Assembly candidate has raised much money for the campaign, and no debates are scheduled, so the race is most likely to be played out on the streets of the district.
"This is our first time going one-on-one against each other," Mr. Nieves said. "And this is going to be a campaign that will be won by the candidate who does the best job getting people to the polls."

Ortiz beat Mr. Nieves in the 1994 primary and went on to represent the Brooklyn district. He is running for re-election. (Photographs by John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Harry Lunn Jr., 65, Art Dealer Who Championed Photography

BYLINE: By MARGARETT LOKE 

 BODY:
Harry H. Lunn Jr., the international art dealer who played a major role in creating a fine-art photography market that has seen canonical vintage prints sell for hundreds of thousands of dollars, died on Friday in Paris, where he had a home.
A week earlier, while preparing to board a train to his country house in Normandy, Mr. Lunn had a heart attack and lapsed into a coma, said Clark Worswick, a friend. He was 65. 
 Until Mr. Lunn marketed photographs on an unprecedented grand scale -- with big inventories, slick catalogues and sales on several continents -- few thought photographs would sell to the public.
During the first two decades of this century, Alfred Stieglitz's gallery 291 was much more a showcase for modern art than it was a photography gallery. In the 1930's and 40's, Julien Levy showed photographs at his New York art gallery, but there was no market for them. In the 1950's, Helen Gee's Greenwich Village coffeehouse, Limelight, had a photographic gallery at the back that exhibited the work of masters like Paul Strand, Robert Frank and Imogene Cunningham. But even when pictures were about $15 each, only a few sold.
In 1970, when Mr. Lunn became interested in photography, only one gallery in the United States -- opened by Lee Witkin in Manhattan in 1969 -- was devoted to the medium. Mr. Lunn had a gallery in Washington that sold lithographs and drawings. While visiting a publisher of etchings and photographic portfolios in Manhattan, he saw Ansel Adams's "Moonrise, Hernandez, New Mexico." "This was an extraordinarily graphic, marvelous image," he recalled in a 1996 interview. "As a dealer in prints I could very much relate to it. I didn't even know who Ansel Adams was."
In January 1971, Mr. Lunn exhibited Adams's photographs. Shortly before the show's opening, The Washington Post ran a lengthy review of the show saying, as Mr. Lunn put it, that "this was the greatest thing since Moses and the Tabernacle." From that show, Mr. Lunn sold an astonishing number of Adams prints; at $150 for a 16-by-20-inch picture, sales totaled $10,000.
Mr. Lunn cast far afield, becoming the first art dealer, for instance, to exhibit photographs at the Basel Art Fair in Switzerland. And he was one of the biggest buyers of vintage prints at Sotheby's in London, which had begun offering photography at auction in 1970. In 1975 Sotheby's New York began holding regular photography sales. Christie's New York soon followed.
Informed that Adams would not make more prints after the end of 1975, Mr. Lunn ordered 1,000 prints, concentrating on popular images like "Moonrise," buying them at an average cost of $300. Mr. Lunn created similar markets for a formidable list of photographers including Walker Evans, Robert Frank, Diane Arbus and Heinrich Kuhn.
In 1993, a Stieglitz image of Georgia O'Keeffe's hands with a thimble sold for $398,500 at Christie's New York. At the spring photography auctions in New York this year, when sales at four houses totaled a record $10.28 million, Sotheby's sold a 16-by-20-inch "Moonrise" for $20,700.
Mr. Lunn was born in Detroit in 1933 and majored in economics at the University of Michigan in Ann Arbor. During his senior year, in the mid-1950's, he was recruited by the Central Intelligence Agency. He remained with the agency until 1967 when Ramparts magazine mentioned his involvement in the National Students Association, whose international wing was a C.I.A. front.
His cover blown, Mr. Lunn resigned. He had dealt privately in original etchings and lithographs while he was stationed at the United States Embassy in Paris in the early 1960's, and in 1968 he opened his Washington gallery.
Once photography entered his life, Mr. Lunn became an avid student, growing especially passionate about 19th-century French photography.
Such was Mr. Lunn's reputation, said Mr. Worswick, a photography collector and curator, that about 25 years ago when he was offered a collection of 263,000 Edward S. Curtis photogravures, he went to Mr. Lunn because he was "the only person who could handle it."
As it turned out, Mr. Lunn was financially unable to acquire the collection but the two men became close friends.
Mr. Lunn closed his Washington gallery in 1983 and dealt privately after that. He made a point of buying and promoting the work of controversial contemporary photographers, including Robert Mapplethorpe, Andres Serrano, Joel-Peter Witkin and the team of McDermott and McGough.
Mr. Lunn is survived by his wife, Myriam; two daughters, Alexandra and Florence, and a son, Christophe, all of Paris.
Hank O'Neal, a friend of Mr. Lunn's since the 1970's who has often written about the work of the photographer Berenice Abbott, got to know Mr. Lunn when the art dealer and Marlborough Gallery in Manhattan jointly bought most of Abbott's early vintage prints and held two exhibitions. Like Mr. Lunn, Mr. O'Neal had worked for the C.I.A. One of the rituals they shared was the celebration of Abbott's birthday each year.
With homes in Paris and New York, Mr. Lunn treated trans-Atlantic travel as though it were a taxi ride across town. Last month, he flew to the United States from Paris to commemorate what would have been Abbott's 100th birthday, joining a group that visited her grave in northern Maine.
Mr. Lunn had brought the newest fragrance from Paris, as he had every year for Abbott's birthday, and he sprayed it on her tombstone. "I was walking about," Mr. O'Neal recalled, "and 30 or 40 feet from her grave I saw a flat marker that said 'Harry L.' I called to Harry. He came over and he sprayed that marker too."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 27, 1998, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Monday about Harry H. Lunn Jr., a dealer in fine art photography, omitted the name of a survivor. She is his sister, Barbara Lunn Hall of San Diego.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: IN THE SUDAN;
For This Islamic Tactician, Battle With U.S. Has Begun

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 23

 BODY:
The man who is the driving force of the Islamic government that gave Osama bin Laden refuge here for two years said today that he believed that Mr. bin Laden would try to retaliate against the United States.
"When you start fortifying your embassies it becomes very attractive -- the Americans have made themselves very attractive targets," the official, Hassan al-Turabi, a Sorbonne-educated intellectual who agrees with much of Mr. bin Laden's militant view of the world, said in an interview. "Probably he would try to mobilize friends -- ex-Afghan fighters from Arab countries -- and try to hit back against the Americans, anywhere." 
 The United States attacked sites in the Sudan and Afghanistan that it said are financed by Mr. bin Laden, a wealthy Saudi whom Washington has linked to the Aug. 7 bombings at the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.
Mr. Turabi, the Speaker of Parliament and ideological power behind the governing National Islamic Front, is accused by American intelligence officials of having an important political and financial relationship with Mr. bin Laden.
He said he did not know how much Mr. bin Laden's effectiveness had been destroyed by the American attack on the bases in Afghanistan.
But like other Sudanese officials, Mr. Turabi dismissed the American contention that a pharmaceutical factory here was financed by Mr. bin Laden and served as a cover to make a precursor for nerve gas.
In a line of argument used by officials of his Government since the American attacks, Mr. Turabi branded the United States "terrorist" and accused it of "hating Islam."
Mr. Turabi, who serves tea to guests in floral china cups and is vocal in his contempt for the United States, said he had met Mr. bin Laden "only once or twice" in the Sudan. He said he had not been in contact with Mr. bin Laden since the Saudi was asked to leave here in 1996.
But he seemed to know Mr. bin Laden well enough to describe him as having a "belligerent" temperament and being a man of few words and "a fighter."
He insisted that Mr. bin Laden was not involved in training Islamic fighters at camps in the Sudan -- as the Americans have maintained -- but acknowledged that he had been asked to leave the Sudan because of pressure from Saudi Arabia.
"Bin Laden was not even issuing leaflets from here," Mr. Turabi said. "He was trying to behave."
But apparently in an effort to clean up its reputation as a harborer of terrorists, the Government of the Sudan acceded to the requests from Saudi Arabia, as well as from the United States and Britain, that Mr. bin Laden depart. Mr. bin Laden had been exiled from his homeland in 1994 after calling for a holy war against the Saudi Government. He is a suspect in the bombing of two American military installations in Saudi Arabia that killed a total of 24 Americans in 1995 and 1996.
Mr. Turabi, a lawyer who masterminded a military coup here in 1989, described retaliation by Mr. bin Laden against the United States as entirely justified. "You respond as violently as the violence," he said.
The Sudanese Government persisted today in its case that the Shifa Pharmaceutical Plant, which was destroyed by American cruise missiles, was not a dual-use facility capable of making a precursor for VX nerve gas as well as medicines.
In an effort to demonstrate that the plant was purely a civilian one, the Government has allowed foreign reporters to traipse all over the wreckage, and today it invited the chief United Nations representative in the Sudan, Phillip Borel, on a tour.
But after stepping around broken pieces of the building and over debris that includes wrappers and bottles used for human and veterinary drugs, Mr. Borel said only technical experts could determine precisely what the plant made. He said he saw no reason why United Nations technical experts should not investigate.
One Western official here said there was some surprise in the diplomatic community that the United States had attacked the plant, in the industrial area of the city, which opened last year and was only lightly guarded.
Another, older plant, more closely guarded and with high security walls, has long been considered suspicious, the official said. Western diplomats living near the older plant believe that Iraqi technicians frequently visit it, the official said.
There are other theories, however, that the plant that was destroyed was only lightly guarded as a deception to keep suspicions low.
Whether Mr. bin Laden, the son of a wealthy Saudi construction family, was a financial backer of the plant remains unclear. He was certainly well known as a major investor in a Government that has presided over an economy that has enriched a few at the top but ravaged most of the population.
According to one estimate here, Mr. bin Laden brought as much as $500 million to the Sudan when he came in 1994. One of his most important contributions was a $300 million line of credit, a well-informed academic said.
Mr. bin Laden's construction company built a new road from Khartoum halfway to Port Sudan, but it is unclear whether he divested himself of his business interests here when he left in 1996.
During his two years in Khartoum, Mr. bin Laden lived in a new, large, comfortable two-story brick and stone house with a tiled roof in Ryadh, a well-to-do neighborhood.
A neighbor, a retired diplomat who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said Mr. bin Laden kept to himself and never socialized among Sudanese. He was well protected by his own security men and others provided by the Government. Down the street from the house, the Government dug a trench to stop traffic from passing by the bin Laden residence, the neighbor said.
Mr. bin Laden was punctilious about attending a nearby mosque with a turquoise minaret five times a day for prayer, the neighbor said. He arrived in the Sudan with four wives, the neighbor said, all of whom dressed in the most conservative black Islamic robes, which covered the women's entire faces. The family had about 10 children, with the eldest boy about 18, the neighbor said.
Another neighbor, Magla Abdel Gafaar, 24, said she became friendly with one of Mr. bin Laden's wives, Hamza. Ms. Gafaar said Hamza was the daughter of Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi oil minister whose smooth talk and dapper dress personified the oil-producing nations as they wrested control of their oil from foreign companies in the 1970's.
Sheik Yamani also used his nation's vast oil reserves to dominate the Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries, which embargoed oil exports in 1973 to punish governments that supported Israel.

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 24 about the Speaker of the Sudanese Parliament referred incorrectly to a wife of Osama bin Laden, a Saudi whom the United States has linked to the bombings at the American Embassies in Kenya and Tanzania last month. She is not a daughter of Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the former Saudi Oil Minister.

HEADLINE: From Mosque To Museum;
Restoring an Object's Surface May Petrify Its Heart

SERIES: Past/Present: Staircases to Devotion

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

DATELINE: MARRAKESH, Morocco

 BODY:
Not long ago, the imam at the Casbah mosque agreed to show an interested outsider the mosque's ancient minbar.
The idea was to compare it to the 12th-century minbar, or pulpit, from the Kutubiyya mosque here, which conservators from the Metropolitan Museum of Art have lately restored and installed to justified local fanfare, in the remains of the city's immense Badi Palace. The Kutubiyya's minbar is worth traveling halfway around the world to see. And it is not likely ever to go anywhere else. 
 Minbars are portable pulpits, decorated wooden staircases on wheels from which the imam addresses the congregation during Friday worship. Six years ago, the Met asked to borrow the Kutubiyya minbar for "Al-Andalus: The Art of Islamic Spain," a big loan exhibition. But the minbar was too fragile to travel; in fact, it badly needed repair.
So the Met did something unusual in the museum world: It proposed to restore the minbar, never mind any exhibition. Mahrukh Tarapor, the museum's associate director, arranged the deal directly with the Moroccan King, Hassan II. Patti Birch, an honorary trustee of the Met who has a home in in Marrakesh, offered to pay for the restoration. The Moroccans supplied craftsmen to help.
The whole deal took a while to get in motion, but two years ago, Met conservators and installation and lighting experts got started. They worked with a Moroccan architect, El Mostafa Hbibi, and several Moroccan woodworkers to shore up the minbar's rickety structure, secure loose panels, clean the surface and design a place for it in the Badi Palace Museum. The result is one of the most amazing sights in Marrakesh, a charismatic object, sublime and handsomely installed.
The smaller Casbah minbar is exquisite, too -- though a wreck -- and is still in use. So however they compare esthetically, the two minbars have now become fundamentally different kinds of objects.
The Kutubiyya minbar, after all, is a modern museum object. Its display in the Badi Palace represents essentially American exhibition standards and a Western approach to conservation. There are no interpolated carvings, for instance, as there are on the other minbar; the very idea of adding new touches to it seems outrageous, like trying to pass off a fake.
On the other hand, the Casbah minbar remains part of a culture seamlessly integrated with the past. It belongs to a living faith. Nearly as old as the Kutubiyya's, it could also be retired to a museum, though one can imagine it being treated quite differently.
For example, in Fez, several hours to the north, city planners have decided to hire local artisans, people from the city's walled center, or medina, who have been strictly trained in an old craft tradition, to fix up the decorated facades of ruined monuments, adding their own designs in the style of the originals. There's nothing kitsch or ersatz about the plan. The medina is not a theme park or a museum. It's a community. The workers who live there get jobs with the restoration, and the buildings are put back into use. One landmark site has become a museum; others are mosques, restaurants, homes and a university dormitory.
 
Relative Values, Parochial Esthetics
It is a philosophy of historical continuity: If the heel on your favorite shoe breaks, you don't throw the shoe away or stick it on a shelf to admire it. You replace the broken heel with a new one and keep walking.
Looking at the minbar in the Casbah mosque, it is possible to be reminded how modern conservation, like almost every other issue in art, is a matter of relative values and parochial esthetics. Western conservators, loyal to a secular museum culture, claim a certain objective rightness based on scientific devotion to a work's historical integrity. This is a perfectly justifiable approach if you think in terms of museum objects. But which context is ultimately more faithful to the spirit of something like the minbar: the Casbah mosque or the Badi Palace Museum?
Every generation has claimed to understand the intent of past artists. Restorers in previous centuries who saw the darkened Sistine Chapel ceiling were convinced that Michelangelo was a painter of shadows, so they added their own dark touches to his work, reinforcing a view of him that affected future restorers, and so the cycle proceeded. When an artist named Mazzuoli stuck darkening glue to the Sistine ceiling in the early 18th century, he was just reflecting the beliefs of his day, as restorers today, having cleaned away the grime, reflect the modern faith in science, technology and historical revivalism. A century from now, the ceiling will probably look as much like a work of late-20th-century restoration as the darkened ceiling looked like an anachronism.
The point isn't that the Kutubiyya minbar should be returned to the Kutubiyya mosque and put back into service. It was removed to storage years ago because people here decided that it was too precious to be used.
Commissioned by the Almoravid Sultan Ali Ibn Yusuf in 1137, it was made in Cordoba, Spain. More than 12 feet high, it originally consisted of more than a million differently carved pieces of bone and colored woods, some pieces the size of sesame seeds, in the shapes of stars, Y's, hexagons, arabesques, scrolling vines, palmettes, pine cones, blossoms, checkerboards and Arabic letters. (There are inlaid inscriptions cut from African blackwood and outlined in bone.) Pieces have fallen off during the last eight centuries, but the Met's conservators have painstakingly restored what is left.
A modern craftsman, as a test, recently took a week to reproduce, coarsely, one of the minbar's panels, and from this, experts guess that the whole minbar required 72,000 man-hours of labor.
It was shipped in pieces down the Guadalquivir River, across the Strait of Gibraltar and on camelback over the Middle Atlas mountains to Marrakesh, where it was reassembled.
Someone has estimated that during the eight centuries that it was rolled in and out of its closet in the mosque every Friday, the minbar traveled a total of 250 miles. Imagine rolling one of your family's heirloom dinner plates between New York and Washington, and you can estimate, more or less, the wear and tear.
The Met acted remarkably in the situation, committing resources to an object that doesn't directly benefit its audience. Skeptics may have asked why the museum was so generous. But one can't help wondering: If something equivalent from the West -- say, a Giotto altarpiece -- had been discovered abroad and needed repair, wouldn't American museums have competed for the honor to restore it?
 
A Museum With One Treasure
The Kutubiyya minbar has found a home in the most dramatic secular setting here: the vast, crumbling Badi is essentially a museum only for it, at least so far, because no other objects are inside. The 16th-century palace was destroyed by the ruler Mouley Ismail in the 17th century, its gold, marble, onyx and ivory stripped and used to build a palace in Meknes, some 200 miles northeast of here. With a courtyard the size of several football fields, what is left of the Badi might plausibly be compared to the Baths of Caracalla in Rome. The minbar occupies one of the few palace rooms that still has a roof.
There's nothing in Marrakesh quite like this mix of old with new: an up-to-date display in a ruin. At dusk, as visitors start to leave, storks, which nest on the Badi's walls during the day, descend into the palace courtyard to waddle around the reflecting pools and orange trees. The storks make a kind of clacking sound; they lean their heads way back and smack their beaks together. And as the noise of the city dies down a little, they sound like an orchestra of castanets, drowning out the coo of the doves that also live in the palace.
It's almost prehistoric. And suddenly a 12th-century minbar doesn't seem so old.
 
Past/Present
This is the second article in a series about how different cultures interpret and make use of the art of the past. The first article examined restoration efforts in the old city, or medina, of Fez.

HEADLINE: For Butterflies, a Promise of Peace With Truckloads of Trees

BYLINE: By CAROL YOON 

 BODY:
HIGH in the mountains of central Mexico, monarch butterflies arrive by the millions each winter to take refuge, their black and orange wings festooning stands of towering fir trees. But conservationists have grown increasingly concerned as the butterflies in these small patches of forest, some of which were set aside as preserves, compete with the needs of the residents around them.
Now conservationists are trying to help the butterflies by helping the residents. In July, 40,000 trees were planted near El Rosario in the state of Michoacan in an effort to save the fragile habitat where monarchs congregate after their long flight south from the eastern United States and Canada. 
 Rather than becoming new roosts for monarchs, the newly planted trees, are intended to be cut.
The idea is to provide the local farmers with trees they can grow for firewood, construction and selling, leaving the monarch forests intact.
"The monarch overwintering areas were really being hit hard," said Robert L. Small, who runs the Michoacan Reforestation Fund, a one-man fund-raising organization aimed at buying trees to reforest the mountaintops of central Mexico.
The local subsistence farmers "were poor and had to have wood to live on, and they would sell whatever they could," Mr. Small said.
"This is extreme poverty," he said. "We're trying to give them an economic alternative that they've never been offered before."
Mr. Small, a retired public administrator who runs the fund from his home in Oakland, Calif., raises money that is used by the La Cruz Habitat Protection Project, the Mexico-based arm of this conservation effort, to buy the trees.
The project had a tentative start last year with the planting of 7,000 trees, most of which were killed by El Nino according to Jose Luis Alvarez, the Mexican nurseryman who has overseen the planting.
Expressing frustration over the many previous failed attempts to stop logging in the area, Dr. Lincoln Brower, a biologist at Sweet Briar College in Virginia and a monarch advocate, said: "I've grasped at a lot of straws in the last 20 years. A lot of what people do is for show, but Bob and Jose may really have found something.
"I don't see any alternatives that anyone has suggested that have as much promise as this one does."
By planting seedlings, Oyamel firs, the trees where the monarchs roost, and pines, farmers can begin making money from reforested land in a few years, Mr. Alvarez said. Oyamels can be harvested as Christmas trees in four years, and pines can be harvested for wood in as little as five years. The hope, Mr. Alvarez said, is for farmers to use the donated trees to begin a cycle of planting, harvesting and replanting that will maintain a standing forest.
But at first, even giving away the trees was not easy. Mr. Alvarez said residents were concerned that if they reforested their land it might be taken by the Mexican Government as a monarch sanctuary.
Mr. Small said that in 1986, when the Government set aside land for the monarchs, the people in the communities that had been using those forests received no financial compensation.
Mr. Alvarez said that attitudes were slowly changing and that all 40,000 seedlings he delivered to El Rosario were immediately loaded onto burros and carried up the mountainside by farmers to plant on their land.
Conservationists agree that even next year's hoped-for planting of 100,000 trees is just a beginning, the equivalent of a mere 100 acres of forest. They say the effort must grow considerably to keep the monarch sanctuaries out of harm's way in this poverty-stricken region. At least one similar reforestation effort is under way, run by the Mexican Government.
Planting trees near the monarch sanctuaries may have benefits besides the obvious economic ones.
As trees have been cut around the sanctuaries, stronger winds are blowing through the reserves, drying the normally moist habitat and making the trees more prone to disease, Dr. Brower said.
As trees are planted, he said, this potentially devastating problem should begin to disappear.
Mr. Alvarez said: "There are thousands of acres out there that have been transformed into corn or oat fields. I want it all to go back to forest. I think this is definitely the answer."
