HEADLINE: Where to Focus Our Economic Jitters?

BYLINE: By Alan S. Blinder; Alan S. Blinder is a professor of economics at Princeton University and vice chairman of the G-7 group. He is a former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J.

 BODY:
We Americans are now in the summer of our economic content. But much of the rest of the economic world has become a dangerous place. Several Southeast Asian nations are in what can only be called a depression. China, it is said, may have to devalue its currency. Japan is sagging badly. Russia lurches from one crisis to the next. And parts of Latin American look shaky.
Some pessimists are even fretting about the United States: the stock market seems precarious, we save too little, our trade deficit is alarming, the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates, growth is slowing. But I believe that our worries should be directed across the Pacific; anxieties about the American economy are overblown. 
 Although the great American growth machine slowed dramatically in the last quarter, the apparently meager 1.4 percent growth rate resulted largely from an inventory correction and the General Motors strike. Without those two factors, growth would have topped 4 percent despite a notable drag from foreign trade.
And besides, a little slowdown is welcome right now, when there is a real danger of overheating. The stock market has been correcting -- calmly so far -- for what seem to be the right reasons: it is coming to see unrealistically optimistic earnings forecasts as, well, unrealistic. And those awful trade deficits, I would argue, are just what the doctor ordered for the rest of the world.
So there is no need for panic on the domestic front. Neither is the situation in Russia, which is grabbing the gloomy headlines these days, a serious economic concern for the United States (although it is a deadly serious foreign policy matter). The Russian economy is simply too small and too little connected to the rest of the world to matter much.
If you want to worry, start with Japan. Its economy, once mighty, has struggled for most of this decade and now appears to be in the grips of a serious recession. Despite near-zero interest rates for nearly three years and several large stimulus packages, the economy has failed to perk up. And the Japanese political system has repeatedly shown itself incapable of taking decisive action.
Since Japan accounts for roughly one-eighth of the world economy, all that is bad enough in itself. But there is much more.
Most obviously, much of Asia is in serious trouble, and the region's biggest economy is too sick to help. A healthy Japan could be assisting its smaller neighbors financially while they lifted themselves out of the morass, in part by exporting to Japan. But that escape route has been effectively closed by Japan's recession.
Can Asia recover while its largest economy sinks? It's a good question, to which I fear the answer is no.
Furthermore, the whole world is fearful of financial contagion. When Thailand's markets got sick in July 1997, Malaysia's and Indonesia's quickly followed. A few months later, a crack in the (comparatively) tiny Hong Kong stock market echoed loudly in New York. In June, a falling yen shook emerging markets all over the world, and a sinking ruble did so again this month. Imagine, then, the potential financial repercussions of a real financial meltdown in Japan.
What to do? The United States may be the undisputed world leader, but most of the answers lie in Japan.
First, and most assuredly foremost, Japan must clean up its banking mess and nurse its financial system back to health. In my view, it is more important that Japan do so quickly than that it follow what might be called the American way -- shuttering moribund banks, paying off depositors with public money, kicking out the management and selling off the bad assets. That recipe sounds about right to me. But remember that, in the case of our own savings and loan debacle, we dithered for years before finally biting the unpalatable bullet. If insisting on an American-style approach will delay the process further, better to use a less confrontational, more Japanese approach -- even if that means, for example, keeping wounded banks alive by merging them into stronger ones. The motto should be, Just do it.
Second, government policy must remain strongly expansionary. That means keeping interest rates extremely low, enacting permanent tax cuts and providing even more dollops of Government spending. The time to debate the merits and demerits of these three ways to stimulate domestic spending is long gone. Japan must use every option available.
Third, both Japan and the rest of the world need to tolerate an exchange rate in the current range (about 145 yen to the dollar) or even lower. Let's not forget that Japan is still home to some of the world's great manufacturing corporations. A cheaper yen makes these companies' products more attractive to foreign buyers. The important point here is that having a super-weak yen should not be viewed as a permanent condition. Rather, it is a temporary, cyclical phenomenon, much like near-zero interest rates and the yawning budget deficit. As the Japanese economy recovers, so will the yen.
Critics object that a weak yen imperils other Asian countries by making their exports less competitive. They have a point, but an exaggerated one. Only South Korea competes directly with Japan in a variety of product lines; other Asian countries aim lower on the technology ladder. And remember the object of this exercise: to get the Japanese economy growing again. A healthy Japan will provide markets for its neighbors.
And what about the United States? Is there anything our Government should be doing to help? Yes, but fortunately not much, other than to make sure that our own giant economy keeps humming.
First, the world's financial markets certainly do not need an interest rate increase from the Federal Reserve right now. Fortunately, Fed decision makers have been smart enough to do nothing for almost 18 months now.
Second, even though I subscribe to many of the criticisms of the International Monetary Fund, Congress should quickly pass the I.M.F. financing measure that the Administration has requested. Yes, this may amount to throwing some good money after bad. But we can ill afford to shut down the world's economic fire department just when dry tinder appears to be everywhere and sparks are flying.
Third, our Government should keep badgering the Japanese, who seem to need lots of external pressure to overcome internal political inertia. However, less smug American triumphalism might be in order. For example, as suggested earlier, the Japanese need not fix their banking problems in precisely the way we fixed ours. The United States should behave more like a worried companion trying to talk sense into a friend, less like a haughty scold.
Finally, with our economy operating at (or indeed beyond) capacity while Asia is in the doldrums and Europe is in only so-so shape, we must expect our already huge trade deficit to grow. Providing a market for weak-sister economies may be the most constructive thing we can do for the world economy right now. And, fortunately, we spendthrifty Americans are in an excellent position to do just that. It would be a colossal mistake if our growing trade deficit were to push the United States into protectionism. That's not the way a leader behaves in a dangerous world.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Wall Street has reason to lose sleep over some signs that U.S. shoppers are showing fatigue.

BYLINE: By Gretchen Morgenson 

 BODY:
THEY'VE shopped and they've shopped. Now are they starting to drop?
The marathoner of the moment, as far as Wall Street is concerned, is the American consumer, one of two prime movers behind the booming economy of the last four years. Shop-happy consumers brought the nation out of the recession back in 1991 and, together with corporations investing in capital equipment, have kept growth in gross domestic product perking far longer than in any other economic cycle. These same free-spending consumers are needed to snatch up foreign goods and pull the world's faltering companies back from the brink. 
 Now, however, there are signs that the marathoner may be tiring. And since capital spending by corporations is also declining, a prolonged weakness among consumers could add insult to an already-injured stock market.
Straws in the wind on consumer spending come from surveys conducted by International Strategy and Investment, a brokerage firm in New York specializing in economic research. Every week, the firm surveys almost 100 companies, including retailers, auto dealers, manufacturers, home builders and banks.
"We're getting indications that consumer spending is starting to soften," said Jason Trennert, vice president at I.S.I. "We're not counting the consumer out. And no question, lower interest rates are going to provide a fairly strong backdrop for consumer spending. But some of the headwinds on the economy are starting to affect consumer spending."
The analysts at I.S.I. often identify significant economic trends well ahead of the rest of Wall Street. For instance, the firm spotted the Asia debacle and warned of its consequences in the spring of 1997, when most Wall Street firms still considered the Asian economies a picture of health. Ed Hyman, a founder of the firm, has been named the top economist by Institutional Investor magazine for 18 consecutive years.
The most recent data from I.S.I. show the lowest reading on overall economic strength since January, an indication that the economy is cooling. The index, in which 100 represents strong growth, stood at 48.8 as of Aug. 21, down from 50.3 in July and 55.9 in May. The I.S.I. numbers are not seasonally adjusted.
The survey found a whiff of weakness in consumer spending at retailers and auto dealers. For two weeks now, retail sales have slowed at the six large national retail chains interviewed by I.S.I. The weakness was broad based, showing up at both a discounter and a department store chain. I.S.I.'s retailer index fell to 39.6 last week, down from a reading of 54 in May.
Retailers reported strong sales in the first week of August, giving hope for a bang-up back-to-school season. But the sales growth fizzled; subsequent weeks have been dismal.
I.S.I. sees a similar trend in auto sales. Although new-car sales rose slightly last week, Japanese and luxury models were responsible. Many dealers reported significantly fewer car shoppers, Mr. Jennert said. "A couple of weeks ago they thought inventory problems were behind slow sales, but now they say floor traffic is off," he added.
What the consumer does is important because consumption accounts for two-thirds of gross domestic product and because a host of weak countries are counting on Americans to buy their goods while Asians and others cannot. Most forecasters expect that growth in consumer spending will drop from the 6 percent reported earlier this year to about 3 percent by year-end. If this number turns out to be too optimistic, the economy will feel the pain.
Further clues to the shoppers' mind-set come today when the Conference Board releases its consumer confidence figures. On Friday, the University of Michigan publishes its confidence report. In early August, the Michigan sentiment figures showed only a slight decline from the previous month.
Mr. Trennert wonders if the consumer pullback that his firm is beginning to see is a result of the summer squalls in the stock market. Are consumers spending less because many of them have lost money, at least on paper?
"Our work has shown a strong correlation between retail sales and the performance of stocks," Mr. Trennert said. "Stocks tend to lead by about four weeks. Everytime we've seen the stock market move up or down signficantly, the moves tend to influence consumer spending." Since the value of the average stock portfolio is probably down 10 to 25 percent from the highs, it would not be surprising if consumers reined in their spending a bit.
One thing consumers still have going, of course, is declining interest rates. With Treasury yields near historic lows, home-mortgage refinancings will put additional income in consumers' pockets. So, even if stocks continue to drift lower, American investors will have some good news to balance out the bad.

HEADLINE: Mr. Yeltsin's Unsteady Hand

 BODY:
Five months after abruptly firing Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin, Boris Yeltsin has just as abruptly brought him back. An increasingly erratic President Yeltsin flailing about in the Kremlin is becoming a major cause for concern in Moscow and in Washington, recalling the unnerving days when ailing and aging Soviet leaders like Leonid Brezhnev continued to wield power despite faltering judgment.
Although Mr. Chernomyrdin is a known quantity, his return to office is anything but reassuring. It seems to signal a particularly untimely retreat from economic reform. The challenge for President Clinton, who still plans to proceed with a Moscow summit meeting scheduled for next week, is to lend a stabilizing hand to the Yeltsin-Chernomyrdin Government, without appearing to lend American endorsement to any slowing of reform. 
 Only last March, Mr. Yeltsin dismissed Mr. Chernomyrdin and, declaring that revitalizing the Russian economy required "new blood," appointed a Cabinet of youthful and committed reformers under Sergei Kiriyenko. Now, in the midst of a dangerous banking crisis that could destroy Russia's ability to borrow in international markets, Mr. Yeltsin has dumped those reformers in favor of a man whose legacy of halfway measures and tolerance for corruption contributed mightily to Russia's underlying problems.
As Russia tries to navigate its way out of a financial crisis that requires making difficult choices, it can ill afford Mr. Chernomyrdin's cautious, compromising leadership style. Economically, Russia is now in a deep, downward spiral. The Government has been unable to collect taxes or pay its workers and has lost the confidence of foreign investors who only months ago were pouring money into a country that was ill equipped to handle it. Finding a way to restructure the debts of both the Government and the Russian banks will be a difficult challenge. The previous Government had promised to announce its plans yesterday, but did not last long enough to do so.
While bringing back Mr. Chernomyrdin makes little sense in terms of Russia's economic problems, it is much easier to decipher politically. Mr. Chernomyrdin, who was himself a Soviet-era industrial manager, has good relations with the two sectors of Russia's political establishment most threatening to Mr. Yeltsin's authority -- the Communist opposition in Parliament and the powerful new financial and industrial groups that now dominate the news media and contribute heavily to political campaigns. By appointing their ally, Mr. Chernomyrdin, the ailing Mr. Yeltsin may have improved the odds on his own political survival at the expense of Russia's economic future.
The big industrial groups bankrolled Mr. Yeltsin's 1996 re-election victory, and their leaders have exercised considerable political influence ever since. They loathed the financial reforms announced by the Kiriyenko administration, particularly its efforts to tighten tax collection. They are also determined to make sure that the Russian banks they own, and not foreign creditors, stand first in line when the Government eventually resumes paying its debts. Mr. Chernomyrdin's return may be a sign that Mr. Yeltsin feels increasingly unable to stand up to these industrial tycoons.
Despite these disturbing signs, Washington should not postpone next week's summit meeting. That would diminish Mr. Yeltsin's waning political prestige. Instead Mr. Clinton and his entourage should use their stay in Moscow to get a firsthand reading of Russia's increasingly volatile political scene. Mr. Clinton should also press for better coordination on foreign policy issues. Mr. Yeltsin's outburst last week against American missile attacks on terrorist targets and Moscow's excessive indulgence of Saddam Hussein highlight the urgent need for repair work in this area.
Finally, Mr. Yeltsin and Mr. Chernomyrdin should be reminded that moving forward with economic reforms is the best prescription both for healing Russia and for maintaining strong American support.

HEADLINE: Northrop to Cut 8,000 Jobs In Wake of Failed Merger

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24

 BODY:
The Northrop Grumman Corporation said today that it planned to reduce its work force by 8,000 people, or about 15 percent, by the end of 2000 as it tries to remain competitive as an independent aerospace company.
The announcement of the cutbacks, most of which will be in Southern California, comes a month after the planned acquisition of Northrop by Lockheed Martin collapsed in the face of Government antitrust concerns. Since then, Northrop, the nation's fourth-largest aerospace company, has seen its stock plunge to about half its peak value amid doubts about whether the company can survive in an industry dominated by three larger rivals: Boeing, Lockheed and Raytheon. 
 Northrop has maintained that it can compete and prosper on its own, and today's announcement was part of the effort to do that.
"Now that we knew that we were going to be independent, we wanted to get on with life," Kent Kresa, the company's chairman and chief executive, said in an interview. He said Northrop would have taken such action "many months earlier" had it not been waiting for the deal with Lockheed to be completed.
Byron K. Callan, a Merrill Lynch analyst, said the cutbacks were part of a trend for weapons companies, adding, "They are focusing on their competitive strengths versus one another rather than on what they can buy next." He said he would not change his earnings estimates for Northrop as a result of today's announcement.
Northrop's stock, which initially rose on the news, fell 12.5 cents to close at $68.6875 -- about half its 12-month high of $139 when it looked as if the merger would be completed, and well below the $90 or so at which the shares traded last month when the deal fell through.
Aerospace stocks have been weak in general partly because of the Asian economic crisis and the feeling that the era of acquisitions is now over, said Paul H. Nisbet of JSA Research in Newport, R.I.
But Northrop's stock has been particularly weak, Mr. Callan said, because investors worry that the company will make a hasty acquisition in an attempt to increase its size.
Northrop, which is based here, said today that it would realign operating units and consolidate laboratories and factories to save $300 million in annual operating costs beginning in 2001. It will take a $60 million charge this year to cover the costs of the streamlining.
The realignment will result in the loss of 2,100 jobs. In addition, the elimination of 4,100 more jobs has been in the works but not announced until today, a company spokesman said. These cuts stem largely from slower shipments of commercial aircraft parts that Northrop makes for Boeing, which has been hurt by the Asian crisis.
The loss of 4,300 jobs beyond those had previously been announced, stemming from the winding down of the B-2 bomber program, for which Northrop is the prime contractor. The company plans to hire 2,500 workers in its information technology and electronics businesses, bringing total employment at the end of 2000 to 46,000, down from 54,000 now.
Some 7,000 of the lost jobs will be in Southern California, dealing a new blow to the region's aerospace employment, which had seemed to stabilize after years of sharp declines. Raytheon and Boeing have also announced big job cuts here this year.
Northrop Grumman also said today that it was unlikely to achieve its goal of $12 billion in revenue until 2003, a year later than planned. But with the new cutbacks, it expects operating margins to rise to 12.5 percent, higher than the previous goal of 11 percent.
The reorganization will reduce the number of divisions from five to three. One division, based in Baltimore, will deal mainly with electronic sensors. Another, in Dallas, will handle commercial and military aircraft systems. The third, in Herndon, Va., will handle information technology and services.

HEADLINE: Claims Against Liz Claiborne Dismissed

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
A Federal judge in Manhattan has thrown out portions of a lawsuit accusing Liz Claiborne, the garment manufacturer, of improperly conspiring with union leaders to betray the interests of workers at a Brooklyn sweater factory. But the judge refused to dismiss two of the workers' key complaints against the union.
The opinion, released Aug. 18 by Judge Harold Baer Jr. of the Federal District Court in Manhattan, came in response to motions by Claiborne and the Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees, known as Unite, which had sought to have the case dismissed in its entirety. Although the judge refused to eliminate two claims against the union at this stage of the case, he noted that "undoubtedly it will be difficult for the plaintiffs to ultimately prevail" in their fight. 
 "Judge Baer's ruling comes at an early stage in the judicial process, before the union has had an opportunity to submit evidence on its behalf," said Jo-Ann Mort, a spokeswoman for Unite. "We are confident that the case will be dismissed completely on summary judgment, after we have had an opportunity to submit evidence."
The unusual lawsuit was filed last fall by employees of Mademoiselle Knitwear Inc. in Brooklyn, once a showcase of union-management cooperation but now in bankruptcy amid a tangle of angry litigation.
The workers asserted that Claiborne had reneged on a commitment to order many sweaters from Mademoiselle, and that the union had improperly agreed to settle an arbitration case aimed at enforcing that commitment. In exchange for the settlement, the workers charged, Claiborne agreed to pay the union approximately $20 million over three years, none of which would accrue to the benefit of Mademoiselle workers. All of the workers' claims against Claiborne were dismissed by Judge Baer.
As a result, all of Mademoiselle's "baseless and false" accusations "must be considered thoroughly discredited," said Roberta S. Karp, Claiborne's general counsel. Having also won an earlier trademark infringement case against Mademoiselle, she said, the company was confident that it would also win a separate lawsuit pending against it by Mademoiselle.
Judge Baer also dismissed the portions of the complaint that accused the union of accepting what the workers termed "a bribe" from Claiborne in exchange for settling the arbitration claims. Federal labor laws limit the enforcement of union anti-bribery provisions to government prosecutors, not to private plaintiffs, the judge ruled.
"Assuming the workers have been exploited to the extent detailed in the amended complaint with millions of dollars illegally passing from employers to the union and its leadership -- in utter disregard of the membership in their well-being -- a matter deserves a further look and is being referred to the United States Attorney's office in this district for investigation," the judge explained.
The payment was legitimately made under the terms of Claiborne's contract with the union, Ms. Karp said. The Federal prosecutor's office "has been aware for over a year of the allegations the court referred, and it has taken no action," she noted.
Judge Baer also dismissed all claims against the specific local, Local 155, that represented workers at Mademoiselle, because it had played no role in the arbitration dispute or its settlement. The arbitration had been undertaken on behalf of Mademoiselle workers by another union local, Local 23-25, with support from the parent union.
But the judge rejected arguments by Unite and Local 23-25 that their indirect relationship with the Mademoiselle workers barred any claims against them for not fairly representing those workers. "The actions attributed to Unite and Local 23-25 in initiating, conducting and settling the arbitration claims" provided sufficient grounds for the workers to assert in court that they had not been fairly represented, Judge Baer ruled.
To prevail, he noted, the workers will have to show that the union's settlement of the arbitration claims against Claiborne was "arbitrary, discriminatory, or in bad faith" -- a very difficult hurdle, he added. "Nonetheless, at this stage of litigation, the plaintiffs should be allowed to proceed," he ruled.
Howard I. Rhine, the lawyer for the Mademoiselle workers, said he was encouraged by the ruling, and was confident that the remaining claims in the complaint would move forward to trial next spring.

HEADLINE: Lawsuit Attacks Bond Issue Aimed at Indian Expatriates

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
A Long Island man who was not allowed to buy bonds being offered by two Indian banks has filed suit in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, saying the practice of offering them only to Indian expatriates violates state and Federal antidiscrimination laws.
"These banks are slapping Americans in the face by offering these bonds only to Indians," said D. Daniel Engstrand, the lawyer for the plaintiff, Leonard Schoenfeld, of Northport, who is not Indian. "A lot of people say, 'Oh, it's like Israeli bonds,' but anybody can buy Israeli bonds. They are not restricted." 
 The suit, filed as a class action on behalf of all non-Indian investors, seeks $387.5 million in compensatory damages for lost investment income and another $100 million in punitive damages from the Bank of India and the State Bank of India, both in Manhattan.
"The suit is meritless, and we intend to defend it vigorously," said Subhash Arora, vice president for operations at the Bank of India. He declined to elaborate.
A woman who answered the telephone at the State Bank of India said that she and others there had been instructed not to comment.
A spokesman with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington said that there was no securities law that would prohibit such an offering. He added, however, that civil rights law might be applicable.
The bond offering, which began earlier this month and ended yesterday, had raised $2 billion as of last week. The banks are offering 5-year Resurgent India Bonds in $2,000 increments for 7.75 percent interest. The yield on the bonds, which are backed by the Government of India and are to be used for road building and other capital projects in India, is about 2 percentage points higher than 5-year United States Treasury notes.
The bonds, which can be redeemed in dollars, are being promoted to Indian expatriates as a high-yield investment and an act of patriotism, particularly in the wake of declining Western aid following India's detonation of five nuclear devices in May.
Mr. Engstrand, however, said the refusal to sell to non-Indians was in retribution for economic sanctions imposed on India by the United States.
"It's mind-boggling," he said. "Any company doing business in the state is not allowed to refuse to do business or refuse to sell or trade on the basis on that person's nationality or heritage or origin."
Mr. Engstrand said that Mr. Schoenfeld saw an advertisement for the bonds and tried to buy them on Thursday, but both banks refused to sell them to him because he was not Indian. The suit was filed Friday.
The bonds were also offered by Citibank's Non-Resident Indian services. The department could not be reached for comment yesterday evening.
Mr. Engstrand said that the banks stated on the Internet that the bonds were available only to Indians who could prove citizenship with an Indian passport or other documentation. The site also said that people of Bangladeshi or Pakistani origin who had an Indian passport could not buy the bonds, he added.
"They cannot do this in this country," he said. "There is a Federal statute that says that any foreign bank doing business in this country must abide by the antidiscrimination statute of the state in which they are doing business, as well as the Federal antidiscrimination statutes."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Prices of Treasuries Are Mixed; 30-Year Yield Rises to 5.46%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the price of the 30-year bond down for the first time in four days as the dollar fell against the Japanese yen.
The dollar declined amid speculation that Japan was ready to take action in the currency market when necessary to bolster the value of the yen by selling dollars. 
 A weak dollar would make dollar-denominated investments like United States Government securities less attractive to foreigners, who have been supporting the recent rally in bonds by seeking the safety of bonds as stock markets overseas tumble.
The 30-year bond was down 1 4/32 , to 100 19/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.46 percent, from 5.43 percent on Friday.
Traders point out that with yields at historic lows, it is becoming harder to get investors to buy Treasury securities. Buying is not expected to increase until investors get more signs of sustained weakness in the American economy.
Another factor in bond pricing yesterday was the turbulence in the stock market. Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed-income department at the J. W. Genesis Financial Corporation in Boca Raton, Fla., said this environment was not for the faint hearted.
"Today we are seeing and getting inverse reactions to the stock market -- when stocks go up, the bond market goes down; when stocks go down, bonds go up," he said. "Right now we are pretty much in a trading range, and with global events so compelling I doubt any one of this week's economic reports will have much of an impact on prices."
The market will get reports today on consumer confidence in August and existing-home sales in July. Tomorrow durable goods orders for July will be announced, and personal income figures for July will be released on Friday.
Elsewhere, in when-issued trading ahead of tomorrow's $15 billion auction of two-year Treasury notes, the securities are being offered at a price to yield 5.19 percent.

HEADLINE: Hicks, Muse in Modest Deal For 62% Coho Energy Stake

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, venturing onto a field already littered with investor casualties, announced a $250 million bet today that the oil business is ready for a comeback.
Hicks, Muse, a leveraged buyout firm based here, agreed to pay $6 a share, in cash, for 62 percent of Coho Energy, an oil exploration and production company with properties mostly in Mississippi and Oklahoma. 
 Although the deal itself is modest, Hicks, Muse says it plans to use Coho and its managers as a platform to buy other companies that find, produce, process and transport oil. Hicks, Muse is also looking over oilfield services companies and properties that companies want to unload.
Hicks, Muse, which usually borrows more than it invests, signaled its seriousness by making its Coho purchase entirely from its own funds. For Coho, the deal amounts to a private offering of additional shares, to Hicks, Muse, that will give it the wherewithal for a shopping spree in an uncrowded market.
Thomas O. Hicks, the Hicks, Muse chairman, said his firm planned to continue buying in the next six to 18 months, then realize the gains over five or seven years as oil prices return from the current $13-a-barrel range to the $18 he predicts.
"Today is the most attractive time we've seen to invest in oil and gas in the last 10 or 15 years," Mr. Hicks said in an interview.
As oil prices have collapsed, so have shares of Coho and most others in the industry. Coho, having traded as high as $13 last fall, closed at $4.6875 on Friday. After news of the Hicks, Muse investment, they rebounded to $5.4375 today.
Analysts called the 28 percent premium over Friday's closing price that Hicks, Muse is paying a sensible long-term proposition. Coho will have the money to become a consolidator among medium-sized oil companies that might be pressed to raise cash by selling some or all of their holdings, said C. Van Levy, an analyst at Jefferies & Company. "Provided these quality properties hit the market, I think it's a good move," he said.
Among the investors who had already jumped in before the shares hit bottom are the Hicks, Muse partners themselves. In May, they personally bought 2.2 million Coho shares at nearly $7 a share. Jack D. Furst, one of those partners, said that today's investment might also be early, but that the firm needed to establish a foundation for further acquisitions now.
For Mr. Hicks, Coho represents a cautious return to a sector he last invested in about two decades ago, only to face the 1980's oil price crash. He learned that oil is too risky for companies to bear heavy debt.
One of the energy industry's best-known outside investors this time around has been Richard Rainwater of Fort Worth. Though not familiar with the Coho particulars, Mr. Rainwater praised the Hicks, Muse strategy. He, too, is hunting for oil-industry acquisitions, having already bought some shares and some oil futures. In a television interview a year ago, he said that he would relish the prospect of $12 to $13 energy prices if it created opportunities. "Now what's happened is people like Hicks, Muse who are pretty smart investors are taking advantage of it," he said today.
Though Mr. Rainwater's energy companies have fallen in recent months, he still has substantial long-term gains.
The Rainwater case for higher oil prices is based on growing global demand -- which has been slowed by Asia's economic turmoil -- and limited resources. In the Hicks, Muse outlook, low prices will force oil production cutbacks, especially in the United States, with rising demand then likewise leading to higher prices.
Coho Energy, named after the salmon to reflect its Canadian roots, operates primarily in Oklahoma, where it spent $250 million for Amoco's properties last year, and in Mississippi. The declining value of other holdings has forced it to take large write-offs this year.
Coho itself has grown through acquisitions, then proving that the acquired properties had far more oil than the sellers thought. Jeffrey Clarke, the company's chief executive, applauded Hicks, Muse's timing. "Most people get into this industry at the top," he said. "These guys have gotten in at the bottom, or as close to the bottom as you're ever going to see."

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Ruling on Planned Use of Statistical Sampling in 2000 Census

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the decision by a three-judge Federal panel in a lawsuit filed by the House of Representatives against the Commerce Department over the proposed use of statistical sampling in the 2000 census. The decision was obtained from the Federal District Court's Internet site. 
 Plaintiff, the United States House of Representatives, seeks summary judgment against the Department of Commerce and the Bureau of the Census ("defendants") in this action challenging defendants' plan for the 2000 census. Plaintiff claims that using statistical sampling to supplement the headcount enumeration used to apportion representatives among the states violates the Census Act, 13 U.S.C., and Article I, section 2, clause 3 of the Constitution. The House seeks a declaration that statistical sampling is unlawful and/or unconstitutional and an injunction preventing defendants from using statistical sampling in the 2000 census. . . .
The Constitution requires Congress to conduct an "actual Enumeration" of the population every 10 years "in such Manner as they shall by Law direct." Congress has delegated broad authority over the conduct of the census to the Secretary of Commerce through the Census Act. The Census Act governs the Census Bureau's (the "Bureau") gathering of economic, social and demographic data about the United States, including the decennial apportionment census mandated by the Constitution.
Despite the constitutional mandate to obtain an "actual enumeration" of the population, "no census is recognized as having been wholly successful in achieving that goal." The 1990 Census was no exception. According to the Bureau, " t hough better designed and executed than any previous census, the census in 1990 took a step backward on the fundamental issue of accuracy. For the first time since the Census Bureau began conducting post-census evaluations in 1940, the decennial census was less accurate than its predecessor. . . . the undercount rate of 1.8 percent in 1990 was 50 percent greater than the rate had been in 1980." United States Department of Commerce, Bureau of the Census, Report to the Congress -- The Plan for Census 2000, (revised August 1997). Specifically, the bureau reports that children, renters (particularly in rural areas), and racial and ethnic minorities were significantly undercounted. Among those the 1990 census missed were 4.4 percent of African-Americans, 5.0 percent of Hispanics, and 12.2 percent of American Indians living on reservations, but only 0.7 percent of non-Hispanic whites. This undercounting of certain groups relative to others, known as the "differential undercount," raises the possibility of Congressional malapportionment, as jurisdictions with large numbers of undercounted persons may have a greater share of the total population than the census figures suggest.
Concerned about problems with the 1990 Census, Congress passed the Decennial Census Improvement Act of 1991, which directed the National Academy of Sciences to study "the means by which the Government could achieve the most accurate population count possible," including consideration of "the appropriateness of using sampling methods in combination with basic data-collection techniques." . . .
Statistical sampling is best understood as using information derived from a portion of a population to infer information on the population as a whole. The Bureau intends to use sampling in three different phases of the 2000 census. . . .
 
Motion for Summary Judgment
The interpretation of two provisions of the Census Act, sections 141(a) and 195, is ultimately determinative as to whether statistical adjustment to the initial head count is permissible or proscribed. These provisions were last amended in 1976, and the resolution of this dispute depends upon the substantive effect of the amendments. Plaintiff contends that while the 1976 amendments encourage, if not require, the extensive use of sampling to collect the myriad of general demographic information that the Bureau is obliged to compile under the Census Act -- from occupational to educational to income -- they do not permit the use of statistical sampling to determine population for purposes of apportionment. Defendants allege that Congress's grant of authority to use sampling techniques extends to the apportionment enumeration. Other courts that have addressed these two sections and the effect of the 1976 amendments have rejected the view that the Census Act prohibits statistical sampling. For the following reasons, the court must disagree.
 
Section 195 of the Census Act
Amended section 195 provides: Except for the determination of population for purposes of apportionment of Representatives in Congress among the several States, the Secretary shall, if he considers it feasible, authorize the use of the statistical method known as "sampling" in carrying out the provisions of this title. . . .
Defendants note that the 1976 amendments to section 195 altered the call for non-apportionment use of statistical sampling methods from "may," which is an authorization, to "shall," which is a mandate. Defendants argue that an exception from a mandate is not a prohibition in the area covered by the exception; instead, the area covered by the exception is discretionary.
To illustrate defendants' interpretation of how this sentence structure operates, consider the directive, "Except for Mary, all children at the party shall be served cake." That all children other than Mary must be served cake is beyond dispute. However, that mandate does not affirmatively prohibit the host from serving cake to Mary. The decision as to whether to serve cake to Mary is, by defendants' understanding of the instruction, a matter left to the host's discretion. Applied to the instant case, defendants claim that with respect to apportionment, current section 195 commits the decision to use sampling to the discretion of the Secretary. . . .
Though defendants' interpretation of the except/shall sentence structure is proper in some instances, the court finds it to be strained and incorrect when applied to amended section 195. . . . In the party hypothetical, one would expect that the person who issued the directive "except for Mary, all children at the party shall be served cake" would be quite surprised to learn that Mary had been served cake. . . .
Consider the directive "except for my grandmother's wedding dress, you shall take the contents of my closet to the cleaners." It is far more likely that the granddaughter would be upset if the recipient of her directive were to take the wedding dress to the cleaners and subsequently argue that she had left this decision to his discretion. The reason for this result, as contrasted with the cake example, is because of our background knowledge concerning wedding dresses: We know that they are extraordinarily fragile and of deep sentimental value to family members. We therefore would not expect that the decision to take a dress to the cleaners would be purely discretionary.
The apportionment of Congressional representatives among the states is the wedding dress in the closet. . . . The apportionment function is, after all, the "sole constitutional purpose of the decennial enumeration." The manner in which it is conducted may impact not only the distribution of representatives among the states, but also the balance of political power within the House. And, the apportionment has a direct effect upon the Presidency as well, as the number of electors in the electoral college is "equal to the whole Number of Senators and Representatives to which the State may be entitled in the Congress." That the Congressional apportionment function merits particularized treatment is best demonstrated by the fact that when Congress first authorized the use of sampling in 1957, that function was expressly excepted. Having been completely explicit then, it is hard to believe that Congress decided to rely upon subtle shifts in language to direct the opposite in 1976. . . .
Ultimately, the court agrees with plaintiff's assertion that " d efendants' argument that Congress eliminated a 200-year-old prohibition against the use of statistical estimation techniques in the constitutional census by way of a permissive negative inference from an exception to a statutory mandate is wholly implausible." . . .
It is a cardinal principle of statutory interpretation that dramatic departures from past practices should not be read into statutes without a definitive signal from Congress. . . . Perhaps the most eloquent statement of this concept comes from then-Justice Rehnquist, writing in dissent in Harrison v. PPG Industries, "In a case where the construction of legislative language such as this makes so sweeping and so relatively unorthodox a change as that made here, I think judges as well as detectives may take into consideration the fact that a watchdog did not bark in the night" (quoted in Chisom). Despite defendants' characterization of the force of the legislative history, and the characterization of at least one reviewing court, the court finds no indication that the watchdog barked in the night. . . .
Congress was issuing a much stronger directive to the Department of Commerce to employ sampling methodologies in most aspects of its Title 13 data gathering responsibilities. However, Congress's explicit directive again includes that ubiquitous qualifier -- "except in the apportionment of the U.S. House of Representatives." The inclusion of this "except" language must be read to mean that one area was affirmatively carved out from the general desire to augment the use of sampling -- the area of the Congressional apportionment enumeration. The second sentence of the excerpted language is even more damaging to defendants' argument, as it states that the only difference between the old and the new section 195 is a reduction in the Secretary's discretion to use sampling, not a categorical creation of discretion in an area in which he previously had none.
The absence of the legislature's bark is all the more compelling when one considers what the watchdog is guarding. . . . The House of Representatives' apparent lack of interest in a statutory modification that goes to the fundamental matter of its composition cannot be ignored by the court.
Finally, this court agrees with plaintiff's contention that " i t borders on the absurd that Congress would enact such a momentous change in such an oblique fashion." Had Congress wished to authorize sampling techniques employed in the apportionment enumeration, it could have done so quite simply by either: a) deleting the "except" clause in its entirety; or, b) modifying the clause so as to affirmatively declare what defendants claim to be true by implication; that the Secretary may, in the exercise of his discretion, use sampling techniques to supplement the inital headcount enumeration to determine population for apportionment. Because of the straightforward means available to Congress to accomplish its purported goal, this court declines to ascribe to Congress the "surprisingly indirect route" that defendants advance.
 
Section 141(a) of the Census Act
Whatever strength there is to the claim that using statistical sampling in the apportionment enumeration does not violate the Census Act comes from the fact that section 195 must be read together with the other provision addressing sampling methodologies: section 141(a). Prior to 1976, section 141(a) did not address sampling procedures. The post-1976 version states, in relevant part: The Secretary shall, in the year 1980 and every 10 years thereafter, take a decennial census of population . . . in such form and content as he may determine, including the use of sampling procedures and special surveys (emphasis added).
To the extent that section 141(a), which standing alone appears to permit statistical sampling in Congressional apportionment, and section 195, which indisputably proscribes the same, conflict, the rules of statutory construction dictate the resolution. The more specific provision controls the general. . . .
Consequently, while 141 permits sampling techniques and surveys in the conduct of the decennial census, that general grant is subject to the more specific "Use of Sampling" directive in 195, which, as explained above, explicitly proscribes the use of sampling for apportioning representatives among the states. . . .
Reading section 141(a) and section 195 together, and considering the plain text, legislative history and other tools of statutory construction, this court finds that the use of statistical sampling to determine the population for purposes of the apportionment of representatives in Congress among the states violates the Census Act. . . .
Because this court finds that the Census Act prohibits the use of statistical sampling to determine the population for the purpose of apportionment of representatives among the states, there is no need to reach the constitutional questions presented.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Ask Wider Libya Ban if Trial Is Refused

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
If Libya refuses an offer to try two Libyan suspects in The Hague for the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, the United States will press the United Nations to extend sanctions on Libya to include an oil embargo, a senior American official said today.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook of Britain confirmed in simultaneous announcements today that they were willing for the Libyans to be tried in a third country, but by Scottish judges under Scottish law. They had previously insisted that the trial take place in the United Kingdom or the United States. 
 American officials called the offer, which is close to a proposal made by Libya, "nonnegotiable" and said Libya must respond quickly by handing over the suspects. Otherwise, they said, the offer will be withdrawn.
There was no immediate response from the Libyan leader, Muammar el-Qaddafi, but the Arab League, seeming to speak for Libya, welcomed the proposal cautiously.
In Cairo, the league Secretary General, Esmat Abdel Meguid, said today: "Libya and the Arab League are in agreement in principle, but we need to know the details, in particular whether there are any conditions. If this proposal conforms with the Arab and Libyan offer for a Scottish panel of judges to try them at The Hague in accordance with Scottish law, this would be the beginning of the solution to the crisis."
The United Nations Secretary General, Kofi Annan, who was asked by the United States and Britain to notify Libya of the details of the proposal and to handle the suspects' extradition, endorsed the idea.
The plane blew up over Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988, killing 259 people on the aircraft -- including 189 Americans -- and 11 on the ground.
"We note that Libya has repeatedly stated its readiness to deliver the suspects for trial by a Scottish court sitting in a third country," Ms. Albright said. "We now challenge Libya to turn promises into deeds."
Ms. Albright said the plan "is not subject to negotiation or change, nor should it be subject to additional foot dragging or delay."
 If Libya fails to hand over the suspects, who have been identified as Abdel Basset al-Megrahi and Lamin Khalifa Fhimah, Washington will seek an expansion of United Nations sanctions to include sales of Libyan oil, a State Department official added, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
But other officials said they considered an international oil embargo unlikely. They said, though, that a Libyan refusal would at least make it difficult for the United Nations to ease the sanctions it imposed in 1992 on Libya for refusing to hand over the suspects, who are believed to be Libyan intelligence agents.
If the suspects are handed over, both the United States and Britain will support action in the Security Council to suspend the international sanctions against Libya, which include a ban on flights to and from the country. But American unilateral sanctions against Libya for being what it considers a "state sponsor of terrorism" will continue, American officials said.
Libya has repeatedly broken the ban on flights, sending token flights to Mecca in Saudi Arabia for the annual Muslim pilgrimage. Foreign dignitaries, including President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt last month and President Idriss Deby of Chad today, have started flying to and from Tripoli, the Libyan capital, instead of traveling by road.
Libya has not made any recent announcements on the proposal for a trial in a third country, but the lawyer for the suspects, Ibrahim Legwell, said last month that they would accept a trial in The Hague "if the conditions for a fair trial are provided."
At the time, Mr. Legwell's conditions included an international panel of judges, which the United States and Britain have rejected. But the Libyan Foreign Minister, Omar Mustafa al-Montassir, said explicitly in a letter to the United Nations in January that the judges could be Scottish.
If convicted, the suspects could serve up to 30 years in a Scottish prison, American officials said.
Ms. Albright and the National Security Adviser, Samuel R. Berger, told the families of those who died in the Pan Am bombing about the decision in a conference call this morning. "These families don't all agree on the proper strategy for achieving accountability in this case," Ms. Albright said. "But they all agree that the delays in bringing the suspects to trial have gone on for far too long."
Susan Cohen of Cape May Court House, N.J., whose daughter, Theodora, died in the explosion and crash, said she was very upset about the outcome. "Today has been a day which has been, in a sense, a victory for Qaddafi and the terrorists," Mrs. Cohen said in a telephone interview. "This sets a bad precedent. If terrorists out-wait us, do they now have a right to decide where to be tried? I don't think the Administration has really thought through the longterm implications of this."
American officials in contact with all the families said a majority of them favored the proposal.
Glenn Johnson of Greensburg, Pa., said in an interview today that he, his wife, Carole, and the board members of the group, Survivors of Pan Am 103, supported the idea.
"We felt this might allow us to get justice and get off-center," he said. "This still meets with what we can live with. With everything that's happened, we need to take the initiative, and this will force Qaddafi to make a decision."

HEADLINE: U.S. and Iraq Toughen Stances on Weapons Inspection

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 24

 BODY:
The United States and Iraq hardened their positions today over Baghdad's decision to end cooperation with weapons inspections.
Washington and Britain have begun pressing for an end to periodic sanctions reviews, which would have the effect of keeping Iraq permanently under a crushing embargo "until they're back on the reservation," a Western diplomat said. 
 The last review was in April; the next was scheduled for October.
Iraq insists on a more friendly inspection system and perhaps another visit, or a new initiative, from Secretary General Kofi Annan, bypassing the Security Council.
The new statements of resolve -- stopping well short of any kind of military threat on Washington's part -- followed a report to the Security Council this morning by Mr. Annan's special envoy to Iraq on his unsuccessful attempt last week to persuade the Iraqi Government to resume cooperation.
The envoy, Prakash Shah, an Indian diplomat, told the Council members that in two essentially perfunctory meetings with Iraqi officials in Baghdad earlier this month he had been told that the United Nations was offering nothing new and therefore there was nothing to discuss.
Peter Burleigh, the deputy United States representative said that Mr. Shah "basically said to the Council that he's gotten nowhere."
"The U.S. position is that we will be consulting this week, looking toward a Council resolution on Iraq," Mr. Burleigh said. "We're suggesting the suspension of sanctions reviews until Iraq comes back into cooperation."
Nizar Hamdoon, Iraq's representative to the United Nations, said Baghdad still wants a new set of inspectors to replace the existing United Nations Special Commission, known as Unscom, which is responsible for dismantling biological and chemical weapons, missile systems, and the means to produce them.
Iraq has also stopped cooperating with the International Atomic Energy Agency, which monitors nuclear developments.
Mr. Hamdoon also did not rule out shutting down all future technical monitoring and surveillance of Iraq in addition to ending surprise visits by United Nations inspectors, which were terminated on Aug. 5. He said all options remained open to Iraq.
"We have stopped all cooperation with Unscom," Mr. Hamdoon told reporters, "and we are waiting the genuine move on the Council's part to address Iraq's concerns."
"Most important is the restructuring of Unscom as a body," Mr. Hamdoon said. "Unless this restructuring takes place, Iraq finds it very difficult -- almost impossible -- to have any meaningful cooperation with Unscom."
Mr. Hamdoon's pitch to bring the Secretary General into direct negotiations with Iraq again is meeting a cooler reception from Mr. Annan's aides this time, diplomats said. He reached an agreement with Iraq at meetings there in February, averting a crisis.
Washington, which was not enthusiastic about the involvement of the Secretary General earlier this year, now seems intent on keeping him in the forefront of the debate with Iraq, some Council members say. Iraq has violated its agreement with Mr. Annan as well as Security Council resolutions.
Another trip to Baghdad by Mr. Annan has been discussed only in general and preliminary terms, diplomats say. Iraq has not invited him.

HEADLINE: Giuliani Takes Credit for Growth in Tourism

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
A record number of people visited New York City last year, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his quality-of-life campaign had played a crucial role.
The number of travelers to the city reached 33 million in 1997, up 3.9 million from 1996, Mr. Giuliani said. There was a sharper increase in American visitors than in foreign visitors, who made up only about 20 percent of the total. The number of American business travelers reached 10.4 million, up 28 percent, while the number of American vacationers reached 16.5 million, up 8 percent. 
 Mr. Giuliani and Fran Reiter, president of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau, said the strong national economy, hotel construction and increased investment in Times Square were all partly responsible for the jump in tourism. But the Mayor also eagerly credited his quality-of-life initiatives, including bans on sex shops in residential neighborhoods and tighter rules on where businesses can store garbage.
"You shouldn't minimize the importance of improving the quality of life," said Mr. Giuliani, announcing the tourism figures at a news conference in the Novotel hotel in midtown Manhattan. "When people come to this city and see it better than they saw it before, then this is a city they'd want to come back to."
He added, "Each one of the efforts may seem like a small one, but it has a tremendous amount to do with the overall revival of the spirit of the city."
The new domestic tourism figures came from a survey conducted by D. K. Shifflet & Associates, a research company in McLean, Va., which mails questionnaires to 25,000 households around the nation each month asking about recent trips and travel plans. About 60 percent usually respond, said Michelle Schwartz, a spokeswoman for the tourism bureau, which pays D. K. Shifflet for the New York parts of the survey. The statistics on foreign visitors came from the United States Department of Commerce, she said.
New York City was the third most popular destination for American travelers last year, after Orlando, Fla., and Las Vegas, Nev., according to the tourism bureau. In 1996 it ranked fifth, behind Orlando, Atlanta, Chicago and Las Vegas.
Among foreign countries, Argentina accounted for the largest increase in tourists, sending 161,000 Argentines to New York last year, up 46 percent from 1996. The number of visitors from Brazil increased by 31 percent, to 333,000. And the United Kingdom sent 726,000 visitors, up 29 percent from 1996. The largest number of visitors, 983,000, came from Canada, a decrease of 7 percent. The number of tourists from Switzerland fell by 28 percent, and the number from South Korea fell by 27 percent.
Ms. Reiter, formerly Mr. Giuliani's Deputy Mayor and campaign manager, was appointed president of the tourism bureau last winter and promised to mount a more intensive effort to promote tourism in the city. The bureau had been criticized by hotel and restaurant industry leaders for failing to come up with more imaginative ways to lure visitors.
This year has been different, Ms. Reiter said. The city has tried to recruit more tourists from Britain and Germany by putting on elaborate dinners for tourism executives in those countries.
The tourism bureau flew chefs from Lutece, the Rainbow Room, Windows on the World and the "21" Club to London and Frankfurt to cook the dinners, Ms. Schwartz said. Retailers including F.A.O. Schwarz and Donna Karan set up exhibits, and musicians performed songs from Broadway musicals, she said.
The tourism bureau is planning similar marketing efforts for Latin American countries, Ms. Reiter said.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: IN PAKISTAN;
Missile Said to Be in Hands of Afghan Neighbor

BYLINE: By BARRY BEARAK 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Aug. 24

 BODY:
An unexploded American missile, believed to be a stray from last week's attack on suspected guerrilla training centers in Afghanistan, has been found in a remote area of Pakistan, the Pakistani Foreign Ministry said today.
This proves that Pakistani airspace was violated during the missile barrage, the Ministry said in a statement, adding that a formal complaint would be made to the United Nations Security Council. 
 Panic-stricken villagers discovered the long object lodged in the sand and informed local authorities, press reports said, and an evacuation was ordered.
The missile was handed over to the military, the Foreign Ministry said.
American officials here had little to say about the allegation. "The Government of Pakistan brought this story to our attention, and we are looking into it," said Richard Hoagland, the spokesman for the American Embassy here.
Soon after the attack on the camps in Afghanistan, Pakistan had said that a missile had fallen within its soil, killing several people. To Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's embarrassment, this charge was then deemed incorrect and had to be withdrawn.
So far, Pakistan's protests about the American attack have been delicately measured, attempting to mollify its angry citizens while at the same time not distancing itself unnecessarily from the United States, whose influence might be needed to help Pakistan out of its economic crisis.
The country is close to defaulting on billions of dollars in international loans.
Pakistan is rife with conflicting rumors: that the Government had advance knowledge of the attack and betrayed its allies in Afghanistan; that the Government tipped off the main target, Osama bin Laden, who is accused by the United States of financing terrorist attacks, thus saving his life, and that the Government actually attempted to finger Mr. bin Laden and pinpoint his whereabouts.
Islamic militants here have insisted that Pakistan was a willing helpmate for the United States' attack in Afghanistan.
One group, the Jammat-I-Islami, has charged that, in preparation for the attack, American warships breached Pakistani waters in the Arabian Sea and that the Pakistani Navy chose to ignore them..
But just as the Foreign Ministry was complaining today about American violations of Pakistani airspace, the Defense Ministry dismissed any notion of American encroachment in its seas, saying the warships were "well clear" of its territorial waters.
"It is important that national interests not be compromised by making wild statements," said a Defense Ministry spokesman.

Investors Mixed on Moves By Russian Government
Investors around the globe took a cautiously optimistic view of the latest moves by Russia to reverse its recent economic slide. On Wall Street, stocks ended mixed, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 32.96 points, to 8,566.61. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index added 6.96 points, to 1,088.14, while the Nasdaq composite index fell 6.79 points, to 1,790.82.
Markets around the world were mixed. Russia's benchmark equity index rose 5.67 percent. In Japan, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues fell 2.03 percent. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index increased 4.2 percent. Markets in Brazil and Chile fell more than 1 percent. Page D10
 
Top Yeltsin officials promised to share power with the Communist-dominated Parliament that has sought to frustrate the nation's economic reforms. A1
 
German banks, the biggest lenders to Russia, with about $30 billion in outstanding loans, are carefully watching the crisis in Russia. The German Government has guaranteed repayment of most of that money, and stands to lose billions if the loans go sour. A8

Merrill Lynch has agreed to pay $2 million to settle Securities and Exchange Commission charges that it failed to tell buyers of Orange County, Calif., bonds important information it knew about the county's precarious financial condition. D2

Northrop Grumman is cutting its work force by 15 percent by the end of 2000. Most of the job cuts will be in Southern California. D6

A New Drug for Crohn's Disease
The Food and Drug Administration approved the first drug specifically for Crohn's disease, an often debilitating bowel ailment. The drug, infliximab, will be marketed under the brand name Remicade by its maker, Centocor of Malverne, Pa. F6
 
Hyundai and Union Settle Strike
Workers for Hyundai Motor played soccer while waiting for the settlement that was reached yesterday, ending a strike that crippled South Korea's largest auto maker. Hyundai and the union have agreed to cut 277 jobs, only one-sixth the number sought by management. The outcome illustrated how hard it was for South Korean companies to dismiss workers. D4
 
Judge Dismisses Part of a Lawsuit
A Federal judge has thrown out portions of a lawsuit accusing the clothing manufacturer Liz Claiborne of improperly conspiring with union leaders to betray the interests of workers at a Brooklyn sweater factory. But the judge refused to dismiss two of the workers' complaints against the union. D5
 
Spanish Hotels to Stay Competitive

HEADLINE: Study Puts High Price on Fixing a Crumbling City

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
Offering a sobering portrait of an aging metropolis, a new study by the City Comptroller has found that New York would have to spend more than $90 billion over the next decade to make the necessary repairs to put the city's subways, water mains, schools and bridges in safe working order.
The figure is vastly higher than the $52 billion that government agencies now plan to spend on repairs. But the Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, said that if City Hall, the Board of Education and the Transit Authority did not spend more money now on repairs and maintenance, conditions would further deteriorate, meaning costs would be much higher in the future. 
 "If the ultimate goal is to have an adequate physical plant where every facility functions well and safely, this is what is required," Mr. Hevesi said in an interview. "It is not a wish list. This is not the optimal. This is by our definition a state of good repair."
The Comptroller and his report dealt only with the city's fundamental infrastructure; they did not address recent problems -- falling bricks, crashing scaffolding -- that have plagued construction sites and privately owned buildings in the city.
The idea that parts of the city's infrastructure are deteriorating is certainly not new. But the report -- based on the work of auditors, investigators and engineers -- is the first in 20 years to describe the scope of the problem and to estimate the money needed to make repairs.
Schools and the city transit system account for more than half of the projected cost in the report. Providing more space for growing enrollment, and repairing many of the city's 1,028 aging school buildings would cost $28 billion. Fixing the city transit system, including rebuilding and repairing subway stations and improving track and signaling systems, would take an additional $21 billion, the report maintained.
Like any projection, those in the report are based on assumptions -- ranging from the influence of the weather on water pipes to how many people will be riding subways or attending schools -- that may or may not prove accurate in the future.
David Neustadt, a spokesman for the Comptroller, said teams of engineers made sample visits to more than 200 sites and then used what they learned to make projections about the likely condition of similar sites. The investigators also reviewed records from 18 agencies, and used the agencies' own condition reports to make their evaluation.
A spokeswoman for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Colleen Roche, declined to comment on the report yesterday afternoon. "We have not been given the same courtesy of being given a copy of the report," she said. "I am not able to comment on what appears to be government by press release."
Mr. Neustadt said that the Comptroller's conclusions were discussed with each agency before the report was written and that there were no major objections.
"None of this," Mr. Hevesi added, "is offered with hostile intent or to be critical." He described the status of the city's infrastructure as " a huge governmental problem that we have to solve."
Despite its large price tag for repairs, Mr. Hevesi's report has some good news. It found that since the city's fiscal crisis of the 1970's, the city has made strides in improving the condition of many parts of its infrastructure, including the subways, jails and many sanitation stations. Over all, the Comptroller said, New York is "a very well-managed city." But the sheer size of the city's physical assets, combined with the cost of maintaining them and their age -- many of them are rapidly reaching the end of their typical life span -- makes it difficult to find a single solution.
The 900-page report, in the works for 18 months, reflects the varied needs and the ways in which small items can quickly add up:
*The city has 223 firehouses, many of which were built decades ago and not designed to handle modern, 12,000-pound fire engines. As a result, floors in 125 firehouses are in danger of buckling, or have already begun to give way. Although the Fire Department has shored up the floors, it only has had the money to fix 46 floors.
*The city's East River bridges -- the Brooklyn, Manhattan, Williamsburg and Queensboro Bridges -- are undergoing a $3.2 billion rehabilitation. Of the city's 838 other bridges, more than 70 percent are in poor or fair condition. The report says 148 bridges are expected to deteriorate from good condition to fair condition in the next 10 years if maintenance is not increased.
*The report projects a shortage of beds in homeless shelters in two years. By 2007, a shortage of between 1,556 and 4,800 beds is predicted. There are no plans to build more shelters.
*By 2007, 1,060 miles of water mains -- about one-sixth of the system -- will be more than 100 years old, which is their predicted life span. The city only has money to replace 204 miles.
*More than 340 of the city's 468 subway stations need major renovations, at an estimated cost of $5.96 billion. The transit agency expects to spend about $1.82 billion on the repairs in the next five years.
"The title of the study is 'Dilemma in the Millennium,' " Mr. Hevesi said. "And it is a dilemma, it really is."
The city does not have the money to fix everything. And, the Comptroller said that even if the money was available, it would be impossible to do so much construction at the same time. The very effort of digging up pipes, tearing up highways and closing off buildings for repair could bring chaos.
In addition, the city is still paying off debts from financing past projects. Now, about 16 percent of the city's tax revenues go toward paying off its debt, according to the city's Independent Budget Office.
"There is a real tension between the need to spend additional money on infrastructure and the need to control debt service," Douglas A. Criscitello, director of that budget office, said, adding that his office projected that the debt service should reach 18.6 percent by 2002.
"It seems to go in cycles," he said. "The city backed away from some of its capital needs after the 70's fiscal crisis and recommitted in the 1980's. It dipped in the early 90's and has gone back up since then. It tracks the economy."
Samuel I. Schwartz, director of Cooper Union's Infrastructure Institute, said that the city's spending on infrastructure began to drop after World War II and that this accelerated after the 1970's fiscal crisis.
"At the turn of the century, there were 200 workers cleaning the Brooklyn Bridge," said Mr. Schwartz, a former chief engineer for the city's Transportation Department. "By the mid-1980's, there were three."
Mr. Schwartz said the city faced a longstanding problem since deferring maintenance would create greater spending needs in the future. He said the city should consider setting aside money, perhaps from its budget surplus, for annual maintenance.
"The Williamsburg Bridge is a terrific example," he said, citing continuing repairs to the 98-year-old bridge, which also needed extensive maintenance in the 1980's. "Had we maintained the bridge properly, in 1990 dollars we would have spent $190 million over 90 years. Instead, we are going to have to spend in excess of $400 million while we suffer enormous delays due to lane closings."
It is not absolutely necessary that every city asset is in perfect working order, Mr. Hevesi, the Comptroller, said, provided that the city has a plan to manage problems associated with an aging system. The city's Environmental Protection Department, for example, contends that it is more effective to replace water mains during street repairs, or when there is an indication of a problem, than to rip up existing mains based on their age.
Joel A. Miele, the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner, said age was not the primary cause of water main breaks, even when the mains were more than 100 years old. Mr. Miele said the number of main breaks each year had remained constant during the 50 years that the department has kept records. (The 11-year average is 576 breaks, and there were 461 last year.)
Mr. Miele said he did not believe that the department needed any more money to manage safely the water system. He pointed out that the department had kept the number of breaks down and was developing a new computer system to track the condition of water and sewer lines across the city.
"We are very comfortable with the schedule we have," Mr. Miele said.
Improvements to infrastructure are often costly and can be practically invisible to the general public, and therefore are not a favorite topic of politicians. "I can't recall any politician who ran successfully on the issue of infrastructure," said Roy Sparrow, a professor at New York University's School of Public Service.
On the other hand, Mr. Sparrow said, what made New York into a great city was a long-term investment in bridges, ports, railways and roads. The city, he added, is now coming the limit of that investment.
"We are living on past capital," he said.
