HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE CONNECTION;
Doubts Grow That Taliban Would Give Up Terrorist Mastermind to the U.S.

BYLINE: By STEVE LeVINE and RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Aug. 24

 BODY:
With Osama bin Laden having apparently survived the barrage of missiles rained down on his stronghold across the border in Afghanistan, the United States still has the problem of how to get its hands on the man it considers the No. 1 terrorist.
One possibility that has been floated is for the United States to negotiate with the Taliban, the Islamic movement that controls most of Afghanistan, to surrender Mr. bin Laden -- perhaps in exchange for several million dollars in aid or even diplomatic recognition. 
 But diplomats who have dealt with the Taliban doubt that anything could come of such negotiations, particularly with their anger over Thursday's attack.
Furthermore, the Taliban have repeatedly failed to keep promises to United Nations agencies and Western governments -- promises to stop the opium trade, to form a broad-based government and to ease its restrictions on women, like forbidding them to work or to get higher education.
Diplomats and experts say the Taliban will not relinquish Mr. bin Laden largely because of his relationship to Mohammad Omar, the "supreme" leader of the Taliban.
Mr. Omar, 39, is rarely heard from or seen in public, keeping company mostly with a small group of subordinates in the Taliban's leadership council. Mr. bin Laden is one of the few individuals outside this group whom Mr. Omar has permitted to become close to him.
Both men were part of the mujahedeen movement, which waged war against the Soviet Union during its military intervention in Afghanistan from 1979 to 1989. But they did not meet then.
Mr. Omar is said to have fought with a moderate faction and emerged from the war a virtual unknown.
Mr. bin Laden, who inherited a fortune that his father earned building roads in Saudi Arabia, commanded a unit of volunteers under the nom de guerre Abu Abdullah and earned a reputation for being courageous and charismatic. His unit captured the southeastern Afghan city of Khost, in the area bombed on Thursday night. He lost the toes on his left foot in combat.
Not long after the 1989 Soviet withdrawal, Mr. bin Laden, who was not welcome in his native Saudi Arabia because of support for militants, moved to the Sudan and lived in a spacious, well-guarded home on a dusty road in the capital, Khartoum.
It was in the Sudan that Mr. bin Laden, along with building roads, reportedly began to finance militant Islamic movements and assaults against governments he opposed. In 1993, he reportedly sent his operatives into Somalia to attack the American-led peacekeeping mission.
Under pressure from the United States and Saudi Arabia, the Sudan deported him, along with other alleged terrorists, in 1996.
Mr. bin Laden returned to Afghanistan, which was racked by civil war. The mujahedeen leaders ensconced in Kabul, the capital, were fighting among themselves. And a new group had emerged -- the Taliban, whose core fighters came out of Saudi-financed religious schools in Pakistan.
In two years, the Taliban had risen to capture the entire south and most of the west of Afghanistan.
But the Taliban military drive stalled. Its financial resources had all but dried up, and diplomats and Western relief officials who visited the movement's center in Kandahar, the traditional royal capital, believed that it had peaked and was on the decline.
Then Pakistani intelligence officers, who were backing the Taliban, introduced its leaders to a new, wealthy friend -- Mr. bin Laden. Money traditionally plays a key role in Afghan political and military shifts, by winning the fealty of local leaders.
Mr. bin Laden gave $3 million to the movement, said Afghans and diplomats familiar with the transaction, a sum that could go a long way in the poor nation.
With the money in hand, the Taliban and their Pakistani allies began a round of visits to important militia commanders in eastern Afghanistan. These local leaders were plied with cash and threats of lost power, and many agreed to ally themselves with the Taliban.
In a sweep in the beginning of September 1996, the Taliban rushed north with little resistance, capturing Jalalabad. Ten days later, Kabul fell.
Mr. Omar's gratitude to Mr. bin Laden was quickly apparent. Mr. bin Laden, his three wives and a 160-member coterie shifted south to Kandahar. There the two men were often seen together, and an enormous house was built for Mr. bin Laden.
Mr. Omar remains financially beholden to Mr. bin Laden. Economically destitute and considered a renegade movement by much of the world, the Taliban have few sources of income. Chief among them has been opium. Western diplomats said this week that the opium production in areas it controls was increasing and that there were heroin-processing labs inside Afghanistan.
A Pakistan official here said that if Mr. bin Laden was giving the Taliban $10 million a year -- no one knows the real amount -- it would be a lot in the desperately poor country.
In the last few days, Mr. Omar has demonstrated his loyalty.
"We will never hand Osama over to anyone," Mr. Omar said last week. "We will protect him with our blood at all cost."
The air strikes are not likely to diminish that loyalty, diplomats said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
British Air Likely to Buy Airbus Planes

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, Aug. 24

 BODY:
British Airways, in a blow to the Boeing Company, is expected to announce its first purchase from the rival Airbus Industrie, awarding a contract this week for as many as 259 medium-range, single-aisle planes worth $11 billion, managers at one of the companies said.
The order, if all options are exercised, would be the largest to Airbus by a European airline, as well as British Airways' first break in recent years with Boeing, its main supplier. 
 British Airways, which is the biggest European carrier, is also buying long-haul Boeing 777 jets. The combined purchases are expected to be the basis of an overhaul of the British carrier's routes, which will emphasize point-to-point flights, rather than using feeder aircraft to bring passengers to major hubs, like Heathrow, London's principal airport.
Initially, British Airways is expected to order 59 planes in the Airbus A320 family, with options for as many as 200 more. The value of the orders reflects the planes' list price, but airlines usually receive a discount on large and long-term agreements.
The order -- which could be announced as early as Tuesday, when Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain is to visit Airbus headquarters in Toulouse, France -- would be especially welcome to Airbus at a time when the Asian economic crisis has taken a toll. The big Asian carriers had been the mainstay of its business in recent years.
Seeking to portray British Airways' anticipated order as gain for Boeing as well, an executive for the Seattle-based company said late today that Boeing planned on Tuesday to announce a British Airways order for 16 777's and options to buy 16 more, worth about $5 billion based on current list prices.
Still, airline-industry analysts called the Airbus decision a defeat for Boeing in its effort to sell an updated version of its 737. It was the second major European victory for Airbus this year; in February Iberia, the Spanish airline, decided to order as many as 76 medium-haul jets worth $4 billion from Airbus, instead of the 737.
"In this segment, Airbus has put not only its foot in the door, but its whole leg," said Raymond E. Neidl, of Furman Selz in New York. "It's a big loss for Boeing."
Although neither company would confirm the reports, rumors had circulated for some time that British Airways would place an order with Airbus, because of both the European consortium's aggressive pricing and its political access. British Airways said in February that it would ask Boeing and Airbus for bids for short-haul planes to replace aging ones for regional European subsidiaries.
At the time, British Airways executives said they wanted to buy about 30 medium-range planes, worth about $975 million, with options on 70 more, which would have taken the order up to roughly $3.2 billion.
The much larger order appears to reflect the rapid pace of deregulation in Europe, and the challenge posed by heightened competition, both from strengthened mainstream carriers, like Lufthansa, and from newer, no-frills airlines. Earlier this year, British Airways joined the no-frills battle, with a low-fare affiliate called Go.
The Airbus family of single-aisle A320's, which began chipping away at Boeing's 737 about a decade ago, comprises the A320, which carries as many as 150 passengers; the A319, with up to 126 passengers, and the A321, which also carries up to 150.
If British Airways takes delivery of all 259 planes, Airbus would be likely to outstrip Boeing as the carrier's leading provider of aircraft. British Airways has about 350 planes in its fleet.
Still, it appeared that Boeing would not be a total loser. Earlier this month, Robert Ayling, British Airways' chief executive, said the carrier would also order long-haul, wide-bodied jets to meet its future needs as airline deregulation progresses in Europe, and many industry experts expect it to choose Boeing's 777. In the past, British Airways has mainly flown Boeing 747's, 757's, 767's and 777's.
The driving forces behind the British fleet overhaul are moves by the Continent's airlines to deregulation, and British Airways' proposed alliance with American Airlines. Under conditions set by the European Commission for the alliance with American, an AMR Corporation unit, British Airways will have to rely heavily on wide-bodied planes like the 777 for point-to-point flights, while the short-haul Airbus fleet will be used on domestic British and European routes.
Airbus is working to transform itself from a consortium of four European aircraft makers -- Aerospatiale of France, Daimler-Benz Aerospace, British Aerospace P.L.C. and Construcciones Aeronauticas of Spain -- into a single corporation that would be a linchpin of a restructured European aerospace and arms industry.
In July, giving in to British and German pressure, France announced it would relinquish full Government control of Aerospatiale, the nation's largest aerospace company, by selling a big stake to Groupe Lagardere and offering shares on the stock market.

HEADLINE: U.S. Forest Service Hopes to Buy a Costly, but Picture-Perfect, Slice of West

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: JEMEZ SPRINGS, N.M.

 BODY:
In what would be the largest purchase of private land by the United States Forest Service in at least a quarter-century, Congress and the Clinton Administration are working together on a deal for the Baca Ranch, a 95,000-acre expanse of pristine meadows and fir-covered mountains so emblematic of the West that it has served as backdrop for Stetson hat advertisements and Marlboro Man billboards.
For Hollywood directors, Madison Avenue advertisers, or the rare invited guest, the appeal of the isolated greensward cupped in the walls of an ancient volcano is often the same. The family-owned Baca Ranch imparts a rare sense of discovery. Driving on Route 4 over a dark and winding mountain pass, the visitor suddenly emerges into a "Lost Horizon" world of hot springs, trout streams and meadows of wildflowers, where cattle and the state's largest elk herd graze side by side. 
 But the same sense of wide-open Western independence evoked by the vistas has prevented the sale of the land for years. And the deal that is being negotiated for the ranch, which has been owned by one family for almost 40 years, is as much about Western attitudes toward public land as it is about money.
The Administration has long supported the purchase of the ranch, which has been called "the hole in the doughnut" because it is an island surrounded by the Santa Fe National Forest. Last February on a visit to New Mexico, President Clinton even had Air Force One make a detour to fly over the ranch for a better view of its dominant feature -- the 15-mile-wide crater of the dormant volcano.
Republicans, noting that almost one-third of New Mexico is already owned by the Federal Government, have long opposed further purchases. But in August, Republican sentiment began shifting dramatically.
Under legislation drafted by Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, the Baca would be a separate unit of the National Forest system, owned by the United States Forest Service, but managed by a trust, comprised of members appointed by the President. This board would be charged with responding to local concerns and making the park economically self-sustaining.
In addition, Mr. Domenici's bill would tie an agreement to buy the ranch to legislation intended to speed sales of lands owned by the Bureau of Land Management that the agency has decided it does not need.
Republicans, particularly those in Western states, are eager to free up more Federal land for private development.
Mr. Domenici said today that the sale of such land could increase support among Western senators for his legislation, to be introduced early next month.
"I think we could get set aside, this fall, $20 million to $40 million," Mr. Domenici said, "money that says to the owners we are going to do business."
 Reflecting this new Republican interest, the Baca Ranch was visited on Monday by three Republican House members, Bill Redmond, of northern New Mexico; James V. Hansen of Utah, who chairs the National Parks and Public Lands subcommittee of the House Resources Committee, and Ralph Regula of Ohio, the chairman of the Interior subcommittee of the Appropriations committee. After a tour by helicopter and jeep, Mr. Redmond described the Baca as the "Grand Canyon of northern New Mexico."
The last time the owners, the Dunigans, an oil family from Abilene, Tex., expressed interest in selling the ranch, in 1980, the price was $55 million. Competition for the land between the National Park Service and the National Forest Service, as well as the death of the family patriarch, James Patrick Dunigan, squelched any sale.
Although new appraisals have not been completed, the 1998 price could easily be twice as high.
Driving up the price, and public interest, is tremendous population growth in Santa Fe and Albuquerque, two of the state's three largest cities, which are about 90 minutes by car from the ranch. In 1915, when President Woodrow Wilson first considered buying the ranch, recreational tourism was an embryonic activity. Now, more than three million people visit the Santa Fe National Forest every year.
"The Baca could be the Rocky Mountain National Park for the new Santa Fe-Albuquerque megalopolis," said Roger G. Kennedy, a former National Park Service director who lives in Santa Fe, referring to the Colorado park that draws many of its visitors from Denver and Boulder.
 Mr. Kennedy, who ran the National Park Service until 1996, said acquisition of the Baca Ranch was similar to the purchase of land for national parks at the start of the century.
"It's the largest piece of inviolate land anywhere near a major city," he said. "Everything else that size is either very remote or very ugly. This is beautiful and close."
The ranch began to approach its present form about one million years ago, when two massive explosions blew the top off a volcano here, sending 100 cubic miles of ash and lava into the air, some of it reaching what is now Kansas.
In modern times, Indians from the Jemez and Santa Clara pueblos hunted the area in the summer. In 1860, Congress settled a land dispute among ranchers by giving the area to heirs of Luis Maria Cabeza de Vaca, a Mexican sheep rancher. From 1926 to 1962, the ranch was owned by the Bond family, who first grazed sheep, then cattle on the land. Separately, a timber company heavily logged about half of the forest area.
"It's a smaller kind of Yellowstone, with a number of hot spots in the streams," said Frank M. Bond, a Santa Fe lawyer, recalling childhood summers spent on the remote ranch. "Because it has a much more temperate climate that the rest of the Rockies, it has a greater number of bird species."
On a recent afternoon, red-tailed hawks could be seen circling meadows, looking for prairie dogs that popped in and out of their holes. Grouse, mourning doves, flickers and bluebirds abound in this private reserve, which ranges from grasslands and aspens in the valleys to spruce and fir at high elevations, up to 11,000 feet.
In 1962, James Patrick Dunigan bought the ranch for $2.5 million and began gentler management. Through expensive court battles, he ended the timber lease and stopped most of the logging. Mr. Dunigan died in 1980, in the midst of negotiations to sell the ranch to the Federal Government.
His heirs have maintained his management pattern, avoiding overgrazing and logging largely for the health of the forest. Giving priority to the elk, which were reintroduced after World War II, the ranch now maintains more than two elk for every cow -- about 7,000 elk and 3,000 cows.
"I personally have always thought we have been here as caretakers," Anne Dunigan Wilson, Mr. Dunigan's widow, said on a recent visit to a fieldstone hunting lodge her husband had built here.
Andrew Dunigan, one of her sons, said the family has set a December deadline for Congress to show that it is serious about buying the property.
"We are offering the Government and the American people the first opportunity to buy the property," said Mr. Dunigan, a private investor in Dallas. "This is clearly one of the most desirable trophy ranches. There has been great interest over the years by private individuals, some conservation-oriented, some development-oriented."
County zoning allows for houses to be built on lots as small as three quarters of an acre. With growing demand by New Mexico's city dwellers for second homes in the mountains, the threat is real.
"Mobile homes with skirts around them -- that's the specter now," said Dave Simon, regional director of the National Parks and Conservation Association, a group in Washington. As he bounced in a van along a ranch road, Mr. Simon added: "There is constant pressure on ranchers up here to develop. The best places up here would be cherry-picked for development."
The threat of development has caused many conservationists to rally behind the new bipartisan efforts to preserve the area. But environmentalists and the Administration insist that any board be charged with putting conservation values ahead of economic values in running the ranch as a park.
"The resource values of this property must come first," Kathleen McGinty, chairman of the White House Council on Environmental Quality, said in a statement after visiting the ranch in July. "The trustees may not sacrifice those values in an effort to make the property financially self-sufficient."
While aides of Republican and Democratic Congressional members work to hammer out legislative language by Labor Day, negotiations are spurred by the thought of the Baca Ranch being sold to developers.
"I would hate to see it divided up and sold off," said Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, and a longtime advocate of public ownership of the ranch. "I think prospects are good that we can go ahead when Congress reconvenes."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Fed Reports Decline in Loans to Large Businesses

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Business loans to large customers declined in the second quarter, the first decline since the first quarter of 1996, according to a survey by the Federal Reserve.
The Fed said today that in general the survey provided additional evidence of narrowing of interest-rate spreads but smaller changes in other terms and in lending standards. 
 The Fed said 9 percent of domestic respondents indicated that demand for loans to large customers had softened, attributing the weakness to decreased merger and acquisition activity, lower investment in plant and equipment and more financing from nonbank loan sources. The use of internally generated funds and a decrease in needs for inventory financing also contributed to the lower demand, the Fed said.
The Fed polled 57 domestic banks and American branches of foreign banks for the quarterly survey.
It showed few changes in standards for commercial and industrial loans to middle-sized and large corporate customers among domestic respondents. Just 5 percent of banks eased standards to smaller firms, while 15 percent reported narrowing spreads on loans to medium and large firms, down from 35 percent in the May survey.
In July, acting Comptroller of Currency Julie Williams said a similar survey by her office found banks more willing to accept downside risk "without commensurate potential upside return."

HEADLINE: Fatalities From Drunken Driving Drop, but Total Traffic Deaths Hold Steady

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

 BODY:
New figures on traffic deaths, released yesterday by Federal safety regulators, showed that campaigns against drunken driving are producing some success even as the overall number of deaths on the nation's roads remains stubbornly high.
Alcohol-related traffic deaths in the United States dropped by 1,029 last year, a 6 percent decrease from 1996. But the overall number of traffic deaths was virtually unchanged as 931 more people were killed in crashes that did not involve alcohol, a 3.7 percent increase, according to statistics released yesterday by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which is part of the Transportation Department. 
 Traffic deaths involving alcohol plunged in the 1980's but had been showing signs of leveling off until the release of yesterday's data. Alcohol was involved in only 38.6 percent of all traffic deaths last year, the lowest percentage since the Federal Government began keeping records in 1975.
Karolyn Nunnallee, the president of Mothers Against Drunk Driving, said that the decrease in 1997 appeared to reflect a public reaction to the Princess of Wales's death in a car crash on Aug. 31 last year, and to a long-running fight in Congress over whether to require states to lower the minimum level of alcohol in blood at which a driver is considered legally drunk.
Tests after the crash that killed Diana found that her driver had consumed several times the quantity of alcohol necessary to be considered drunk in the United States. Congress ended up passing legislation recently that gives extra highway construction money to states with lower alcohol minimums but does not require states to adopt such rules.
Transportation Secretary Rodney E. Slater attributed last year's decrease in alcohol-related deaths to a steady toughening of state laws against drunken driving and growing public awareness of the problem. The statistics on alcohol-related deaths include drunken pedestrians who are hit by automobiles, as well as drunken drivers.
The rise in deaths not involving alcohol has proved troublesome for safety experts. Dr. Ricardo Martinez, the highway safety agency's administrator, said there were more fatal crashes in daytime, when alcohol is seldom a factor. The increase probably signals that Americans are driving farther each year because of the strong economy, Dr. Martinez said yesterday in an interview.
Yesterday's report estimated that the number of Americans killed for every 100 million miles driven had been steady at about 1.7 since 1992, after falling steeply for decades before then.
The precise death rate may have edged down slightly last year, because Americans drove about 2 percent farther while the overall number of deaths edged down two-tenths of 1 percent. But because of the considerable uncertainty involved in estimating how far Americans drive, the safety agency always rounds off its death rate figures to a single decimal place, and last year's death rate still rounded to 1.7.
Federal regulators have been increasingly worried in recent months that extra deaths may be caused by soaring sales over the last several years of so-called light trucks. These include sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, which roll over more often.
Yesterday's report found that 36 percent of the sport utility vehicles involved in fatal crashes last year had rolled over, compared with 24 percent of pickups, 20 percent of vans and 15 percent of cars. The agency also released separate statistics showing that light trucks were involved in an unusually large and growing number of fatal, two-vehicle collisions last year, although most of the deaths occurred in the cars they hit.
Dr. Martinez said that the very different designs of cars and light trucks were a subject of regulatory concern, but that his agency was looking at data from many years rather than drawing conclusions from a single year's statistics.
"That is an emerging trend that we want to get ahead of the curve on," said Dr. Martinez, a former emergency room physician.
The safety agency said that the number of traffic deaths involving alcohol had fallen to 16,189 last year. The number of traffic deaths that did not involve alcohol rose to 25,778, leaving a drop of 98 in the total number of deaths, to 41,967.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1621 words

HEADLINE: COURT VOIDS PLAN TO USE SAMPLING FOR 2000 CENSUS

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
A Federal court ruled unanimously today that the Census Bureau's plans to use statistical sampling to supplement the 2000 census violated Federal law.
The Census Bureau had hoped to use sampling to avoid a repetition of the 1990 census, which missed 8.4 million people and counted 4.4 million either twice or in the wrong place while relying exclusively on traditional head-counting. 
 Those who stood to gain by sampling included minority groups, whose members have been disproportionately undercounted.
The issue has achieved a heightened importance because census data are used to apportion House seats and draw boundaries for Congressional districts. With House Republicans holding a razor-thin majority, both parties are acutely conscious of any question that might give one side an advantage.
Beyond the partisan wrangling, the issue is of grave concern to cities because some Federal money is allocated on the basis of population.
The decision was welcomed by Congressional Republicans, whose leader, Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia, had brought the lawsuit against the Census Bureau and the Commerce Department. Excerpts, Page A13. The Republicans contended sampling would lead to new errors and be subject to political manipulation. But it dismayed Democrats, who thought that the system would count minority voters missed under recent censuses and that counting them would produce new Congressional and legislative districts likely to vote Democratic.
Opponents of sampling said that the method violated Federal law and the Constitution, which declared that the Federal Government was required to conduct an "actual enumeration" every 10 years. But the special three-judge panel, specifically charged by Congress with hearing census issues, sidestepped the constitutional issue and ruled that the scheme was not permitted under the 1957 and 1976 Federal laws that govern the census. The unanimous decision stressed that the court found no need to decide whether sampling was constitutional because it said the Clinton Administration had wrongly interpreted the Federal law.
The decision can be appealed directly to the Supreme Court, and the Administration is expected to do so.
The judges deciding the issue today were Douglas Ginsburg, an appellate court judge, and Royce C. Lamberth, a district court judge, both appointed by President Ronald Reagan, and Ricardo Urbina, a district court judge named by President Clinton. The panel issued an injunction prohibiting the Census Bureau from using statistical sampling in the next census. In the meantime, the ruling is expected to provide ammunition to Republicans who have been waging a protracted political and legislative battle against sampling.
"I hope this gets the Administration's attention," said Representative Dan Miller, a Florida Republican who is chairman of the House subcommittee on the census. "This is a unanimous decision -- one judge appointed by President Clinton. The wise thing to do is put all their resources into a full enumeration."
But proponents of sampling said today they still hoped for a favorable decision from the Supreme Court. "Ultimately, it will be before the Supreme Court," said Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a Manhattan Democrat. "Nothing has really changed. The nation needs an accurate count that includes everyone."
The Census Bureau's planned sampling methodology was loosely similar to that of public opinion polls in that it would extrapolate information about the population from partial data. But the bureau's plans are more sophisticated. They involve using traditional methods to count everyone in 90 percent of the households in a census tract -- a neighborhood of about 1,700 dwellings. Data from the 90 percent would be used to determine the number and characteristics of the remaining 10 percent, and a further adjustment of the population would be made on the basis of a survey of 750,000 households.
Today's decision was particularly galling to representatives of undercounted minority groups. "It's inexplicable," said Eric Rodriguez, senior policy analyst with the National Council of La Raza, a Hispanic advocacy organization. "I don't understand it. We had an undercount of 5 percent of the Latino population in 1990. If this ruling is upheld we have no reason to expect anything but a 5 percent undercount this time."
Because of large concentrations of blacks in inner cities and increased numbers of immigrants, mainly in the Southwest -- two groups that have notoriously low response rates to mailed census questionnaires -- the 1990 census was the first in modern history to miss more people than the census that preceded it.
Today's ruling turned on an interpretation of two seemingly contradictory provisions in the Census Acts of 1957 and 1976. The 1957 act said that "except for the determination of population for apportionment purposes," the Secretary of Commerce "may, where he deems it appropriate, authorize the use of the statistical method known as sampling." The wording codified the practice of sending the census long form -- the questionnaire that asks how many bathrooms there are in the home, for example -- to one in six households.
In 1976, Congress changed the language of the law, saying that except for purposes of reapportionment, the Commerce Secretary "shall" authorize the use of sampling.
Justice Department lawyers had argued that by changing the wording to make sampling mandatory rather than optional, Congress had effectively removed the prohibition against it for reapportionment purposes. Further they argued that in 1976 Congress added amendments -- Section 141 -- to the act that directed the Commerce Secretary to conduct a census every 10 years "in such form and content as he may determine, including the use of sampling procedures and special surveys."
In today's ruling, written by Judge Lamberth, the panel disagreed with the Justice Department's reasoning.
"Though defendants' interpretation of the except/shall sentence structure is proper in some instances, the court finds it to be strained and incorrect when applied to the amended section 195," he wrote. He stressed the importance of the census to the balance of power in Congress between parties and between states, and said it was hard to imagine that Congress would change the rules without explicitly saying so. He quoted from Justice William H. Rehnquist in a 1980 decision:
"In a case where the construction of legislative language such as this makes so sweeping and so relatively unorthodox a change as that made here, I think judges as well as detectives may take into consideration the fact that a watchdog did not bark in the night."
In bargaining last November over the spending bill that covered the Census Bureau, Mr. Gingrich won Administration agreement to allow general tax revenues to pay for the litigation, a deal that enraged many House Democrats.
"They bought him the gun and said 'shoot me,' " said a Democratic staffer who spoke on the condition of anonymity, "and the court did."
The White House was confident the court would rule that Mr. Gingrich lacked standing to bring the suit since he could not show how the bureau's plans would cause injury to the House. White House lawyers were also confident that the court would decide that because the Administration and Republicans were still haggling, the case was not yet "ripe" for a court ruling.
Today's ruling went against the Administration on both counts.
 
Proposal for 2000 Census Involves 3 Sets of Samples
A plan proposed by the Census Bureau to use statistical sampling to augment the 2000 census would use three sets of samples. The first set would check a selection of houses in a given census tract -- about 1,700 households -- that are presumed to be vacant. The second would check a proportion of residences from which forms were not returned. And the last would be a random nationwide sample to check for accuracy.
The Postal Service in 2000 will probably estimate that 5 percent of the 119 million residential addresses in the country are vacant, the Census Bureau said. Normally, census forms are not sent to those addresses. But studies have shown that at least 11 percent of the homes the Postal Service said were empty were, in fact, occupied.
The bureau, rather than sending forms, would send counters to 1 in 10 of the houses that Postal Service records show as vacant. The number of those dwellings found to be occupied, and the number of people living in them would then be used to estimate the population in housing units that were thought to be vacant nationwide.
In 1990, the bureau sent enumerators to the 35 percent of all addresses that did not return their mail-in census forms. In 2000, the percentage visited would depend on how many households in each census tract mailed in their forms. If 80 percent of the households in a tract returned a form, the bureau would visit half of those houses that did not respond. If 30 percent of the addresses mailed the forms, census takers would visit 6 out of 7 of those households that did not respond.
The bureau's goal was to have a response by mail or visit from 90 percent of the dwellings in each of the country's 60,000 census tracts. Using the information gathered, the bureau would estimate the number and characteristics of the remaining 10 percent.
Finally, the bureau would randomly select 750,000 households nationwide, making sure that each state and all racial, age, economic and other demographic groups were represented. This sample would be used as a "quality control" to check the accuracy of the bureau's efforts and to make adjustments where necessary.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 3; Science Desk

LENGTH: 2217 words

HEADLINE: Putting Money Where Their Minds Are;
Where Scientists Gather, Wagering Flourishes

BYLINE: By JAMES GLANZ; James Glanz writes for Science magazine.

 BODY:
AFTER escaping Germany within months of Hitler's rise to power in 1933 and wandering the world separately for 15 years, Maurice and Gerson Goldhaber were ready for the most ordinary of brotherly relationships when they reunited as particle physicists in the United States. So when Gerson was engaged in the experiment of his life, racing to discover a speck of antimatter called the antiproton, Maurice did what just about any scientist in a close family might do: He bet a colleague $500 that the antiproton did not exist.
Far from showing disloyalty, Dr. Goldhaber was merely carrying on a noble tradition -- wagering on the outcome of scientific questions -- that seems as pervasive in labs, observatories and supercomputer centers as pools on college basketball tournaments are in office parks and machine shops. 
 The tradition was already alive when titans like Johannes Kepler and Isaac Newton were setting the foundations of modern science -- and making bets.
This century's savants have ponied up on everything from the properties of matter's tiniest building blocks to the fate of the entire universe. The stakes generally range from a few dollars to a few hundred dollars, often in the form of pricey dinners or expensive liquor -- and in at least one instance, 100 gallons of gasoline.
"Many bottles of the finest champagnes and malt whiskies, and even more esoteric stakes, rest in abeyance while observers struggle to count rare photons from remote galaxies," wrote Dr. James Peebles of Princeton University and Dr. Joseph Silk of the University of California at Berkeley in the journal Nature a few years ago.
Such bets are "a way to focus attention on what are the really key issues," Dr. Peebles said in an interview. Others think that because scientific betting is as common as shooting craps in a Damon Runyon story, the custom must say something important about physical research.
"There's often a stereotype that scientists are out to create a ground plan of the universe and that they believe their theories with religious fervor," said Dr. Robert P. Crease, a philosopher of science at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. "Bets are interesting, because they reveal the game-like quality with which scientists often approach their work."
But others are far from seeing anything so significant in scientific bets. Dr. Margaret Geller, an astronomer at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, called them "sort of disgusting." She said, "It has always struck me as one of the rather unsophisticated macho aspects of these fields."
Added Sir Martin Rees, an astrophysicist at Cambridge University, "I actually think it is rather frivolous to make them." In a scientific disagreement, professional reputations are the stakes that count, he said.
Maybe so, but the scientific tote board lights up with remarkable frequency. For decades at the old Bell Laboratories (now part of Lucent Technologies) in New Jersey, a betting "book" lay in the tearoom, where scientists gathered for discussions each day at 4 P.M., recalled Dr. Pierre Hohenberg, a physicist who is now a deputy provost at Yale University. "A few of us were ideologically inclined to say that arguments should end up with a bet," Dr. Hohenberg said. "Talk is cheap."
The handwritten, laboratory-style notebook recorded bets on highly technical subjects like competing explanations for superconductivity, in which certain chilled materials transmit electricity without resistance. It also contained more general wagers on political and economic issues. The book disappeared from the tearoom around 1990, perhaps stolen by a sore loser. Long before then, however, a chance remark by a regular bettor at Bell Labs inspired a similar book on the opposite coast.
"On the front page it says, 'The Official SLAC Theory Group Record of Wagers,' " said Michael Peskin of the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center in California. It contains 28 pages of mostly scientific bets dating to 1984.
His own proudest entry, he said, is a winning bet against Dr. Sidney Drell at SLAC regarding the existence and mass of the top quark, an elementary particle discovered to much fanfare in 1995. "Dinner for four," said Dr. Peskin with satisfaction.
The German astronomer Johannes Kepler is believed to have begun the game in 1600, when he was given the problem of figuring out Mars's orbit around the Sun from astronomical observations made by his mentor, Tycho Brahe. Kepler took over the problem from a senior Brahe assistant, Longomontanus.
Kepler bet Longomontanus he would crack the problem in a week or so, said Dr. James Voelkel, a historian of science at Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The stakes are not known, but Longomontanus won going away: It took Kepler five years to find the solution.
That set the stage for what was "undoubtedly one of the most crucial wagers in scientific history," said Dr. Alan E. Shapiro, a historian of science at the University of Minnesota. Kepler's pondering had produced his three laws of planetary motion, which describe the elliptical orbits and how fast planets moved in them. Unfortunately, nobody knew why planets would behave like that.
So as a way to spark competition, Christopher Wren, the English architect and scientist, announced in 1684 that he would give a book worth 40 shillings to anyone who, within two months, could deduce Kepler's laws from the inverse-square law that says the Sun's gravity decreases with the square of the planet's distance from the Sun. Isaac Newton's paper on his solution grew into his Principia, the tract that became a cornerstone of modern physics. "The rest is history," Dr. Shapiro said. By the time he published it, however, years had passed, and Newton could not cash in his winning ticket.
High-profile wagers among scientists continued to crop up from time to time in the 1700's and 1800's. For reasons no one can quite explain, however, the 20th century has been the Monte Carlo night of scientific culture. "In my life I have made countless bets on science; I may not be able to remember all of them," said Dr. Walter Lewin, an astronomer at M.I.T.
Even so, some notable players complain that there is not enough action to go around. "Most scientists are not interested in bets," said Dr. Michael Turner an astrophysicist at the University of Chicago, still fuming after a conference where no one would make a new bet with him on the rate at which the universe is expanding, called the Hubble constant.
"Bets imply a certain irrationality or in-your-face attitude," Dr. Turner said. "I love 'em."
Like a gambler blowing ostentatiously on his dice, Dr. Turner stands out in his enthusiasm, but he is hardly alone. Relating a not-so-unusual episode in his book "The Neglect of Experiment" (Cambridge, 1986), the historian Allan Franklin counted no fewer than three separate bets on tests of whether "parity" -- a kind of left-right symmetry -- was preserved in subatomic interactions.
The late physicist Richard P. Feynman, for example, gave 50-to-1 odds on a dollar bet and paid off when experiments in 1957 showed that the laws of physics were not quite the same when left and right and up and down were reversed, as in a mirror -- just as predicted by two theorists, T. D. Lee and C. N. Yang.
Nearly everyone involved in those bets eventually won a Nobel Prize in physics for one reason or another. Betting by leading scientists continues to the present: Dr. William Phillips of the National Institute of Standards and Technology, who shared a 1997 Nobel, has $100 plus interest riding on whether or not unexplained surprises turn up in the physics of the quantum microworld any time over the next 50 years.
In his wager with Dr. Benjamin Bederson of New York University, Dr. Phillips said he bet against surprises bigger than just a new particle or force, "but I'd love to be wrong."
A similarly high-minded detachment marks the skein of bets made by the cosmologist Stephen W. Hawking. The bets, several of them made with Dr. Kip Thorne and Dr. John Preskill of the California Institute of Technology, often involve the properties of black holes -- massive, collapsed bodies whose gravity is so intense that even light cannot escape. This tone is not always reflected in the stakes: Dr. Thorne won a subscription to Penthouse magazine in one bet against Dr. Hawking.
Often the stakes involve expensive liquor.
That tradition may have been started in the 1950's by Dr. Walter Baade, an astronomer at the Palomar Observatory in California. Dr. Baade bet his colleague Rudolph Minkowski, a bottle of Hudson's Bay Procurable whisky that a strange-looking galaxy spewing radio waves was really a pair of galaxies in collision. Dr. Minkowski conceded the bet and then drank most of the whisky anyway. Justice might have been served, since colliding galaxies fell out of favor a few years thereafter.
In the shadow of Dr. Baade and Dr. Minkowski, Dr. Peebles of Princeton is referee for an international bet on the value of the Hubble constant, a number that describes the rate of expansion of the universe. The stakes: a case of single malt scotch. Dr. Lewin of M.I.T., in two separate astronomical bets, staked a dozen bottles of whisky against a pound of caviar; and six bottles of "superb" champagne against three of cognac and three of champagne. Marc Davis of Berkeley agreed to wager "a case of the best wine from Italy against the best California wine" with an Italian physicist on the size of the largest structures in the cosmos.
Near the end of the oil crisis, almost 20 years ago, Dr. Frank Shu of the University of California at Berkeley bet Dr. George Djorgovski of Caltech 100 gallons of gasoline that by Jan. 1, 2001, theorists will have determined several crucial cosmic parameters to within 20 percent. One such parameter is the mass density of the entire universe -- still a notoriously controversial number. In view of the oil shortage, Dr. Shu and Dr. Djorgovski stipulated that the an amount of of fine wine worth the same amount could be substituted if there were no gasoline left by 2001.
There is at least one good reason for all this wagering, Dr. Djorgovski said. The system that bestows official scientific awards "is usually rewarding old guys for what they've done God-knows-when," he said. He added: "It would be actually nice if there was an active, up-to-date system that would provide prizes for great new achievements quickly. Maybe making bets is a simple, samizdat way of doing that."
Bets can also serve quite a different purpose: as a diversionary tactic to throw other scientists off the scent. In the months leading up to what physicists call the "November revolution" in 1974, Mel Schwartz of Columbia University heard rumors that Dr. Samuel C. C. Ting of M.I.T. had discovered a remarkable new subatomic particle. Dr. Schwartz confronted him -- they were then working in the same laboratory -- but Dr. Ting flatly denied the rumor. Still suspicious, Dr. Schwartz offered to bet $10 that Dr. Ting had found the particle. Dr. Ting accepted.
Dr. Ting immediately wrote in his lab notebook, "I owe Mel Schwartz $10." Dr. Ting said he had been put in an "impossible position," since he wanted to check possible errors before making an announcement. He paid up just two months later, going public after learning that another group led by Dr. Burton Richter of the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center had also seen the particle. Drs. Ting, Richter, and Schwartz all eventually won Nobel Prizes. "What I keep kicking myself about is that I didn't make it $200," Dr. Schwartz said.
Of all the reasons scientists make bets, however, by far the most compelling seems to be the urge to make a point in a way that is not soon forgotten.
A few minutes after Dr. Maurice Goldhaber, now 87 and still active in research at Brookhaven National Laboratory, arrived at a party in 1954, he got into an argument with his host over the existence of the antiproton. The particle had been predicted by the great theorist Paul Dirac, an authority few physicists were prepared to contradict. "I said, 'I don't believe it until it is proven,' " Dr. Goldhaber said. After all, he pointed out, there was the inconvenient detail that the universe around us is made of matter, not antimatter.
The host -- a brilliant if rough-cut theorist named Hartland Snyder -- suddenly reached out and grabbed his hand, recalled Dr. Goldhaber. "He said, 'I bet you $500 that the antiproton exists.' Without thinking I said, 'O.K.' " Even though Dr. Goldhaber's brother Gerson was scrambling to detect antiprotons at Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory and sober reflection told Dr. Goldhaber that his odds of winning the bet were not good, he did not consider backing down.
As it happened, a few months before Dr. Gerson Goldhaber's results were ready, another team at Berkeley detected antiprotons, winning a Nobel Prize for the discovery in 1959. But the widely discussed bet had its own modest influence on the history of science, said Dr. Gosta Ekspong, who was a member of Gerson Goldhaber's team and is now retired from Stockholm University. "People were reported to say that they believed in the existence of the antiproton," said Dr. Ekspong, "because Maurice Goldhaber paid off."

HEADLINE: Survey Finds Public Support For Vouchers

BYLINE: By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
Public opposition to taxpayer support for private and religious schooling, which was clear-cut several years ago, is softening, with Americans closely divided on the use of vouchers to pay tuition at private or church-sponsored schools, according to a poll released yesterday.
A small majority of Americans now favor allowing parents to send their children to any public, private or church-related school if government pays all or part of the tuition, the survey found. 
 The poll, conducted in June by the Gallup Organization for Phi Delta Kappa, a professional association of educators, found that 51 percent favored such support and 45 percent opposed it, a reversal of opinion since 1996, when 43 percent favored it and 54 percent opposed it. In 1997 the results were almost evenly divided, 49 percent in favor and 48 percent opposed. The poll has a margin of sampling error of about four percentage points.
For the first time since the poll began addressing the issue, in 1993, the word "vouchers" was introduced into the questions to reflect the growing prominence of the idea of using government-issued notes to pay for tuition at private or church-sponsored schools.
When asked specifically about vouchers to pay for all of the tuition, 48 percent were in favor and 46 percent opposed. When asked about partial tuition, the public supported the idea, 52 percent to 41 percent.
There has been considerable political and legal controversy over the use of vouchers, especially in church-related schools, and the issue may well be headed for the Supreme Court in its coming term.
Civil libertarians and teachers unions, in particular, have opposed the use of vouchers in religious schools, saying it violates the separation of church and state and will deprive the public school system of an essential part.
Proponents of voucher plans say public schools will benefit from the competition, which will also serve inner-city students by offering them schools with higher standards.
The poll also found that divisions between Republican and Democratic lawmakers on education were not reflected among the public, which registers support for nearly all ideas intended to improve schools.
For example, some 86 percent of Americans support President Clinton's proposal to use Federal money to repair and replace older school buildings, and 71 percent favor voluntary national tests in the fourth and eighth grades, ideas that are opposed by many Republicans. Yet 73 percent of the public also backs the Republicans' proposal to provide block grants to states, with the states taking responsibility for some Federal programs.

HEADLINE: Union Faults G.M. on Plans for Parts Unit

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Leaders of the United Automobile Workers union strongly criticized the General Motors Corporation today, a sign that this summer's strikes in Flint, Mich. did not produce a reconciliation and that next year's national contract talks between G.M. and the U.A.W. will be contentious.
Stephen P. Yokich, the U.A.W.'s president, condemned G.M.'s announcement on Aug. 3 of plans to spin off its auto parts subsidiary. Asked at a news conference here today what the U.A.W. planned to do about G.M.'s plans, Mr. Yokich said that another strike was always possible, although he added that the union might not do anything until Sept. 14, 1999. That is when the U.A.W.'s current national agreements with G.M., the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation are all scheduled to expire. 
 G.M. and the U.A.W. had also agreed at the end of the nearly eight-week-long Flint strikes to begin holding regular, top-level meetings to prevent future confrontations. But Richard Shoemaker, the U.A.W.'s vice president for G.M. issues, said today that there had been few discussions with G.M. since then.
Gerald Holmes, a G.M. spokesman, acknowledged that few meetings had been held since the end of the strikes, but attributed it to vacations. "We are serious about improving the relationship and making this process work," he said.
G.M. executives contended during the strike that the company must reduce its labor costs to start earning a competitive return on its shareholders' investment.
Mr. Yokich and Mr. Shoemaker spoke at their first news conference since they announced on July 28 an agreement to end the strikes. Since then, G.M. has announced several initiatives to try to make the company more competitive: spin off the auto parts subsidiary, consolidate its marketing staffs and build new assembly plants in North America that would require fewer workers.
Both U.A.W. leaders offered a few small hints today of a willingness to compromise. Mr. Yokich, for example, was cautious in discussing G.M.'s plans for new assembly plants.
The new factories would employ fewer workers by relying on outside suppliers to deliver large chunks of vehicles, like complete dashboards, instead of bolting every part together on the assembly line. Some union advocates worry about G.M.'s plans because four out of every five auto supplier factories in the United States are not unionized.
Mr. Yokich said in a conversation with several reporters after the news conference that the union had already won considerable job security for its members and that some changes in production processes were inevitable. The union will put greater emphasis on outside suppliers being in the United States, than being unionized, he said, although the union will still try to organize these suppliers.
Even if jobs are created at nonunion supplier factories in the United States, he said, "It's still an American job, isn't it?"

HEADLINE: Confidence Dips; Home Resales Rise

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Consumer confidence fell this month but held close to a 30-year high, while previously owned homes were resold at a record pace during July, encouraged by plenty of jobs and low mortgage rates.
The Conference Board said today that its consumer confidence index declined to 133.1 in August from a revised July reading of 137.2. The index had set a 30-year high of 138.2 in June. 
 A separate Conference Board index that gauges consumer expectations for the next six months fell to 107.5 this month, the lowest level since October, from 113.4 in July. In another report, the National Association of Realtors said that home resales rose 4 percent last month, to a record annual rate of 4.93 million, after a June decline of 1.9 percent.
By region during July, resales rose 3.3 percent in the Midwest, to 1.25 million units at an annual rate; 13.1 percent in the West, to 1.12 million units, and 1.5 percent in the Northeast, to 680,000 units. They were unchanged in the South, at a rate of 1.87 million units.
The average selling price of an existing home in July fell to $168,500 from $169,200 in June.
Mortgage rates averaged 6.95 percent in July for 30-year loans with a fixed interest rate, compared with 7 percent in June, according to the average of weekly changes in rates published by Freddie Mac.

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Here's some advice for passengers if there is a strike this weekend at Northwest Airlines.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
AS of yesterday, Northwest Airlines was still holding out the possibility of avoiding a strike by its pilots, but prudent passengers should prepare for the worst. That means bracing for a possible strike any time after midnight Saturday, unless there is a settlement.
Northwest, travel agents and other airlines are offing advice about how best to cope with a strike -- along with the caveat that airline strikes, no matter how brief, are almost always frustrating and disruptive. 
 If booked on a Northwest flight that departs before Saturday, the carrier said a strike would not disrupt your travel plans. In addition, KLM Royal Dutch Airlines, Northwest's partner, said that even in the event of a strike it intended to fly all scheduled trans-Atlantic routes.
If you are booked on Northwest, but decide to double-book on another carrier to insure against being stranded, be advised that almost all the other major carriers are temporarily making even their first-class and business-class tickets nonrefundable on flights to and from Northwest's hubs at Minneapolis-St. Paul, Detroit and Memphis. That hard line on the part of Northwest's rivals is to protect themselves from droves of no-shows in the event there is no strike.
Unless there is a strike, Northwest's nonrefundable ticket restrictions remain in force. Then if Northwest cannot accommodate passengers on another carrier, it will make a full refund.
The chances of accommodating many Northwest ticket holders on other carriers during a strike are slim. Almost all airlines already have record passenger loads, and almost none have spare planes or the ability to add extra flights. Also, the closer it gets to the long Labor Day weekend, the more crowded all airplanes will be.
Moreover, many of the domestic routes flown by Northwest are to small cities throughout Minnesota, Michigan, Wisconsin, Iowa and the Dakotas, cities where other carriers have few flights. And Mesaba Airlines and Express Airlines I -- Northwest's principal regional carriers, which will suspend operations in the event of a strike against Northwest -- provide the only air service to many cities in the Midwest and cities served from the Memphis hub.
Even in the Pacific, where Northwest has been a major presence for decades, the economic crisis in Asia has led almost all carriers to reduce service to Japan and other nations, or to substitute smaller airplanes.
On a somewhat happier note, Northwest frequent fliers who planned to use a free ticket that expires during the strike, if there is one, will have the expiration date of those miles extended.
Finally, Northwest is encouraging passengers with questions about flights to get in touch with their travel agents or phone its toll-free reservations line in the United States or Canada (800 225-2525). But keep in mind that flights are often canceled at the last minute, and that reservations lines are often jammed for hours during or just before a strike.
 
More Airline News
Malaysia Airlines is offering a special package for two, good for travel between now and Nov. 30. For $739 a person, a couple can fly round trip from Newark or Los Angeles to Kuala Lumpur or any of a dozen other cities in Malaysia. The price also includes four nights, with breakfast each morning, at one of many participating hotels. As usual, reservations are based on space availability.
Qantas Airways has a package deal good for travel between Los Angeles or San Francisco and Sydney from Sept. 11 through Dec. 24. Starting at $1,098, it includes round-trip air fare, five nights at a four-star hotel, a sightseeing cruise, harbor cruise and assorted other freebies. Bookings can be make through Qantas Vacations; the toll-free number is (800) 252-6286.

HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE;
Upgrading a Cluster of Older Hotels in Manhattan

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
Throughout central Manhattan, the comeback of the hotel market in the mid-1990's is bringing new investment, major building renovations and economic success to what were marginal properties in the 80's. The work has often been undertaken after new ownership and management takes over. And it goes forward with a certain number of long-term tenants in place.
Among the buildings in line for this treatment in coming months are two properties long associated with low-rent, single-room-occupancy operations. 
 One is the Martha Washington Hotel, with entrances at 30 East 30th Street and 29 East 29th Street, long owned by Bernard Sillins. Another is the Allerton House for Women, at 130 East 57th Street, on the southwest corner of Lexington Avenue, formerly operated by the estate of Sol Goldman. Mr. Goldman died at 70 in 1987, leaving an estimated 400 New York City properties. About 15 have been sold, said Allan Goldman, his son. He and his sister, Jane Goldman, are now operating the rest.
In deals that closed a year ago, Property Markets Group, a real estate investment company owned by Ziel Feldman and Kevin Maloney, has taken control of both properties and is now in the early stages of major rehabilitation programs. Property Markets owns about 75 Manhattan buildings, with about 2,400 apartments and 60 stores, all bought in the 90's. One of these is the Belnord, the landmarked 276-unit rental building at 225 West 86th Street, which was purchased in partnership with Gary Barnett in 1994. The company's office now is in rebuilt space on the fifth floor of Allerton House, where Mr. Goldman long had his office.
"We have been attracted to hotels that are distressed and underutilized because of years of neglect," said Mr. Feldman, a 40-year-old real estate lawyer. Mr. Maloney, 39, is a former savings bank lending officer. They have hired Bohn Associates, an architectural and interior design firm, to develop a design theme for their hotels.
Property Markets Group is also a managing partner in a group that bought the Commander, a fully occupied 218-unit apartment hotel at 240 West 73d Street, two years ago. A renovation program there is perhaps three years off, Mr. Feldman said.
Renovation involves re-equipping and often reconfiguring rooms once they are vacant, as well as new carpeting and lighting and major lobby renovation. Existing tenants, whose occupancy rights are protected by the city's hotel rent stabilization regulations, are offered upgraded rooms in consolidated locations, but sometimes they will not consent to move from rooms that they have occupied for decades.
Farthest along in the reconstruction process among Property Markets Group's hotels is the Broadway American, at 222 West 77th Street, on the southeast corner of Broadway. It is a 12-story building, built in 1910, with 425 rooms and 7,000 square feet of retail space. In 1991, a reconstruction was undertaken by a management that held a long-term lease, but the lessee ultimately lost the project to the owner, the Goldman estate.
"About 20 percent of the rooms had bathrooms when we bought it," Mr. Feldman said. "The rest used common baths in the hall." There are now about 85 long-term tenants, most of them dating to the days when the hotel was operated as the Ben Franklin apartments. About 75 agreed to relocate to upgraded rooms on lower floors, but the rest have stayed in place in their unrenovated rooms.
The reconstruction plan envisions ultimately reducing the total number of rooms to 341, of which 48 would be convertible to two-room suites. Three new levels are being added at the roof level to create penthouse suites with views of both Central Park and the Hudson River. The Manhattan firm of David Kenneth Specter & Associates was the architect.
The hope is that the hotel will be ready for guests by the end of year, Mr. Feldman said. Room rates will average $150 a night, he said.
The Broadway American will join a growing group of recently renovated Upper West Side hotels, among them the Lucerne, the Beacon and the Milburn, that have a total of roughly 1,000 rooms and are getting rates of more than $150 a night, hotel specialists report.
The Allerton Hotel for Women, with 464 rooms, was one of a chain of moderately priced hotels that was started by James S. Cushman in 1916. When Property Markets Group acquired the lease from the Goldman estate a year ago, about 50 women, all long-term tenants, were still living in the building, Mr. Feldman said. Leasing to outsiders ceased six months ago, he said.
Like many former Goldman properties, its potential value, because of its location, is far greater than its earning capacity in its present condition. But before a building permit is granted for interior reconstruction, a new owner must obtain a certificate from the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development assuring that there has been no harassment of tenants to vacate their apartments. The process normally takes three to five months.
Last year, certificates of no harassment were issued for 124 buildings, and so far this year, the figure is 77, the department said, adding that claims of harassment have led to hearings in only a handful of buildings. Denial of a certificate bars an applicant from applying again for three years.
The Martha Washington is closing for new guests this week, but the occupancy rights of its 153 permanent tenants will remain undisturbed, Mr. Feldman said. The purchase price for the 469 rooms was $18.5 million, he said.
The Allerton House for Women was leased for 49 years from the Goldman estate at a figure starting at $2.5 million a year, he said. The rate is linked to the rental potential of close to 15,000 square feet of retail space in the building.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
The Serpent In the Garden Of Renewal

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
PLUMP, green apples plopped to the ground as Jose (Chema) Soto pried them loose from the branches. He climbed down and caught his breath, a reminder that he should exercise more since having a heart attack. He beheld the tree, which towered over the Caribbean-style wooden shack that he and his friends built in the middle of a Bronx community garden bursting with enough vegetables and flowers to rival any greengrocer.
Decades ago, this was just an empty lot on the corner of 158th Street and Brook Avenue. Mr. Soto and his friends turned it into Rincon Criollo -- Down-Home Corner -- where they nurture more than just plants. It is a place where the traditional Puerto Rican music of bomba and plena has flowered. It is ground zero for folklore. 
 Too bad for Mr. Soto that it is also near ground zero for the next phase of the Melrose Commons urban renewal zone, where hundreds of new homes have already arisen on surrounding blocks. For Rincon Criollo and 14 other community gardens that have long thrived on lots leased annually from the city, the future seems as unpredictable as the weather. A few months ago, the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development took control of the properties to allow for speedier development. Some gardens will vanish under bricks and mortar. Mr. Soto is lucky, since borough officials have proposed letting him start over a block south in what is now a fenced thicket of weeds. Some luck.
"What are we supposed to do, take our peach and apple trees out by the roots?" Mr. Soto said. "Over there, the ground is full of rocks. It took us more than 20 years to do this. Before we see trees like this over there, we'll be dead."
He pointed to the proposed lot. "Not even a curse would grow there," he concluded. "Don't move me anywhere."
The community gardeners have banded together to mount their own urban land reform effort. They have met with politicians, circulated petitions and enlisted the aid of advocacy groups. They knew that their leases were temporary, but they wonder why the city had to go after them, considering all the other lots that have lain fallow and fenced in for years.
"Why didn't they take it before, when it was dirty?" said Luis Gonzalez, whose garden is near Crotona Park. "Are they showing it to potential buyers because they saw how we cleaned it up?"
Adding to their worries, they said they have yet to hear from Housing Preservation officials to explain what plans lie ahead. A spokeswoman for the agency did not respond to a reporter's questions about the Melrose gardens.
THE Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, said development plans, still five years away from groundbreaking, are jeopardizing four gardens. He said that a community effort to redesign the neighborhood has included plans to relocate several existing gardens and create three more acres of parkland. He suggested that the city agency take a closer look at such local efforts.
"We're trying very hard here to do the right thing for the community so it can rebound with housing and gardens," he said. "But with a plan. Not the way H.P.D. does, which is, 'Give me all of it, and I won't talk with you.' It's mindless, to use a favorite mayoral term."
Several dozen gardeners met at Rincon Criollo last week to map new strategies. They were joined by residents of other communities who were also fighting to preserve their oases. Some of them munched on grapes picked from vines dangling above the maze of spotless walkways between the garden plots.
"The government never expected this," Mr. Soto said. "This used to have only rats, junkies and a hole that was 10 feet deep. Now it is a place for deep culture."
Miguel Sierra, a plenero who has been active in Rincon Criollo for 15 years, can attest to that. From the little shack on Brook Avenue, he has gone on to perform at theaters and museums. In turn, he has played host to countless musicians, athletes and politicians who make sure they pay their respects at Rincon Criollo whenever they visit the city.
"This is the missing link between Puerto Rico and New York," he said. "Here. We feel like we're in Puerto Rico."
The plenas that he sings add to that atmosphere. For years they carried the news of the era in song. The gardeners' current plight would seem like a logical topic for a plena. "We are working on one," Mr. Sierra said. "It is our secret weapon. We will hold onto it until the last minute."

HEADLINE: Who's Afraid of Genetic Engineering?

BYLINE: By Jimmy Carter; Jimmy Carter, the 39th President of the United States, is chairman of the nonprofit Carter Center.

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
Imagine a country placing such rigid restrictions on imports that people could not get vaccines and insulin. And imagine those same restrictions being placed on food products as well as on laundry detergent and paper.
As far-fetched as it sounds, many developing countries and some industrialized ones may do just that early next year. They are being misled into thinking that genetically modified organisms, everything from seeds to livestock, and products made from them are potential threats to the public health and the environment. 
 The new import proposals are being drafted under the auspices of the biodiversity treaty, an agreement signed by 168 nations at the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro. The treaty's main goal is to protect plants and animals from extinction.
In 1996, nations ratifying the treaty asked an ad hoc team to determine whether genetically modified organisms could threaten biodiversity. Under pressure from environmentalists, and with no supporting data, the team decided that any such organism could potentially eliminate native plants and animals.
The team, whose members mainly come from environmental agencies in more than 100 different governments, should complete its work within six months and present its final recommendation to all the nations (the United States is not among them) that ratified the treaty. If approved, these regulations would be included in a binding international agreement early next year.
But the team has exceeded its mandate. Instead of limiting the agreement to genetic modifications that might threaten biodiversity, the members are also pushing to regulate shipments of all genetically modified organisms and the products made from them.
This means that grain, fresh produce, vaccines, medicines, breakfast cereals, wine, vitamins -- the list is endless -- would require written approval by the importing nation before they could leave the dock. This approval could take months. Meanwhile, barge costs would mount and vaccines and food would spoil.
How could regulations intended to protect species and conserve their genes have gotten so far off track? The main cause is anti-biotechnology environmental groups that exaggerate the risks of genetically modified organisms and ignore their benefits.
Anti-biotechnology activists argue that genetic engineering is so new that its effects on the environment can't be predicted. This is misleading. In fact, for hundreds of years virtually all food has been improved genetically by plant breeders. Genetically altered antibiotics, vaccines and vitamins have improved our health, while enzyme-containing detergents and oil-eating bacteria have helped to protect the environment.
In the past 40 years, farmers worldwide have genetically modified crops to be more nutritious as well as resistant to insects, diseases and herbicides. Scientific techniques developed in the 1980's and commonly referred to as genetic engineering allow us to give plants additional useful genes. Genetically engineered cotton, corn and soybean seeds became available in the United States in 1996, including those planted on my family farm. This growing season, more than one-third of American soybeans and one-fourth of our corn will be genetically modified. The number of acres devoted to genetically engineered crops in Argentina, Canada, Mexico and Australia increased tenfold from 1996 to 1997.
The risks of modern genetic engineering have been studied by technical experts at the National Academy of Sciences and World Bank. They concluded that we can predict the environmental effects by reviewing past experiences with those plants and animals produced through selective breeding. None of these products of selective breeding have harmed either the environment or biodiversity.
And their benefits are legion. By increasing crop yields, genetically modified organisms reduce the constant need to clear more land for growing food. Seeds designed to resist drought and pests are especially useful in tropical countries, where crop losses are often severe. Already, scientists in industrialized nations are working with individuals in developing countries to increase yields of staple crops, to improve the quality of current exports and to diversify economies by creating exports like genetically improved palm oil, which may someday replace gasoline.
Other genetically modified organisms covered by the proposed regulations are essential research tools in medical, agricultural and environmental science.
If imports like these are regulated unnecessarily, the real losers will be the developing nations. Instead of reaping the benefits of decades of discovery and research, people from Africa and Southeast Asia will remain prisoners of outdated technology. Their countries could suffer greatly for years to come. It is crucial that they reject the propaganda of extremist groups before it is too late.
