HEADLINE: Administration to Fight Ruling Barring Sampling in Census

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
While acknowledging that a Federal court ruling on Monday was a blow to its efforts to use sampling to supplement the 2000 census, the Clinton Administration said today that it would still press Congress for the money the Census Bureau would need to plan for sampling.
The Administration immediately said it would appeal the ruling, which was made by a special three-judge panel that said statistical sampling violated Federal law. Late this afternoon the Administration filed a notice of appeal asking the Supreme Court to review the decision. 
 "This is the first stop on a long journey of resolution," said Everett M. Ehrlich, a former Commerce Department official who is now a Democratic member of an independent board that is monitoring the Census Bureau's plans.
But any Supreme Court ruling is not expected until next year. That leaves plenty of time for the Administration and House Republicans to engage in a knock-down-drag-out fight this fall over a spending bill to pay for the bureau's plans for the next census -- plans that still include the use of sampling.
Advocates of statistical sampling say it would provide a more complete count of the nation's population. Groups that analysts say were underrepresented in the 1990 census could benefit from a census in 2000 based on sampling. These groups, mostly the urban and rural poor, tend to live in predominantly Democratic areas, and therefore counting them might benefit that party in drawing district lines.
Republicans rejoiced in the court ruling. "The public perception is that it certainly enhanced our standing," said Pete Jeffries, a spokesman for Representative Dennis Hastert, an Illinois Republican and ardent foe of sampling. "This shows that this is just another example of the Clinton Administration trying to run roughshod over the law and the Constitution."
Robert J. Shapiro, Under Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, the division that oversees the Census Bureau, was just as vehement that sampling would prevail.
"Regardless of the court decision," Mr. Shapiro said, "this is going to be a very tough political fight that will be hard-fought on all sides. The opponents of the use of scientific methods will try to use this ruling to try to make their case, just like the proponents of scientific methods use the testimony of noted scientists to make their case."
The court decision and the coming fight in Congress flow from an agreement negotiated in November by Speaker Newt Gingrich and Erskine B. Bowles, the White House chief of staff.
Under the deal, which broke a logjam over a spending bill, Mr. Gingrich was able to proceed with a lawsuit paid for by taxpayers to have sampling declared unconstitutional or illegal, the suit heard by the three-judge panel. The agreement also allowed for any decision to be appealed directly and expeditiously to the Supreme Court.
The spending bill, under the agreement, would not fully finance the Departments of Commerce (which oversees the Census Bureau), Justice or State for the full fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, though there is dispute between the parties on just what it would finance. The Administration and the Democrats say the agreement was to finance the three departments for six months while everyone waited for a decision on sampling from the Supreme Court. The Republicans assert that they agreed to finance only the Census Bureau, and only for six months.
The Administration is pushing for financing all of the operations of the Commerce, Justice and State Departments for six months, figuring that the pressure of a looming Government shutdown -- even a partial one -- would drive the Republicans to resolve the sampling matter.
The Republicans reason that if the Census Bureau were to run out of money next spring the Administration would be so desperate to gain the rest of the financing that it would agree to drop its plans to use sampling.
The fight over sampling also comes as Mr. Clinton's personal popularity has been brought low by his acknowledgment of his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky.
"The President's political difficulty certainly has to be factored in," said one former Administration official familiar with the census battle. "It could go either way."
But some Democrats say that the possibility that Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, will submit a report to Congress that accuses Mr. Clinton of having engaged in illegal activity might strengthen Mr. Clinton's resolve in the census fight.
"The President's highest priority is to regain the confidence of the Democrats in Congress," said Tony Coehlo, the former House whip who is another Democratic appointee to the census monitoring board. "He ain't going to renege on this one."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Marsh & McLennan to Buy Big British Insurance Broker

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Fortifying its position as the world's largest insurance broker, Marsh & McLennan of New York said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the London-based Sedgwick Group, the largest independent broker in Europe, for $2.05 billion in cash.
The deal increases Marsh & McLennan's business with the largest corporations in Europe and with midsized companies in the United States, the two main areas that Sedgwick had developed. And while Marsh & McLennan has a commanding presence in financial services, Sedgwick brings the combined company expertise in marine and energy coverage, from oil-drilling rigs to the suppliers of drilling equipment. 
 "The biggest things we get in this are operations in places where we were not operating, or not operating as well, and a greater accumulation of professional expertise," said A. J. C. Smith, Marsh & McLennan's chief executive. In Asia alone, he said, "this doubles our scale."
To acquire the British company, Marsh & McLennan agreed to pay 2.25 a share, or about $3.60 -- 58 percent more than Sedgwick's closing price on the London Stock Exchange Monday. The price, a total of 1.25 billion, or $2.05 billion, works out to about 15 times earnings under generally accepted accounting principles in the United States at a time other insurance brokers have been trading at 10 or 11 times earnings.
The deal was the latest in a struggle for dominance in the worldwide brokerage business between Marsh and its chief rival, the Aon Corporation of Chicago. And analysts said they thought Marsh had agreed to pay such a premium partly to keep Sedgwick out of the hands of Aon. Otherwise, said Ira L. Zuckerman, vice president for research at Nutmeg Securities in Westport, Conn., "they wouldn't have made as high a bid as they did."
"My feeling," Mr. Zuckerman added, "is that it was sort of pre-emptive."
Joan Steel, an Aon spokeswoman in Chicago, declined to comment on whether the company had been interested in buying Sedgwick. Nor would she discuss analysts' speculation that Aon might submit a higher bid.
Some analysts also suggested that alternatively Aon might consider offering a higher bid for the Willis Corroon Group, another big London brokerage that an investor group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the New York buyout firm, said last month it had agreed to buy for $1.4 billion. Ms. Steel of Aon would not comment on that prospect either.
Sedgwick and Willis Corroon were the last of the big competitors of Marsh and Aon, leaving a handful of smaller insurance brokers that analysts said were likely to be bought in coming months.
The American depository receipts of Sedgwick -- each representing five shares -- rose $5.125, to $17.375 yesterday; Marsh & McLennan's shares fell $1.125, to $55.5625.
Marsh had a little more than $6 billion in revenue last year, compared with $5.7 billion for Aon. The combined revenue of Marsh and Sedgwick at the end of last year would have been $7.6 billion, putting the new company far ahead of Aon.
Aon moved ahead of Marsh, the longtime leader in the business, in January 1997 with the purchase of Alexander & Alexander Services for $1.23 billion. But then Marsh reclaimed the No. 1 spot two months later by taking over Johnson & Higgins for $1.8 billion.
In growing ever bigger, the companies hope to gain economies of scale, and to increase their market share and the range of expertise they offer customers. With more influence, they hope also to be able to negotiate better prices with insurers for their corporate clients.
Keith Buckley, a senior vice president and analyst at Duff & Phelps, said corporate customers could benfit from lower prices from Marsh if it succeeded in cutting costs through the merger. "But the downside is that competition between the brokers will have lessened," he said. "Corporate customers will be forced to deal with fewer, more powerful brokers, which may not always have their best interests at heart."
Mr. Smith, Marsh's chief executive, said he was "comfortable that the price" his company was paying "was a good one." Some savings, he said, would come in trimming the combined work force of 52,000. But he said more of the reduction was expected through retirements and turnover than through layoffs.
With the Sedgwick deal coming so soon after the acquisition of Johnson & Higgins, Cathy Seifert, an S&P Equity Group analyst, said this raised questions about how smoothly Marsh would be able to combine the two companies. "If it is very disruptive," she said, "that could be a positive for Aon."
In seeking to solidify the deal, Marsh's bankers obtained a commitment from the holders of more than 40 percent of Sedgwick's stock that they would accept the offer. There is a caveat, however. If another bidder offers 10 percent more, the deal can be reconsidered.
Asked whether he expected a counterbid from Aon, Mr. Smith said, "I would hesitate to be involved in a bid for a professional management staff where the staff were committed to somebody else."

Purchase by Reinsurer
 FRANKFURT, Aug. 25 (Bloomberg News) -- Hannover Re, the world's fifth-largest reinsurer, said today that it had agreed to buy the Clarendon Insurance Group of the United States for $500 million.
Hannover Re is buying Clarendon from management and from a Finnish company, Kansa International.
Clarendon, of New York, is active in so-called program insurance, covering groups of individuals like young drivers, a high-risk category.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Pay Farmers to Shoo Cows Off City's Watershed

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
In a move aimed at cutting the flow of pollution and parasites into New York City's drinking water, the United States Agriculture Department plans to unveil a $10.4 million program today that will pay farmers to stop growing crops and grazing cattle along streams feeding the city's upstate reservoirs.
The goal is to transform the banks of 165 miles of watershed streams from easily eroded cropland or pasture into pollution-filtering buffer zones of grassland and forest, Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said in a statement to be released today. 
 Farmers who abandon fields along streams will be paid a yearly fee of $100 to $150 an acre for the loss of the use of their land, agriculture officials said.
Several dairy farmers living near the reservoirs expressed cautious interest in the program yesterday.
David Post, whose grandson belongs to the eighth generation of his family to work their 200-year-old farm in Stamford, said he recognized the value of having forested areas, cool streams for trout and banks untrammeled by cow hooves. If the money is sufficient to compensate for the loss of prime land, he said, then plenty of farmers will sign up.
"This will probably work all right," he said. "I'm a hunter and fisherman, I like to see wildlife. And, believe it or not, I'd just as soon send the cleanest water down there that we can -- as long as it doesn't impact me and my family."
The money, to be paid to farmers under contracts lasting 10 to 15 years, is a tiny fraction of the $600 million New York City has already committed to spending to prevent pollution of its far-flung water supply.
But by providing a strong financial incentive to farmers to move plows and cows back from stream banks, the Federal project is expected to significantly improve water quality, city environmental officials said yesterday.
Anything that has the potential to eliminate the sight of a herd of cows wading and defecating in water bound for city faucets is welcome, said Joel A. Miele, the city's Commissioner of Environmental Protection.
For decades, such sights have been commonplace around several of the city's largest reservoirs, in rural regions west of the Hudson River. "I quiver when I think about it," Mr. Miele said. "Hopefully we'll see less and less of that.
"I recognize the fact that the farmers need every bit of acreage they've got there to stay economically viable. This program thanks the farmers financially for giving up that little bit."
Ninety percent of the city's drinking water starts out as runoff in rural hills 100 miles to the northwest, in the Catskills and Delaware River Valley, where the water trickles across farmers' fields and picks up undesirable silt, chemicals, nutrients that promote algae growth, and intestinal parasites before traveling downstream into reservoirs and eventually city taps.
Almost all of these contaminants are naturally removed from the water as it flows toward the city, but Federal environmental officials have increasingly pressed the city to either bolster protection of its water at the source or build a $6 billion filtration plant. New York is one of the few cities in the nation whose water is not filtered.
The Agriculture Department initiative will complement the work of several city programs created in the last four years. Gale Sheridan, executive director of the Watershed Agricultural Council, a quasi-public, city-funded agency that encourages farmers to reduce pollution, said the Federal program "gives a chance for farmers to get an annual payment that they can use to rent land further from the water."
"That keeps them in business, and helps us have better water quality," he said.
The new program in the New York City watersheds is a variant of a long-standing national program, the Conservation Reserve Program, that encourages farmers to leave some sensitive lands fallow. But the payments offered were too low to attract farmers in upstate New York, where fertile valley-bottom land for dairy herds has always been a coveted commodity.
The New York program, limited to the 350 farmers whose fields drain into the city water supply, effectively doubles the payments offered under the Conservation Reserve Program.
Related efforts to reduce farmland runoff using Agriculture Department money have already begun in Maryland, where farm pollution has tainted Chesapeake Bay, and in Illinois and Minnesota, where rivers are similarly suffering, agriculture officials said.
In New York, $7.7 million of the program's $10.4 million cost will be paid by the Agriculture Department, with the remaining $2.7 million to be paid by New York City, department officials said.
Timothy D. Searchinger, a lawyer for the Environmental Defense Fund, a private group based in New York, said farmers in the Northeast cannot survive financially without this kind of compensation. "Probably the only way to preserve farming there is if these dairy farmers produce not only milk, but environmental benefits," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Federal Government is offering farmers money to keep their dairy cows, like these fording a stream in Delaware County in 1997, away from streams that feed New York City's reservoirs. (Suzanne DeChillo/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: States Bracing For Northwest Pilots' Strike

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
They are stockpiling baby diapers, trying to line up extra buses and appealing to other airlines for help, but the authorities in Minneapolis, Detroit and seven upper Midwestern states from Illinois to North Dakota admit that there is not much they can do if pilots at Northwest Airlines strike on Saturday, shutting down the region's single largest airline.
"The impact on us would be devastating," said Kevin J. Kramer, the director of economic development for North Dakota, where Northwest provides virtually all the state's jet service. "We have all our eggs in one basket." 
 The situation is not much better in Detroit and Minneapolis, which are home to the nation's 9th- and 13th-busiest airports. An estimated 8 out of 10 flights in and out of both cities are Northwest's.
In a letter to President Clinton earlier this month, the Governors of Minnesota, Michigan, Wisconsin and four other states estimated that their economies would lose hundreds of millions of dollars in the first week alone if Northwest, the country's fourth-largest airline, stopped flying.
No one can say for sure whether a strike will be averted before the deadline -- one minute past midnight on Saturday morning. The latest round of negotiations between Northwest and the pilots began at an undisclosed location on Aug. 17 under the auspices of a Federal mediator, who has ordered both sides not to talk to reporters. The negotiations are to continue right up to the strike deadline.
Both sides say publicly that they are eager to reach a settlement, and Donald J. Foley, Northwest's chief spokesman, said some progress had been made during the recent negotiations. But the key issue of pay remains unresolved.
As Saturday draws closer, the belief among politicians and business executives that there will be a strike appears to be increasing.
Northwest began notifying passengers yesterday that it would cancel about 100 domestic flights Friday to insure that its planes are not stranded in far-off airports if the pilots walk out.
"We have made the appropriate preparations to pull down the airline as of midnight on Friday night if we are unable to reach an agreement at the negotiating table," Mr. Foley said.
Last year, when the pilots struck American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, President Clinton intervened within minutes, ordering the pilots back to work and the negotiators back to the table.
But some believe that the President, in his politically weakened state following his admission of an inappropriate relationship with Monica Lewinsky, will be more reluctant to intervene now.
"We told our clients early in the process that Clinton would intervene," said Brent Garback, the chief executive of Total Travel Management, the largest corporate travel agency in Michigan. "But given his problems we now think he won't."
Mr. Clinton may also be reluctant to interfere because the Air Line Pilots Association, which represents pilots at Northwest and 49 other carriers, is a major contributor to the Democratic Party. Earlier this month, 24 Democratic Congressmen, including the minority leader, Richard Gephardt of Missouri, and the Democratic whip, David Bonior of Michigan, wrote the President, urging him not to intercede.
A White House official who insisted on anonymity said that as he had in the American strike the President would not intervene until after the strike deadline to maintain the pressure on both sides to settle.
Robert B. Reich, who was Labor Secretary during the American strike, said that the President was not likely to act this time unless it was clear that both sides were looking for a face-saving way out.
"Certainly the President doesn't want to be viewed as powerless," said Mr. Reich, now a professor at Brandeis University. "He especially doesn't want to look that way now."
The average Northwest pilot now is paid $120,000 a year, according to the union. Northwest says it is offering its 6,200 pilots a 10 percent pay increase over five years, placing them on par with their counterparts at United Airlines, American Airlines and Delta Air Lines, the three larger domestic carriers.
The pilots counter that Northwest is not offering the hefty stock options and profit sharing that the other airlines give their pilots. They are asking for a 15 percent wage increase over five years, greater job security and guaranteed vacation time.
But the real issue is what the pilots and other Northwest workers feel they are owed for the sacrifices they made in 1993, to save the airline when it was near bankruptcy. Northwest's 45,000 unionized employees accepted wage cuts and work rule concessions worth $886 million.
The largest share, worth $365 million, came from the pilots, who agreed to cut their wages and other benefits 15.5 percent for 39 months in exchange for three seats on Northwest's board of directors and more than 14 million shares of stock.
Since then, the airline industry and Northwest have rebounded, registering four years of record profits. The unions say they want their share.
In addition to the pilots, Northwest also faces tough negotiations with five other unions. Last month, the International Association of Machinists, which represents 27,000 Northwest workers, rejected a tentative contract that would have given them a 14 percent pay increase.
Workers have been particularly embittered by $73 million worth of stock sold by Northwest insiders earlier this year when the share price was near its 52-week high of $65.3125. The group was led by John H. Dasburg, Northwest's chief executive, who sold 322,000 shares worth $19 million, according to CDA/Investnet of Rockville, Md.
With a strike looming, Northwest stock has since slid more than 50 percent, reaching a 52-week low of $28.50 a share on Friday. It closed yesterday at $29.50, up 56.25 cents.
Samuel C. Buttrick, an airline industry analyst at Paine Webber, estimates that Northwest will have lost up to $100 million in the month before the strike deadline because of lost bookings. But he added that Northwest had $3 billion in cash, more than enough to weather the storm.
Officials in Minneapolis and Detroit said their appeals to other airlines to send in extra planes during a strike had failed because, with the booming economy, most airlines are flying at full capacity.
But Paul Omodt, a spokesman for the pilots' union, called concerns about the impact of a strike exaggerated. "It is kind of ridiculous to think there are no alternatives," he said. "If there is a strike, there will be an initial shock to the system. But then some airlines will pick up the routes. It is found money for them."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Ruble Falls Steeply, Causing New Wave of Panic
A fresh wave of panic swept through Russia's financial institutions as the currency plunged, three banks announced a merger to shore up their stability and the Government disclosed a plan to stretch out repayment of its debt.
 Coming at a moment when Russia's newly designated Prime Minister is still negotiating with the Parliament over the makeup of his Government, the ruble's abrupt drop stoked new fears of inflation similar to the spiraling rates that sent Russia into a depression in the early 1990's. The drop in the value of the currency was the deepest in four years. It was stopped only when the central bank of Russia intervened. Page A1. 

Most major market indexes were rallying strongly early yesterday, but dropped slightly after hearing about the situation in Russia. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 36.04 points, to 8,602.65. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed up 4.72 points at 1,092.86. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index gained 7.35 points, to 1,798.17. But the Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks hit a new 52-week low, falling 3.94 points, or 1 percent, to 389.76. D6.
 
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.43 percent, from 5.46 percent. D6.
 
Inquiry Into Microsoft's Intel Role
The Government is investigating whether Microsoft has used its market muscle to force even Intel to shelve new technology efforts that conflicted with Microsoft's ambitions. The antitrust lawsuit accusing Microsoft of using unfair business practices to protect its monopoly in operating systems and to extend that monopoly into the new markets for Internet software and commerce was filed by the Justice Department and 20 states. The trial is scheduled to start Sept. 23. A1.
 
Marsh & McLennan's $2 Billion Deal
Marsh & McLennan has agreed to buy the London-based Sedgwick Group, the largest independent broker in Europe, for $2.05 billion in cash. The deal increases Marsh & McLennan's business with the largest corporations in Europe and with midsized companies in the United States. D2.
 
British Airways Orders Airbus Jets
British Airways has ordered as many as 188 short-haul, single-aisle jets from Airbus Industrie in a contract worth $8.5 billion. Until now, British Airways had relied on Boeing as its supplier. D2.
 
U.A.W. Criticizes G.M. Spinoff
Stephen P. Yokich, president of the United Automobile Workers, has condemned General Motor's plan to spin off its auto parts subsidiary, and said another strike was always possible. But he added that the union may not do anything until its agreement with the Big 3 American auto makers expires next fall. D2.
 
Consumer Confidence Index Drops
The Conference Board's consumer confidence index declined to 133.1 in August, but analysts said the decrease did not signal a big change in sentiment, although consumers might start to exercise some caution. In another report, the National Association of Realtors said that home resales rose 4 percent in July, to a record annual rate of 4.93 million. D3.
 
I.M.F. Is Softening Its Policies
The International Monetary Fund is softening its policies, becoming more tolerant of arrangements it would have rejected a year ago, and even allowing some Asian debtors not to repay all they owe to foreign banks. A10.
 
Applied Materials Cuts 2,000 Jobs
In response to a global downturn in the semiconductor industry, Applied Materials announced plans to cut 2,000 jobs, or about 15 percent of its work force, mostly in Santa Clara, Calif., and Austin, Tex., and executive salaries by 10 percent. D3.

HEADLINE: Ship With Proud History Arrives at Its New Home

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: GLEN COVE, N.Y., Aug. 25

 BODY:
When the Regina Maris, a 90-year-old three-masted wooden barkentine, was being towed out of Greenport Harbor Sunday night, crew members said that those left behind on the dock were taking bets that she would never make it through Plum Gut's rough tidal waters.
"The tide was running against us, but she slipped right through," said Rudolph Schukert, a crew volunteer. "She was built to sail, and sometimes it felt like she was under her own power. You forgot she was being towed." 
 This morning, flags flying, the 239-ton vessel eased into Hempstead Harbor here, 90 nautical miles west of Greenport, and was welcomed to her new home port by the Mayor of Glen Cove, Thomas R. Suozzi, who climbed her rigging and declared her a symbol of his efforts to revitalize the city's waterfront.
The 140-foot-long Danish-built vessel, whose maritime history includes the smuggling of Jewish refugees from northern Europe during World War II, was scheduled to be scuttled at sea at the end of this month. Officials in Greenport, her home for the last eight years, said the aging vessel had become a public liability.
Touched by her history of helping others to survive, Mayor Suozzi decided to come to the ship's rescue and provide her a new home.
"There are only about 200 tall ships left in the world, less than half of which are made of wood," he said. "And the Regina Maris is only one of two wooden barkentines left. The supply of these tall ships is small, but the demand is great."
Mayor Suozzi said it could cost as much as $4 million to make the ship seaworthy again. Although Mr. Suozzi said he hoped to be able to raise the money through private donations, he said the ship would be a dockside attraction even without a complete restoration.
The first to contribute to the effort was Barbara Johnson, a Nassau County legislator from Port Washington, who paid the towing fee.
"I'm an American Jew and I had relatives who perished in the Holocaust in the ovens at Auschwitz, and when I heard that this ship was used to transport Jews to save them, I was determined to pay for the transport of the Regina Maris to Glen Cove," she said.
She presented a check for $3,000 to James Barker, of Barker Marine Limited of Port Washington, who towed the ship at cost. Mr. Barker, in turn, gave the check to Hope House Ministries of Port Jefferson, which provides shelter for the homeless.

HEADLINE: Lewis Powell, Crucial Centrist Justice, Dies at 90

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Lewis F. Powell Jr., the Supreme Court Justice who brought a voice of moderation and civility to an increasingly polarized Court during his 15-year tenure, died today at the age of 90. An announcement from the Court reported that Justice Powell, who retired 11 years ago and had been in failing health, died of pneumonia at his home in Richmond, Va.
Justice Powell already was one of the country's most prominent corporate lawyers, with practical legal skills polished by decades of experience, when his nomination to the Court by President Richard M. Nixon in 1972 gave him an unexpected second career. He was 64 years old, an age at which he said he had expected to start "tapering off," when he took the seat made vacant by the retirement of Associate Justice Hugo L. Black. 
 His role on the Court eventually became so central to the institution's ideological balance that his retirement in 1987 unleashed a furious political battle over the nomination of Robert H. Bork, the prominent conservative President Ronald Reagan named to replace him. Mr. Bork's nomination was defeated and the seat eventually went to the more moderate Anthony M. Kennedy.
First in his native Virginia and then on the national scene, Mr. Powell had long since reached the highest ranks of the legal profession. He had been president of three major legal organizations, the American Bar Association, the American Bar Foundation and the American College of Trial Lawyers. He was a senior partner of one of Virginia's oldest law firms, a trustee and general counsel of Colonial Williamsburg and a director of 11 major corporations.
Born into the insularity and rigid stratifications of the post-Reconstruction South, Justice Powell cherished his roots in Richmond and at the same time transcended them. From a young age, he was drawn to the wider world while maintaining his ties to home. His long life in some respects mirrored the journey of the modern South from the country's fringe to its mainstream. He described his initial response to the Supreme Court's ruling in Brown v. Board of Education, the 1954 decision that segregation in the public schools was unconstitutional, as one of shock. Yet as a Virginia civic leader and later as a Supreme Court Justice, he stood for moderation and consensus-building on matters of race.
He played a pivotal role on a Court that was marked by sharp ideological divisions. He was the balancer and compromiser, a political moderate with an aversion to heated rhetoric and doctrinal rigidity. Neither his colleagues nor lawyers practicing before the Court could take his vote for granted. He had to be persuaded by the weight of argument, and his vote was frequently the decisive one, whether the subject was state aid to parochial schools, remedies for racial discrimination or the rights of illegal aliens.
The most important opinion of his Supreme Court tenure was probably one in which he wrote only for himself. In the Bakke case, a landmark affirmative action decision in 1978, he bridged two competing four-Justice blocs to extract an opinion that barred the use of rigid racial quotas but permitted race to be taken into account in university admissions.

 
He never lost either his acute sense of the Court's great power or his conviction that the power had to be used sparingly. For him, judicial restraint was crucial to keeping the balance of power among the three branches of Government.
A concurring opinion he wrote in a 1974 decision, holding that a taxpayer could not bring a suit challenging the way the Central Intelligence Agency was financed, expressed as clearly as anything else Justice Powell's vision of the role of the Court.
"We should be ever mindful," he wrote in United States v. Richardson, "of the contradictions that would arise if a democracy were to permit general oversight of the elected branches of Government by a nonrepresentative, and in large measure, insulated judicial branch."
"Repeated and essentially head-on confrontations between the life-tenured branch and the representative branches of Government will not, in the long run, be beneficial to either," he said. "The public confidence essential to the former and the vitality critical to the latter may well erode if we do not exercise self-restraint in the utilization of our power."

On the other hand, Justice Powell did not hesitate to place the Court's weight on the side of those who had nowhere else to turn. In 1982, he joined the Court's liberal bloc in providing the crucial fifth vote for a decision requiring Texas to give a free public education to the children of illegal aliens.
"I am not unmindful of what must be the exasperation of responsible citizens and government authorities" over the influx of illegal aliens, he wrote in concurring with the majority opinion in Plyler v. Doe. But the fact remained, he said, that "innocent" children were being denied an education solely because of their parents' illegal status, and were thereby "singled out for a lifelong penalty and stigma." He said that "it can hardly be argued rationally that anyone benefits from the creation within our borders of a subclass of illiterate persons."
 
A Courtly Demeanor And a Tidewater Drawl
If in his professional career Lewis Powell seemed to epitomize the legal establishment, his courtly demeanor and soft Tidewater drawl made him the image of the classic Southern gentleman. Almost ascetically thin, he was so unassuming that he often appeared to melt into the background. In crepe-soled shoes, he strolled the Court's corridors and grounds unrecognized by tourists.
His questions from the bench during oral argument were few and were posed in a voice barely above a whisper. But they were precise and potentially devastating to the argument of any lawyer who did not have the answer. His soft manner did not hide the quick and tough mind that had served him both as a lawyer and as head of the Richmond school board in the 1950's, a troubled decade during which he argued successfully against the "massive resistance" campaign that some white city leaders advocated in defiance of the Supreme Court's desegregation mandates.
According to his biographer, Prof. John C. Jeffries Jr. of the University of Virginia Law School, a burning ambition and desire to excel drove Mr. Powell as a young lawyer into positions of leadership in his law firm, his profession, and his community; an ability to win the confidence of clients and colleagues made his success possible.
Lewis Franklin Powell Jr. was born in Suffolk, Va., on Sept. 19, 1907, into a family with deep roots in the region. One of his father's relatives, although not a direct ancestor, was Nathaniel Powell, one of the original Jamestown settlers and for a time the colony's acting governor. Justice Powell's mother, Mary Lewis Gwathmey, was raised on a Virginia plantation by an uncle who had accompanied Gen. Robert E. Lee to the surrender of the Confederate forces at Appomattox.
The family's proud history was no guarantee of lasting prosperity. Mr. Powell's father, raised on a modest farm with little formal education, finally achieved a hard-won financial security as manager of a Richmond company that manufactured boxes and furniture.
Lewis Jr. was the oldest of four children. Growing up in a near-rural area of Richmond known as Forest Hill, he attended a local private academy that aimed at preparing boys for the University of Virginia. But he engaged in a gentle form of rebellion and struck out instead for Washington and Lee University in Lexington, Va., where he achieved both academic and social success and began to expand his horizons.
As president of the student body, he attended a student leadership conference in California and met Edward R. Murrow, a student leader from the state of Washington. The young Southerner and the future television journalist became close friends, traveling together in Europe after a student conference in Brussels in 1930 and visiting together again in London during World War II.
Mr. Powell was elected to Phi Beta Kappa and received his undergraduate degree in 1929 with a major in commerce. By counting some undergraduate courses toward a law degree, he was able to graduate two years later from Washington and Lee's law school, where he was first in his class. Throughout his life, he kept strong ties to Washington and Lee, to which he gave his personal and Supreme Court papers, now housed in the Lewis F. Powell Jr. Archives on the campus in Lexington.
After law school, Mr. Powell earned a graduate law degree from Harvard Law School. One of his classes was an administrative law seminar taught by Felix Frankfurter, who later served on the Supreme Court and who impressed the young lawyer with a pragmatic approach to legal issues that was very different from the more formal and unskeptical approach of the professors at Washington and Lee.
 
Moving Back To Richmond
After turning down an offer of a job at a prestigious Wall Street law firm, Davis, Polk & Wardwell, Mr. Powell returned to Richmond in 1932, moved in with his parents and began his legal career as an associate in a small firm. Soon he moved to a bigger firm, and by 1938 had become its 10th partner. Except for his service in World War II, he stayed at that firm, known for many years as Hunton, Williams, Gay, Powell & Gibson, until he took his seat on the Supreme Court. He played a leading role in the evolution of the firm, later known as Hunton & Williams, beyond its regional roots to a corporate law practice that was national in scope.
In 1936, when he was 28, Mr. Powell married Josephine Pierce Rucker, the daughter of a prominent Richmond obstetrician. The two had met years earlier, but Mr. Powell first became interested in the doctor's daughter after hearing that she had set a broad-jump record of 22 feet at Sweet Briar College. Their marriage was a lifelong love affair that produced four children: Josephine Smith; Ann Pendleton Bowen, known as Penny; Molly Sumner, and Lewis 3d. Mrs. Powell died in 1996. In addition to his children, Justice Powell is survived by nine grandchildren and one great-grandson.
He volunteered for military service in World War II, spending more than three years in Europe and North Africa as a combat and staff intelligence officer with the Army Air Forces. He rose in rank from first lieutenant to colonel, earning the Legion of Merit, Bronze Star and Croix de Guerre. He spent the last half of his tour in a military intelligence unit known as the Special Branch, helping to analyze decoded German messages. He presented daily briefings to senior officers, including, at times, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, who used the top-secret information to select Allied bombing targets. Colonel Powell ended his assignment with several dozen officers under his command, and his return to peacetime law practice was something of an anticlimax.
Active in the American Bar Association early in his career, he served a term as its president from mid-1964 to mid-1965. He used the position as a platform to lobby for an increased Federal role in providing legal services to the poor, and helped shape the legal services program of the Office of Economic Opportunity.
Although he never held elective office, he was a leading figure in Virginia public affairs as head of the Richmond school board from 1952 to 1961. He was a member of the Virginia State Board of Education from 1961 to 1969, serving as its president for the 1968-69 term.
At that time, Virginia was dominated by the Democratic machine of Senator Harry F. Byrd, who advocated stiff resistance to the Supreme Court's 1954 desegregation decision. Mr. Powell believed that such resistance would be deeply destructive. Under his leadership the Richmond schools did not defy the Court. On the other hand, integration was very slow in coming to Richmond as elsewhere. When Mr. Powell left the school board in the spring of 1961, only two of 23,000 black students in the Richmond public schools were attending school with white children.
 
Backing by Kennedy For the High Court
Ten years later, the Congressional Black Caucus opposed his nomination to the Court, arguing that he should have done more from his position as a community leader to fight segregation and its legacy. Liberal Democrats on the Senate Judiciary Committee came to his defense, however. When the committee approved his nomination, Senator Edward M. Kennedy and three other Democratic members issued a concurring report that praised Mr. Powell's record. "Lewis Powell was one of the courageous men in Virginia who was determined to obey the law of the land," the report said.
In 1990, Virginia inaugurated as its governor L. Douglas Wilder, the first black person in the country to be elected governor of a state. Mr. Wilder invited Justice Powell, who was retired by then, to administer the oath. As Professor Jeffries recounted the scene in his book, "Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr." (Scribners, 1994), Justice Powell called out above the applause that followed the swearing-in: "It's a great day for Virginia!"
Professor Jeffries wrote: "For the sea of young black faces raised in pride and triumph, the good wishes of a frail old white man may have meant very little, but to those with long memories, it was a gracious benediction from the best of the old order."
Nixon announced Mr. Powell's nomination to the Supreme Court, along with that of William H. Rehnquist to fill a second vacancy, to a nationwide television audience on Oct. 21, 1971. The announcement came barely 24 hours after the American Bar Association's judicial fitness committee refused to endorse two Nixon candidates who had been considered the front-runners for the seats. Mr. Powell had turned down an earlier offer of a seat on the Court from the Nixon Administration, and rebuffed Attorney General John N. Mitchell's effort to interest him in the new vacancy. He finally accepted with a deep reluctance that was overcome only by a direct appeal from Nixon, who said it was Mr. Powell's patriotic duty to serve.
The bar association gave its former president its highest possible rating, and the nomination was well received in legal circles. He was confirmed by the full Senate on Dec. 6, 1971, and he and Mr. Rehnquist were sworn in as the 99th and 100th members of the Court on Jan. 7, 1972.
Justice Powell approached his new job without any great relish. He regretted leaving Richmond and the law practice that he loved. "The truth is that I'd rather be a lawyer than a judge," he told his former colleagues. "I really prefer to be competitive rather than neutral, detached and disinterested." Nevertheless, he said, he had no doubt that if he had it to do over he would still accept the appointment.
After moving to Washington, Justice Powell maintained strong ties to Richmond. He and his wife kept their Richmond house, a colonial mansion that had belonged to Mrs. Powell's parents, and returned there every summer. He also kept an office in the Federal courthouse in Richmond. In Washington, the couple lived in an apartment in the southwest section of the capital, near the Potomac River.
 
60 Hours a Week On Court's Business
But the Court, when it was in session, was Justice Powell's real home. He told a group of lawyers and judges in a 1983 speech that except for the summer recess, he worked 60 hours a week, "considerably more than my chargeable hours ever were at the peak of a large and demanding law practice."
Justice Powell's role as the Court's master of compromise and coalition-building was nowhere brought into sharper focus than in the 1978 case of Allan P. Bakke. That case, in which the Court was asked to rule on the legality of a state medical school admissions program that set aside a fixed number of places for black and other minority-group applicants, sparked a vigorous national debate over affirmative action that continued for years.
With the Court split 4 to 4, Justice Powell extracted a controlling opinion from the deadlock by joining first one four-member bloc and then the other. He agreed with one group of Justices that the challenged program was unlawful because it totally excluded whites from any consideration for the 16 places. But he then joined the other four members of the Court to conclude that a university could properly consider race and ethnic origin as a "plus" factor among other factors to achieve a diverse student body.
"The State has a substantial interest that legitimately may be served by a properly devised admissions program involving the competitive consideration of race and ethnic origin," Justice Powell said in his solitary opinion. The concept of affirmative action was preserved and the debate, at least in the short run, defused.
 
Pivotal Role in Cases Of Church and State
Justice Powell also played a pivotal role in numerous Supreme Court cases that defined the constitutional boundary between church and state. Cases challenging various programs of state aide to parochial schools reached the Court with regularity, and Justice Powell's vote was often decisive in upholding or striking down a particular program. In that role, the former school board president was keenly aware of the potentially inflammatory nature of the debate over the relationship of religion and government. He believed that, apart from doctrinal niceties, it was vital for the Court to avoid fueling those fires.
For example, in 1977 he joined a fragmented majority that upheld an Ohio parochial aid law. In his concurring opinion in Wolman v. Walter, he noted that "at this point in the 20th century," the risk of "deep political division along religious lines" was "remote."
But in 1985, with the political debate over church and state at a peak, Justice Powell provided the fifth vote striking down parochial aid programs in New York City and Grand Rapids, Mich. His concurring opinion in Aguilar v. Felton, the New York case, cited the "continuing risk of continuing political strife," noting that "the potential for such divisiveness is a strong additional reason" for finding the programs unconstitutional. In the 30 religion cases in which he participated -- many of them decided by closely divided votes -- he was never on the losing side. The Court itself eventually adopted a different approach to questions of church and state, overruling the Aguilar case in a 1997 decision called Agostini v. Felton.
More often than not, Justice Powell voted with the conservatives in cases dealing with criminal law. He believed that prison inmates and their lawyers abused their right of access to the Federal courts by filing frivolous lawsuits, and he joined a majority of the Court in the mid-1980's in invoking new procedures for avoiding protracted appeals in death penalty cases.
He voted to uphold the death penalty in numerous cases, including a notable case that asked the Court to examine accusations that application of the death penalty was infected by racism. Challengers to the death penalty in Georgia presented statistics showing that killers of whites were more likely to be sentenced to die than those whose victims were black. Writing for the Court in a 5-to-4 opinion, McCleskey v. Kemp, Justice Powell said that the statistical study did not "demonstrate a constitutionally significant risk of racial bias" sufficient to invalidate the death penalty in Georgia.
The death penalty was one of two subjects on which Justice Powell changed his mind after he left the Court. He told his biographer, Professor Jeffries, in a 1991 interview that he regretted his vote in the McCleskey case and other death penalty cases. "I have come to think that capital punishment should be abolished," he said.
He described his view as based on pragmatic concerns rather than on questions about the morality or constitutionality of the death penalty itself. Doubts about the death penalty could never be resolved and would inevitably bring the judicial system itself into disrepute, the Justice said. Professor Jeffries detected a deeper source of disquiet in the retired Justice. "After 15 years of capital cases, Powell knew firsthand their deadly hold on the judge's peace of mind," he wrote.
 
With the Majority In Roe v. Wade
Justice Powell was a member of the majority in Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision that gave women the constitutional right to obtain abortions, and he did not waiver in his support of that principle. He wrote the Court's opinion in a 1983 case striking down restrictions on abortion imposed by the city of Akron, Ohio. His opinion acknowledged and rebuffed the efforts of anti-abortion forces to persuade the Court to overrule Roe v. Wade. The argument was settled, Justice Powell wrote; the doctrine of adherence to precedent "is a doctrine that demands respect in a society governed by the rule of law."
In an interview with the British Broadcasting Company after his retirement, Justice Powell described a long-ago incident at his law firm that had shaped his views on the desirability of legalized abortion in the years before Roe v. Wade. A 19-year-old messenger for the firm had called him at home early one morning with a desperate request for help. His girlfriend had died while trying, with the messenger's help, to abort a pregnancy. The messenger could have been charged with murder.
In the interview, Justice Powell said he visited the city prosecutor on the young man's behalf. "To make a long story short, no prosecution was ever brought," he said, adding: "So I was in full agreement with the decision of the Court in Roe. I thought a woman ought to have the right, and I still think so."
In 1986, the question for the Court was whether the constitutional right to privacy recognized in Roe v. Wade should also apply to consensual sex between homosexual adults. In a 5-to-4 decision, Bowers v. Hardwick, the Court rejected that analysis of the right to privacy. Justice Powell joined Justice Byron R. White's majority opinion that described as "at best, facetious" the argument that there was constitutional protection for homosexuality.
Four years later, in a question-and-answer session after a speech to students at New York University Law School, Justice Powell said he had originally voted the other way but had changed his mind at the last minute. He said he now regretted his vote and had concluded that the dissent "had the better of the arguments."

Poor Health Forced Retirement
He announced his retirement on the last day of the Supreme Court in June 1987, giving health problems as the reason. Two years earlier, he had nearly died of uncontrolled bleeding after surgery for prostate cancer and had not regained his energy. He was 79 years old, reed-thin and frail in appearance. But he had an active and productive retirement. Until 1996, when his health declined sharply, he sat regularly as an appeals court judge -- an available but little-used prerogative of retired Justices -- on the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond. He gave speeches, gently but pointedly reminding his former colleagues of the importance of civility and adherence to precedent. On Jan. 7 last year, 25 years to the day after taking the oath as a Supreme Court Justice, he closed the office he had kept at the Court and returned to live full time at his home in Richmond.
A political firestorm followed Justice Powell's departure from the Court in 1987, though he never commented on it. President Reagan nominated Robert H. Bork, a Federal appeals court judge and leading conservative legal scholar who had made no secret of his view that much of modern constitutional law, from the criminal procedure rulings of the Warren Court to the abortion decision in Roe v. Wade, was profoundly misguided. The Democratic-controlled Senate defeated the nomination after a nearly four-month battle. A second nomination for the vacancy, that of Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, was withdrawn. President Reagan's third choice, Anthony M. Kennedy, a Federal appeals court judge from Sacramento, Calif., was eventually confirmed and took Justice Powell's seat on Feb. 18, 1988.
President Clinton paid tribute to Justice Powell yesterday, saying: "For over 15 years on the Supreme Court, he approached each case without an ideological agenda, carefully applying the Constitution, the law and Supreme Court precedent regardless of his own personal views about the case. His opinions were a model of balance and judiciousness. As a result, he was the decisive voice on the court in addressing some of the most important issues of our day."

Powell Jr., top, being sworn in as a member of the Richmond School Board in 1950, the start of a decade of turmoil over integration. HEADLINE: Giuliani Picks a Chief Lobbyist Whose Father Once Held the Job

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed Anthony P. Piscitelli yesterday to be the city's chief lobbyist in Albany, saying Mr. Piscitelli had a "genetic capacity" for the position because his father held the job two decades ago.
Mr. Piscitelli is replacing Robert M. Harding, who became the Mayor's budget director last month after spending four years as the city's lobbyist in the State Capitol. He will be in charge of promoting the city's legislative agenda in Albany, a job requiring strong persuasive powers. 
 Mr. Piscitelli's father, Peter A. Piscitelli, was the city's chief lobbyist under Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1978 and 1979. He is now a partner in Wilson, Elser, Moskowitz, Edelman & Dicker, one of the most powerful lobbying firms in New York. Anthony Piscitelli, known as Skip, spent the last two years working for Wilson, Elser, which represents mostly private businesses on matters involving city and state government.
Wilson, Elser was paid $1 million last year to influence governmental decisions, more than any other firm that lobbies the city, according to a report by the City Clerk's office.
"Skip Piscitelli brings a tremendous amount of experience to this very important assignment," Mayor Giuliani said in announcing the appointment, "one that's really critical to the fiscal stability of the city and critical to our achieving many of our policy objectives. In addition to his vast experience and knowledge as a lawyer and as a person who understands what's going on in Albany, this is also inherited."
People who have worked with Mr. Piscitelli described him as low-key and experienced. He was an assistant lobbyist for the city from 1990 to 1994, working on environmental and economic development issues under both Mayor David N. Dinkins and Mayor Giuliani. Mr. Piscitelli, 42, then spent two years as a lobbyist at Gibney, Anthony & Flaherty, the firm that employed Peter J. Powers, one of the Mayor's closest friends, until Mr. Powers became a deputy mayor in 1994.
"My general impression is that Skip's a nice guy who has been doing lobbying for quite a while," said Abraham M. Lackman, finance director for the State Senate and Mr. Giuliani's first budget director. "He has paid his dues."
Both Mr. Piscitelli and his father are Democrats, but both said their greatest strength was transcending party labels. Still, Mr. Piscitelli said his biggest challenge would be convincing legislators from New York City who are not allies of Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, that "we're there to carry the message of the city of New York."
But in the end, the Mayor's combative style will probably be an asset to Mr. Piscitelli, Mr. Lackman said. "People perceive this Mayor as being powerful," he said. "And when people perceive your principal as being powerful, it makes your job easier."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE ATTACKS: THE CONNECTION;
Iraqi Deal With Sudan On Nerve Gas Is Reported

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 25

 BODY:
At the end of the Persian Gulf war in 1991, when the Sudan was one of Iraq's few remaining friends in the world, the Government here struck a bargain with Baghdad, foreign diplomats and Sudanese said today.
In return for Iraqi financial help and assistance by military and civilian experts, the Sudan agreed to allow its installations to be used by Iraqi technicians for steps in the production of chemical weapons, they said. 
 The deal was beneficial to both countries. The struggling Sudan got economic help, and Iraq was able to move ahead with chemical weapons far away from the gaze of United Nations weapons inspectors.
"Sudan is a wonderful place to do secretive things," a former Sudanese Government official said.
A diplomat here said the Clinton Administration had known about the Iraqi chemical weapons activities here for some time. The United States attacked a pharmaceutical factory in Khartoum last week and says it was because the factory was making a rare chemical used for the nerve agent VX.
The Sudanese Government has insisted that the factory was used only for the manufacture of medicines and has called for an international investigation to prove its contention.
The diplomats and the former Government official said it was not absolutely clear at which of several plants the Iraqis were working on chemical weapons or their precursors. It was not clear either, the diplomat said, whether completed chemical weapons were made or only precursors.
They said, however, that a military complex on the southern outskirts of the city, not the plant that was attacked, was the most likely place for the production.
Immediately after the gulf war, 40 Iraqi Government employees were sent to the heavily guarded military complex, one diplomat said.
"The Iraqis are there to guard chemical weapons or substances that Iraq doesn't want in Iraq," the diplomat said.
Hundreds of other Iraqi experts have worked in various fields in the Sudan since the gulf war, including the manufacture of munitions, the diplomat and the former Government official said.
The destruction of the pharmaceutical factory in the industrial area of Khartoum was a surprise because it had been touted since its opening in early 1997 as a breakthrough in the local production of inexpensive medicines, the diplomat said.
It was reportedly only lightly guarded.
Administration officials said on Monday that the pharmaceutical factory, Shifa Pharmaceutical Industries, had been targeted after soil samples from outside the plant, secretly obtained months ago, were found to have a rare chemical needed for the manufacture of VX.
The chemical, ethyl methylphosphonothinonate, known as Empta, has no industrial uses, the Administration official said. The only viable explanation for the presence of the "precursor chemical" is the production of VX, the official said.
Today, Administration officials said the pharmaceutical plant was not the only installation in the Sudan suspected of producing chemicals for VX, but rather the one where the United States had the most persuasive evidence.
"There were other facilities where there was really hard evidence," an official said, "but there was not a smoking gun; there was not a soil sample."
It seemed possible that the pharmaceutical factory was not actually making the "precursor chemical" that the Administration described, the diplomats here said. They believed that the factory had been chosen as a target because it could be more precisely hit than the military plant and without running the risk of spreading deadly vapors.
The Administration has said in the last two days that it was confident of its justification for hitting the pharmaceutical plant and saw no reason for an investigation into whether Empta was produced there.
Traces of Empta would survive destruction of a site by fire, said a chemical weapons expert, Amy E. Smythson of the Henry L. Stimson Center in Washington. The center specializes in arms control research.
Under Secretary of State Thomas R. Pickering said today in Washington: "We see evidence that we think is quite clear on contacts between Sudan and Iraq. In fact, el Shifa officials, early in the company's history, we believe, were in touch with Iraqi individuals associated with Iraq's VX program."
Iraq and Iran are about the Sudan's best friends in the Arab world. Because the Sudanese Govenrment has been accused of harboring training centers for terrorists, the Sudan has tense relations with neighboring Egypt and poor relations with Saudi Arabia.
Relations between the United States and the Islamic military rulers who came to power here in 1989 deteriorated to the point where the American Embassy was closed in 1996. The Sudan is on the State Department's list of terrorist states.
The Iraqi-Sudanese relationship has blossomed over time and includes the assignment of Iraqi military officers at an air base outside Khartoum, Sudanese officials say. The Iraqis have helped with civilian activities, including repairing irrigation machinery for agricultural projects, they said.
The Iraqis and the Sudanese have also developed trade relations, including an order from the destroyed pharmaceutical plant for veterinary drugs to be exported to Iraq. The sanctions committee of the United Nations Security Council approved the supplies under the "oil for food" program that allows Iraq to sell some oil despite economic sanctions in order to buy relief supplies.
The export-import relationship involving civilian products could well have been developed to help cover the export of agents for chemical weapons, officials said.
The immediate connection between the pharmaceutical plant and Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile now living in Afghanistan whose training camps were hit by cruise missiles the same night as the Sudanese factory, was not clear.
The United States originally suggested that the pharmaceutical plant was financed by Mr. bin Laden, which could have been the case during the plant's construction, diplomats said.
The factory is now owned by Saleh Idresse, a Sudanese who also has citizenship in Saudi Arabia. Businessmen in Khartoum said Mr. Idresse had plenty of cash, the sources of which are not clear. They said he had paid $27 million in cash for the Shifa plant.
He is also reported to have invested in what Sudanese refer to as the Government "military industrial complex." This includes the plant in southern Khartoum, the diplomat said, where the Iraqi technicians worked on the chemical weapons agents.

Iraq Denies Involvement
 UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 25 (By The New York Times) -- Iraq's representative at the United Nations denied today that his country had been involved in the development or production of chemical weapons in the Sudan and said the Iraqi Government would welcome an independent investigation of the factory in Khartoum destroyed by the United States.
"Iraq has had pharmaceutical contracts with the Government of Sudan, and I believe that this was the factory that was producing those medicines," said Nizar Hamdoon, the Iraqi representative, said of the Shifa Pharmaceutical Industries plant.
"So in that context, we have had commercial ties," Mr. Hamdoon said. "But beyond that, we strongly deny that there has been any chemical connections."
He accused the United States of trying to deflect attention from the attacks on the factory by saying Iraq was helping the Sudan produce components for the nerve gas VX.
Copies of documents from an Iraqi order placed with the plant, under the program that allows Iraq to import food and medicines to alleviate the hardships of sanctions, show that Iraq ordered 100,000 liter bottles of a compound that United Nations officials said was intended for de-worming farm animals.
The purchase was approved by the Security Council sanctions committee on Iraq, but there is no record of the shipment's having been made or received.

HEADLINE: Seaside Dreams From Asbury Park

BYLINE: By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 25

 BODY:
In the last dozen years this long-sagging New Jersey shore city has seen an eclectic bunch of would-be saviors, with plans ranging from the mundane to the sublime.
There was the Indian tribe that wanted to open a boardwalk casino. There were the followers of the Maharishi Mahesh Yogi who bought a beachfront hotel in a plan to create a transcendental meditation center. 
 And there was the developer who proposed a series of entertainment pavilions along the boardwalk, saying the family of Michael Jackson would operate one and Jacques Cousteau's organization another.
All of them ran aground, whether stalled by recessions, bankruptcies or a pervasive skepticism over the city's ability to reduce high rates of crime and poverty. But today a small group of residents and business owners rushed yet again into the fray, urging members of the City Council to accept a new offer from the New Jersey Redevelopment Authority to take on the long-stalled rebuilding effort.
Standing in the shadow of the hulking and incomplete Ocean Mile Condominiums project, which was abandoned by a bankrupt developer in 1992 and became a symbol of the city's plight, the group called the Asbury Park Consortium called on other residents to join them in putting away their fears of further disappointment.
The state agency could offer funds and expertise for planning, as well as help in attracting private development -- assistance that members of the consortium said was crucial to any successful rebuilding effort. But opponents of state involvement say they are skeptical of the promises of outsiders, and wary that state officials might press for more low-income housing development.
Proponents said that ceding some control to the state was a small price to pay to jump-start a redevelopment effort that has languished for so long. "It's a simple choice between something versus nothing," said John Hamilton, a Councilman who supports state involvement. He said that few if any desirable private developers were pressing to help rebuild the mile-long stretch of properties across from the beachfront and boardwalk.
The Council is slated on Friday to hold the first of two votes on inviting the state into the city.
William Best, the executive director of the state authority, said the 18-month-old agency had so far spent $13 million in 17 cities in the state and leveraged more than $52 million in private investments. Financed with about $425 million, the agency can offer a range of help to 67 specially designated cities, he said.
This city of 17,000 people, just 60 miles from New York City, probably last saw some luster in the 70's when a local star, Bruce Springsteen, was packing them in at the Paramount Theater and Convention Center on a boardwalk that was still lined with amusements and carnival rides. It had already been declining as a resort area for some years, and racial disturbances at the time sped that decline.
Today the city is 70 percent black and has an unemployment rate of 18 percent -- more than three times the statewide rate. The city's median income is $20,754, about half that of surrounding Monmouth County. About 22 percent of its families have earnings below the poverty level and 31 percent of its residents do not have high school diplomas.
In the 80's, the city adopted an ambitious redevelopment plan, of which the Ocean Mile condominiums were a key element. But the developer, Joseph Carabetta, who had the rights for the entire waterfront, was swamped by the recession and was forced to declare bankruptcy. Lawsuits by creditors and disarray among members of the Council over what course to take further complicated the city's efforts to move on.
"The only ones who got rich were the lawyers," said Rita Marano, owner of Kingsley Avenue Deli, as she displayed an editorial cartoon of lawyers dragging sacks of money out of town, from a local paper several years ago.
Even as all of this was going on, Asbury Park's leadership was undergoing a racial change from white to black. Long-smoldering distrust between whites and blacks mixed with the disappointment and finger-pointing of the failed redevelopment efforts to make movement even more difficult, said Henry Vaccaro, a former partner in the bankrupted redevelopment effort.
Coalitions have grown up and collapsed. Council members have been elected only to be voted out in recall elections over promises they had made.
"We've been deceived and disappointed so many times by so many people that we don't know who to trust anymore," said a local landlord, Norman Lemonde, with a world-weary shrug.
Like Mr. Vaccaro and Ms. Marano, Mr. Lemonde says he is wary of state involvement. Citing state efforts in the 70's and early 80's, they equate state involvement with the building of low-income housing rather than commercial development. They also say that they fear an increase in people on government assistance and an ever-expanding local government, which they say has become the city's employer of last resort in the absence of private sector jobs.
Mr. Best insisted that the state had no such plans, but Ms. Marano's motto is once burned, twice cautious.
"It's a sin to say it, but some people can make a lot of money on poor people," she said.
Mr. Hamilton, the Council member pushing for the city to ally formally with the state redevelopment authority, said he welcomed the support of the people who held the press conference today.
Unlike Mr. Vaccaro and other veterans of the heated and contentious early years of the redevelopment effort, they were new, more optimistic voices. One immediate result of the state involvement would be the payment of some $6.5 million in back taxes on the redevelopment acres held by Mr. Carabetta. In the absence of those revenues, the city has been increasingly dependent on state aid to meet its budget.
Echoing Mr. Hamilton's optimism is Wilbert Russell, the city's fourth city manager in three years, who has been on the job for just three months. He said he has been struck by how consumed people were with the mistakes of the past as he has worked to help the Council evaluate the idea of state involvement.
"I see their disappointments," he said, "but I just keep telling them that if they keep looking back, that's where they are going to wind up."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Asbury Park, N.J., has for decades proved resistant to efforts at redevelopment. In the 1970's, when Bruce Springsteen was a local star, the city was a popular entertainment spot on the Jersey Shore. (Keith Meyers/The New York Times)
 
Map of New Jersey showing location of Asbury Park: Asbury Park, a city of 17,000, is 60 miles from New York City.

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1192 words

HEADLINE: Slowly, Rising and Falling, Flood Swallows Town

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: DEL RIO, Tex., Aug. 25

 BODY:
Pat Calderon was standing on tiptoe atop his projection television console, the dark water in his living room so deep it was licking his chin, when his 82-year-old disabled mother, who was floating nearby on an upholstered love seat, asked if he would mind fetching her a dry blanket.
"I said, 'Mom, look where we are, we're in a flood,' " said Mr. Calderon, a fifth-grade teacher from San Felipe Estates in Del Rio. "I was holding on to that love seat so it didn't tip over and dump her in the water. I felt like that Titanic guy." 
 For six hours, they were stranded like that, the water slowly rising and then slowly falling, revealing a jumble of sopping carpet, furniture, books, videotapes, electronic equipment, all covered in gunk. A candle had bobbed all night on a floating end table while lightning flashes revealed the swift current tearing through what was left of his neighborhood.
"I was in the middle of this stuff and I couldn't believe it was happening," Mr. Calderon said.
Small groups of mud-streaked residents picked through what was left of their soggy belongings in San Felipe Estates today as hundreds remained homeless and the city struggled to return to normal after the disaster that left 10 dead on both sides of the river and more than 20 still missing. Five others had also died in flooding farther north in the Texas Hill Country.
The huge swell that put two-thirds of Del Rio under water early Monday -- some of it, like Mr. Calderon's neighborhood, more than eight feet under water -- had gushed down San Felipe Creek and its normally dry tributaries into the Rio Grande, and it was already halfway to the Gulf of Mexico by this afternoon.
All that was left was a swath of town covered with mud and debris, collapsed buildings, buckling pavement, chewed-up bridges and cars scattered everywhere, upside down, on their side, on top of buildings, on top of one another, so many matchbox cars in an untidy toy box.
"It came so quickly," said Councilwoman Gloria Sotelo, who was handing out drinking water at an American Red Cross shelter this afternoon. "By the time you crossed the street, the water was up to your knees. By the time you turned back, it was up to your shoulders."
Ms. Sotelo, like many of the more than 600 people seeking shelter in the Del Rio Civic Center because their homes were gone or uninhabitable, had known some of the six people in town who officials said had died and the dozen or so who were swept away and were still missing.
"It's too sad to think about now," Ms. Sotelo said.
Across the river, in Ciudad Acuna, Mexico, 4 people died in the floods and 10 remained missing, said Mario Neyra, a Mexican relief official.
Red Cross doctors worked from folding tables on the Del Rio civic center's stage while hundreds of people sprawled on cots and foam mattresses, and children scampered through the crowd.
Jessica Porras sat on a pillow on a metal folding chair in the civic center, her day-old daughter, Ruby, squalling in her lap.
"My husband was at work and I started having contractions around 11 o'clock Sunday night," Ms. Porras said. "It was all of a sudden the rain came and the kitchen started filling up with water. The water kept going up and the contractions kept getting worse, so I finally called an ambulance."
Ms. Porras had her daughter at 2:14 A.M., while the water was rising, and when she returned home next morning, she found it flooded. Neighbors said she and the ambulance had barely beat the deluge.
Cyndi Wright, a Red Cross spokeswoman, said that 635 people had slept in the center Monday night and at least that many were expected tonight. Two other shelters had been closed Monday night when the rising water threatened to swamp them. In Eagle Pass, more than 700 people slept in five shelters.
"We seem to have enough food, but water is still at a premium," Ms. Wright said.
Ms. Sotelo described the flood's victims as "mostly poor, about 90 percent of them, and a lot of them without insurance, so I don't know how we're going to handle it."
Del Rio is a remote city of more than 30,000 people in the arid scrub land on the Rio Grande 145 miles west of San Antonio. Like the rest of Texas, it was in the midst of the biggest drought in at least four decades when the remnants of Tropical Storm Charley dumped 17 inches of rain on Sunday and early Monday.
Though there is some ranching nearby, and a few small farms, most of the city's economy flows from its border crossing, the factories just south of the border and Laughlin Air Force Base. "We're basically a small, working community, and this flood hit the poorest part of town," Ms. Sotelo said. "The whole county has come out to help with this, though."
Local fast-food outlets sent hamburgers, tacos and sandwiches to the shelters. Churches were collecting old clothes. The flood swamped the city's water pumps, and the taps are expected to stay dry for several more days, forcing people to use swimming pool water to wash. Dozens of people walked with plastic buckets down to the swollen creek to fill them with muddy water to flush their toilets.
Around the city, people waited in line for drinking water donated by the Air Force and by local ranchers with untainted wells.
"We've just got a town that's full of precious people," said Jackie Isenhour, a retired restaurant owner who was also helping out at the shelter.
The swell that hit Del Rio early Monday had passed through Eagle Pass, the next significant city downriver, by late Monday night. Unlike Del Rio, Eagle Pass had some warning. Hundreds were evacuated and, while the water did flood many city streets, there were no deaths or injuries.
Across the river, in Piedras Negras, one person was killed in the flooding, Mr. Neyra said, and three people were still missing tonight.
Farther downriver, at Laredo, all three international bridge crossings were ordered closed and the swell is expected to sweep through about 1 P.M. on Wednesday. Just beyond Laredo is Lake Falcon, which officials said would swallow up most of the flood water and stop it from pushing farther downriver.
Pat Calderon said his mother, Leonore, was resting comfortably at a relative's house tonight. She had resisted leaving their house when the water started rising. "She was in her wheelchair, grabbing onto the wall, saying she wouldn't go," he said. By the time it was clear that they ought to leave, the water was too high to get away.
"First I put my mother on her bed, then watched the water come up the bedpost," he said. "Then the mattress started floating. The water came up to my chest. I had to stand on a chair, and it came up to my chest again. If that love seat hadn't floated by, I don't know what I would have done with my mother."
He looked around the wreckage of his house, mud, like peanut butter on a sandwich, smeared across it. The current had picked up his blue Lincoln, carried it 50 yards up the street and dumped it on the roof of his brother's auto parts store.
"I hope we never go through anything like this again," Mr. Calderon said. "At least we made it. We're a little stinky, but we made it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Solia Herrera carrying all she could yesterday from her Del Rio home. Two-thirds of the city was under water from a storm early Monday. (Associated Press)
