HEADLINE: Schumer Proposes New Spending Programs

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Asserting that Wall Street's wave of prosperity had failed to lift most inner-city neighborhoods in New York, Charles E. Schumer, a Democratic candidate for Senate, proposed a series of Federal spending programs yesterday to encourage development in downtrodden cities and to raise the incomes and savings of the poor and middle class.
Mr. Schumer, a Democratic Congressman from Brooklyn, urged a sharp increase in the minimum wage, tax credits for first-time home buyers who move into designated urban neighborhoods and a new tax-free savings account program in which the Government would partially match savings that low-income families put aside for at least five years. 
 Mr. Schumer framed his proposals, which he gave in a speech in Jamaica, Queens, as a specific appeal to minority voters, who tend to make up a significant proportion of the turnout in Democratic primaries. Mr. Schumer -- one of three Democrats seeking the nomination to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato -- said that poor minority neighborhoods had failed to share in Wall Street's good fortune, producing what he warned was a dangerous imbalance in the state's economy.
"Remember the 20's," Mr. Schumer said, referring to the decade leading up to the Great Depression. "If the prosperity and the wealth is concentrated at the very top, sooner or later there's not enough buying power in the rest of the population."
Mr. Schumer noted that New York has ranked near the bottom of the 50 states in job creation. "That's unacceptable," he said. "When you consider how much the bull market on Wall Street has done to help our economy, you realize just how poorly the rest of New York is faring."
The Representative, who has proposed a variety of spending programs in this campaign -- including making college tuition deductible -- said the cost of his latest proposal would be less than $1 billion. He added that he would pay for the proposal by cutting defense spending or agriculture subsidies. "I think we can easily find a billion dollars," he said.
The speech came after a period in which Mr. Schumer had kept a relatively low-profile public campaign schedule, possibly reflecting the fact that candidates in all the major races this year have found it difficult to compete for attention with President Clinton's legal difficulties and the bombings in Africa. Mr. Schumer, however, has been running a heavy schedule of campaign advertisements, unlike either of his rivals, Mark Green, the New York City Public Advocate, and Geraldine A. Ferraro, the former Queens Representative.
Mr. Schumer delivered his speech at the Jamaica Business Resource Center, a nonprofit organization that assists minority and small-business owners. The Congressman sat at one end of a table, addressing an audience of just 15 people, including his mother and father, who were in the neighborhood and stopped by to hear their son speak.
Some of the details of Mr. Schumer's proposals, which he described as a "major policy address," appeared to be falling into place as the day went on. Asked after his address if interest earned on his proposed savings account would be tax exempt, Mr. Schumer responded: "You know, that's a good question. I don't think it would be tax free, but maybe it should be. Making it tax free would be a good idea."
Yesterday afternoon, after a series of inquiries, Mr. Schumer's spokesman, Howard Wolfson, called a reporter to say that both the interest and the money invested in the account would be tax free. Mr. Wolfson said it was largely a moot question because most families that would qualify for the program made too little money to be obliged to pay taxes.
Under that program, parents with a household income of less than $25,000 a year would be able to have $10 deducted from their weekly paycheck, which would be matched by $5 a week from the Government. That would produce savings of $780 a year, not counting interest.
Families would not be allowed to spend the money for five years. After that, there would be no restrictions on how the money could be used, though Mr. Schumer said he hoped families would spend it on such things as paying for college tuition or a down payment on a house.
Mr. Schumer also proposed raising the minimum wage, now $5.15 an hour, to $7.50 by 2002, and linking it after that to inflation. Efforts to raise the minimum wage have been strongly resisted by Republicans in Congress.
Mr. Schumer also proposed that first-time home buyers get a $2,000 tax credit when they buy homes in low-income neighborhoods designated by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. And he said that nonprofit groups, like churches and hospitals, should get the same payroll-tax credit for hiring people on welfare that is currently awarded to private business.
"None of what I talked about today constitutes a handout," Mr. Schumer said. "A handout is temporary."
He added: "I am talking about a plan that can never be taken away, a plan that levels the playing field so that the game is fair."
Mr. Schumer mentioned neither of his rivals in his speech, and they, in turn, offered a reserved reaction to the proposals. Both Mr. Green and Ms. Ferraro support an increase in the minimum wage. Mr. Green has proposed raising it to $7.33, but Ms. Ferraro has not offered a specific number.
"There are a lot of ideas, but I don't think these are new ideas," said Stephen Gaskill, Ms. Ferraro's spokesman. "Those are things that are out there already. He's packaging this as a new innovative program, and it's not."

HEADLINE: Gore Gives No Hint That Anything Could Be Amiss

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Looking tan and relaxed after a two-week Hawaiian vacation, Vice President Al Gore returned to full public view today, giving little hint that anything of major consequence had happened while he was away.
In a daylong schedule here that included a rousing speech to a convention of 5,000 civil servants, a stop at an elementary school and a rally for the Hawaii Democratic Party, a noticeably energized Mr. Gore emphasized the positive and the future, focusing on issues like education, health care and the need for union members and Democrats to support the party in the November elections. 
 Mr. Gore's remarks were unusually fiery for someone who has openly joked about his reputation as a stiff and sometimes awkward speaker.
Through much of his address to the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees underlining the Administration's strong support for labor, he belted out many of his points, lacing his remarks with jokes and gestures that ignited the crowd.
He concluded with a challenge for the 1998 elections: "Are you willing to more than match the intensity that the right-wing extremists will bring to the battles that lie ahead?"
The response was a loud and long standing ovation.
But Mr. Gore's remarks were equally notable for what he did not say, leaving little doubt that the omissions were part of a calculated effort to distance himself from matters that roiled Washington last week. He made no mention of President Clinton's acknowledgment of a relationship with a former White House intern nor did he acknowledge new questions that have come up about his own fund-raising activities in the 1996 campaign.
In what a spokeswoman for the Vice President indicated would be the rule for at least the next few days as Mr. Gore and his wife, Tipper, make their way back to Washington, he took no questions. The Gores are scheduled to leave Hawaii on Wednesday for San Francisco, where he plans to attend several more events before leaving for Washington on Thursday afternoon.
For Mr. Gore, whose allegiance to President Clinton over the last six years serves as a springboard for his own Presidential aspirations, the months ahead are laden with political peril for him and the Democratic Party.
Unlike the President, Mr. Gore has enjoyed a virtually spotless public persona throughout his long political career.
But an important question facing him is whether voters will continue to be able to separate the two men, or whether Mr. Clinton's problems have so sullied his Administration they will damage Mr. Gore as well. And while voters may see Mr. Gore as more trustworthy, if less magnetic, than Mr. Clinton, the Vice President may have his own troubles down the road as Attorney General Janet Reno reconsiders whether to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate fund-raising telephone calls he made from his office.
If she does so, the campaign finance investigation, which has failed to capture much public interest so far, may become an enormous liability for him.
As a consequence of Mr. Clinton's difficulties, Mr. Gore must maintain a delicate balance between his loyalty to a close friend who has been damaged, but who has done more than any other President to lay the financial groundwork for his running mate's ascension, and a detachment that enables the Vice President to preserve his own integrity, his sense of loyalty and, of course, his political viability.
"He has to walk a fine line, the nature of which is pretty clear," said Stuart Rothenberg, a political analyst in Washington. "Bill Clinton has been Al Gore's No. 1 benefactor. He is also the No. 1 reason Al Gore is the heavy favorite to become the party nominee for President. So he needs to remain loyal to the President but at the same time maintain a separate identity to avoid the appearance he is Bill Clinton's toady."
The practical question for Mr. Gore is how to clutch all the benefits of serving as Mr. Clinton's friend and adviser while avoiding the obvious baggage of the President's relationship with the former intern, Monica S. Lewinsky.
With elections three months away and the Administration eagerly seeking support for its proposals on education, health care, the budget surplus and other issues, Mr. Gore might be most helpful for the party and himself, aides said, by campaigning around the country for Democratic candidates.
Even the schedule of his first two days after vacation suggests that he is keen to get started. Here in Hawaii, where the economy has sagged for seven years and Democrats have controlled state government for nearly 40, Gov. Benjamin J. Cayetano is trailing in polls to a Republican challenger. Both Mr. Cayetano and Representative Patsy Mink accompanied Mr. Gore today.
In San Francisco, Mr. Gore is scheduled to attend a reception on Wednesday night for Michela Alioto, a former Gore aide who is the Democratic candidate for California Secretary of State.
While many Democratic officials say that Mr. Gore might be an ideal emollient to soothe any public disdain for a wounded President, Republicans may be just as happy to have Mr. Gore out stumping -- but for entirely different reasons.
"If Al Gore is coming to my state, I would have no problem or hesitation raising the facts of the cloud of controversy about 1996 and his role in illegal or unethical behavior," said Frank Luntz, a Republican pollster.
To many voters of both parties, the unresolved fund-raising issues could prove far more problematic for Mr. Gore than any of Mr. Clinton's problems.
Questions about Mr. Gore's role were once put to rest, last December, when Attorney General Reno said she had found no evidence that Mr. Gore had raised money for direct aid to the campaign.
But the issue arose again last week when it was disclosed that the Justice Department had obtained a 1995 White House memorandum with handwritten notations that appeared to contradict Mr. Gore's account of his fund-raising telephone calls, according to Government officials. The notations indicate that Mr. Gore and several campaign officials discussed how some of the large contributions raised by the Vice President would be diverted to accounts to directly finance the Clinton-Gore campaign, Government officials said.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Lets Its Rule on Full Repayment Slip

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Pummeled by Asia and now Russia, the International Monetary Fund is gradually softening its policies, becoming more tolerant of arrangements it would have rejected a year ago -- and even allowing some Asian debtors not to repay all they owe to foreign banks.
Now the Russian Government is pushing this process of favoring the country in crisis a step or two further. 
 The Russians have announced that $40 billion in debt, scheduled for repayment over 18 months, will be "stretched out," and paid over three to five years. Probable devaluations of the ruble over so long a period raises the odds that foreign lenders, which include Chase Manhattan and Bank of America, will not be fully repaid in dollars.
As a result, one of the great debates of the Asian crisis is showing signs of being settled by events.
The I.M.F. and its powerful mentor, the Clinton Administration, have faced criticism for months now that their policies are pitched to assure full repayment of foreign lenders, at the cost of economic growth. Rescuing these lenders and investors from their risky actions only encourages more risky lending and more financial crises. Or so the argument goes, even among some Democrats and Republicans in Congress who oppose an $18 billion appropriation to fund the I.M.F. But now events appear to be overtaking words.
"We are basically reacting to the realities that are unfolding," said John Boorman, the I.M.F.'s director of policy development and review.
Trying to revive the disastrous Indonesian economy, for example, the I.M.F. since May has encouraged corporate borrowers in that country to renegotiate their debts to foreign lenders. The hope is that with a lower debt load, these companies can return to more normal operations. In some cases the foreign lenders are agreeing to collect less than 100 cents on the dollar. It is the first time that has happened with I.M.F. blessing since the Latin American debt crisis of the 1980's.
What's more, the fund has shifted away from demanding of the Indonesian Government one of its standard austerity measures: a budget surplus. That demand ended last month when the I.M.F. agreed instead to enough extra government spending, particularly for imported food, to run up the deficit to 8 to 10 percent of the total budget.
"I don't think we have ever at the I.M.F. had a program where we targeted a fiscal deficit as large as 8 to 10 percent," Mr. Boorman said.
Russia puts the fund, and the Clinton Administration, much more on the spot. The fund had authorized a $22 billion loan to Russia, only to have the Russians, earlier this month, devalue their currency and change the repayment terms for much of its debt, including the $40 billion in Russian short-term government paper.
Foreign investors, converting dollars to rubles, had bought about $10 billion of this total, and now that the repayment has been prolonged, ruble devaluations are likely to wipe out some of their investment. The stretch-out terms, announced today, provide for interest payments in the 20 percent to 30 percent range, annually -- probably not high enough to offset ruble devaluations.
Stanley Fischer, the fund's first deputy managing director, offered an angry characterization of the Russian initiative. "The I.M.F. regards the fact that Russia was unable to meet its commitments and has had to restructure them unilaterally as extremely unfortunate and regrettable," Mr. Fischer said. "The nature of the international economy will change if this is the way business has to be done."
Does that mean the I.M.F. won't make its next scheduled loan payment to Russia of more than $4 billion, scheduled for next month? Not necessarily.
The fund does not pressure banks to swallow loan write-offs against their wishes, but this time something like that could happen. Russia must comply with some loan conditions, Mr. Fischer and Mr. Boorman said. Above all, the Russian Duma, or lower house of Parliament, and Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, Russia's new Prime Minister, must accept the I.M.F.-imposed goal of a balanced budget in two or three years. But repayment to foreign lenders, in full, may be allowed to slip -- if the Government can demonstrate that it has no choice to revive its economy.
"If markets are going to operate properly," Mr. Boorman said, "and if markets are going to price risk appropriately, then in some circumstances that risk is going to materialize, in nonpayment of some debt, as it is materializing now."
One of the I.M.F.'s severest critics, the Harvard Institute for International Development, headed by the economist Jeffrey Sachs, is beginning to recognize, and applaud, the shift taking place at the fund.
"The fund is moving in the right direction, but slowly," said Steven Radelet, a Harvard Institute economist. "Unfortunately we were months into the Asian crisis before the I.M.F. began to adapt these more flexible policies. Its officials are coming around because their initial strategies failed" to revive the countries they were trying to help.
The fund, for example, has relaxed its blanket opposition to budget deficits. It has pulled back on its endorsement of unrestricted short-term lending across borders, recognizing that such loans set off the Asian crisis, when the lenders tried to call them in. And it is publishing, on the Internet, the texts of various agreements that in the past were not made public.
The fund's shifting stance is not without precedent. Years of stagnant economies in Latin America followed the debt crisis of the early 1980's when most Latin nations defaulted on debts owed to foreign banks. After nearly eight years in which the banks tried to force repayment of the entire debt, the Reagan Administration and the I.M.F. brokered an agreement that guaranteed repayment, but of a greatly reduced amount.
But the Mexican debt crisis of 1994 met with stiff resistance on the part of the I.M.F. and the Clinton Administration to any debt write-offs or concessions in standard I.M.F. practices. The same reaction greeted the Asian crisis. When South Korean banks, for example, renegotiated their foreign debt late last year, the I.M.F. blessed an agreement that stretched out repayment of short-term debts over several years, but called for repayment of the full dollar amount, with interest.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
APPLIED MATERIALS TO CUT 15% OF ITS WORK FORCE

BYLINE: Reuters 

 BODY:
Applied Materials Inc., the world's largest supplier of equipment used to make computer chips, said yesterday that it planned to cut 2,000 jobs, or about 15 percent of its work force, in response to a global downturn in the semiconductor industry. The company will cut 750 jobs in Santa Clara, Calif., where it is based, and 600 at its plant in Austin, Tex. Most of the other cuts will be at sites around the world and will take place by the end of October. The company will also cut executive salaries by 10 percent. Applied said it expected to report a nonrecurring charge for the restructuring and to record a loss for its fourth quarter, ending Oct. 25. Since December, Applied has been restricting hiring, reducing the number of temporary workers and contractors and scheduling mandatory shutdown days.

HEADLINE: METRO BUSINESS;
Shortage of Workers Imperils Connecticut

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
Connecticut's economy is booming now, but it could slow down because there are fewer workers for too many jobs, according to a quarterly economic report.
"In order for this growth to continue, we have to find people to fill these jobs," said William A. McEachern, a University of Connecticut economics professor and editor of The Connecticut Economy, which was published this week. 
 Since 1992, the state has added 121,000 jobs, or 80 percent of the jobs the state lost during the recession of the late 1980's and early 90's, according to the report. While the state continues to add jobs, job growth has slowed during the first half of this year.
Professor McEachern said that the economic slowdown may already have begun, but that he wanted to see what happens over the next quarter or two of this year before making that call. It will be difficult for Connecticut companies to attract more workers to the state, since most regions of the country are doing as well as Connecticut, he said.
Some workers could be found by tapping into the ranks of the underemployed -- part-time workers who would like full-time jobs and self-employed people who want extra income, according to the report.

HEADLINE: METRO BUSINESS;
Citibank Sued Over Bonds

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Citibank is the newest target in a discrimination lawsuit that charges three banks with excluding non-Indians from a bond sale.
State Bank of India and Bank of India were sued for $487.5 million last week in State Supreme Court in Manhattan in connection with their sale of five-year, 7.75 percent India Resurgent bonds only to people of Indian descent. Citibank was added to the suit yesterday because it also sold the bonds exclusively to Indians, said D. Daniel Engstrand, the plaintiff's lawyer. 
 "It appears that Citibank is willing to disregard American antidiscrimination laws in its pursuit of a new client base made up of wealthy Indian investors living in the U.S.," Mr. Engstrand said in a statement.
Citibank officials were not available for comment. Citibank is owned by Citicorp.
State Bank of India said the bond sale, completed yesterday, raised a larger-than-expected $4.1 billion, which may help offset economic setbacks following India's nuclear tests in May. The bonds are attractive because they offer an interest rate higher than United States Government five-year bonds.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
Sometimes Delightful, Never Easy: It's Fringe

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
It was quite a few minutes past the monologue's scheduled starting time in the stifling Red Room on East Fourth Street, a space so cramped it could be a candidate for renovation by California Closet. Wilting theatergoers were daubing strands of disintegrating tissues across their scalps as the man in charge stepped to the front of the theater.
"Sorry we're starting late," he said, "But --" 
"That's 'Fringe'!" an audience member piped up, finishing the thought.
Yes, that is. Over at Surf Reality, a living-room-size space above a shop on Allen Street, a performer named Trav S.D. was bulldozing his way through his mock lecture, "Misshapen Jack the Nebraska Hunchback," when a fuse blew and the lights went out. In the freakish darkness, Trav implored, "Do you have the lantern?," at which point the man at the light board retrieved a flashlight and, shining it directly into Trav's face, illuminated the rest of the show.
The incessant whirr of floor or ceiling fans, useless against the humidity in any event, seemed to work like water torture on the nerves of some solo artists -- one I went to see had disconsolately failed to return for her curtain call -- and the light headedness induced by the intolerable heat during an all-male production of "The Importance of Being Earnest" made a case for retitling it "Into Thick Air."
But you know what? That's Fringe. The conditions at the second New York International Fringe Festival may not be ideal -- O.K., in some instances, the state of the restrooms alone is enough to make you run screaming into the night -- but the notion is not to impress the theatergoer with plushness. The youthfully self-important assumption of the festival, which continues through Sunday in 17 spaces in the East Village and Lower East Side, is that you have a need to be here almost as much as the young performers who are trying out ideas and personae -- trying out whole theatrical paths, really -- and to heck with the lights and the air-conditioning.
In practice, this ethos tends to push the playgoer to extremes. You can feel especially desolate at the really bad stuff: the only thing more unbearable than a self-indulgent piece about guitar-playing 25-year-olds living together in a warehouse, railing against corporate greed and dreaming of careers in poetry, is staging the piece in an underventilated garage. Conversely, there is an exaggerated sense of validation when, to your relief and pleasure, a show defies the odds, and works.
As its name implies, a fringe festival, pioneered in Edinburgh as an offbeat adjunct to a renowned play festival, is an opportunity to spotlight the work of aspiring playwrights, actors and directors. The New York festival, spread over a dozen days, is providing exposure this year to 144 troupes, monologuists and performance artists in what is perhaps the most theater-intensive city in the world.
The resulting audience is well-informed and jaded: at any given show, a casting agent may be sitting next to an acting student who is next to a rabid fan of that stalwart of Off Off Broadway, Mac Wellman. Which also makes for a demanding audience, although not necessarily an unappreciative one. The packed house Sunday night for "The Importance of Being Earnest," for instance, was so patient and intrepid it practically brought tears to a reviewer's eyes.
Presented in the sweltering confines of the Red Room, less a playhouse than an unintended bayou, and reduced by its adapter and director, Hugh Hysell, to a lean but playable 80 minutes, the production was just good enough to have been worth it. Mr. Hysell's notion was a tweaking of Wilde's farce, to make it a comedy of gay coupling. As it turns out, however, its most significant feature is not the cheeky inventiveness of turning Gwendolen and Cecily into Gerald and Kurt, but the comic ingenuity of the young actors who played them, Adam Beckworth and Harris Dorman.
No other scene in this production, updated to the present and set in Chelsea and the Hamptons, quite rises to the level of the one in which Gwendolen-Gerald and Cecily-Kurt banter with only slightly disguised contempt after discovering they both are engaged to a man named Ernest. It succeeds not so much because it works on Mr. Hysell's terms, but on Wilde's. Mr. Beckworth's readings of the playwright's indestructible aphorisms are dead-on; they manage to sound minted yesterday. "I never travel without my diary," he avers. "One should always have something sensational to read in the train."
Mr. Hysell's worst idea is a prologue establishing gay matrimony as a legal right; his best is a Lady Bracknell, played in drag by Dan Matisa, as the most masculine character on the stage. And while the entire cast is eager to please, on Sunday night it was the audience, 100 strong, who deserved an ovation. How smart it would have been, in the play's cocktail scene, for the butler Merriman to have distributed cool drinks to the overheated crowd.
In many of the festival offerings, the best one can hope for is to find satisfaction in some aspect of a production. In "Rum and Vodka," a monologue by the Irish playwright Conor McPherson, whose "The Weir" is expected to come to Broadway later this season, John O'Callaghan plays a charming alcoholic monster who relates the story of the previous three days of his dissipated, worthless life, in which he loses his job, abandons his family, takes up with a woman and commits a senseless act of violence.
The tale Mr. McPherson spins may be a subtle one, but Mr. O'Callaghan, under Ed Sahely's direction, supplies no discernible variety to the story's shifting tone. Although he recounts it as history, there is no sense of aftermath in the performance, and what should be a shattering account is merely a blank sort of witnessing.
In the same vein, "The Interpreter of Horror" by Kelly Stuart, author of the smashing "Demonology," a dark comedy of office politics that had a brief but successful run at Playwrights Horizons two years ago, is something of a disappointment. Set in a diner in which a new waitress, June (Laura Kirk), is menaced by everyone from a hard-boiled veteran server (Alice Bergmann) to the rigid manager (Michael LaFetra) to a perverted patron (Peter Ackerman), "The Interpreter of Horror" is at this stage a satire divided against itself. The nightmare sequences of June's fantasies are not successfully integrated into the story. The play, at the Kraine Theater, is a bit of a muddle.
Still, an embryonic theater piece can reveal something valuable, as demonstrated by "Queen Esther: Unemployed Superstar," a monologue by a talented young actress who goes by the name Queen Esther. The work itself is not particularly noteworthy. It is several rewrites and one strong central idea away from being stageworthy. But Queen Esther is a charismatic presence, and her notion of growing up, a black girl in Texas, and dreaming of singing "I Gotta Be Me" on "The Mike Douglas Show" is a funny one.
Watching her show is like viewing a career in a chrysalis. You can sense that she's yet to spread her wings. But hey. That's Fringe.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Comp anies are increasingly seeking to identify their products with music, both old and new.

BYLINE: By Andrea Adelson 

 BODY:
TELEVISION advertisers today, more than ever, are seeking to make their commercials music to the ear -- building brand identity both with replays of classic rock tunes and with original scores they have commissioned.
Auto makers seem especially fond of trying to grab attention with "underscores," as they are called. Consider Toyota's "Everyday People" ad, borrowing its hook from the Sly and the Family Stone tune. Or General Motors' Chevrolet, scoring points about durability with the Bob Seeger standard "Like a Rock." 
 But car makers are not alone in sounding like a classic rock station. The Rolling Stones' hit "Start Me Up" provided the perfect word play for Microsoft's Windows 95 campaign.
Also, a handful of traditional retailers have discovered the brand-building potential of music. The Limited's Victoria's Secret, Spiegel's Eddie Bauer, the Gap's Banana Republic and Starbucks are extending their merchandising reach with name brand CD's, an unexpected outcome of selecting soundtracks to shape their stores' environment. The compilations of previously produced work has proved so popular with customers that Starbucks, for instance, has issued 20 CD's since 1995.
But some advertisers, sensing that the use of well-known rock hits is growing tired, are putting a renewed effort into hiring composers to create original scores that are as important to brand building as imagery. Campaigns by Chrysler, BMW and Conseco Insurance are recent examples.
And Intel and Sears, Roebuck have adopted recognizable aural icons to sign off each of their television commercials. "It makes them original and identifiable," said Anthony Marinelli, a Los Angeles composer, who has rearranged music for Sears into a variety of musical styles, including an urban rendition.
Also in demand are John Trivers and Liz Myers, a husband-wife composing team from Manhattan Beach, Calif., who got their start writing tunes for the Blue Oyster Cult. When unemployed, they turned to commercial composing for Apple Computer. More recently, they composed an Italian-style opera for the Ford Motor Company, which began using the spot in June but masked the aria with a voice-over.
"Advertisers recognize that the sound of music can trigger recognition of their product," Miss Myers said.
"It's more memorable than a tag line," Mr. Trivers added.
On a recent morning an agency creative director called the couple's ocean-view recording studio, describing what was wanted for a soap commercial. "Not sugary, not sappy; celebratory, spiritual, breezier, extremely fluid," he said.
Miss Myers, her eyes shifting between a television monitor and the keys of a baby grand piano, improvised 15 bars or so. Within an hour of the conference call, she picked three tracks from among seven to get a full orchestral treatment, but left the decisive cut to the soap maker's agency.
Mr. Trivers, choosing from a dozen or more bass guitars, added a filling riff. From a keyboard-synthesizer, his wife overlaid a breezy tinkling of bells and symphonic strings. A sound engineer minded the tracks.
Conseco got a similar Trivers-Myers treatment for its first television spots, a $25 million campaign that began in February by Fallon McElligott in Minneapolis. "It was very important for us to be distinctive; there's a lot of sameness in the advertising of competitors," said James W. Rosensteele, a spokesman for the insurance company, which is based in Carmel, Ind. "We were trying to break away in both sound and image. We wanted to engage people intellectually and not rely on pure emotional appeal."
Instead of the warm and fuzzy images typically associated with insurers, Conseco's vignettes show life's unexpected turns. The music also takes unexpected turns.
Paul L. Saylor, a partner at Bozell Worldwide, a unit of True North Communications, produced six spots for Chrysler, relying on one musical theme with slight variations. He said buying music rights was effective when a campaign idea lent itself to the tune, citing "Like a Rock" for Chevy trucks.
But "what's great about creating new stuff is that it remains fresh because it's not overplayed," he said, adding that longevity is crucial for an auto campaign that lasts a year.
Seeking to develop an edgy style for BMW's campaign last year, Fallon McElligott commissioned a pulsating techno-pop soundtrack, filmed black and white footage from the driver's point of view and used text titles instead of a voice-over.
"We wanted the music to cut through," said Bruce Bildsten, the agency's group creative director.
BMW's new spots, which are to start Sept. 14, extend the same visual and musical theme. The arrangement came from Johannes Hammers and Rico Conning, commercial composers in Santa Monica, Calif.
"We feel like we have a musical signature," Mr. Bildsten said. "Extending that signature is important to the brand's success."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Politics aside, census sampling still raises questions of accuracy.

BYLINE: By Michael M. Weinstein 

 BODY:
A PANEL of three Federal judges delivered a blow to Democrats this week when it ruled that sampling techniques planned for the 2000 census violated Federal law. The issue is far from dead, though, as the Administration now plans to appeal to the Supreme Court.
Democrats embrace sampling -- data derived from a small set of households -- to supplement census information gathered door to door and through the mail. They believe it would add millions of blacks, Hispanic people and poor to the census rolls. That would lead to billions of dollars of additional Federal spending in Democrat-controlled districts and perhaps a dozen or more additional Democratic seats after Congressional districts are redrawn. The Republicans loathe sampling for the same reasons. 
 But the debate is about something more difficult, and less partisan, than politics. The handful of statisticians who have mastered the ferocious mathematical and practical complexities are split over the usefulness of sampling. William Kruskal, former chairman of the statistics department at the University of Chicago, speaks for many of his colleagues when he admits that "no one really knows."
A middle ground, using sampling techniques for parts of the census and not for others, makes perhaps the most sense.
The bureau proposes three separate uses of sampling. One sample would focus on a small group of households that fail to mail in their census forms or to respond to repeated visits by census takers, and then use statistical techniques to reach a description of all nonresponding households. Most experts appear to agree that this use of sampling is a sensible way to cut the soaring costs of conducting the census without sacrificing accuracy.
The second proposed use, to correct for the undercount of minorities and poor people, draws more criticism.
The 1990 census underestimated the population by less than 2 percent. But it underestimated the number of blacks by more than 4 percent and the number of Hispanic people by about 5 percent. Likewise, it missed more renters than homeowners and more poor families than rich.
The bureau proposes to fix this problem by conducting a follow-up survey of 750,000 households. The bureau would compare the two surveys to determine, for example, how many urban blacks appeared in the follow-up survey but not the first -- an indication of how many were missed in the initial census. The bureau would then use a complicated series of calculations to estimate what portions of several dozen demographic groups were initially missed.
Critics, like Prof. David Freedman of the University of California at Berkeley, say the sampling procedure is fraught with problems. What if someone moves, shows up on the rolls of the second survey but appears nowhere in the country in the initial census? Was he one of the millions of uncounted Americans? Perhaps not. He might have been accounted for by the proposed statistical correction for nonresponding households (the first use of sampling) even without his ever having filled out a form.
Here's an even trickier problem. Sampling could improve the census count for every state, yet damage the overall value of the census. That's because the important census figures, in terms of funding and Congressional representation, are not the absolute numbers for each state and county, but rather their respective shares of the national population. After all, there will be 435 House seats no matter how many people are counted. If sampling does a better job locating missing households in one state than in another, the distribution of House seats and Federal spending could be made less fair.
Imagine that the initial census misses 1,000 black households in Harlem and 100 black households in Phoenix because of evasive households and less-than-diligent census takers. The follow-up sample will be plagued by similar problems. What if it turns up, say, only 50 of the missing black households in Harlem but 75 of the missing households in Phoenix. Then each state's population count will improve, but Arizona's share of the total population will be overstated.
The bureau says its elaborate models can handle these problems. Besides, none of the critics have shown that sampling would do more harm than good, the bureau says.
Most statisticians agree that sampling can improve the counting of minorities and poor in areas as large as Congressional districts and states. But many are unwilling to conclude the small follow-up sample can yield accurate estimates for small areas, say the size of census blocks (about 30 households). One intriguing option would be to use sampling to correct estimates for states and Congressional districts, but not for smaller areas. After all, no important policy depends on accurate counts of small areas.
Politics may scuttle any such middle-ground resolution. The bureau fears how Congress would respond to census data that show state population totals higher than the sum of population figures for each census block in the state. Call this the Lotus 1-2-3 dilemma: the bureau's rows and columns would not add up -- and Republicans on Capitol Hill would no doubt scream that the bureau was counting fictitious people. And if the bureau goes the other route, applying corrections to small areas, it will be prey to a court challenge, most likely by Republicans, that could throw out all statistical attempts to account for missing minorities.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Up On Worries Over Equities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities edged up yesterday, amid fresh concerns about Russia's economic crisis and the raised anxiety level of world equity markets.
"The market appeared a bit wobbly today, even as it partially ignored the release of July durable goods orders due to the problems in both Russia and Latin America," said Anthony Chan, managing director and chief economist for Banc One Investment Advisers in Columbus, Ohio. Durable goods unexpectedly rose 2.4 percent last month, their biggest monthly gain in almost a year. 
 By late in the day, the Treasury's 30-year bond was up 4/32, to a price of 101 7/32, pushing down its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, to 5.42 percent, from 5.43 percent on Tuesday. Bond yields are at their lowest levels in three decades.
Mr. Chan said the greatest fear among bond investors was whether they could justify paying more for bonds -- and pushing yields below 5.50 percent -- without an indication that the Federal Reserve was close to easing short-term interest rates.
Yesterday the Fed was in the bond market to satisfy its seasonal needs. In the process, known as a coupon pass, the Fed bought $1.521 billion in securities, adding funds to the banking system and providing some support to the longer maturities.
The report on July durable goods orders, which was released early in the session, surprised investors because the aircraft and electrical order components were so strong that they more than offset the weakness in autos caused by the General Motors strike.
The market also had to deal with supply yesterday, as the Treasury sold $15 billion of new two-year notes at an auction, which went a little better than expected. The notes were sold at a yield of 5.125 percent.

HEADLINE: Durable Goods Orders Grew 2.4% in July

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Orders placed with the nation's manufacturers for durable goods unexpectedly rose in July as demand for aircraft and electronics offset a decline in auto orders that was linked to the General Motors Corporation strikes. Excluding transportation goods, orders recorded the biggest gain in almost a year.
The Commerce Department said today that total durable goods orders rose 2.4 percent last month. The department also revised June's data to show an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent; in an earlier revision, the Government had said June's orders fell one-tenth of 1 percent. 
 Excluding transportation equipment, orders for which often fluctuate sharply from month to month, durable goods orders rose 3 percent during July.
"Despite the weakness in Asia and other parts of the world, orders have remained at a fairly healthy pace," Rick MacDonald, an economist at Standard & Poor's MMS in Belmont, Calif., said.
The Federal Reserve Board uses the durable goods report to gauge the nation's factory conditions and to monitor consumers' appetite for more expensive items.
July's increase in total orders was the third in the last four months and was the largest gain since a 4.4 percent rise in November. The increase in orders excluding the transportation category was the seventh in the last eight months and was the largest gain since a 3.2 percent rise in August 1997.
Orders for electronic equipment, including semiconductors, telephones and televisions, grew 12 percent last month. Orders for transportation equipment increased three-tenths of 1 percent as demand for aircraft offset declines in automobiles, trucks and ships.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Falls 79.30 as Investors Fret About Trouble Abroad

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday as a plunge in Russian markets deepened fears that slumping economies around the world would cut corporate profits.
Shares of United Technologies, J. P. Morgan, Chevron and other companies with international businesses led the drop. Banks fell on concern that a Russian debt restructuring disclosed Tuesday would lead to losses on overseas bond holdings. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average fell 79.30, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 8,523.35. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 8.66, or eight-tenths of a percent, to 1,084.19, and the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index dropped 30.04, or 1.7 percent, to 1,768.13.
The Russell 2000 index of small stocks dropped 9.34, or 2.4 percent, to 380.42.
Stocks pared losses after Stanley Druckenmiller, the chief investment officer of George Soros's $22 billion group of funds, told CNBC that the United States stock market was the most attractive in the world, and predicted that money would pour into domestic assets because of the turmoil in other countries' markets.
Investors were willing to pay record-high valuations for stocks for the last three years because interest rates around the world were falling, inflation was under control and most countries' economies were growing. Now, emerging markets are stumbling, raising concern about stability and undermining growth in developed nations.
Still, optimistic investors say lowinterest rates and a growing domestic economy will support earnings and share prices.
United Technologies, which gets more than 40 percent of its sales abroad, fell 3 3/16, to 82 7/8.
While United States banks have less exposure to Russia's economic problems than their European counterparts, some of the biggest, including Morgan and Citicorp, stand to lose money.
Morgan fell 2 15/16, to 117 15/16; Citicorp lost 2 1/4, to 133 7/8, and Bankers Trust dropped 4 3/4, to 92 1/8. Travelers Group, which is merging with Citicorp, fell 1/2, to 54 1/8.
Oil stocks slumped after three large oil-exporting countries canceled a meeting to discuss prices, reducing hopes for production cuts. Amoco fell 1, to 49, and Chevron dropped 1 11/16, to 76 1/2.

HEADLINE: Harold W. Ezell Is Dead at 61; Immigration Official in West

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Harold W. Ezell, who as a Federal immigration official supported amnesty for millions of illegal immigrants only to become a decade later the co-author of a state initiative denying them public benefits, died on Tuesday at Hoag Memorial Hospital Presbyterian in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 61 and lived in Newport Beach.
The cause was liver cancer, a hospital spokeswoman said. 
 After working as an executive for Wienerschnitzel International, a hot dog franchise company, Mr. Ezell was commissioner for the Immigration and Naturalization Service's western region under Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush. He supported the Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986, which granted legal residency to about three million illegal immigrants, more than half of them in California.
In promoting that amnesty offer, Mr. Ezell donned a sombrero and appeared as part of a group called Trio Amnestia, with his deputy and an Hispanic radio personality called El Tigre. At the same time, he crusaded to stop illegal immigrants from entering the United States, organizing night tours to the Mexican border to show illegal immigrants coming into the country and conducting raids on factories and restaurants.
In the early 1990's, after leaving the immigration agency, Mr. Ezell found a niche as a go-between for foreign millionaires seeking United States citizenship.
"I believe we've done a great job with boat people, and I think that a few yacht people are not going to hurt America," he told The New York Times in 1991.
As California's economy remained in the doldrums into the mid-1990's and public sentiment against illegal immigration grew, Mr. Ezell helped write Proposition 187, which would have denied public benefits, including health care and education, to illegal immigrants. Though the measure was approved by Californians in 1994, a Federal judge in Los Angeles ruled it unconstitutional and it has not been enforced, but many of its provisions were embodied in the Federal welfare reform act.
"He believed people should be welcome in this country, but they should come in in a legal manner, and that illegal activity of any kind should not be rewarded," said State Senator Dick Mountjoy, a Republican from suburban Los Angeles who supported Proposition 187.
But Mr. Ezell often raised the ire of immigrant and civil liberties advocates with comments that critics said made it impossible to have a dispassionate discussion of the issue.
Mr. Ezell is survived by his wife, Lee; two daughters, Pamela Ezell of Los Angeles, and Sandi Bushnell of New Jersey; his mother, Edna of Wilmington, Calif., and his brother, Donald, of Wilmington.

HEADLINE: Possible Strike By Pilots Seen As a Rarity

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
If the pilots at Northwest Airlines go on strike this weekend, it will be the first time a major airline has been shut down in the age of so-called fortress hubs -- the big metropolitan airports that are dominated by a single carrier.
In the last five years, the major domestic carriers have largely retreated from competition with one another, focusing instead on routing passengers through a handful of hub airports that they all but control. 
 Thus, Continental Airlines dominates Houston and Cleveland, while Delta Air Lines dominates Atlanta and Cincinnati, and United Airlines dominates Denver. But no major carrier has a tighter stranglehold on its hub airports than Northwest.
In Detroit, Minneapolis and Memphis, Northwest controls 75 to 82 percent of all airplane seats, according to a study by Lehman Brothers released earlier this year. That dominance makes Northwest's role so crucial to the regions it serves that the prospect of a strike to many state and local officials is practically unthinkable.
"Obviously, the more and more communities become dependent exclusively on a single provider," said Alfred E. Kahn, the Carter Administration official who presided over the airline industry's deregulation in 1978 and is now a professor emeritus at Cornell University, "the more the public interest cannot become indifferent to a strike."
This raises the question of whether the Government would permit a lengthy airline strike, or any strike at all.
Both Northwest executives and the Air Line Pilots Association say they hope no one has to find out. Indeed, the chances of a strike seemed to fade slightly yesterday as one person who was briefed on the negotiations said the two sides had made significant progress, with the key issue of pay remaining unresolved.
But Northwest announced yesterday that it was canceling 400 flights tomorrow and Saturday in preparation for a strike if a settlement is not reached by 12:01 A.M. Saturday, the deadline set by the pilots. Northwest also said that it might be forced to lay off some workers temporarily if a strike dragged on.
"Layoffs are the last option we consider in any strike situation," said Jon Austin, a Northwest spokesman.
Last year, President Clinton stepped in minutes after 9,300 pilots at American Airlines walked out, invoking his authority under the 1926 Railway Labor Act to force the pilots back to work for 60 days while a special Presidential emergency board tried to broker a settlement.
Under the act, the President has the power to create an emergency board if a labor dispute threatens "to interrupt interstate commerce to a degree such as to deprive any section of the country of essential transportation service."
This was the first time a President had halted an airline strike since 1966. Many people now believe that it will be difficult for Mr. Clinton not to intervene if Northwest stops flying because the economic repercussions, particularly for the upper Midwest, would be as bad or worse than those faced when American, a unit of the AMR Corporation, went on strike.
So far, the White House is being coy about its plans in an attempt to force both sides to settle. Administration officials have even told Northwest executives, who they believed were a little too confident that the President would ride to their rescue, not to count on intervention.
"It would be a mistake for anybody to negotiate assuming that the President will appoint a board," a White House official said, speaking on condition of anonymity.
But if the pilots do strike, Mr. Clinton may be forced to act. Though Northwest, which is the country's fourth-largest airline, is much smaller than American Airlines, the No. 2 airline, it has a tighter grip on its hubs. American's bases in Chicago and Dallas-Fort Worth are among the handful of major airports where there is still competition among major carriers, said Philip Baggaley, the chief airline bond analyst at Standard & Poor's.
The Clinton Administration estimated last year that the American strike would strand about 43,000 passengers a day at a cost of $200 million to the economy, a figure that was subsequently challenged by several economists. Northwest said that 67,200 passengers a day would be affected if its pilots walked out and that a strike would cost $737 million in its first 10 days.
The pilots' union dismisses those estimates, saying that other airlines will move in to pick up Northwest's passengers. But Northwest's virtual monopoly means that there are few alternatives.
Trans World Airlines said yesterday that it would fly larger planes between Minneapolis and its hub in St. Louis beginning this weekend to pick up the slack. But the extra capacity amounts to just 85 seats a day, a fraction of what would be lost if Northwest stopped flying.
Pro Air, a year-old carrier based at Detroit City Airport, said its two 146-seat 737 jets were already flying more than 12 hours a day, making it hard for it to add flights. And United Airlines, a unit of the UAL Corporation, said it was unlikely to add more flights between Minneapolis and Detroit and its hub in Chicago.
Charles Braswell, the corporate travel manager for the Chrysler Corporation, which has its headquarters outside Detroit, believes that Northwest's dominance increases the likelihood of a strike.
"If there were competition in the market, it would preclude either side from being out for any length of time," he said. "They may lose customers when they go out, but they know they will end up winning them back again once they come back because there are so few choices."

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
Russia Delivers a Blow to Global Capitalism

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Russia's huge default on its debts, and the harsh terms it is offering to those foreigners who made the mistake of lending money to it, have petrified investors and are making capital much harder to get for other countries around the world. For that reason, the default is also increasing the risk of global recession.
Economically, Russia has never been as important as it was politically. Investors had assumed that the West would do whatever was necessary to prop up the Russians, if only to keep nuclear weapons from falling into the wrong hands. In fact, there seemed to be an assumption that private loans to nearly any government carried an implicit Western guarantee, although none had been promised. 
 "I would not give one nickel to help any creditor or investor," said Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin. Nevertheless, in previous bailouts engineered by Mr. Rubin, whether in Mexico in 1995 or Korea last year, investors in government bonds did well because that seemed necessary to avoid economic collapse.
It was not news that Russia had big economic problems, or that the Government had been unable to solve them. But until last week investors still thought default was all but impossible. In June Russia was unable to borrow all the rubles it needed, even at extraordinarily high interest rates. But it was able to borrow $1.25 billion in dollars from foreign investors, who were promised about 12 percent a year for five years.
An investor who bought one of those bonds in June, and tried to sell it now, would lose nearly two-thirds of the money invested. And naive investors are not the only ones who have suffered. Funds managed by the international financier George Soros lost a lot of money, as did Credit Suisse First Boston, the big investment bank.
What went wrong? The International Monetary Fund package assembled this summer proved to be far too small, given the chaos in the Russian Government. The I.M.F. lacked the money to put together the much larger package of aid that would have been necessary to avert default, and major Western governments, including the United States, refused to put up their own money. In an interview with a German newspaper, Stanley Fischer, the deputy director of the I.M.F., blamed Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany for the West's failure to act.
Now, with the safety net withdrawn, the ruble appears to be in free fall. Those who lent money to Russia are being forced to trade in their old securities -- which promised extraordinarily high returns for lending money for only a few months -- for securities yielding lower interest rates over a longer time. The risk is that, even assuming Russia is able to honor its latest promises, the rubles it pays back will be worth far less than the ones it borrowed.
It is not clear now who is really in charge in Moscow. President Yeltsin's choice of Viktor Chernomyrdin as prime minister needs parliamentary ratification, which may not be forthcoming unless he can reach agreement with the Communist leadership of the Duma. And even if that happens, there is no guarantee the Government will be able to collect taxes and actually administer the country. The outlook for the Russian people is grim.
So too may be the outlook for countries far away from Russia, with economies and governments in far better shape. Investors, having awakened to the reality of risk, now are pulling money out of emerging markets from Hong Kong to Brazil. At best, many governments will have to pay higher interest rates to borrow, putting a damper on growth. At worst, they will find new capital unavailable at reasonable costs, and will have to strain to repay loans as they come due. Russia's direct importance to the world economy may turn out to be far smaller than its impact on investor psychology.
Perhaps the damage can be limited, and investors will decide that Russia's problems should not affect their views of, say, Argentina. But if not, economic incompetence in post-Soviet Russia could prove to be a bigger threat to world capitalism than Stalin ever was.

HEADLINE: The Royal Treatment;
Ruling FamilyFeuds as Oil Income Drops in Brunei

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: BANDAR SERI BEGAWAN, Brunei

 BODY:
Beneath a canopy of crystal chandeliers in a dazzling throne room here earlier this month, a gentle-looking young prince in a golden tunic was handed a jewel-encrusted dagger and proclaimed heir to the Islamic Sultanate of Brunei.
Royal succession is a serious business in this secluded, oil-rich country on the northern coast of Borneo, where Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah has ruled with absolute authority since Brunei gained independence from Britain in 1984. And never more so than now, when the Sultan is battling both a bitter family feud and a free fall in oil prices, which has thrown the fief into a financial bind. 
 The crowning of the Sultan's eldest son, the 24-year-old Prince al-Muhtadee Billah, was a suitably solemn affair -- steeped in six centuries of Malay tradition that gave it an almost otherworldly aura.
"We have been praying for this day," a young woman said after the ceremony on Aug. 10 as the Prince was drawn through the capital in a gold-and-white chariot. Like most of Brunei's 305,000 people, she regards the royal family with a reverence verging on awe. Thanks to the richest oil reserves in Southeast Asia, the Sultan has transformed his country into an enclave of docile affluence.
But the investiture of Prince Billah comes at a time of rising turmoil in this normally peaceful country, although it is still relatively unscathed by the Asian economic crisis swirling around it. The Sultan recently stripped his younger brother, Prince Jefri Bolkiah, of his posts as head of Brunei's state investment agency and its largest conglomerate, reflecting allegations that the Prince squandered billions on bad investments and a profligate life style.
Even the Sultan has come under scrutiny for living like Croesus while a decline in oil prices drains Brunei's economy. Building a 1,788-room palace with air-conditioned stables and hiring Michael Jackson to perform at his 50th birthday party was fine as long as oil sales were pumping nearly $2 billion a year into Brunei's coffers. But with oil prices down one-third since January, Brunei has already lost about $400 million, or 20 percent of its revenue last year.
Brunei Shell Petroleum, a unit of the Royal/Dutch Shell Group and the dominant oil producer, is sending home expatriate workers, while local merchants are feeling the pinch as shoppers flock to neighboring Malaysia to buy cheaper goods. Analysts say Brunei is experiencing something new in its well-lubricated history: a cash-flow squeeze.
That squeeze may force the country to cut back on entitlement programs that earned it the nickname "Shellfare state." At $25,200, Brunei's citizens already have the highest per capita income in Southeast Asia. But the Government still doles out free health care and education -- not to mention subsidized rent and interest-free loans for civil servants to buy houses.
"We've been fortunate in our history because we've never had to prioritize," said Selamat Munap, the Deputy Finance Minister. "We've been able to take care of our children, our sick, our elderly. Perhaps we will have to be more rigorous in our standards for Government spending."
Mr. Selamat delicately avoids mentioning the royal family, which has taken care of itself best of all. But diplomats here say the Sultan now recognizes that his relatives must curb their lavish ways. The Sultan, they say, is particularly angry with Prince Jefri, who set off on an epic spending spree in the early 1990's, buying luxury hotels from Paris and London to New York and Los Angeles.
"There was a dawning appreciation that they were getting ahead of their earnings," said one Western diplomat, who, like almost everybody here, insisted on anonymity out of fear of offending the Sultan.
The extent of the rift in the royal family became clear when Prince Jefri stayed away from Prince Billah's investiture, the most important ceremony since the Sultan's coronation in 1967. Prince Jefri, who is in self-imposed exile in the United States, issued a statement that he could not return to Brunei because "there is little I can do to oppose the destructive action of reactionary forces, which are becoming increasingly entrenched at all levels of government."
A spokesman for Prince Jefri said Islamic fundamentalists from Libya and Iran were playing an influential role in Brunei's Government -- a contention that the Government dismisses as preposterous.
Still, with the Government starting a global investigation of the Prince, and the Prince hurling brickbats in response, Brunei is being dragged out of its velvet-lined obscurity. Before independence, it had been a British protectorate, with origins that date back to the 13th century, when a prince from western Borneo became the first sultan of this lush, heavily wooded land.
To some extent, Brunei's troubles are rooted in its most fortunate event: the 1929 discovery of oil off the coast. By 1996, Brunei was pumping 160,000 barrels a day, mostly for export to Japan. Oil and natural gas now generate 90 percent of the Government's income.
Even to people who could not find his country on a map, the Sultan of Brunei became famous as the richest man in the world. It is a title he only recently ceded to William H. Gates, the chairman of Microsoft; like other oil barons, the Sultan's net worth declines as fast as the price of crude.
With an estimated fortune that reached $35 billion in the early 1990's, the royal family has enjoyed life on a grand scale. Prince Jefri, 44, savored it with particular gusto, buying playthings like a sleek yacht, an Airbus jet, a Sikorsky helicopter and five-star hotels including the Plaza Athenee in Paris, the New York Palace and the Bel Air in Los Angeles.
Prince Jefri's ambitions extended beyond shopping. As Finance Minister from 1984 to 1996, he built, among other projects, a giant amusement park, free to visitors. Prince Jefri pursued his ventures through a web of private companies and Government agencies. The Amedeo Development Corporation, a private company owned by the Prince, built the amusement park and other projects in Brunei. Amedeo Crown, a Prince Jefri-owned company listed on the British island of Jersey, acquired Asprey, the London jeweler, while Prince Jefri family trusts own the American hotels.
The Brunei Investment Agency, a Government operation that the Prince led as chairman, manages investments and owns more hotels, including the Dorchester in London and the Beverly Hills Hotel in California.
Reconstructing what happened at these companies is difficult because their operations are cloaked in secrecy. The reputed advisers will not even confirm whether they work for Prince Jefri, the royal family or the Government.
Executives with ties to Prince Jefri said that Amedeo and the Brunei Investment Agency were both audited by the accounting firm KPMG Peat Marwick. Citibank is said to be their main adviser. Given the blurry line between the interests of the royal family and those of the state, these executives said it would be hard for any outsider to impose strict financial controls.
Last month, reports began to arise of huge, undisclosed losses at both Amedeo and the Brunei Investment Agency. Financial analysts said the investment agency's assets might have been pledged to buy hotels. The losses came as an acute embarrassment to the Sultan, who had offered loans to help his ailing neighbors, Thailand and Indonesia, only to discover that Brunei could not afford them.
So the Sultan abruptly stripped Prince Jefri of his jobs at both organizations and ordered the Government to seize Amedeo's assets in Brunei. The Sultan hired auditors from Arthur Andersen in London to calculate the losses, which some analysts say could reach billions of dollars.
Mr. Selamat, the Deputy Finance Minister, declined to comment on Amedeo's collapse but acknowledged that "any major corporate failure is going to have some impact on the economy of Brunei."
Prince Jefri's financial troubles came after another embarrassing episode, in which Shannon Marketic, a former Miss U.S.A., accused him and the Sultan of trying to turn her into a sex slave. The lawsuit is pending, though the Sultan has sovereign immunity and Prince Jefri has immunity as a potential heir to the throne.
Prince Jefri would seem to have a bleak future in Brunei. But he contends that because his overseas properties are owned by separate companies and trusts, he still owns those assets and intends to keep them.
"I do not seek a fight and prefer to be left alone," he said in a statement. "I shall, however, vigorously defend my position and interests of my family."
An adviser to Prince Jefri, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said the Government was exaggerating the losses at Amedeo to discredit the Prince and destroy his power base within the country. The Government also recently seized three oil concessions that gave Prince Jefri a steady stream of income.
Now the Prince and his advisers are plotting a strategy to hold on to the remaining properties. Brunei's investigation has set off alarm bells in Europe and the United States, and Prince Jefri's lieutenants have had to reassure employees and suppliers that the hotels and other properties are not about to be seized.
Prince Jefri may be finally tightening his belt, too. At Asprey Group, the venerable but money-losing luxury-goods company he bought for $388 million in 1995, the Prince is merging the flagship Asprey with its sister company, Garrard, and selling off unprofitable businesses.
"The idea that because we have a principal who is a prince, we can spend whatever our hearts desire, is not true," said Ian Dahl, the chief executive of Asprey in London. "We run a very tightfisted company."
Prince Jefri's adviser said he was being hounded by Islamic militants, including another of the Sultan's brothers, Prince Mohamed. "This is a classic power struggle between those who favor a more conservative, religious approach and those who favor a more open, tolerant approach," the adviser said.
Brunei has become more straitlaced in recent years. Alcohol is no longer served in bars or restaurants. But other facts of life here may have less to do with religion than money. Several observers said the Sultan's largess had created a politically satisfied, even sedated, populace. Even people who live in houses on stilts in Brunei's 500-year-old water village own satellite dishes.
"The people feel they've gotten a good deal from the Sultan," said Rex DeSilva, the editor of The Borneo Bulletin, which calls itself an independent newspaper even though it is controlled by Prince Mohamed. "If a ruler can't be popular with all that, who can?"
Indeed, the Sultan's biggest challenge may be economic rather than political. For years, he has promised to wean Brunei from its reliance on oil by diversifying its economy. Yet the Government's efforts to become a trade and tourism center have come to naught. Given that Brunei has about 23 years of oil reserves left, that problem may fall to the Sultan's son.
For now, Prince Billah may help overcome some of Brunei's current ills. Unlike his playboy uncle, Prince Jefri, or even his father at a younger age, Prince Billah projects a less frivolous image. Educated at Oxford, Prince Billah is said to be a sober young man. His idea of indulgence, according to royal propaganda, is a game of snooker and the tame saxophone music of Kenny G.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
1998: AYear Emerging Markets Seem Synonymous With Anguish

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The collapse in the world's emerging stock markets -- the Thailands, Polands and Russias -- has been breathtaking. Not since these markets began to attract strong investor interest at the end of the 1980's have they had such a sharp decline, one that wiped out so many years of gains.
Their plunge over the last year, worldwide, now outranks that during the Mexican peso crisis of 1994-95 and that during the Persian Gulf war of 1990-91. 
 Without a quick rally, August will be the worst month for stock markets in developing economies since 1988, when their performance began to be tracked in index form. So far this month, these markets have lost 20 percent of their value. Since Asian financial crises began in July 1997, they have erased all their gains back to December 1991, according to the Morgan Stanley Capital International emerging markets index.
A second index, that of the International Finance Corporation, a member of the World Bank Group, has thee markets declining to where they were in February 1992.
"Anyone who has tried to pick the bottom has been destroyed," said Ron Chapman, head of international equities at the Dreyfus Corporation, who has had his own fingers burned.
Near-panic selling in disregard of a country's economic fundamentals is causing many investors and stock analysts to reconsider whether these markets are sensible for even the hardy long-term investor, the kind who has accepted volatility in exchange for large potential gains.
And the risks seem to be growing, with Russia's deepening economic crisis pulling the far healthier Latin American stock markets down with it.
The latest phase of the Russian crisis is also exposing another, possibly more damaging, fault line: a collapse in the prices of emerging- market bonds. It is in the global capital markets that emerging-market countries in Eastern Europe, Asia and Latin American borrow to meet government financial needs.
If that borrowing becomes very expensive, investors will worry about the ability of Latin American countries to pay off their debts and to cover their trade deficits, which are already at worrisome levels. That, in turn, will put more pressure on the currencies, forcing countries to raise their interest rates to defend their exchange value. Such developments could rapidly undermine a country's otherwise stable economic fundamentals.
Emerging nations are already paying a lot to get investors to buy their securities. The difference, or spread, between the yield on emerging-market debt and United States Treasury securities has jumped by nearly six percentage points, to 13 percentage points, according to the J. P. Morgan emerging-market bond index. Only after the Mexican peso crisis erupted in December 1994 has the spread widened that fast. At the peak of that crisis in 1995, emerging markets were paying on average 19 percentage points more than the United States did on its Treasury securities.
Mexico, of course, did not default on its debt, with considerable aid from the United States and other industrial nations.
But the refusal of the International Monetary Fund, the United States and its economic partners to rescue Russia before it essentially devalued the ruble two weeks ago and defaulted on some debt has caused a serious reassessment of the risks in all emerging markets.
"Does the system now have a lender of last resort?" asked Desmond Lachman, head of emerging markets economic research at Salomon Smith Barney and a former official of the International Monetary Fund. "Bulgaria didn't fail, Thailand didn't fail, Indonesia didn't fail. But now Russia fails." For troubled economies, he said, "the I.M.F. and the Group of Seven are no longer there as a backstop."
As this view takes hold, emerging-market bonds may come under even more intense pressure.
For now, investors still interested in these markets must wait until the frantic selling ceases. And this will not happen until hedge funds and other money managers who have big losses in places like Russia stop selling to raise cash. Having borrowed to make many of their bets even bigger, they need cash to pay off their loans. In some cases, that means selling stocks in Latin America, where markets have more liquidity, as well as in other regions.
The disclosure yesterday that George Soros, the legendary hedge fund operator, lost $2 billion in Russia in the last year shows how great the damage may be.
"Emerging markets have become more a game for speculators and traders -- and a nightmare for dedicated long-term investors," said Robert J. Pelosky Jr., global emerging markets strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "In the short run, fundamentals don't seem to matter."
But even after the dust clears, many investors are likely to balk at plunging back into emerging markets despite analysts' estimates of great opportunities at such prices.
"There has to be some new management system for these crises," said Gary Kleiman, senior partner at Kleiman International Consultants, a research and advisory firm in Washington. Without a new international system for containing currency crises and the fallout that often follows, Mr. Kleiman said, it will be hard to persuade his institutional clients to bet on emerging markets.
"There is little upside and too much downside risk for those who can't afford to leave their money there for 5 years to 10 years," he said. "It is probably better just to leave."
Mr. Pelosky of Morgan Stanley said he thought that emerging-market investors would shift from selecting specific countries to picking specific companies. "The game is going to be very different," he continued, "in the next two to three years." In the past, investors have jumped in on economic potential, betting, for example, that the rapid growth and low inflation in Asia in the early 90's would guarantee great returns.
But in the future, he said, investing would be based more on "what this company does and how does it compare to its competition."
This nitty-gritty approach fits with the long-term hope for emerging markets: that economic fundamentals will again determine the winners and losers.
