HEADLINE: SHAKE-UP IN RUSSIA: THE MONEY;
Acting Premier Tries to Hang on to Credits

BYLINE: By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 26

 BODY:
As Russia confronts its worst financial crisis since the collapse of the Soviet Union, with the ruble poised for a free fall, the Acting Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, made a sudden trip to Ukraine to persuade the head of the International Monetary Fund not to cut off its next installment of credits.
Alarmed by the ruble's 9 percent drop yesterday, anxious Russians rushed to their banks this morning only to be given mixed signals on when, and how, they can retrieve their savings. An early round of dollar trading on the Moscow currency exchange was voided today for the first time in the history of the exchange, while the value of the ruble dropped 40 percent against the German mark in a single transaction. 
 The Central Bank of Russia, under bitter attack at home and abroad for its handling of the crisis, said today that it could no longer afford to protect the ruble, reporting that it had already spent $8.8 billion doing so in the last two months. Later in the day, the bank said it would not slap limits on currency transactions. Such a move, it said, would be a step back to "another economic model."
As the banking crisis threatens to engulf Russia's entire financial system, the Central Bank took its first tough action today by withdrawing the license of Bank AB Imperial, Russia's 13th-largest bank, which had reportedly defaulted on payments on foreign loans earlier this month.
Yesterday three major Russian banks announced plans to merge, while six Moscow banks today said they would pool their resources to end the deadlock of nonpayments that has crippled Russian banking transactions.
Mr. Chernomyrdin's quick trip to the Crimean resort of Simferapol, where Michel Camdessus, managing director of the I.M.F., was to meet this afternoon with the President of Ukraine, Leonid Kuchma, was seen as a sign of Russia's growing concern that the monetary fund will refuse to issue its next installment of $4.8 billion in credits, due to be reviewed by the fund's board in September.
Delivery of the funds is now Russia's only hope for a new injection of foreign aid, as Western leaders warned today that it would be up to the Russian Government to pull the country out of its looming financial nightmare. "There are no shortcuts in restoring market confidence, and the next steps are up to the Russia," Barry Toiv, a White House spokesman, told reporters in Edgartown, Mass., where President Clinton was on vacation.
That nightmare was already on the horizon for thousands of Russian companies, caught between the ruble's downward spiral and a gridlock in the Russing banking system. Several companies today reported that their banks had not forwarded payments made by customers. "They take money out of your account, and it may or may not leave your bank, you don't know," said a director at a Russian food processing plant. Another Russian businessman who also asked not to be identified said: "As a client of the bank, I don't care what they are waiting for. After one week of this, they are killing me."
President Boris N. Yeltsin has made no further comment on the crisis since a televised appearance Monday, when he gave a brief explanation of his reappointment of Mr. Chernomyrdin, the man he had dismissed as Prime Minister five months ago.
"Financial and economic policy is a question to which I am giving my attention minute by minute," Mr. Chernomyrdin told the Itar-Tass news agency. "I am extremely dissatisfied with the work of the Central Bank over the last two days."
As Mr. Chernomyrdin flew to Ukraine today, leaders in Russia's Parliament continued their public bargaining over the future of his Government and its policies. At a news conference today, the Parliament Speaker, Gennadi Seleznyov, a Communist, said Parliament was still working on its own anti-crisis plan, which he said Mr. Chernomyrdin must endorse before his appointment can be confirmed at a session now scheduled for Sept. 2.
"We might be ready by next Monday afternoon," said Mr. Seleznyov, referring to the anti-crisis document, "but we would not want to rush things since we are speaking about a very serious document." In a television interview tonight, Mr. Seleznyov again appealed for Mr. Yeltsin's resignation, a possibility that a Kremlin spokesman today dismissed as "stupid."
Mr. Chernomyrdin yesterday told parliamentary leaders he was open to a coalition government that would include members of the Communist opposition, but Mr. Seleznyov has insisted that negotiations over ministerial appointments come after adoption of a joint strategy to handle the current crisis.
Asked today at a news conference if the Communist Party, which holds the largest bloc in the Parliament, will join the new government, Mr. Seleznyov said that the question had not yet been resolved.
While the political haggling over the new government continues, financial analysts said Russia's financial situation was worsening by the hour, with no clear policy from the Central Bank or the Government in sight.
"Some banks are really bankrupt," said Nikolai Gusev, a trader at Regent European Securities, an investment company, "and the population is going to start withdrawing their money."
Only 20 percent of Russian savings accounts are held in commercial banks -- with the rest in the giant government-controlled Sberbank -- but much of these are held in several of the largest banks now reported to be in trouble.
"There is no clear scheme for an operation transferring deposits to Sberbank," Mr. Gusev said. "There have been only words, and no concrete words."
Some Russian banks were putting their walk-in customers today on waiting lists, others were returning money in dribs and drabs. "You can call and check your place on the list, and they don't allow people to cut the line as far as I can see," said Pavel Mirovc, a 29-year-old sales consultant who was waiting in line at a downtown branch office of Most Bank. "But of course I am worried. They are giving out very little money."
"We've been coming every day," said a middle-aged woman, as she and her husband were leaving the same bank early this evening. "They give us our money little by little. But at least they are giving something. But we've become part-time guards of the bank."
Most analysts attributed the heaving trading on Moscow currency exchange yesterday to the Central Bank's continued supply of credits to Russia's troubled banks, and by its decision last week to lower the banks' minimum capital requirements, which freed up ruble reserves that the bankers then exchanged for dollars.
An anti-crisis program, announced on Aug. 17 by Mr. Chernomyrdin's predecessor, Sergei Kiriyenko, included a 90-day moratorium on payments of debts owed by Russia's commercial banks to foreign lenders. Some Russian banks this week have said they will ignore the moratorium and pay their debts, but with the fall in the ruble, many foreign creditors have been left wondering where the other banks will find the money to meet their debt payments when the moratorium ends in mid-November.
The Government's plan to swap $40 million held in Russian short-term Treasury bills for new longer term securities has also left foreign investors with a bitter taste. But its main effect is on Russian holders of the Treasury bills -- major banks, but also pension and other investment funds -- which are now stuck with assets that are worth less than their original value, and are less accessible.
Mr. Chernomyrdin today tried to distance himself from the debt restructuring plan, which was originally announced by the Kiriyenko Government. "I would like people to understand us correctly: this decision was predetermined," he said. "In actual fact, our task was only to formulate it, and we could not do otherwise."
According to most analysts, the Central Bank has to take decisive action to restore credibility to the financial system. "What they have to do is limit rubles reserves, and start to close down banks," said Holger Mueller, banking analyst at Fleming UCB, an investment firm. "They have to do it right now, and do it as fast possible, because there is still value in these banks, and they have to make sure there is no asset stripping."

HEADLINE: Russian Derivatives May Burn Investors

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN 

 BODY:
Trading in the rapidly devaluing ruble came to a screeching halt yesterday, renewing concerns about Russia's ability to manage $40 billion in ruble-denominated debt, roughly 25 percent of which is held by foreign investors.
But Western investors and banks could face greater losses from the complex financial instruments known as derivatives. Indeed, the amount of Russian derivatives at risk for foreign investors may be sharply higher than that of bonds and loans. While the lack of public disclosure make estimates difficult, some currency traders and emerging-market specialists have set the value of derivatives at risk in Russia as high as $100 billion. Many analysts, however, think the figure is probably much lower than that. 
 Derivatives, among the most innovative and volatile products born of a new era in computer-generated financial alchemy, have been a boon to companies trying to limit risks and have also proved seductive to speculators trying to make a fast buck.
The value of derivatives is pegged to that of underlying assets, like stocks, bonds and currencies. They are typically used by savvy financial players to lessen the pain of unforeseen economic shifts, such as the swift ruble devaluation that has stung so many investors in Russia.
Most buyers of ruble-denominated bonds entered into a variety of derivatives contracts requiring rubles to be exchanged for dollars or German marks at set rates in the future to cushion tumbles in the ruble's value, in much the same way as homeowners purchase insurance to protect themselves in case their houses burn down. And the ruble's drastic drop has already burned a broad range of investors in Russia.
Credit Suisse First Boston said yesterday that its profits for the first six months of the year would be reduced to $500 million, from $254 million, largely because of heavy losses in Russia. Funds managed by George Soros, the globe-trotting investor and currency speculator, lost about $2 billion in Russia in the last year, according to an announcement his group of funds made yesterday.
Many Western investors described the debt restructuring announced by the Russian Government on Tuesday as punitive, but some were also willing to acknowledge that the losses they suffered had as much to do with the risky nature of the markets they were playing.
"Frankly, all of us made a bet on the ability of the Government to get its fiscal house in order," said Andrew Ipkendanz, head of global emerging markets for Credit Suisse First Boston in Moscow. "They didn't; we lost money, and so you move on."
It is still unclear what kind of damage American banks may suffer in Russia. Large American banks have relatively little exposure in Russia given their size -- about $7.68 billion, according to Brown Brothers Harriman & Company. Derivatives make up part of that amount, but other undisclosed positions could add to the banks' derivatives worries.
Fears about mounting losses in emerging markets in Eastern Europe, Asia and Latin America sent the stocks of most major American banks -- principal players in the derivatives market -- sharply lower yesterday.
Bankers Trust's shares plunged 4.9 percent, to $92.125; J. P. Morgan's shares sank 2.43 percent, to $117.9375; BankAmerica's shares fell 1.9 percent, to $77.625, and Citicorp's stock dropped 1.65 percent, to $133.875. Chase Manhattan, however, edged up two-tenths of 1 percent, to $64.25.
Still, trying to determine the total value of currency derivatives in Russia, and who may wind up on the winning and losing sides of the deals, is a guessing game. Although the global derivatives market is huge and lucrative, the contracts are privately negotiated and the value of the deals are not disclosed on public exchanges like the stock market. Relatively little disclosure about derivatives is required of American banks, although accounting rules were recently changed to remedy that situation.
"It's incredibly difficult to quantify because the disclosure just isn't there," said Elisabeth Jackson-Moore, manager of Moody's Investors Service's office in Nicosia, Cyprus, who analyzes Russian banks. "We're certainly concerned that there could be a chain reaction because Western investors may have hedged their position with Russian banks, and Russian banks may have hedged their positions with other banks, and so forth."
Capital Markets Risk Advisers, a New York consulting firm specializing in derivatives, estimates the Russian foreign exchange contracts and currency derivatives of one form or another currently total about $65 billion. Mr. Ipkendanz of Credit Suisse First Boston said that Russian central bankers told creditors this week that $10 billion in currency contracts with Russian banks were maturing by the end of the year, a figure that does not include contracts with offshore hedge funds.
How well these contracts are honored, Mr. Ipkendanz added, will be the "next chapter" of Russia's financial saga. When two parties agree to take opposite sides in a derivatives deal, the prospects that the loser will pay the winner is only as good as the paper on which their contract is written and the integrity of the participants. J. P. Morgan was forced to designate $587 million in currency swaps in Asia as nonperforming earlier this year, largely because of disputes with Asian counterparties about the deals.
Russian banks are currently operating under the protection of a 90-day debt moratorium. It is unclear what their financial health will be when the moratorium ends.
"Technically, it's only a 90-day moratorium," said Charles Peabody, an analyst with Mitchell Securities Inc. in New York. "But if the banks are bankrupt at the end of the period they won't make good on any of the currency swaps."
If that proves to be the case, Western investors can expect to swallow further losses in Russia.

SECTION: Section D; Page 6; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 208 words

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Japanese Stocks Are Sharply Lower

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Aug. 27

 BODY:
The benchmark Japanese stock index plunged early today after markets dropped across Europe and the United States.
The broad international losses on Wednesday followed a statement by the Russian central bank that it could no longer afford to prop up the ruble, sending Moscow financial markets into a tailspin and rekindling fears about economic instability. 
 Here this morning, big banks like the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi and exporters like Honda paced the fall in Japanese share prices.
Ken Okamura, strategist at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, said, "The Russian ruble jitters have hurt markets everywhere and the effects of that have hit Japan." In addition, he said, "the financial crisis is reaching a crescendo -- it may not be the last crescendo, but it's pretty loud."
At the midday trading recess, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 405.99 points, or 2.73 percent, at 14,460.04. It fell as low as 14,446.20. On Wednesday, the average dropped 206.90 points, or 1.37 percent.
On the Tokyo foreign exchange market, the dollar bought 143.82 yen, down 0.85 yen from late Wednesday in Tokyo.
In Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index was up 3.43 points -- less than one-tenth a percent -- at 7,837.83 in the first half-hour of trading.

INTERNATIONAL A3-11
 
Arms Inspector Resigns, Citing Hindrances by Iraq
The long-serving American weapons inspector in Iraq, William S. Ritter Jr., resigned, complaining that the Secretary General, the Security Council and the Clinton Administration had stymied the inspectors on "the doorstep" of uncovering Iraq's hidden weapons programs. A1 

Agency Studies Sudan Chemical
The chemical that the United States cited in justifying its bombing of a Sudanese factory could be used for commercial products, and not just for producing the nerve agent VX, said the international agency that oversees the treaty barring chemical arms. But agency officials said they were unaware of any commercial product on the market that contained the chemical or of another chemical compound made with it. A8
 
Guerrillas who have trained at the camps in Afghanistan struck by American missiles said that the attack would not interfere with the training of Muslim revolutionaries there or harm their morale. A8
 
The South African Government asked the F.B.I. to join its inquiry into the explosion at a Planet Hollywood restaurant in Cape Town. A8
 
Tycoons' Role in Russia
Last weekend's shake-up of the Russian Government demonstrated the power of tycoons who were able to exploit the financial crisis and President Boris N. Yeltsin's weakened position to install a more pliant Government. Now they are helping the acting Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, to negotiate with Communists in Parliament. A1
 
Mr. Chernomyrdin went to Ukraine to try to persuade the head of the I.M.F. not to cut off its next installment of credits for Russia, which is facing its worst financial crisis since the Soviet Union collapsed. A10
 
Fighting Around Congo Capital
Government soldiers and rebel fighters fired at each other less than 20 miles from Kinshasa's center. A6
 
Libya Responds to Offer on Trial
Libya indicated it would accept a proposal that two Libyans wanted in the bombing of a Pan Am jet in 1988 be tried in the Netherlands by Scottish judges. But nowhere in the one-page statement was a promise to turn over the suspects. A3
 
Premiers Affirm Ulster Accord
The Prime Ministers of Ireland and Britain said the Northern Ireland peace agreement would succeed despite a terrorist bombing 10 days ago and that new security measures would help curtail future attacks. A7
 
Sedition Charge in Malaysia
Lim Guan Eng, an opposition member of the Malaysian Parliament, was imprisoned on a charge of sedition for criticizing the Malaysian judiciary. In a pamphlet he published in 1995, Mr. Eng questioned the Government's decision not to press statutory rape charges against a politician while detaining the 15-year-old girl involved for three years in "protective custody." A5
 
NATIONAL A12-21
 
Justice to Extend Inquiry Into Gore's Campaign Calls
Attorney General Janet Reno ordered a 90-day preliminary inquiry into whether Vice President Al Gore lied to investigators last year when he was first interviewed about his telephone solicitations of donors from the White House, Government officials said. A1
 
A View to Counter Starr's
Some of President Clinton's political advisers have recommended that his lawyers write an account to counter an expected report to Congress from Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, Administration officials said. A18
 
Storm Strikes the Carolinas
Hurricane Bonnie came ashore in North Carolina, near the mouth of the Cape Fear River, delivering 115-m.p.h. winds to an area still recovering from back-to-back hurricanes in 1996. There were no reports of deaths or serious injuries in the region. A1
 
Rising Waters Reach Laredo
The Rio Grande, swollen by Tropical Storm Charley, rose 26.5 feet above normal in downtown Laredo, though scientists said the worst appeared over. About 600 people were evacuated. President Clinton declared parts of Texas a disaster area. A12
 
Review of King Assassination
Attorney General Janet Reno said there would be a limited examination of recently uncovered evidence in the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. A16
 
Ruling on Sale of Credit Data
A Federal administrative law judge ordered Trans Union, one of the nation's largest credit bureaus, to stop selling detailed credit information without consumers' permission. The company said the judge was wrong and that it would continue its practice until an appeal was decided. A14
 
Rocket Explodes in Florida
An unmanned rocket carrying an advanced communications satellite exploded less than 90 seconds after lifting off from Cape Canaveral, Fla. The cause of the accident was not immediately clear. A12 
 
Impostor Back Behind Bars
Massachusetts moved to revoke the commutation of a life sentence for a man who had claimed that the aftereffects of his wartime service in Vietnam were partly responsible for his committing murder. The man, Joseph Yandle, who is back in custody, now admits that he never served in Vietnam. A21
 
Absent From Tobacco Talks
R. J. Reynolds and Brown & Williamson will not, for now, participate in the new round of negotiations between tobacco producers and 38 states that began in New York. A18
 
The $2.3 Million Dog, Maybe
Researchers at Texas A& M University have accepted $2.3 million from the unidentified owners of a dog to try to clone the pet. A16
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-10
 
Judge Approves March Over City's Objections
A Federal judge ordered New York City to allow the Million Youth March on Sept. 5 in Harlem, rejecting the argument that the neighborhood could not safely accommodate the crowd. The city will appeal. B1
 
Asbestos Taints Agency Files
Many immigration cases have been delayed because about 400,000 immigration files are out of reach in a records room in Newark that was contaminated by asbestos after water leaked through ceiling tiles. B1
 
A Break From Jury Duty
Manhattan residents are now being called for jury duty only once every four years instead of once every two years, New York's Chief Judge said, because twice as many people are showing up for jury duty because of recent changes in the system. That leaves the Bronx the only county in the state where residents are called every two years. B1

Debate over Mark McGwire's use of a nutritional supplement led the commissioner and the players' union to announce that medical experts would study the issue of such supplements. BUSINESS DAY D1-23
 
Russia Cuts Into Soros
The $21.5 billion group of Soros funds has lost $2 billion in Russian markets in the last year, officials said, though even with those losses the $10.6 billion flagship Quantum Fund was up 19.13 percent for the year. D1
 
Stocks fell as a plunge in Russian markets deepened fears of a slump in corporate profits. The Dow fell 79.30 points, to 8,523.35, the S.& P. 500 declined 8.66, to 1,084.19, and the Nasdaq dropped 30.04, to 1,768.13. D5
 
Preparing for an Airline Strike
Northwest said it was canceling 400 flights tomorrow and Saturday in preparation for a pilots strike that could begin if a settlement is not reached by 12:01 A.M. Saturday. A person briefed on the negotiations said progress had been made, though the pay issue was unresolved. D1
 
Merck Agreement on Rivals
The F.T.C. and Merck have agreed that the Merck-Medco Managed Care unit will not discriminate against drugs made by Merck's competitors or exploit private marketing information about other drug makers that Medco receives. Merck said the agreement formalized policies it adopted three years ago. D3

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Crisis in Russia Worsens As Defense of Ruble Wanes
The Central Bank of Russia said it could no longer afford to protect the ruble after spending $8.8 billion doing so in the last two months. With the ruble poised for a free fall, the Acting Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, went to Ukraine to try to persuade the head of the International Monetary Fund not to cut off its next installment of $4.8 billion in credits.
A trader at the Moscow Interbank Currency Exchange, left, had little to do after trading in the ruble was suspended. Page A10. 

The market turmoil in Russia, the plunge of the ruble, the increase in prices and the banking crisis led that country's financial barons to reassert themselves and install an Acting Prime Minister who will accede to their concerns. A1.
 
The crisis in Russia has caused turmoil in Latin America. It has pummeled the region's markets, caused currencies to drop and forced interest rates so high that some bankers are urging customers not to borrow. Analysts are lowering what have been healthy growth estimates for Latin America for next year and perhaps beyond. D4.
 
Stocks Decline on Profit Concerns
Stocks fell as the Russian crisis deepened fears that slumping economies around the world would cut corporate profits. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 79.30 points, to 8,523.35. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 8.66, to 1,084.19, and the Nasdaq composite index dropped 30.04, to 1,768.13. In Tokyo early today the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 405.99 points, or 2.73 percent, to 14,460.04. D5.
 
Judge Halts the Sale of Credit Data
A Federal administrative law judge ordered one of the nation's largest credit bureaus, Trans Union Corporation, to stop selling detailed credit information from consumers to advertisers and marketers without the consumers' permission. Trans Union said it would appeal. The company maintains financial records on as many as 200 million Americans. A14.
 
Merck in Accord With F.T.C.
Merck & Company and its Merck-Medco Managed Care unit have agreed with the Federal Trade Commission to bar Medco from discriminating against drugs made by Merck's competitors or exploiting private marketing information about other drug makers that Medco receives. D3.
 
Starwood Set to Change Structure
Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide is expected to announce today that it will convert to a standard corporate structure. Starwood recently lost a battle with Congress and the White House to extend the tax advantages of its corporate structure as a "paired share" real estate investment trust. D23.
 
Durable Goods Orders Rose in July
Orders placed with the nation's manufacturers for durable goods unexpectedly rose 2.4 percent in July as demand for aircraft and electronics offset a fall in auto orders linked to the General Motors strikes. Excluding transportation goods, durable goods orders rose 3 percent in July. D2.
 
Harnischfeger to Cut 3,100 Jobs
Harnischfeger Industries said it would cut about 3,100 jobs, or 20 percent of its work force, because a glut of paper was reducing demand for its products. The company also reported a quarterly loss that was wider than analysts had expected. D23.
 
Con Ed Selling Generating Plants
Consolidated Edison plans to sell virtually all of its electric generation stations in New York City. Its investment adviser, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, has sent information to more than 100 potential buyers. Winners are expected to be announced next year. B1.
 
Long Bond Yield Plunges to 5.42%
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond declined slightly to 5.42 percent, from 5.43 percent on Tuesday. D5.
